         <tei:p>Bulletin of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A revision of the 'acaecate' earthworms<tei:lb/>of the Pheretima group (Megascolecidae:<tei:lb/>Oligochaeta): Archipheretima,<tei:lb/>Metapheretima, Planapheretima,<tei:lb/>Pleionogaster and Polypheretima.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>E. G. Easton</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Zoology series Vol 35 No 1 26 April 1979</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology, and<tei:lb/>an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready. Volumes will contain about<tei:lb/>three hundred pages, and will not necessarily be completed within one calendar year.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subscription orders and enquiries about back issues should be sent to: Publications Sales,<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London SW7 5BD, England.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World List abbreviation: Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Zool.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History), 1979</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISSN 0007-1498 Zoology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol 35 No 1 pp 1-126<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road<tei:lb/>London SW7 5BD Issued 26 April 1979</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>QfcNfcKJU.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 NAY 1979</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A revision of the 'acaecate' earthworms of the<tei:lb/>Pheretima group (Megascolecidae: Oligochaeta):<tei:lb/>Archipheretima, Metapheretima, Planapheretima,<tei:lb/>Pleionogaster and Polypheretima</tei:p>
         <tei:p>E. G. Easton K</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Department of Zoology, British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London SW7 5BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contents</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction ............. 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morphology ............. 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Numerical studies ............ 9</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distribution 13</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Classification 17</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxonomy ............. 20</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus Archipheretima Michaelsen, 1928 ........ 21</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus Polypheretima Michaelsen, 1934 28</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus Planapheretima Michaelsen, 1934 ........ 64</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus Metapheretima Michaelsen, 1928 78</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus Pleionogaster Michaelsen, 1892 114</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Species incertae sedis . . . . . . . . . . .116</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Species transferred to 'caecate' Pheretimoid genera 119</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements . . . . . . . . . . . .120</tei:p>
         <tei:p>References 120</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Index to specific and subspecific names . . . . . . . .124</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Following the studies on the Pheretima group of Asio-Australasian earthworms by Sims &amp; Easton (1972),<tei:lb/>those genera lacking intestinal caeca, Archipheretima, Metapheretima (inc. Ephemitra), Planapheretima,<tei:lb/>Pleionogaster and Polypheretima, are examined by taximetric procedures. One hundred and fourteen<tei:lb/>nominal species and subspecies are reviewed ; 75 species are regarded as valid and a further 25 are described<tei:lb/>as new. Keys, descriptions and distributions are provided to the genera and species. The morphological<tei:lb/>development and structural specializations of the male pores are detailed and their taxonomic importance<tei:lb/>is discussed. The nephridial systems of several species are described and doubt is expressed about the<tei:lb/>validity of attributing classificatory significance to these characters. The distribution of the Pheretima<tei:lb/>group of genera is established in the context of plate tectonics and the restrictions are correlated with<tei:lb/>present day climatic factors.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sims &amp; Easton (1972) employed numerical techniques to detect phenetic assemblages within the<tei:lb/>genus Pheretima auct. which at that time included 746 nominal species. From their studies on a<tei:lb/>sample of 114 species, they concluded that eight genera should be recognized. Four, Archiphere-<tei:lb/>tima Michaelsen, 1928, Ephemitra Sims &amp; Easton, 1972, Metapheretima Michaelsen, 1928 and<tei:lb/>Planapheretima Michaelsen, 1934, contained species lacking intestinal caeca and the remaining<tei:lb/>four, Amynthas Kinberg, 1867, Metaphire Sims &amp; Easton, 1972, Pheretima Kinberg, 1867<tei:lb/>(sensu Sims &amp; Easton, 1972) and Pithemera Sims &amp; Easton, 1972, accommodated species with<tei:lb/>caeca on the intestine. The authors assigned the nominal species previously included in Pheretima</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Zool.) 35 (1): 1-126 Issued 26 April, 1979</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>2 E. G. E ASTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>auct. to species-groups within these genera although they did not attempt to describe or taxono-<tei:lb/>mically revise the individual species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This report is a continuation of those taximetric studies and contains the results of critical<tei:lb/>appraisals of all the taxa included in the 'acaecate' genera (Archipheretima, Ephemitra, Meta-<tei:lb/>pheretima and Planapheretimd) also the closely allied monotypic genus Pleionogaster Michaelsen,<tei:lb/>1892. After full investigation, the genus Metapheretima is now redefined to include Ephemitra<tei:lb/>and some of its species are assigned to Polypheretima Michaelsen, 1934, previously a synonym.<tei:lb/>Numerical procedures similar to those employed by Sims &amp; Easton (1972) were adopted to test<tei:lb/>the phenetic validities of the genera and to detect infra-generic groups. Descriptions, synonomies<tei:lb/>and distributions are given of 100 valid species which are recognized among the five genera<tei:lb/>investigated. The higher systematics and zoogeography of the acaecate genera are briefly discussed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1m</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 1 Planapheretima hasselti, transverse section of body. Im, longitudinal muscle;<tei:lb/>km, circular muscle; hy, epidermis; cu, cuticle. (From Horst, 1883.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morphology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>An account of the morphological features observed to vary among the species of the Pheretima<tei:lb/>group of genera and found to be useful for delineating taxa was provided by Sims &amp; Easton<tei:lb/>(1972). Since then the taxonomic significance of variations in setal number, segment size and<tei:lb/>number of spermathecae has been demonstrated by Easton (1976). During the course of the<tei:lb/>present investigation it became apparent that further morphological specializations can usefully<tei:lb/>be employed for generic and specific recognition. The following require comment.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Body shape</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The body shape of most species is approximately circular in cross-section although it may be<tei:lb/>flattened or concave ventrally in the region of the genital field. The spasmodic contraction of the<tei:lb/>archiform muscles (Oishi, 1930) in the more anterior segments during preservation may in par-<tei:lb/>ticular give the body a flattened appearance. The majority of species included in Planapheretima<tei:lb/>are arboricolous, these too have depressed bodies but with the longitudinal muscles grouped in<tei:lb/>paired lateral blocks (Fig. 1). (Associated with this condition are cryptic coloration, crowded<tei:lb/>ventral setae and often a glandular ventral surface forming a 'creeping sole'.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is assumed that the diameter : length proportion is constant for individuals of all species of<tei:lb/>the Pheretima group killed by a standard method (excluding regenerating specimens) as established<tei:lb/>for Amynthas hupiensis by Grant (1955).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Setae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Examination of long series of individuals show that, in the Polypheretima elongata species-<tei:lb/>complex, the number of setae on segment vii is positively correlated with the volume of that seg-<tei:lb/>ment and that two groups of taxa may be recognized with different setal densities (Easton, 1976).<tei:lb/>In Metapheretima sentanensis and M. triciae the setal densities are considerably higher and they</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ACAECATE PHERETIMOID EARTHWORMS 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>form a third group (Fig. 2). Unfortunately the majority of other species discussed in this report are<tei:lb/>known only from one or few individuals. Nevertheless, it is possible to assign these taxa to one or<tei:lb/>other of the three groups recognized on the basis of data derived from the examination of a<tei:lb/>single individual. The number of setae increase posteriorly usually to about segment xxx and<tei:lb/>then decrease in number to the posterior end of the body (Beddard, 1895 : 291; Hatai, 1924;<tei:lb/>Sivickis, 1930). These variations are not included among the taxonomic criteria employed in the<tei:lb/>present revision.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>0) 100-<tei:lb/>5 90<tei:lb/>g 80</tei:p>
         <tei:p>"5 70</tei:p>
         <tei:p>k. 60</tei:p>
         <tei:p>50</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Z 40</tei:p>
         <tei:p>V* ^* "</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 o o</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>L</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A A</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I I I I I I I I I I</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 2 3 456789 10</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Segments! volume</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 2 Correlation between the number of setae and segmental volume of segment vii (scales logarith-<tei:lb/>mic). Setal densities: L, low (Polypheretima kinabaluensis); /, intermediate (P. elongata, everetti,<tei:lb/>phacellotheca and stelleri) ; H, high (closed circles - Metapheretima sentanensis, open circles -<tei:lb/>M. triciae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The setae are usually situated in a single ring around the equator of each segment, but in a few<tei:lb/>species of Planapheretima and Metapheretima some may be displaced to form two or three rings.<tei:lb/>In most species the setae are regularly distributed around each segment, being rarely crowded<tei:lb/>ventrally or dorsally. However, in the majority of species of the genus Planapheretima the setae<tei:lb/>are densely crowded ventrally (see Body shape}.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The ventral and dorsal gaps in the setal ring (aa and zz) are often larger than the adjacent gaps<tei:lb/>(ab and yz) but seldom exceed twice the size of the adjacent gaps ; exceptionally in Archipheretima<tei:lb/>they are much larger and in A. ophiodies the dorsal gaps are equal to one quarter of the body<tei:lb/>circumference. The conventional setal nomenclature has been followed throughout (Stephenson,<tei:lb/>1930).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Penial setae occur rarely in the Pheretima group of genera and are unknown among the acaecate<tei:lb/>species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Dorsal pores</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The location of the first dorsal pore is fairly constant in most species, usually occurring in the<tei:lb/>region of 1 1/12 but it may be in any furrow between 5/6 and 13/14, even 19/20 in the case of Poly-<tei:lb/>pheretima coplandi.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>4 E. G. EASTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Clitellum</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The clitellum is usually restricted to three segments (xiv-xvi) but it may begin on xii or xiii and<tei:lb/>extend posteriorly to xvii or xviii. The clitellum is annular on segments xiv-xvii but may be in-<tei:lb/>complete ventrally on xii, xiii or xviii. All of the species of Polypheretima as well as the majority<tei:lb/>of Metapheretima have clitella restricted to three segments. All of the species of Archipheretima<tei:lb/>andPleionogaster have extended clitella as do most of the species of Planapheretima. Occasionally<tei:lb/>clitella are found to be poorly developed in fully grown individuals. This condition is believed<tei:lb/>to be characteristic of a postsexual phase (Gates, 1972a : 318).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 Male pores</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The species investigated may be divided into two groups on the basis of the structure of the male<tei:lb/>pores. In the first, each male pore is situated in the centre of a circular or oval papilla, the poro-<tei:lb/>phore, which is often pigmented; crescentic genital markings are never associated with these pores<tei:lb/>(while the spermathecal pores are always small). In the second group the male pores do not<tei:lb/>discharge through porophores and crescentic markings are often present (here the spermathecal<tei:lb/>pores may be small or large).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In both groups the male pores may have accessory structures which show a wide range of intra-<tei:lb/>and inter-specific variation. Among these diversifications it is possible to recognize a morphological<tei:lb/>series of increasing complexity in each group ranging from a simple superficial pore to a condition<tei:lb/>in which the pore discharges into a copulatory pouch. In a separate study of the ontogenesis of<tei:lb/>species possessing the more complex pore structures, it was found that during development each<tei:lb/>individual passes through successive growth phases which represent the condition of adults of less<tei:lb/>highly specialized species. The structure and development of the copulatory pouches in the two<tei:lb/>groups differ yet the developmental processes are sufficiently similar for the two to be regarded<tei:lb/>as an example of parallel development.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(a) Male pores on porophores. The total range of variation in the structure can be traced during<tei:lb/>growth in Polypheretima elongata and, in the case of the more complex structure, P. koyana.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the immature condition (Fig. 3a-b) the circular porophore of elongata is faintly demarcated<tei:lb/>with a poorly discernible crescentic ridge enclosing the porophore. With increased maturity<tei:lb/>both the porophore and the ridge become more distinct (Fig. 3c). During the next phase the<tei:lb/>porophore begins to invaginate along its lateral margin while its median edge often becomes<tei:lb/>raised above the surface of the body (Fig. 3d). At its maximum development in elongata, the<tei:lb/>porophore is almost completely enclosed leaving only a characteristic crescentic aperture to the<tei:lb/>copulatory pouch visible on the body surface (Fig. 3e). In this species the copulatory pouch is<tei:lb/>restricted to the body wall and does not invade the coelom; the porophore occupies the medial<tei:lb/>wall of the copulatory pouch.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Juvenile individuals of Polypheretima koyana have copulatory pouches indistinguishable from<tei:lb/>those described above in mature adults of elongata (Fig. 3e). With increasing maturity the aperture<tei:lb/>to the pouch of koyana becomes a longitudinal slit and develops tumid lips while the porophore<tei:lb/>occupies the floor of the pouch (Fig. 3f). Insufficient material of this species is available to allow<tei:lb/>intermediate stages between figures 3e and 3f to be recognized.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male pores are on porophores in all species of Polypheretima as well as some species of Archi-<tei:lb/>pheretima and Planapheretima. The porophores may be within copulatory pouches in species of<tei:lb/>Polypheretima. However, it is possible that when more mature individuals become available for<tei:lb/>study some of the species which are noted as having simple male pores will be found to have more<tei:lb/>complex structures.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chen (1946) described the porophores of Planapheretima continens as occasionally bearing a<tei:lb/>penis-like structure (Fig. 3g), this species has not been examined. However, during the examin-<tei:lb/>ation of an individual of elongata, a similar structure was observed which proved to be an artifact<tei:lb/>caused by an incomplete removal of the cuticle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(b) Male pores lacking porophores. The stages in development of the male pore present in the<tei:lb/>species lacking porophores are represented in a series of individuals of Metapheretima kilii and,<tei:lb/>in the case of the most complex condition, M. oinakensis.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ACAECATE PHERETIMOID EARTHWORMS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 3 Development ot male pores, (a-f) Polypheretima; (g) Planapheretima continens;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(h-1) Metapheretima.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>6 E. G. E ASTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In an immature individual of kilii the male pore is at the centre of a low conical body (Fig. 3h).<tei:lb/>With increasing maturity the conical body increases in size and elevation (Fig. 3i), and the upper<tei:lb/>portion finally develops into a slim, penis-like structure (Figs 3j-k).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In oinakensis the male pore is terminal on a slim penis similar to that found in kilii (Fig. 3k),<tei:lb/>but it is incorporated within a copulatory pouch (Fig. 31). The intermediate stages by which this<tei:lb/>form of copulatory pouch develops are unknown, but in view of its different structure they are<tei:lb/>unlikely to be similar to those found in elongata. Development possibly involves the invagination<tei:lb/>of the body wall around the whole periphery of the basal end of the penis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male pores lack porophores in all species of Metapheretima and Pleionogaster and some species<tei:lb/>of Archipheretima and Planapheretima. The male pores may be in copulatory pouches in species<tei:lb/>of Metapheretima. Several species (Metapheretima deirdrae, jocchana and sembaluensis, Pleiono-<tei:lb/>gaster horsti. Planapheretima maculatd) have male pores considerably larger than those usually<tei:lb/>encountered.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In two species. Archipheretima ophiodies and Planapheretima hasselti, the male pores are on<tei:lb/>raised areas which extend onto xviii-xx and xvii-xix respectively (Figs 12a and 29b).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 Female pores</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The female pores are either paired or single, occurring ventrally on the equator of segment xiv.<tei:lb/>Occasionally individual variants may have paired female pores, although they belong to species<tei:lb/>in which the pore is usually single, the converse condition also occurs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7 Genital markings</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Glandular areas and other markings are present on the ventral surface of the anterior body wall<tei:lb/>of both clitellate and aclitellate individuals of many species. The nature and arrangement of these<tei:lb/>markings are specifically distinct and so provide valuable diagnostic information. They vary<tei:lb/>intraspecifically but these differences (degree of development and number of markings) may be<tei:lb/>attributed principally to growth since the patterns are usually constant in mature worms.<tei:lb/>(a) Diffuse genital markings with poorly defined periphery are present only in the Archipheretima<tei:lb/>iris species-group where they are always intersegmental (Fig. 4a).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(6) Discrete genital markings with clearly defined periphera commonly occur in all of the genera<tei:lb/>revised below, they are usually segmental and only rarely intersegmental. These markings are<tei:lb/>usually circular or oval and differentiated into two or more concentric areas (large markings,<tei:lb/>Fig. 4b, small Fig. 4d) ; rarely, in Polypheretima aringeana, the central area of each genital marking<tei:lb/>is differentiated into small spots (Fig. 4e). The glandular tissue associated with the markings is<tei:lb/>usually restricted to the body wall, termed 'sessile' (Gates, 1972). In species with very small<tei:lb/>markings, such as grata, the glandular tissue may invade the coelom in the form of a stalked<tei:lb/>gland. (In grata genital markings are present within the copulatory pouches but absent from the<tei:lb/>external, postclitellar ventral body surface.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genital markings on segment xviii are often similar in shape and position to those on ad-<tei:lb/>jacent segments, but they may be crescentic in shape and are closely associated with the male<tei:lb/>pores (Fig. 4c). Crescentic markings are present in Metapheretima (distinguishing the genus from<tei:lb/>Polypheretima), Pleionogaster and possibly two species of Planapheretima (celebensis and<tei:lb/>moultoni). Histologically crescentic markings are indistinguishable from the more common<tei:lb/>circular and oval genital markings.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(c) Annular ridges encircle the male pores in several species of Metapheretima (orcrista, parmata,<tei:lb/>glamdringi, jocchana) and one species of Planapheretima (maculatd). Several other species of<tei:lb/>Metapheretima, all members of the oinakensis species-group, have similar, but less extensively<tei:lb/>developed structures. Functionally these structures would appear to facilitate the transfer of<tei:lb/>sperm between opposing male and spermathecal segments during copulation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 Septa</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the oesophageal and pharyngeal regions septa are often absent, incomplete or thickened.<tei:lb/>Considerable variation exists within a species and septal characters appear to be of little diagnostic</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ACAECATE PHERETIMOID EARTHWORMS 7</tei:p>
         <tei:p>value (especially in view of the imprecise terms 'delicate', 'membranous', 'thickened', etc., which<tei:lb/>are used in descriptions). The absence or incomplete development of the septa associated with the<tei:lb/>gizzard (8/9 and 9/10) and, when present, the oesophageal pouches (10/11 and 11/12) can be<tei:lb/>correlated with the degree of development of these organs. In Pleionogaster, in which the oeso-<tei:lb/>phageal gizzard is vestigial, the anterior septa are uniform.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The septal muscles form part of the musculature of the hydrostatic skeleton (Chapman, 1958).<tei:lb/>Thickened muscular septa may therefore be indicative of an active burrowing species, certainly<tei:lb/>the musculature is poorly developed in arboricolous forms whose functional requirements are<tei:lb/>different.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>^ --.--.- ."jS'.'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>d e</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 4 Terminology of genital markings, (a) diffuse; (b) large discrete; (c) crescentic; (d) small<tei:lb/>discrete; (e) Polypheretima aringeana type.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 Alimentary canal</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within the Megascolecidae (sensu Gates, 1959) the Pheretima group of genera is characterized by<tei:lb/>the presence of an oesophageal gizzard in viii. In most species the gizzard is well developed,<tei:lb/>invading the next two posteriad segments, but in the monotypic Pleionogaster it is vestigual and<tei:lb/>its function is taken over to some extent by the intestinal gizzards which characterize the genus.<tei:lb/>Oesophageal pounches, structures of unknown function, may be present in some species of<tei:lb/>Metapheretima. They are usually paired, flexed anteriorly, and arise from the dorsal surface of<tei:lb/>the oesophagus immediately posteriad to the gizzard. The extent of their development varies<tei:lb/>considerably among the series examined; they are often darkly pigmented and always have a<tei:lb/>well-developed blood supply.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Intestinal caeca are absent from most of the species investigated with the exception of a few<tei:lb/>Asian species of Planapheretima. In some of the latter and several related acaecate forms, the<tei:lb/>intestinal wall was reported as being glandular (Chen, 1946) but it has not been possible to ex-<tei:lb/>amine material and the taxonomic significance of this specialization is uncertain.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10 Lateral hearts</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Four pairs of circumoesophageal contractile blood vessels are usually present, one pair in each of<tei:lb/>x-xiii, although the posterior or anterior pair may be absent or incomplete. As the number of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>8 E. G. EASTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pairs often vary individually within a species, the differing conditions are of little taxonomic<tei:lb/>significance.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>11 Anterior male reproductive system</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The majority of species of the Pheretima group are holandric (testes paired in both x and xi) as<tei:lb/>are all of the known species of Archipheretima, Planapheretima and Pleionogaster. Species with a<tei:lb/>proandric condition (testes paired in x only) are rare and acaecate examples are accommodated<tei:lb/>in Metapheretima (with the possible exception of sibogae in Polypheretima). Metandric species<tei:lb/>(testes paired in xi only) occur in both Polypheretima and Metapheretima; in the former genus<tei:lb/>metandry is restricted to (and diagnostic of) members of the badia and patae species-groups.<tei:lb/>However, in Metapheretima the character has a limited taxonomic value since metandry is present<tei:lb/>in most of the species-groups recognized.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>With the possible exception of several species of Archipheretima, the testes are invested by tough<tei:lb/>membranous sacs in all species of the Pheretima group, including Polypheretima fida, although<tei:lb/>testes sacs were recorded as being absent in this species (Michaelsen, 19136; Stephenson, 1930).<tei:lb/>In Archipheretima the sacs are usually more delicate and larger, mostly forming a lining to the<tei:lb/>parietal wall, although they have been reported as absent in some species (Gates, 1970a). The shape<tei:lb/>and the extent of the testes sacs varies with genus, species and to some extent with the maturity of<tei:lb/>an individual. In a few species the seminal vesicles and lateral hearts may also be enclosed within<tei:lb/>the testes sacs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The seminal vesicles are paired, posteriorly directed, sac-like evaginations of the hinder septa<tei:lb/>of each testes segment. In most species each pair is restricted to one segment where their size varies<tei:lb/>with maturity, but in several Chinese species of Planapheretima, they extend several segments<tei:lb/>anteriorly and posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Small, paired sacs which resemble the seminal vesicles may be present on the posterior surfaces<tei:lb/>of septa 12/13 and 13/14. These structures of unknown function have been termed ovisacs (Bed-<tei:lb/>dard, 1895), coelomic sacs (Sims &amp; Easton, 1972) and pseudoseminal vesicles (Gates, 1972). It is<tei:lb/>proposed here to adopt the term pseudoseminal vesicles, to avoid confusion with other structures<tei:lb/>described as coelomic pouches and coelomic sacs by Beddard &amp; Fedarb (1902).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>12 Ovaries</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The female gonads are paired and free in xiii in all the species investigated as well as the majority<tei:lb/>of other species of the Pheretima group. However, the ovaries are enclosed in delicate walled<tei:lb/>sacs in Pithemera mira and several related taxa from New Britain and nearby islands (Gates,<tei:lb/>19726).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>13 Spermathecae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The duct and ampulla of each spermatheca are distinctly demarcated in mature individuals of<tei:lb/>most of the species reviewed here. In immature specimens, and mature examples of Archiphere-<tei:lb/>tima, the duct merges gradually into the ampulla. In species of the acaecate genera a diverticulum<tei:lb/>(rarely several diverticula) arises from the spermathecal duct and provides a useful diagnostic<tei:lb/>character for generic, species-group and specific identifications. Several types of diverticula are<tei:lb/>encountered (Fig. 5).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The spermathecal pores may be either small (and difficult to see) or large, often within tumid<tei:lb/>lips. Gates (19720 : 150) described the large spermathecal pore as secondary since he recognized<tei:lb/>a minute (primary) pore within the invagination. The taxonomic aspect of this specialization was<tei:lb/>not investigated during the present study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The number and situation of spermathecae may vary within a thecal segment. These variations<tei:lb/>are reflected in the arrangement and number of spermathecal pores which are often diagnostic<tei:lb/>of species-groups and species. The pores may be segmental as in Polypheretima annulata and P.<tei:lb/>voeltzkowi or, more usually, intersegmental. In both situations they occur either in a single furrow,<tei:lb/>or segment, or in several consecutive furrows between 4/5 and 8/9, even 7/8/9/10 in the case of<tei:lb/>Metaphire sanseiana (Ohfuchi, 1951). When monothecate there is a single pore either dorsally or</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ACAECATE PHERETIMO1D EARTHWORMS 9</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ventrally placed in each segment (a single lateral pore indicates an abnormal example of a bithe-<tei:lb/>cate species). Bithecate species have two symmetrically placed pores, while numerous pores<tei:lb/>arranged in paired symmetrically placed batteries are external evidence of polythecate species.<tei:lb/>Most species are monothecate, bithecate or polythecate but some may be divided, being,<tei:lb/>for example, bithecal in some segments and polythecal in others. Immature specimens of poly-<tei:lb/>thecal species may be bithecal while the number of spermathecae in the batteries of the species of<tei:lb/>the Polypheretima elongata species-complex increases with maturity (Easton, 1976).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In bithecal and polythecal species the ventral separation of the pores (or batteries) can be<tei:lb/>expressed as a fraction of the body circumference at that segment. This proportion is reasonably<tei:lb/>constant in a taxon and often diagnostic. In this paper the separation of the most posterior sper-<tei:lb/>mathecal pores is utilized since occasionally the more anterior pores are more closely paired.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 5 Spermathecae. (a) differentiated with simple ectal diverticulum ; (b) differentiated with<tei:lb/>simple ental diverticulum; (c) undifferentiated with multilocular diverticulum (Archipheretimd)',<tei:lb/>(d) differentiated with multilocular diverticulum (Metapheretimd); (e) differentiated with numerous<tei:lb/>diverticula.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>14 Nephridia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The nephridia were excluded from the present numerical and taxonomic investigations due to the<tei:lb/>uncertainty about their systematic significance (see Classification) and for much the same reasons<tei:lb/>that they were omitted by Sims &amp; Easton (1972). The study of the nephridia would necessitate the<tei:lb/>destructive dissection of well-preserved specimens, and it was clearly undesirable to go to such<tei:lb/>extreme lengths to obtain information. Secondly, some species are represented by specimens often<tei:lb/>in poor condition due to either inadequate fixation, or previous dissections, so that information<tei:lb/>can no longer be obtained from them. Only a minority of the original descriptions include details<tei:lb/>of the nephridial system, so that it would be difficult to correlate this information.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nevertheless, variations in the nephridial system of a few species were studied for other reasons<tei:lb/>since, in the most recent classification of the Megascolecoid earthworms, Jamieson (197 la &amp; b)<tei:lb/>attributed considerable systematic importance to the structures of the excretory systems (see<tei:lb/>Classification).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Numerical studies</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Since only 14 acaecate species were assessed in the numerical investigations of Sims &amp; Easton<tei:lb/>(1972), it was decided to subject the majority of the 92 species recognized here to a<tei:lb/>fuller numerical appraisal. The taxa selected for study and the characters assessed are listed in<tei:lb/>Tables 1 and 2 respectively. The data utilized was extracted from the specific descriptions in the<tei:lb/>taxonomic section of this paper, instead of from the examination of a single individual which<tei:lb/>has been the practice of earlier authors. The techniques used resemble those employed by Sims &amp;<tei:lb/>Easton (1972) but the analyses were performed with the aid of a program adapted from the<tei:lb/>CLASP computer program (Gower &amp; Ross, Rothamsted Experimental Station) for use with the<tei:lb/>Varian V72 computer in the British Museum (Natural History). The mutual similarity coefficients</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>10</tei:p>
         <tei:p>E. G. E ASTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>of the taxa investigated were calculated using a coefficient of similarity defined for both quantita-<tei:lb/>tive and qualitative characters. A two-dimensional plot of the taxa involved was obtained using<tei:lb/>the method of principal co-ordinates analysis and a Minimum Spanning Tree (MST) was added<tei:lb/>to the plot.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 1 List of taxa studied in numerical investigations</tei:p>
         <tei:p>* Species not included in the initial numerical study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Four separate numerical investigations were made. Firstly, a general study was undertaken to<tei:lb/>re-appraise the 'acaecate' genera recognized by Sims &amp; Easton (1972). One result of this study was<tei:lb/>that Ephemitra is merged with Metapheretima, which is itself restricted, and the excluded species<tei:lb/>are here accommodated in Polypheretima. Then followed independent studies of each of the genera<tei:lb/>Metapheretima, Planapheretima and Polypheretima to detect the phenetic inter-relationships of<tei:lb/>their component species. Comparable information on the small genus Archipheretima is obtain-<tei:lb/>able from the initial, general computations while Pleionogaster is monotypic. The results of these<tei:lb/>studies are discussed under each genus in the taxonomic section.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>General Study</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Seventy-eight species were utilized to provide data for the re-appraisal of the genera recognized<tei:lb/>by Sims &amp; Easton (1972). It was not possible to include all of the species listed in Table 1 because<tei:lb/>of the limited capacity of the computer program employed, the taxa marked by an asterisk were<tei:lb/>those excluded from this study.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ACAECATE PHERETIMOID EARTHWORMS 1 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The configuration of the taxa with the first and second vectors of the principal co-ordinates<tei:lb/>analysis as axes is shown in Fig. 6. A considerable degree of clustering is evident, which becomes<tei:lb/>clearer with the addition of the Minimum Spanning Tree (MST) with graded linkages. Four major<tei:lb/>clusters may be recognized. Two, indicated by square and triangular symbols, comprise the six<tei:lb/>species of Archipheretima and 14 species of Planapheretima respectively, which by their discrete-<tei:lb/>ness and the low values of the MST linkages with other clusters confirm the validities of the<tei:lb/>genera. The two other clusters, indicated by closed and open circular symbols contain the taxa</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 2 Characters used for computing coefficients of similarity</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Mean longitude</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Mean latitude</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Ratio of lengths of arcs containing first five dorsal setae (v-z) : first five ventral setae (a-e) on segment<tei:lb/>vii</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Shape of body in cross-section : circular or depressed</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 Creeping sole : present or absent</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 Segment number of anterior end of clitellum</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7 Segment number of posterior end of clitellum</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 Size of spermathecal pores : large or small</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 Ratio of distance apart of posteriormost spermathecal pores : circumference of body</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10 Position (furrow number) of anteriormost spermathecal pores (one 'furrow' = setal row - setal row)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 1 Position (furrow number) of posteriormost spermathecal pores</tei:p>
         <tei:p>12 Position of spermathecal pores: postsetal, intersegmental, or presetal</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 3 Main number of spermathecal pores per furrow</tei:p>
         <tei:p>14 Origin of spermathecal diverticula: ectal or ental</tei:p>
         <tei:p>15 Condition of spermathecal diverticula: single or multiple</tei:p>
         <tei:p>16 Condition of male pores: crescentic copulatory pouches, slightly invaginated porophore, superficial<tei:lb/>porophore, superficial lacking porophore, penate simple or penate within copulatory pouches</tei:p>
         <tei:p>17 Size of male pore (superficial lacking porophore only): large or small</tei:p>
         <tei:p>18 Ratio of distance apart of male pores: circumference of body</tei:p>
         <tei:p>19 Annular ridges associated with male pores: absent or present</tei:p>
         <tei:p>20 Crescentic markings associated with male pores : absent or present</tei:p>
         <tei:p>21 Form of genital markings : diffuse or discrete</tei:p>
         <tei:p>22 Postclitellar genital markings (discrete only) number on each segment</tei:p>
         <tei:p>23 Glands associated with genital markings : sessile or stalked (discrete only)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>24 Oesophagus : simple, slightly pouched, or distinctly pouched</tei:p>
         <tei:p>25 Intestine: caecate, simple, with gizzards</tei:p>
         <tei:p>26 Intestinal wall : unspecialized or glandular</tei:p>
         <tei:p>27 Number of first intestinal segment</tei:p>
         <tei:p>28 Condition of testes : proandric, holandric or metandric</tei:p>
         <tei:p>29 Condition of testes sacs : absent, large membranous, annular, large paired, small paired</tei:p>
         <tei:p>previously assigned to Metapheretima by Sims &amp; Easton (1972). The species identified by closed<tei:lb/>circular symbols have male pores which lack porophores but usually have crescentic markings<tei:lb/>associated with them. The male pores sometimes discharge from within copulatory pouches when<tei:lb/>they are on elongate penes. The taxa principally from the Papuan region, have diverse types of<tei:lb/>spermathecal diverticula and genital markings which are usually in longitudinal rows. Included<tei:lb/>in this cluster are the type species of Metapheretima Michaelsen, 1928 and Ephemitra Sims &amp;<tei:lb/>Easton, 1972. The taxa indicated by open circular symbols have the male pores on porophores<tei:lb/>which lack associated crescentic markings. These male pores sometimes discharge into copulatory<tei:lb/>pouches when the porophore forms a short truncate penis. The taxa, which come from all parts<tei:lb/>of the Pheretima group domain, always have simple spermathecal diverticula, but together<tei:lb/>exhibit a wide diversity of patterns of genital markings. The type species of Polypheretima is<tei:lb/>included in this cluster. The degree of separation of the clusters and the evidence of the MST<tei:lb/>linkages permit the recognition of two distinct genera Metapheretima and Polypheretima.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>12</tei:p>
         <tei:p>E. G. EASTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>36</tei:p>
         <tei:p>86*-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>\ Species 72-85 -</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 6 Principal co-ordinates analysis of 78 'acaecate' species : the configuration of the species with<tei:lb/>the vectors corresponding to the first and a second latent roots. The linkages of the added Minimum</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Spanning Tree are graded to indicate percentage similarities; , +95%; , 90-95%;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>, -90%. The genera recognized are depicted thus: Pleionogaster - star-shaped symbol;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Metapheretima - closed circular symbols; Polypheretima - open circular symbols; Archipheretima<tei:lb/>- square symbols ; Planapheretima - triangular symbols.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ACAECATE PHERETIMOID EARTHWORMS 1 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The species horsti, represented by a star in Fig. 6, is linked by the MST to Metapheretima<tei:lb/>(indicated by closed circular symbols) at 90-0% similarity. This value is higher than many of the<tei:lb/>MST linkages within Metapheretima and the locus of horsti is closer to the centre of the cluster<tei:lb/>than several taxa of Metapheretima, notably jocchana (36). Nevertheless, horsti is the type species<tei:lb/>and only representative of the genus Pleionogaster which is unique among the Megascolecidae in<tei:lb/>possessing intestinal gizzards. Since this character is not only unique but also considered by most<tei:lb/>workers to be of considerable systematic importance, it is proposed to retain this genus as a<tei:lb/>separate entity.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Except for these changes, the numerical results are in accord with those of Sims &amp; Easton<tei:lb/>(1972), when a dissimilar set of morphological attributes were coded and processed on a larger<tei:lb/>computer. These authors indicated that the species accommodated here in Polypheretima could be<tei:lb/>distinguished from other acaecate forms, but they were uncertain of the taxonomic significance of<tei:lb/>the diagnostic characters of this group, and refrained from separating the species taxonomically.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distribution</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The distribution of the acaecate members of the Pheretima-group of genera need to be discussed<tei:lb/>in the context of the indigenous ranges of all the species within the group. Moreover, assessments<tei:lb/>of the affinities and origin(s) of the individual pheretimoids need to be considered in the light of<tei:lb/>the wider distribution of the group as a whole.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Pheretima group domain</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The concept of the Pheretima group domain, the area in which all of the autochthonous species<tei:lb/>of the Pheretima-group of genera occur (Fig. 7), was pioneered by Michaelsen (19036, 1908,<tei:lb/>19286). In the last work the area was defined as comprising Japan, China, Burma through south-<tei:lb/>east Asia and the Indo- Australasian Archipelago to Queensland then to New Caledonia, the New<tei:lb/>Hebrides, the Caroline Islands and, tentatively, the Comoro Islands. The results of recent col-<tei:lb/>lecting now make it possible to establish most of the boundaries with greater precision. The nor-<tei:lb/>thern limit is bounded by the most northerly records of Metaphire agger a (Kobayashi, 1934) which<tei:lb/>form a line linking Chihfeng, Yamhsin (Chinhsein) and Tashihkiano (Tashihchiano) in Man-<tei:lb/>churia with P'yongyang (Heijo) and Kumgang-san (Mt Kongo) in Korea (Kobayashi, 1940). In<tei:lb/>the west, Chen (1931, 1936, 1946) recorded a rich indigenous fauna from Szechwan Province<tei:lb/>while Gates (19720 : 149) recognized that the Chindwin-Irrawaddy axis marked the westerly<tei:lb/>limit of the domain in Burma. In the south only a single indigenous representative of the Pheretima<tei:lb/>group, Amynthas queenslandicus (Fletcher, 1887), has been recorded from Australia since enchy-<tei:lb/>traeoides Michaelsen, 1916, also from Queensland, was shown by Gates (1961) to be a synonym<tei:lb/>of the peregrine species A. minimus (Horst, 1893). Expeditions organized by Dr B. G. M. Jamieson<tei:lb/>have collected several new indigenous species in northern Queensland, although only peregrine<tei:lb/>species were found in Northern Territory (Easton, in prep.). It seems certain, therefore, that much<tei:lb/>of the tropical forest of Queensland belongs to the domain. The precise eastern limit of the domain<tei:lb/>is uncertain, since several species have ranges which include Pacific islands. Species have been<tei:lb/>described from the Marianas, Caroline Islands, Solomon Islands, New Hebrides and Loyalty<tei:lb/>Islands, which have not been encountered in other parts of the domain and it seems reasonable to<tei:lb/>to follow Michaelsen (19286) and include at least these islands within the realm. The Comoro<tei:lb/>Islands also possess a species of the Pheretima group which does not occur elsewhere. Although<tei:lb/>Michaelsen (19286) included the Comoro Islands within the domain, in view of the evidence<tei:lb/>discussed below, these islands are here excluded.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is evident that the Pheretima group domain extends throughout the forested lands of Asia<tei:lb/>and Australasia, but it is curiously restricted in some areas. In the north and northwest the limiting<tei:lb/>factors are apparently climatic. In Korea and Manchuria the northern boundary coincides with<tei:lb/>the 8 isotherm (annual mean temperature), and in Manchuria the western limit of the domain is<tei:lb/>marked by the 400 mm isohyet (Kobayashi, 1940). It is possible that isolated populations may<tei:lb/>occur in moist refuges to the west of the 400 mm isohyet since it has been suggested (Wadia, 1960)<tei:lb/>that the dessication of central Asia is a post-glacial phenomenon. To the southwest the 400 mm</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>14</tei:p>
         <tei:p>E. G. E ASTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Polypheretima</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Metapheretima</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Archipheretima</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Planapheretima</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pleionogaster</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 7 Geographical limits of the Pheretima group domain and the distribution of the acaecate</tei:p>
         <tei:p>genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>isohyet enters the Himalayas, where low precipitation and temperature provide a major barrier<tei:lb/>to earthworm migration.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Further south there are neither rainfall nor temperature barriers of any significance which may<tei:lb/>be correlated with limits of the Pheretima group. Nevertheless, a discrete boundary can be seen to<tei:lb/>exist and here it is necessary to examine the Caenozoic palaeogeography of Asia and Peninsula<tei:lb/>India to understand the pattern of distribution. During the Mesozoic when the Tethys ocean<tei:lb/>separated Peninsula India from Asia the direct interchange of earthworm faunae was not possible.<tei:lb/>In the Tertiary era conditions changed and the Indian and Asian plates approached their present<tei:lb/>relative positions. Western Burma and Bangladesh remained a barrier to earthworm migrations,<tei:lb/>since the Cretaceous and Tertiary sediments in this area did not become land to any great extent<tei:lb/>until the end of the Pliocene (1-5-3-5 million years ago) (Wadia, 1953). In Burma proper, although<tei:lb/>the ridges of the Chin hills/Araken Yoma and Pegu Yoma were formed during the Eocene and<tei:lb/>Miocene respectively, the intervening valleys remained below sea level even during the Pliocene<tei:lb/>(Krishnan, 1952). When the land links were eventually established the Pheretima group could have<tei:lb/>invaded Peninsula India from the east, but only the more successful peregrine species apparently<tei:lb/>did so. These occur nowadays throughout much of southern India and they may have attained<tei:lb/>this distribution unaided but in view of their occurrence on other continents it is likely that they<tei:lb/>were assisted adventitiously by man. Most of the non-peregrine species of this area remain confined</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ACAECATE PHERETIMOID EARTHWORMS 1 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>to the east of the Chindwin-Irrawaddy axis. This faunal limit lies between 100 and 150 km west<tei:lb/>of a line from the Irrawaddy south to Mandalay to the foot of the Shan plateau to the Sittang<tei:lb/>valley, i.e. the boundary of the Asian archean rocks (Rao, 1974 : 238).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In Australia the limiting factors forming the southern boundary of the Pheretima group domain<tei:lb/>are not known precisely but they appear to be largely ecological.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As most Megascolecoidea (Megascolecidae sensu Jamieson, 197 la and Eudrilidae) are indi-<tei:lb/>genous on land masses which once formed part of Gondwanaland, it seems likely that they evolved<tei:lb/>in this region and that their precursors existed in Gondwanaland prior to the Mesozoic break up<tei:lb/>of this ancient continent. The presence of the Pheretima group and other Megascolecid species<tei:lb/>in southeast Asia and the occurrence of several genera in North America, is probably due to<tei:lb/>invasions of these Laurasian land masses from the widely dispersed fragments of Gondwanaland.<tei:lb/>In this model of Megascolecoid dispersal, the origin of the Pheretima group would lie in New<tei:lb/>Guinea and northern Australia since these are the only major Gondwanaland derived areas<tei:lb/>inhabited by indigeneous species. The invasion of Asia by way of the Indo-Australasian Archi-<tei:lb/>pelago could therefore have followed the collision of the Australian and Asian Plates during the<tei:lb/>Miocene, 7-26 million years ago (Raven &amp; Axelrod, 1972).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>If the primordial pheretimoids had emerged before the Mesozoic breakup of Gondwanaland,<tei:lb/>it would have been possible for them to have migrated westwards to other regions and give rise<tei:lb/>to the species suspected of being indigenous in the Comoro Islands. However, the absence of any<tei:lb/>surviving indigenous species in the intervening areas, and the paucity of the Pheretima group in<tei:lb/>the Malagasian fauna, makes this seem unlikely. Emigration may have occurred eastwards to the<tei:lb/>Solomon Islands, New Hebrides and New Caledonia which, prior to 80 million years ago, were<tei:lb/>juxtaposed to Queensland (Griffiths, 1971). It should be noted, however, that today the Pheretima<tei:lb/>group is not indigenous in New Zealand although these islands too rifted from the eastern<tei:lb/>margin of the Australian Plate at that time. Other mechanisms by which earthworms may have<tei:lb/>colonized oceanic islands were discussed by Stephenson (1930).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distribution of the 'acaecate' pheretimoids</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The individual acaecate genera, although often sympatric, have dissimilar ranges (Fig. 7). Archi-<tei:lb/>pheretima is restricted to Borneo and the Philippines while the genera Polypheretima and Plana-<tei:lb/>pheretima are the most widespread, occurring throughout the Indo-Australasian archipelago to the<tei:lb/>northern and western limits of the Pheretima group domain. In Asia, they are now restricted to<tei:lb/>isolated refuges so presumably they were once continuously distributed throughout the area.<tei:lb/>Metapheretima is restricted principally to New Guinea, where it is the commonest acaecate<tei:lb/>pheretimoid. The monotypic genus Pleionogaster, closely allied to Metapheretima (see numerical<tei:lb/>studies) and probably a product of the Metapheretima radiation, is recorded only from the Philip-<tei:lb/>pines and possibly the Moluccas. The genera Polypheretima, Planapheretima and Metapheretima<tei:lb/>probably represent three radiations from the Papuan area.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The species-groups comprising the genus Metapheretima are largely sympatric and there is<tei:lb/>seemingly insufficient evidence to recognize any evolutionary patterns among them. Similarly,<tei:lb/>the ranges and morphological variation of the species of Archipheretima are too poorly known to<tei:lb/>permit valid conclusions to be drawn.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The infra-generic assemblages recognized within Polypheretima are, on the other hand, mainly<tei:lb/>allopatric and when their ranges are considered together with their morphological variations, the<tei:lb/>information provides a means of tracing the probable evolution of the genus. The species-groups<tei:lb/>of Polypheretima (see taxonomy section) form a series in which the morphological specializations<tei:lb/>increase as the geographical ranges decrease (Fig. 8). The most widespread, the bifaria species-<tei:lb/>group (Division I), is holandric with simple male pores (the species grata, voeltzkowi and the<tei:lb/>annulata species-complex, also members of Division I, are considered to be local specializations) ;<tei:lb/>the polytheca species-group (Division II) is similarly holandric but the male pores open within<tei:lb/>copulatory pouches ; while the most restricted in their distributions, the badia and patae species-<tei:lb/>groups (Division III), not only have male pores within copulatory pouches but also they are<tei:lb/>metandric. Although the badia and patae species-groups apparently have high mutual affinities<tei:lb/>(see Taxonomy section), in view of their widely separated ranges, it is probable that they have</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>16</tei:p>
         <tei:p>E. G. EASTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>developed metandry independently. Possibly the bifaria, polytheca, badia and patae species-groups<tei:lb/>represent successive radiations which occurred in different parts of the range of Polypheretima.<tei:lb/>These radiations are probably of considerable antiquity since the ranges of the species-groups<tei:lb/>cannot be correlated with either Wallace's or Weber lines. Two species for example, P. elongata<tei:lb/>and everetti, even occur on both sides of Wallaces line.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>annulate species-complex<tei:lb/>bifaria species -group<tei:lb/>&amp; grata</tei:p>
         <tei:p>polytheca species-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>patae species -group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>badia species -group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>limits of ranges uncertain</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 8 Polypheretima: geographical distribution of the component species-groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The two divisions of Planapheretima are also allopatric. Species of Division I have unspecialized<tei:lb/>intestines and occur in the Indo- Australasian archipelago while those of Division II have special-<tei:lb/>ized intestines and are indigenous to the Asian mainland. Probably precursors of Division II<tei:lb/>had simple intestines but whether this group arose in Asia is more speculative (see taxonomy<tei:lb/>section).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the northwestern and southeastern limits of the Pheretima group domain the acaecate genera<tei:lb/>occur only sporadically in isolated refuges, here the Pheretima group is represented mainly by the<tei:lb/>caecate genera Amynthas, Metaphire and Pheretima s.s. Many of the Asian species of Amynthas<tei:lb/>and Metaphire differ from species of Polypheretima only in the possession of intestinal caecae<tei:lb/>while most of the Papuan and Australian species of Amynthas may be considered to be caecate<tei:lb/>analogues of Metapheretima. Since the possession of intestinal caeca is a specialization, the caecate<tei:lb/>species may have emerged independently more than once, possibly from this acaecate stock and<tei:lb/>have replaced them in the northwestern and southeastern parts of the domain.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ACAECATE PHERETIMOID EARTHWORMS 1 7</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Classification</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For some time the opinion has been often held that 'the key to the classification of the ... (ter-<tei:lb/>restrial oligochaeta) is to be found in the modifications of the excretory system' (Beddard, 18906).<tei:lb/>The result is that the structure of the nephridial system has played an increasingly important part<tei:lb/>in earthworm classifications, although its application often has been hampered by the paucity of<tei:lb/>available information. During the last two decades several disparate classifications of Megascole-<tei:lb/>coid earthworms have been proposed (Omodeo, 1958; Gates, 1959; Lee, 1959; Jamieson, I91la<tei:lb/>&amp; b). In the latest Jamieson divided the Megascolecinae, which includes the Pheretima group of<tei:lb/>genera, into three tribes. The tribes Dichogastrini and Megascolecini both include genera with<tei:lb/>combined male and prostatic pores, and a meronephridial excretory system. In genera assigned to<tei:lb/>the former tribe the median nephridia are exonephric ; while in those of the latter tribe, median<tei:lb/>nephrida are enteronephric or absent. Enteronephridia have been recorded from no more than<tei:lb/>five species of the Pheretima group of genera; Metaphire posthuma by Bahl (1919), Amynthas<tei:lb/>hupiensis by Grant (1955), tentatively in Pleionogaster horsti by Gates (1943) and possibly in<tei:lb/>Amynthas hawayanus and A. diffringens by Bahl (1919) although the identities of the specimens<tei:lb/>representing these species have been questioned (Gates, 19376). Jamieson (197 la) accepted Bahl's<tei:lb/>(1946) syllogism that since a few species of Pheretima possess enteronephridia so all members of<tei:lb/>the genus (now the Pheretima group of genera) have them too, therefore he assigned the group to<tei:lb/>the enteronephric tribe Megascolecini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Due to the importance accredited to the structure of the nephridial system and the paucity of<tei:lb/>data available for most species of the Pheretima group, the nephridial systems of examples of the<tei:lb/>acaecate genera were examined. Comparisons were made with the description of Bahl (1919) who<tei:lb/>recognized three types of nephridia in M. posthuma.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1. Tufted nephridia, present in the segments anterior to the gizzard and discharging into the<tei:lb/>pharynx.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2. Body wall nephridia, present in all segments except i. These are numerous, Bahl recorded<tei:lb/>200-250 in a segment and Grant (1955) reported 175 in each segment in A. hupiensis. Bahl<tei:lb/>reported that in M. posthuma each nephridium discharged independently but Beddard (1888)<tei:lb/>stated that in A. hawayanus each nephridium was linked by a reticulum to other nephridia, both<tei:lb/>of its own and of adjacent segments. [It should be noted that Beddard (1888) provisionally identi-<tei:lb/>fied the specimens as aspergillum but later (1895 : 43) he established that they were bermudensis =<tei:lb/>hawayanus.] Spencer (1888) reported a similar nephridial reticulum in Megascolides australis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3. Median nephridia, present on septum 15/16 and posteriorly to the end of the body. Eighty to<tei:lb/>one hundred nephridia are present on the anterior and posterior surfaces of each septum in M.<tei:lb/>posthuma and 70-80 in the case of A. hupiensis (Grant, 1955). In both species, the nephridia are<tei:lb/>enteronephric in that they are linked by paired, postseptal ducts which run dorsally and medianly<tei:lb/>to discharge into paired supraintestinal ducts, these in turn discharge, at intervals, into the in-<tei:lb/>testine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In this present study, examples of two species, Metapheretima sentanensis and Polypheretima<tei:lb/>taprobanae, were examined in detail and examples of four other species, M. neoguinensis (type<tei:lb/>species of Metapheretima), P. stelleri(type species of Polypheretima), P. elongata and Pleionogaster<tei:lb/>horsti (=jagori, type species of Pleionogaster) were compared with them. The specimens examined<tei:lb/>had been preserved in alcohol for several years prior to study, so they were stained with methylene<tei:lb/>blue to enhance the recognition of the decolourized internal structures. Modifications and varia-<tei:lb/>tions were found in each of the three types of nephridia described above among the species<tei:lb/>examined (Table 3).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1. Tufted nephridia are present in iv-vi in all of the species examined. The nephridia occur as<tei:lb/>paired lateral masses on the peripheries of the anterior surface of the septa and paired excretory<tei:lb/>(?) ducts can be traced passing between each nephridial mass and the pharyngeal mass. Additional<tei:lb/>tufted nephridia are present in vii and viii in neoguinensis and in vii-ix in horsti and sentanensis.<tei:lb/>When the posterior septa of these segments are absent or incomplete the nephridia form paired<tei:lb/>lateral bands on the body wall. In sentanensis paired excretory ( ?) ducts can be traced passing from</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>18</tei:p>
         <tei:p>E. G. EASTON</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ACAECATE PHERETIMOID EARTHWORMS 1 9</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the nephridial masses of vii and viii forward to enter the body wall in the vicinity of the spermathe-<tei:lb/>cal pores. In xi where each lateral band is subdivided into three discrete masses, no ducts can be<tei:lb/>recognized. Gates (1943) first described the tufted nephridia of vii-ix in horsti and similar structures<tei:lb/>have been recognized in several species of Lampito (Bahl, 1924) and Megascolex (Vata, 1945).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2. Body wall nephridia vary in number according to the species and the region of the body studied,<tei:lb/>they are however always absent from the anteriormost segments. In horsti and sentanensis they<tei:lb/>are particularly sparse (c. 10 and c. 20 per segment respectively). The external nephridiopores<tei:lb/>described by Beddard (1888) and Bahl (1919) cannot be recognized. The reticulum described by<tei:lb/>Beddard (1888) appears to be present although transverse microsections need to be studied to<tei:lb/>confirm this observation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 9 Metapheretima sentanensis: schematic diagram of a transverse section through the<tei:lb/>equatorial region of a posterior segment showing the semiannular sinuses and associated nephridia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the posteriormost segments of two of the specimens examined (sentanensis and taprobanae)<tei:lb/>the body wall nephridia of each segment apparently discharge into a pair of semi-annular lateral<tei:lb/>sinuses (Fig. 9). Excretory ducts leading to external pores are apparently absent. These structures<tei:lb/>may be analogous to the coelomic pouches of M. posthuma described by Beddard &amp; Fedarb<tei:lb/>(1902), but it is possible that they are artifacts resulting from the epithelial lining of the coelom<tei:lb/>becoming detached during fixation or preservation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3. Median nephridia are present in all of the species studied, but their numbers and positions vary<tei:lb/>from species to species. In elongata and stelleri they are sparse and close to the body wall and are<tei:lb/>apparently linked to the reticulum of the body wall nephridia. In horsti a single pair of large<tei:lb/>nephridia with preseptal funnels are present from septum 18/19 and Gates (1943) tentatively<tei:lb/>recognized a pair of postseptal excretory ducts leading to the dorsal portion of the intestine in<tei:lb/>each segment. In taprobanae there are numerous nephridia with preseptal funnels on each septum<tei:lb/>from 15/16 to the posterior end of the body. They lie in paired lateral arcs approximately halfway<tei:lb/>between the intestine and the body wall. In sentanensis a single pair of nephridia with preseptal<tei:lb/>funnels are present on septum 43/44, but the number of nephridia increase posteriorly to septum<tei:lb/>70/71 where there are about 40 with preseptal funnels and 20 with postseptal funnels. The neph-<tei:lb/>ridia then decrease in number until septum 90/91 where there are about 10 with preseptal funnels<tei:lb/>and only two or three with postseptal funnels. Where they are reduced in number, the nephridia<tei:lb/>are dorsally situated. In neoguinensis, the nephridia are close to the periphery of each septum,<tei:lb/>occurring regularly through the body from septum 18/19.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Discussion</tei:p>
         <tei:p>From this brief morphological survey it emerges that the nephridial systems of the species<tei:lb/>examined differ considerably, although they all possess median nephridia. Enteronephric ducts.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>20 E. G. EASTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>diagnostic of the Megascolecini (Jamieson, 1971a &amp; b) and recorded in Metaphire posthuma by<tei:lb/>Bahl (1919) and Amynthas hupiensis by Grant (1955), could not be identified in any of the species<tei:lb/>studied although exonephric ducts, diagnostic of the Dichogastrini (Jamieson, 197 la &amp; b),<tei:lb/>appear to be present in Polypheretima elongata and P. stelleri.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As nephridial structures characteristic of two of these different tribes are present within the<tei:lb/>homogeneous assemblage of species forming the Pheretima group of genera, it seems that these<tei:lb/>structures are unreliable characters for higher classification. If they were accepted, then members<tei:lb/>of the Pheretima group would be distributed between the Dichogastrini and the Megascolecini.<tei:lb/>Clearly this would be unacceptable. Until new taxonomic criteria can be recognized, or evidence<tei:lb/>conflicting with the results of the phenetic study become available, it is intended to revert to the<tei:lb/>older classification of Megascolecoid earthworms proposed by Gates (1959) within which the<tei:lb/>Pheretima group can be more readily accommodated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Megascolecidae (Gates, 1959) - 'species with racemose prostates of the Pheretima type,<tei:lb/>without a central lumen and presumably of mesodermal origin' - includes the Pheretima group<tei:lb/>of genera (c. 760 nominal species) and about thirteen other genera with approximately 280 species.<tei:lb/>Similarly, the tribe Megascolecini Jamieson, \91\a &amp; b accommodated ten genera containing<tei:lb/>about 210 species in addition to the Pheretima group. Of the 280 species in the Megascolecidae<tei:lb/>sensu Gates, some 130 are from the Indian region, 130 from Australia and the residue from New<tei:lb/>Zealand. As previously mentioned, the Pheretima group originated on the Australian Plate so its<tei:lb/>closest allies might be expected to be present among the indigenous Megacolecidae of Australia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxonomy</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The component species of the Pheretima group of genera are readily distinguishable from the<tei:lb/>members of the other genera forming the family Megascolecidae (sensu Gates, 1959) by the pre-<tei:lb/>sence of an oesophageal gizzard in segment viii. The gizzard is usually well developed to the extent<tei:lb/>that it often lies within the parietes of not only segment viii but also segments ix and x. In Pleiono-<tei:lb/>gaster, however, the oesophageal gizzard is only vestigial and here it is replaced functionally by<tei:lb/>intestinal gizzards which are diagnostic of the genus. Additionally all pheretimoids are peri-<tei:lb/>chaetine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The species of this group of genera form two loose assemblages ; those with a pair of lateral<tei:lb/>caeca or a single median caecum arising from the anterior region of the intestine, and those without<tei:lb/>this specialization. The latter category, the 'acaecate' species are revised here and assigned to five<tei:lb/>genera : Archipheretima, Metapheretima (inc. Ephmitra), Planapheretima, Pleionogaster and Poly-<tei:lb/>pheretima. On the basis of the numerical investigations described above and detailed under the<tei:lb/>genera concerned, the species are often placed in divisions and species-groups also, in two<tei:lb/>instances, species-complexes are recognized. Some of these infra-generic categories may represent<tei:lb/>superspecies while others may, in time, be considered to represent subgenera, but until further<tei:lb/>information becomes available, they should be regarded as being no more than aggregations of<tei:lb/>morphologically similar species placed together to facilitate identification. They are not co-<tei:lb/>ordinate, even within any one genus. One of the species-complexes recognized was erected to<tei:lb/>contain five closely allied taxa comprising the Polypheretima elongata species-complex (Easton,<tei:lb/>1976). At the present time the mutual relationships of these taxa are unknown, in many ways the<tei:lb/>complex resembles a polytypic species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The majority of acaecate species are known from only one or two series, and whenever possible<tei:lb/>examples of all known records have been examined in this study. The following abbreviations have<tei:lb/>been utilized to denote the institution in which material is deposited.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Adelaide South Australian Museum</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amsterdam Zoologisch Museum, Universitat van Amsterdam</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Berlin Museum fur Naturkunde an der Humbolt-Universitat zu Berlin</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bogor Museum Zoologicum Bogoriense, Bogor, Indonesia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BMNH British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cambridge University Museum of Zoology, Cambridge, England</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genoa Museo Civico di Storia Naturale 'Giacomo Doria'</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ACAECATE PHERETIMOID EARTHWORMS 21</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hamburg Zoologisches Institut und Zoologisches Museum, Universitat Hamburg</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Honolulu Bernice P. Bishop Museum</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leiden Rijksmuseum van Natuurlijke Historic</tei:p>
         <tei:p>New York American Museum of Natural History</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stockholm Naturhistoriska Riksmuseet</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Turin Museo ed Institute di Zoologica Systematica, Universita di Turin</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vienna Naturhistorisches Museum Wein</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aclitellate and clitellate individuals among the material examined are indicated by the letters A<tei:lb/>and C respectively.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to the genera of the Pheretima group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Setae crowded ventrally, creeping sole present, body usually flattened dorsoventrally</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Planapheretima (p. 64)<tei:lb/>Setae not crowded ventrally, creeping sole absent, body always cylindrical ... 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Intestine lacking caecum(a) or gizzards 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Intestine with gizzards ......... Pleionogaster (p. 114)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Intestine with caecum(a) ............ 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Crescentic markings associated with male pores (Fig. 4c) . . Metapheretima (p. 78)<tei:lb/>Crescentic markings absent ........... 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Clitellum extending over more than three segments; spermathecal diverticula multilocular</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Archipheretima (p. 21)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clitellum restricted to three segments, spermathecal diverticula simple . Polypheretima (p. 28)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5(2) Intestinal caecum(a) originating in or near segment xxii ..... Pithemera 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Intestinal caecum(a) originating in or near segment xxvii ...... 6</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 Male pores simple ............ Amynthas 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male pores within copulatory pouches ......... 7</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7 Nephridia on spermathecal ducts ........ Pheretima 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nephridia absent from spermathecal ducts ....... Metaphire 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 For keys to the nominal species and species-groups of the 'caecate' genera, Amynthas, Metaphire, Pheretima and<tei:lb/>Pithemera, see Sims &amp; Easton (1972). For species transferred to these genera since 1972 see below (p. 119).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ARCHIPHERETIMA Michaelsen, 1928</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Megascolex (part): Beddard, 1895 : 370.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amynthas (part): Beddard, 1900a : 612.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pheretima (part): Michaelsen, 1900 : 234.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pheretima (Archipheretima} (part) Michaelsen, 1928a : 7.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pheretima (Archipheretima): Michaelsen, 19346 : 15.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Archipheretima: Sims &amp; Easton, 1972 : 200, 232.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE SPECIES. Megascolex iris Michaelsen, 1892, original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Megascolecidae with an oesophageal gizzard in viii, intestinal caeca and gizzards<tei:lb/>absent. Body cylindrical, setae never excessively crowded ventrally, creeping sole absent. Male<tei:lb/>pores superficial or on circular porophores, never within copulatory pouches. Spermathecal<tei:lb/>diverticula multilocular.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Body cylindrical. Clitellum annular, extending over four or more segments in<tei:lb/>mature individuals (xii, xiii-xvi, xvii, xviii). Dorsal pores present from 12/13. Setae perichaetine<tei:lb/>with large dorsal gaps (up to 0-25 body circumference), often slightly crowded ventrally. Lateral<tei:lb/>hearts in x-xii and sometimes xiii.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Oesophagus with a well-developed gizzard in viii, lacking dorsal pouches and calciferous<tei:lb/>glands. Intestine begins between xv and xvii, simple, lacking caeca, gizzards and glandular walls.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holandric, testes free (?) or in large, delicate sacs lining the coelom and usually enclosing the<tei:lb/>anterior seminal vesicles, the lateral hearts and other vessels. Seminal vesicles paired in xi and xii.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Prostates racemose. Paired, combined male and prostatic pores on the ventral surface of xviii<tei:lb/>in the setal ring. Male pores occasionally on porophores which may be elongate and extend onto</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>22 E. G. EASTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>xix and xx. Copulatory pouches absent. Ovaries free. Oviducts leading to single or closely paired<tei:lb/>midventral equatorial pore(s) on xiv. Spermathecae only slightly differentiated into duct and<tei:lb/>ampulla; each with a short multilocular diverticulum. Spermathecae arranged in pairs in three or<tei:lb/>four adjacent segments between v and ix. Spermathecal pores always intersegmental, small, often<tei:lb/>slitlike, ventral or ventrolateral.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genital markings of two kinds have been recorded ; discrete paired, ovoid segmental markings<tei:lb/>and diffuse intersegmental markings. The porophores extending from xviii to xx in some species<tei:lb/>may be confused with genital markings.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Borneo, Philippines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>INCLUDED SPECIES, iris species-group (iris, margaritacea, mazarredi, zonatd), ophiodes, picta.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NUMERICAL STUDIES. In the initial computer study (see above) the affinities of the species as<tei:lb/>revealed by the MST and their configuration on the first and second vectors (Fig. 6) provide the<tei:lb/>basis for the recognition of two distinct species and one species-group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Although a key is provided for the identification of species included in the genus<tei:lb/>Archipheretima, mature individuals may be readily assigned to their species or species-group on<tei:lb/>the form of their genital markings (Figs 1 1 and 12). The species tumifaciens (Lee, 1967) which was<tei:lb/>provisionally included in Archipheretima by Sims &amp; Easton (1972) is now transferred to Meta-<tei:lb/>pheretima as a synonym of M. jocchana (Cognetti, 1911).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to the species of the genus Archipheretima</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 First spermathecal pores in furrow 4/5 (3 thecal segments) .... ophiodes (p. 27)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First spermathecal pores in furrow 5/6 (4 thecal segments) ...... 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First spermathecal pores in furrow 6/7 (3 thecal segments) ...... 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Spermathecal pores closely paired (0-05 body circumference apart) . . . zonata (p. 23)<tei:lb/>Spermathecal pores widely paired (0-20-0-30 body circumference apart) .... 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Male pore small, indistinct (Philippines) ...... mazarredi (p. 23)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male pore at centre of large porophore (Borneo) ...... picta (p. 26)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4(1) Spermathecal pores c. 0-05 body circumference apart (preclitellar genital markings absent)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>iris (p. 26)<tei:lb/>Spermathecal pores c. 0-10 body circumference apart (preclitellar genital markings present)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>margaritacea (p. 25)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Archipheretima iris species-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Archipheretima with poorly defined intersegmental genital markings and simple male<tei:lb/>pores.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Borneo and Philippines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SPECIES INCLUDED, iris, margaritacea, mazarredi, zonata.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Juvenile and other individuals with poorly developed genital markings may be dis-<tei:lb/>tinguished from picta by the absence of a porophore and from ophiodes by the presence of<tei:lb/>spermathecal pores in furrow 7/8. Marker characters of the species included in the iris species-<tei:lb/>group are given in Table 4.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Archipheretima mazarredi (Rosa, 1894)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Megascolex mazarredi Rosa, 1 894 : 6.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amynthas mazarredoi: Michaelsen, 1899 : 15; Beddard, 1900a : 644.<tei:lb/>Pheretima mazarredoi: Michaelsen, 1900 : 283; Gates, 1970a : 155.<tei:lb/>Archipheretima mazarredoi: Sims &amp; Easton, 1972 : 232.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Archipheretima with spermathecal pores about one fifth of the body circumference<tei:lb/>apart in furrows 5/6/7/8/9. Genital markings poorly defined, intersegmental.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. External characters. Length 200-325 mm, diameter 13-15 mm. 105-131 segments.<tei:lb/>Clitellum xiii-xvi. First dorsal pore 12/13. Setae c. 100 on xxv, setal ring crowded ventrally.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ACAECATE PHERETIMOID EARTHWORMS<tei:lb/>Table 4 Marker characters of the members of the Archipheretima iris species-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>23</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male pores c. 0-20 body circumference apart. Female pore single. Spermathecal pores paired,<tei:lb/>5/6/7/8/9, c. 0-20 body circumference apart.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genital markings (Fig. 11 a) diffuse, paired, intersegmental in line with the male pores in 17/18<tei:lb/>and 18/19, 19/20, 20/21.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Internal characters. Septa anterior to 17/18 thickened. Intestine begins in xvii. Lateral hearts in<tei:lb/>x-xiii.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holandric, testes in x and xi, testes sacs membranous or absent, seminal vesicles in xi and xii.<tei:lb/>Spermathecae (Fig. lOa) paired in vi-ix.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>10mm</tei:p>
