         <tei:p>20 First antenna 5-segmented in ?, 7-segmented in &lt;J ...... Rataniaflava</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- First antenna 7-segmented in ?, 9-segmented in $ . . . . . . Ratania atlantica</tei:p>
         <tei:p>21 First antenna 3-segmented; lateral seta of caudal ramus located about 33% of distance along</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ramus ............ Mormonilla phasma</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- First antenna 4-segmented; lateral seta of caudal ramus located about 16% of distance along</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ramus Mormonilla minor</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Description of species<tei:lb/>HARPACTICOIDA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A total of 17 species belonging to 7 families are regarded here as being true planktonic forms.<tei:lb/>Many other harpacticoids have been recorded from the plankton, but they have usually been<tei:lb/>found in the neritic zone and can be regarded as temporarily displaced littoral forms (Wells,<tei:lb/>1970). Occasionally littoral species are carried into oceanic waters by clinging to algae drifting<tei:lb/>in ocean currents (Yeatman, 1962), these can also be regarded as expatriated specimens as they<tei:lb/>are not permanent members of the plankton.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family AEGISTHIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus AEGIS THUS Giesbrecht, 1891</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Prosome 5-segmented with first thoracic somite free and about equal in size to the<tei:lb/>following somite. Genital complex ($) with dorsal and lateral transverse suture line. Caudal rami<tei:lb/>at least twice as long as whole body. Rostrum present or absent. First antenna (?) 6- or 7-seg-<tei:lb/>mented, (() 7- or 8-segmented, weakly or not geniculate. Second antenna slender with 1 -seg-<tei:lb/>mented exopod bearing 1 or 2 setae. Mandible (?) with or without rudimentary palp; apparently<tei:lb/>absent in $. First maxilla ($) well developed, (&lt;) bilobed, rudimentary. Second maxilla (?) well<tei:lb/>developed, (&lt;J) with well-developed basipod but rudimentary rami. Maxilliped 3-segmented; ($)<tei:lb/>well developed, ($) poorly developed. Legs 1-4 with 3-segmented rami, armature formula as<tei:lb/>follows :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coxa Basis Endopod Exopod</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 1 0-0 1-1 0-1 ; 0-1 ; 1, 2, 2 1-1 ; 1-1 ; I, 2, 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 2 0-0 1-0 0-1 ; 0-2; 1, 2, 2 1-1 ; 1-1 ; III, 2, 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 3 0-0 1-0 0-1 ; 0-2; 1, 2, 3 1-1 ; 1-1 ; III, 2, 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 4 0-0 1-0 0-1; 0-1; 1,2, 2 1-1 ; 1-1 ; III, 2, 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 5 elongate, bearing a short naked seta and 5 serrate setae ($) and with 5 serrate setae and 2<tei:lb/>additional plumose setae in &lt;J. Leg 6 with 1 or 2 small setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>204 G. A. BOXSHALL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Aegisthus mucronatus Giesbrecht, 1891.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Some differences of opinion exist over the homology of the caudal rami in this well-<tei:lb/>defined genus. Giesbrecht (1892), Scott (1894), Farran (1905), Rose (1933) and Wells (1970) have<tei:lb/>erroneously interpreted the structures on the anal somite as comprising very short caudal rami<tei:lb/>fused to the anal somite and each bearing an extremely long seta which is itself setate (see Scott,<tei:lb/>1894; pi. 11, figs 31 &amp; 44). In fact the caudal rami are extremely long (often as much as five times<tei:lb/>longer than the body), closely pressed together and armed with a lateral seta in the middle third<tei:lb/>of each ramus and at least 2 apical setae, one of which is plumose (Sars, 1916; Lang, 1948).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aegisthus mucronatus Giesbrecht, 1891</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aegisthus mucronatus Giesbrecht, 1891 : 476.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A. longirostris Scott, 1894 : 104, pi. XI, figs 31^4.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A. dubius Sars, 1916 : 8, 14, pi. VIII.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Female. Prosome without reticulate chitinous markings on dorsal surface ; maximum<tei:lb/>body width at level of second free thoracic somite (Fig. 1A). Genital complex with dorsal and<tei:lb/>lateral transverse suture line, armed with spinules. Rostrum very long and anteriorly directed.<tei:lb/>First antenna 6-segmented with large hook-like process medially on proximal segment. Second<tei:lb/>antenna with 2 unequal distal setae on exopod. Maxilliped (Fig. IB) 3-segmented with 3 enlarged<tei:lb/>spines and 1 seta on middle segment and 3 setae on distal segment. Leg 1 with 3-segmented rami,<tei:lb/>but suture lines between segments 2 and 3 sometimes indistinct; exopod segments 2 and 3 with<tei:lb/>short spines on outer margins. Leg 5 (Fig. 1C) free segment with 3 serrate setae on lateral margin,<tei:lb/>1 serrate seta and a naked seta distally and 1 serrate seta subapically. Leg 6 (Fig. ID) an elongate<tei:lb/>free segment with a short subapical and a long apical seta.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body length of female from 1-90 to 2-55 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. As $ except: cephalothorax (Fig. IE) relatively narrow. Rostrum absent. First antenna<tei:lb/>8-segmented. Second antenna (Fig. IF) with 1 seta distally on exopod. First maxilla bilobed,<tei:lb/>rudimentary. Second maxilla with large claw-like process on basipod, rami rudimentary with 5<tei:lb/>short setae. Maxilliped 3-segmented; weakly developed, carrying 2 short setae on apex of distal<tei:lb/>segment. Leg 5 (Fig. 1G) 2-segmented; first segment with small proximal seta and distal serrate<tei:lb/>seta on outer margin; second segment with 2 serrate seta on outer margin, 2 on distal margin<tei:lb/>(the inner just longer than the outer) and 2 plumose setae on inner margin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body length of male from 1-10 to 1-70 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 352 $$, 48 &lt;&amp;?: N.E. Atlantic Ocean, 18 N 25 W, 'Discovery' Stn 7089.<tei:lb/>BM(NH) registration numbers 1977.155-164 ($) and 1977.165-174 ($). 3 $$, 1 &lt;? syntypes of A.<tei:lb/>longirostris: Gulf of Guinea, 1 55' N 5 55' E (Scott, 1894). BM(NH) registration numbers<tei:lb/>1893.4.22.588-589.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Sars (1916) described A. dubius from male specimens and mentioned the similarities<tei:lb/>between it and female A. mucronatus. He regarded it as a separate species because of the absence<tei:lb/>of a rostrum, the structure of the first antenna and the marked reduction of the mouthparts.<tei:lb/>Farran (1926) suspected that A. dubius was the male of A. mucronatus, as A. mucronatus females<tei:lb/>were found in every haul from which A. dubius was recorded but he did not synonymize the two<tei:lb/>species because Scott (1894) had described both sexes of a new species, A. longirostris, the females<tei:lb/>of which had since been recognized as being synonymous with A. mucronatus. The syntype series<tei:lb/>of A. longirostris contains only 1 male specimen. This specimen lacks a rostrum and its append-<tei:lb/>ages are as described by Sars (1916) for A. dubius. The arostrate males (A. dubius Sars, 1916)<tei:lb/>have been correctly regarded as the males of A. mucronatus by most authors since Lang (1948).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aegisthus aculeatus Giesbrecht, 1891</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Female. Cephalothorax and free thoracic somites with conspicuous reticulate markings<tei:lb/>(Fig. 1H); maximum width of body near mid-point of cephalothorax. Genital complex subdivided</tei:p>

         <tei:p>dorsally and laterally by suture line. First antenna 7-segmented with small prominence medially<tei:lb/>on proximal segment. Second antenna (Fig. II) with 2 distal setae on exopod.          <tei:p>Male. As for $ except: prosome more squat in appearance (Fig. IN); second free thoracic<tei:lb/>somite as wide as cephalothorax. First antenna 7-segmented. First maxilla bilobed, rudimentary.<tei:lb/>Second maxilla with well-developed basipod, claw-like process on basipod less curved than in $<tei:lb/>A. mucronatus, rami rudimentary bearing 1 small and 5 long setae.          <tei:p>Body length of male from 1-28 to 1-35 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 154 ?$, 7 &lt;?&lt;: N.E. Atlantic Ocean, 18 N 25 W, 'Discovery' Stn 7089.<tei:lb/>BM(NH) registration numbers 1977.175-184 (?) and 1977.185-191 ().</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The male of A. aculeatus has only recently been discovered and partially described<tei:lb/>(Owre and Foyo, 1967). The mouthparts in male Aegisthus are reduced and are often difficult to<tei:lb/>observe. No structure was found in either A. aculeatus or A. mucronatus which could be positively<tei:lb/>identified as representing the mandible. The first maxilla was represented by a bilobed structure<tei:lb/>in males of both species ; the larger lobe bearing 5 or 6 setae and the smaller 1 or 2. The second<tei:lb/>maxilla has a well-developed basipod and distal claw but the rami are reduced. The maxilliped<tei:lb/>is 3-segmented in both species. In A. aculeatus males the middle segment bears 2 setules and the<tei:lb/>distal segment 2 naked medial setae and a plumose apical seta. Reduction of this appendage<tei:lb/>has proceeded further in male A. mucronatus with the armature comprising only 2 small setae on<tei:lb/>the distal segment. The second maxillae and maxillipeds are better developed and closer to the<tei:lb/>female condition in A. aculeatus males than in A. mucronatus males.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aegisthus spinulosus Farran, 1905</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Female. Cephalothorax and free thoracic somites without chitinous reticulations<tei:lb/>(Fig. IP); maximum width of body anterior to mid-point of cephalothorax. Rostrum short.<tei:lb/>Genital complex completely subdivided by suture line. First antenna 7-segmented. Second antenna<tei:lb/>and both maxillae as in A. aculeatus. Maxilliped (Fig. 1Q) 3-segmented, armed with 3 enlarged<tei:lb/>spines and 4 setae on middle segment and 4 setae on distal segment. Leg 1 with 3-segmented rami;<tei:lb/>exopod segments 2 and 3 with long spines on outer margins. Leg 5 (Fig. 1R) as in A. aculeatus<tei:lb/>except distal serrate seta on lateral margin only 57% as long as middle serrate seta on lateral<tei:lb/>margin. Leg 6 with 2 equal terminal setae.<tei:lb/>Body length of holotype $ 1-74 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. In the original description of A. spinulosus Farran (1905) commented on its close<tei:lb/>affinity to A. aculeatus, but listed certain important characters which serve to distinguish between<tei:lb/>them. The significant differences are the absence of chitinous reticulations from the cephalothorax,<tei:lb/>the complete subdivision of the genital complex, the armature of the maxilliped (called the first<tei:lb/>maxillipede by Farran) and the sixth leg. If Farran's (1905) description is accurate A. spinulosus<tei:lb/>should be regarded as a valid species and not, as suggested by Lang (1948), as a possible last<tei:lb/>copepodid stage of A. aculeatus.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PLANKTONIC COPEPODS OF THE N.E. ATLANTIC 207</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family ECTINOSOMATIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus MICROSETELLA Brady and Robertson, 1873</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Body fusiform, without marked boundary between prosome and urosome; prosome<tei:lb/>4-segmented with first thoracic somite fused to head, urosome 5-segmented. Rostrum very short,<tei:lb/>ventrally directed. Caudal rami short, each with a long apical seta. First antenna 6-segmented<tei:lb/>(Fig. 2C), with an aesthete on segment 3 or 4 and one on segment 6. Second antenna (Fig. 2D)<tei:lb/>with unarmed basis; exopod 3-segmented with single short seta on segment 1 and 2 long terminal<tei:lb/>setae. Mandible (Fig. 2E) blade with few weak teeth; palp well developed, exopod small with few<tei:lb/>setae, endopod large bearing several setae and a large unilaterally pinnate process (seta ?) with<tei:lb/>an apical seta. First and second maxillae (Figs 2F, G) small. Maxilliped (Fig. 2H) 3-segmented,<tei:lb/>robust. Legs 1-4 with 3-segmented rami, armature formula:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coxa Basis Endopod Exopod</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 1 0-0 1-0 0-1; 0-1; I, 2, 2 1-0; 1-1; II, 2, 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 20-01-0 0-1 ; 0-1 ; I, 2, 2 1-1 ; 1-1 ; II, 2, 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 3 0-0 1-0 0-1; 0-1; I, 2, 2 1-1 ; 1-1 ; II, 2, 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 4 0-0 1-0 0-1; 0-1; I, 2,2 1-1 ; 1-1 ; II, 2, 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 5 with baseoendopod and 1 -segmented exopod; exopod bearing 1 ventral surface seta and<tei:lb/>either 3 ($) or 2 (&lt;$) marginal setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE SPECIES. Microsetella norvegica (Boeck, 1864) (as M. atlantica Brady and Robertson, 1873).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microsetella norvegica (Boeck, 1864)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Setella norvegica Boeck, 1864 : 281.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Ectinosoma atlanticum Brady, 1880: 13, pi. 38, figs 11-19.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Longest seta (inner seta on distal margin) of caudal ramus usually about as long as<tei:lb/>body, sometimes up to 1-5 times longer than body (Figs 2A, B); the second longest seta (outer<tei:lb/>seta on distal margin) about 33 % as long as the longest caudal seta and between 0-3 and 0-5 times<tei:lb/>as long as body. Inner seta on baseoendopod of leg 5 (?) less than half as long as outer seta<tei:lb/>(Fig. 21). Lateral seta on distal margin of leg 5 exopod (&lt;) apparently naked (Fig. 2J).<tei:lb/>Body length of female 0-35-0-57 mm; body length of male 0-33-0-42 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 2 $?: N.E. Atlantic Ocean, 18 N 25 W, 'Discovery' Stn 7089. BM(NH)<tei:lb/>registration numbers 1977.192-193. 1 $: as Ectinosoma atlanticum, Faroe Channel. BM(NH) registration<tei:lb/>numbers 1956.9.25.45. 12 $$: North Sea off Whitby. BM(NH) registration numbers 1976.653-662.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This small species is usually distinguished from the only other species of the genus,<tei:lb/>M. rosea (Dana, 1848), by the relative length of the body and the longest seta on the caudal ramus.<tei:lb/>This seta is often shorter than or about as long as the whole body (Lang, 1948; Owre &amp; Foyo,<tei:lb/>1967; Wells, 1970). However, in the material examined during the present study the length of the<tei:lb/>longest caudal seta was found to vary from 20 % less than body length to 44 % more than body<tei:lb/>length (Table 1). More reliable characters which could be used to separate the species are body<tei:lb/>size, the armature of the baseoendopod in the female leg 5 and the relative length of the second<tei:lb/>longest (outer seta on distal margin) caudal seta. This outer caudal seta is about one third (33 %)<tei:lb/>as long as the inner caudal seta in M. norvegica.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Bathyidia remota Farran, 1926.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The genus Bathyidia was established by Farran (1926) to include a new bathypelagic<tei:lb/>species from the Bay of Biscay, B. remota. Farran's (1926) description of B. remota was incom-<tei:lb/>plete. The generic diagnosis given here is based on re-examination of the holotype of B. remota<tei:lb/>and on the examination of two male specimens. Bathyidia is related to both Tisbe Lilljeborg, 1853<tei:lb/>and Paraidya Sewell, 1940, as well as to the two new genera described below Neotisbella gen. nov.<tei:lb/>and Volkmannia gen. nov. The principal distinguishing characters of these five genera and the<tei:lb/>genera Tisbella Gurney 1927 and Tisbintra Sewell, 1940 are presented in Table 2. Bathyidia can<tei:lb/>readily be distinguished from Paraidya by the segmentation of the first antenna, and from Neotis-<tei:lb/>bella and Tisbella by the segmentation of the endopod of leg 1 . The differences between Bathyidia,<tei:lb/>Tisbe and Volkmannia are the armature of the mandibular palp, the relative size of the endopod<tei:lb/>segments of leg 1, the armature elements of both rami of leg 1, plus the structure and armature<tei:lb/>of the caudal rami.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bathyidia remota Farran, 1926</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bathyidia remota Farran, 1926: 299-300, pi. 10, figs 13-17.<tei:lb/>Tisbe remota Lang, 1948 : 383, pi. 168, fig. 6.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Prosome of? incompletely known, $ cephalothorax slightly indented laterally (Fig. 4A).<tei:lb/>Genital complex (?) and urosome somites 3, 4, 5 and 6 (in 3) provided with ventral and ventro-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PLANKTONIC COPEPODS OF THE N.E. ATLANTIC 213</tei:p>
         <tei:p>lateral rows of spinules along posterior borders (Figs 3C and 5G). Genital area (?) (Fig. 3C) with<tei:lb/>2 short naked setae either side of oviduct openings, a third seta was probably present but is missing<tei:lb/>from the holotype ?. Caudal ramus (Figs 3C and 5G) 2-2-2-6 times longer than greatest width;<tei:lb/>armed with 2 lateral setae in proximal half of ramus (the lateral being 6-6-6-9 times long er than<tei:lb/>the ventro-lateral one), an oblique spinule row on the ventral surface extending distally from<tei:lb/>bases of the lateral setae, another spinule row proximal to the outer distal angle, a naked seta on<tei:lb/>the dorsal surface, a seta at the outer distal angle and one at the inner distal angle, 2 long setae<tei:lb/>on the inner portion of the distal margin and 2 elements towards the outer end of the distal margin.<tei:lb/>The latter 2 elements are flaccid and subdivided giving a forked appearance.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Relative lengths of $ first antenna (Fig. 3A) segments 15 : 19 : 15 : 14 : 7 : 9 : 5 : 16. Armature<tei:lb/>elements incomplete, first segment with 2 spinule rows. First antenna of $ (Fig. 4B) with seg-<tei:lb/>mental armature elements as follows: 1-1, 11-14, III-7, IV-2, V-6+1 aesthete, VI-3, VII-2,<tei:lb/>VIII-2, IX-9. First segment also bearing spinule row. Other cephalic appendages as in generic<tei:lb/>diagnosis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Inner spine on basis of leg 1 (Figs 3H, 5A) with small distal pinnules and a few larger ones<tei:lb/>proximally; exopod segment 3 bearing 6 setiform elements, those on outer margin armed with<tei:lb/>shorter pinnules than those on distal margin ; relative lengths of endopod segments about 46 : 40 :<tei:lb/>14; outer element on endopod segment 3 setiform but armed with short pinnules, middle element<tei:lb/>a simple long plumose seta (holotype $ exhibits aberrant bifurcated condition on only one member<tei:lb/>of leg 1 pair (Figs 3H, I)), inner element a plumose seta similar in length to middle element.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legs 2-4 (Figs 5B-F) ; exopod segment 3 with central patch of larger denticles on posterior<tei:lb/>surface (Fig. 5E); endopod segments 2 and 3 with some denticles and about 5 and 16 spinules<tei:lb/>respectively on their posterior surfaces (Fig. 5F). Leg 2 displaying sexual dimorphism with inner<tei:lb/>seta on endopod segment 1 armed with distal row of spinules (Fig. 5B).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 5 of $ (Fig. 3C) with incomplete armature in holotype but traces of absent setae indicate<tei:lb/>armature similar to &lt;. Leg 5 of ^ (Fig. 4H) with single inner seta on baseoendopod about as long<tei:lb/>as free segment: free segment about 2-9 times longer than wide, its ventral surface covered with<tei:lb/>minute denticles and lateral surface with long spinules; bearing a plumose seta at distal end of<tei:lb/>expanded lateral margin ; projecting distal margin with a tiny setule laterally and 2 long sparsely<tei:lb/>plumose setae apically; inner margin with single pinnate seta distally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 6 of $ (Fig. 5G) comprising 3 long naked setae situated laterally on genital lobes of urosome<tei:lb/>somite 2.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. Holotype $: Bay of Biscay (Farran, 1926). BM(NH) registration number<tei:lb/>1926.12.6.41. 1 (J: Sargasso Sea, Stn S (Deevey and Brooks, 1977). Florida State Museum<tei:lb/>collections. 1 &lt;$: N.E. Atlantic Ocean 18 N 25 W 'Discovery' Stn 7089. BM(NH) registration<tei:lb/>number 1977.225.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The males here assigned to B. remota agree closely with the holotype $ in the charac-<tei:lb/>teristic structure and armature of the leg 1 . The bifurcate nature of the middle seta on endopod<tei:lb/>segment 3 in the holotype is regarded as aberrant because the middle seta on the other member of<tei:lb/>the leg 1 pair, although broken, displays no trace of a bifurcation at the same position on the seta<tei:lb/>(see Fig. 31). The mouthparts are generally very similar in the males and the female. The male<tei:lb/>maxilliped differs from the female in the structure of the third segment, but the male maxillipeds<tei:lb/>of Neotisbella gigas gen. et sp. nov. and Volkmannia forficula gen. et sp. nov. also exhibit this<tei:lb/>character whereas their respective females do not.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The 2 male specimens are almost identical to the female in the detailed armature of their<tei:lb/>caudal rami ; in the position of the spinule rows and especially in the relative lengths of the two<tei:lb/>lateral setae. These and other similarities strongly suggest that the two males are conspecific with<tei:lb/>the holotype $ of B. remota.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus VOLKMANNIA gen. nov.<tei:lb/>DIAGNOSIS. Prosome 4-segmented, urosome 5-segmented in $ and 6-segmented in &lt;$. Dorsal</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Leg 1 endopod about 25-30% longer than exopod; inner spine on basis stout and spinulate;<tei:lb/>spine on outer margin of exopod segment 1 strongly developed, that on segment 2 setiform;<tei:lb/>endopod segment 3 very small bearing an outer spine, a distal seta and a small inner seta. Leg 2<tei:lb/>displaying sexual dimorphism in armature of inner seta of endopod segment 1 . Legs 1-4 with<tei:lb/>very minute denticles on surfaces of coxa, basis and rami; also spinule rows present on posterior<tei:lb/>surfaces of endopod segments 2 and 3 of legs 2-4.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 5 with small baseoendopod and elongate free segment, ventral surface of latter covered<tei:lb/>with minute denticles; baseoendopod with outer plumose seta and 3 inner setae in $ or 1 in &lt;$;<tei:lb/>free segment expanded laterally with short spinules along outer margin; armature comprising 1<tei:lb/>lateral seta positioned at apex of lateral expansion, 1 distal seta on inner margin and 2 plumose<tei:lb/>setae and a small naked seta around apex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 6 represented by 3 long plumose setae in $.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Volkmannia forficula sp. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ETYMOLOGY. This genus is named after Dr Brigitte Volkmann in recognition of her work on the<tei:lb/>genus Tisbe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The new genus can be distinguished from Paraidya, Bathyidia, Tisbella, Neotisbella<tei:lb/>gen. nov. and Tisbintra by the segmentation of the leg 1 and the armature of the mandibular<tei:lb/>palp. Although there is a close superficial resemblance between Volkmannia and Tisbe there are<tei:lb/>significant differences in the mandible, leg 1 and caudal rami. The mandible of Tisbe possesses at<tei:lb/>least one seta on the basis whereas the mandible of Volkmannia has an unarmed basis. The distal<tei:lb/>segment of the leg 1 endopod in Tisbe usually possesses only 2 (occasionally 3) armature elements<tei:lb/>at least one of which is armed with a distal comb of long setules ; similar combs are also found on<tei:lb/>the outer margin elements of exopod segments 2 and 3 in Tisbe species. The distal segment of leg 1<tei:lb/>endopod possesses 3 armed elements in Volkmannia species, and none of the elements on either<tei:lb/>ramus is armed with a distal comb of setules. The caudal ramus of Volkmannia closely resembles<tei:lb/>that found in Bathyidia and Neotisbella, but differs greatly in both structure and armature from<tei:lb/>that found in Tisbe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volkmannia forficula sp. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Prosome rounded, maximum body width about mid-point of prosome (Figs 6A, 8D).<tei:lb/>Genital complex ($) and urosome somites 3, 4, 5 and 6 (in &lt;$) provided with ventral and lateral<tei:lb/>rows of spinules along posterior borders. Genital area (?) (Fig. 6F) with a short outer plumose<tei:lb/>seta and 2 subequal long inner naked setae. Caudal ramus (Fig. 6D) about 2-6 times longer than<tei:lb/>greatest width; armed with 2 lateral setae in proximal half of ramus (the lateral being about 1-9<tei:lb/>times longer than the ventro-lateral one), an oblique spinule row extending from near base of<tei:lb/>lateral seta, another spinule row around outer distal angle, a naked seta on dorsal surface, a<tei:lb/>seta at the outer distal angle and 1 at the inner distal angle, 2 long plumose setae on the inner<tei:lb/>portion of the distal margin and 2 elements in the middle of the distal margin. The latter 2 ele-<tei:lb/>ments are thin walled and flaccid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Relative lengths of $ first antenna segments 14:18:20:16:5:8:3:16 (Fig. 7 A); armature<tei:lb/>elements as follows; segment 1-1, 11-14, III-7, IV-4+1 aesthete, V-0, VI-4, VII-1, VIII-5;<tei:lb/>segment I also bearing 2 rows of spinules. First antenna ($) armature as follows; segment 1-1,<tei:lb/>11-11, III-4, IV-2, V-6 + 1, aesthete VI-2, VII-2, VIII-2, IX-11 (Fig. 8E); segment I also bearing<tei:lb/>2 spinule rows.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Other cephalic appendages as in generic diagnosis (p. 213).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Maxilliped terminal claw with single spinule on concave margin in both sexes (Figs 6E, 8F).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 1 provided with extremely minute denticles on its surface (as in Bathyidia and Neotisbella<tei:lb/>but too small to be accurately figured); inner spine on basis strongly developed, much shorter<tei:lb/>than endopod segment 1 and armed with long pinnules proximally and short pinnules distally<tei:lb/>(Fig. 7D). Outer margin of exopod segment 1 with well-developed spine, slightly swollen proxi-<tei:lb/>mally; outer margins of exopod segments 2 and 3 bearing setiform elements armed with short</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Fig. 8 Volkmannia forficula n. sp.: A, female second leg, posterior; B, third leg; C, endopod of<tei:lb/>fourth leg, anterior; D, male; E, first antenna; F, maxilliped; G, endopod of second leg, anterior;<tei:lb/>H, fifth leg; I, sixth leg.          <tei:p>REMARKS. The general similarity between the males and females described above and the presence<tei:lb/>of very distinctive characters in both sexes, such as the forked middle seta on the apex of leg 1<tei:lb/>endopod, indicate that they are conspecific. Sexual dimorphism was noted in the third maxilliped<tei:lb/>segment, as in Bathyidia and Neotisbella, and in the setation of the baseoendopod of leg 5, as in<tei:lb/>Neotisbella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volkmannia attenuata sp. nov.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Legs 2-4 damaged and incomplete but the armature elements appear to be similar to those of<tei:lb/>Volkmannia forficula.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Body length of holotype $ 1-18 mm. Male unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. Holotype ?: N.E. Atlantic Ocean 20 N 21 W, 'Discovery' Stn 9131 18.<tei:lb/>BM(NH) registration number 1977.324.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species can be distinguished from V. forficula by the elongate endopod of leg 1<tei:lb/>(from which the specific name is derived) and by the proportions of the leg 5 and caudal rami.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus NEOTISBELLA gen. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Prosome 4-segmented, large and vaulted; urosome 5-segmented in $ and 6-segmented<tei:lb/>in c. Dorsal surface of prosome and whole surface of urosome more or less covered with minute<tei:lb/>denticles. Rostrum small. Genital complex ($) subdivided by dorsal and dorso-lateral suture<tei:lb/>line; genital area with 1 long plumose outer seta and 2 short naked inner setae either side of ovi-<tei:lb/>duct openings. Caudal rami more than twice as long as wide, with 2 lateral, 1 dorsal and 4 distal<tei:lb/>setae, plus 2 additional elements on the distal margin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First antenna 8-segmented (?) with aesthete on segment 4; 9-segmented (&lt;$) with aesthete on<tei:lb/>segment 5, geniculate between segments 7 and 8. Second antenna with unarmed basis; 2-seg-<tei:lb/>mented endopod, distal segment with 3 lateral and 7 terminal elements; 4-segmented exopod,<tei:lb/>segments 1 and 3 bearing 1 seta each, segment 2 unarmed and distal segment with 3 seta. Mandible<tei:lb/>with unarmed basis and 1 -segmented rami; endopod with 1 proximal seta on medial margin and<tei:lb/>4 apical setae; exopod with 1 medial and 2 apical setae. First maxilla inner lobe armed with 10<tei:lb/>elements, outer lobe bearing 11 elements. Second maxilla with 1 seta on basal segment, claw<tei:lb/>elongate bearing 1 short plumose seta and a distal row of pinnules. Maxilliped comprising 3<tei:lb/>segments and a terminal claw; middle segment with 3 rows of setules, distal segment bearing 2<tei:lb/>setae; displaying sexual dimorphism with the distal segment bearing a strong chitinous process</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PLANKTONIC COPEPODS OF THE N.E. ATLANTIC 223</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 1 with 3-segmented exopod and 2-segmented endopod, legs 2-4 with both rami 3-segmented;<tei:lb/>armature formula as follows :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coxa Basis Endopod Exopod</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 1 0-0 1-1 0-1; 1, 2,1 I-0;I-1;6</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 2 0-0 1-0 0-1; 0-2; I, 2, 2 1-1 ; 1-1 ; III, I, 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 3 1-0 1-0 0-1; 0-2; I, 2, 3 1-1 ; 1-1 ; III, I, 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 4 0-0 1-0 0-1; 0-2; I, 2, 2 1-1 ; 1-1 ; III, I, 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 1 endopod about 10% longer than exopod; inner spine on basis long and pinnate; spines<tei:lb/>on outer margins exopod segments 1 and 2 setiform; endopod segment 2 with many slender<tei:lb/>spinules laterally and distally. Leg 2 displaying sexual dimorphism in structure of inner seta of<tei:lb/>endopod segment 1. Legs 1-4 with minute denticles on surfaces of coxa, basis and rami; also<tei:lb/>spinule rows present on posterior surfaces of endopod segments 2 and 3.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 5 comprising small baseoendopod and elongate free segment, ventral surfaces of both<tei:lb/>covered irregularly with minute denticles; baseoendopod with outer plumose seta and inner<tei:lb/>plumose seta; free segment with slender spinules all along lateral and ventro-lateral surfaces, and<tei:lb/>on middle portion of medial surface ; armature comprising 1 distal seta on both inner and outer<tei:lb/>margins and 2 plumose setae and a small naked seta around the apex. Leg 6 represented by 1<tei:lb/>short and 2 long plumose setae in &lt;$.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Neotisbella gigas sp. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ETYMOLOGY. The generic name alludes to the superficial similarity between the new genus and<tei:lb/>Tisbella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The only other genera in the subfamily Tisbinae which possess a 2-segmented endopod<tei:lb/>on the leg 1 are Tisbella and Tisbintra.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The reduction in the number of armature elements on leg 1 endopod serves to separate Tisbintra<tei:lb/>from both Tisbella and the new genus. Some of the significant differences between Tisbella and<tei:lb/>Neotisbella are tabulated in Table 2. Other differences are the relative size of the endopod segments<tei:lb/>of legs 2-4, and the presence of an outer spine on exopod segment 2 of the leg 1 in Tisbella<tei:lb/>compared with the setiform element present in Neotisbella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neotisbella gigas sp. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Prosome angular and vaulted in appearance (Fig. 10 A); maximum width in anterior<tei:lb/>third of cephalosome (Fig. 12A). Genital complex ($) and urosome somites 3, 4, 5 and 6 (in c)<tei:lb/>provided with ventral and lateral rows of spinules along posterior borders. Genital area ($)<tei:lb/>(Fig. 1 1G) with a short inner naked seta, a slightly longer naked middle seta and a long plumose<tei:lb/>lateral seta. Caudal ramus (Fig. 10F) about 1-9 times longer than greatest width; armed with<tei:lb/>2 lateral setae in proximal half of ramus (the lateral being about 1-7 times longer than the ventro-<tei:lb/>lateral one), an oblique spinule row on ventral surface extending from near base of lateral seta, a<tei:lb/>spinule row just proximal to the distal margin, a naked seta on the dorsal surface, a seta at the<tei:lb/>outer distal angle and one at the inner distal angle, 2 medium length plumose setae on the inner<tei:lb/>portion of the distal margin and 2 elements in the middle of the distal margin. The latter 2 ele-<tei:lb/>ments are thin-walled and bifurcated at different levels.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Relative lengths of $ first antenna segments 9 : 19 : 19 : 17 : 9 : 10 : 4 : 13 (Fig. 10B); armature<tei:lb/>elements as follows; segment 1-1, 11-13, III-9, IV-3 + 1 aesthete, V-2, VI-5, VII-1, VIII-5; all<tei:lb/>segments provided with minute denticles on surfaces and segment I bearing large area of spinules ,<tei:lb/>segment III about 6 spinules and segment IV 3 irregular rows of spinules.          <tei:p>Other cephalic appendages as in generic diagnosis (p. 222).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Leg 5 $ (Fig. 11F) with single inner seta on baseoendopod about twice as long as free segment:<tei:lb/>free segment about 5-3 times longer than wide; its ventral surface covered with minute denticles;<tei:lb/>its lateral surface and the middle third of the medial surface bearing many spinules; armature<tei:lb/>elements comprising 1 long plumose seta each at the distal ends of the lateral and medial margins,<tei:lb/>2 long plumose setae on the projecting distal margin and a short naked seta positioned between<tei:lb/>them and the lateral seta.          <tei:p>Leg 6 of &lt;$ (Fig. 12G) comprising 1 short sparsely pinnate inner seta and 2 long sparsely pinnate<tei:lb/>outer setae situated laterally on genital lobes of urosome somite 2.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body length of $$ from 1-85 to 2-00 and $ 1-26 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. Holotype $, 1 $ and 5 $$ paratypes: N.E. Atlantic Ocean, 18 N 25 W<tei:lb/>'Discovery' Stn 7089. BM(NH) registration numbers 1977.226 (holotype), 1977.227 () and<tei:lb/>1977.228-232 ($$).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The similarities between the male and females described above strongly suggest that<tei:lb/>they are conspecific. Apart from the obvious characters of urosome segmentation, structure of<tei:lb/>the first antenna and the leg 6, differences between the sexes were noted in the maxilliped, leg 1<tei:lb/>and leg 5. The presence of a spinous process on the third maxilliped segment has been recorded<tei:lb/>in males of Bathyidia remota and Volkmannia forficula. The minor differences between the sexes<tei:lb/>in the inner spine on the basis of the leg 1 and the inner seta on the baseoendopod of leg 5 can<tei:lb/>readily be attributed to sexual dimorphism.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phylogenetic relationships of the new genera</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is interesting to examine the possible phylogenetic relationships of the two new genera, Volk-<tei:lb/>mannia and Neotisbella, to other genera in the family Tisbidae. The new genera belong to the<tei:lb/>subfamily Tisbinae which contains the following genera: Tisbe, Tisbella, Tisbintra, Bathyidia,<tei:lb/>Paraidya, Scutellidium Claus, 1866 and Sacodiscus Wilson, 1924. The aberrant genus Cholidya<tei:lb/>Farran, 1914 is profoundly modified for its parasitic mode of life and is here regarded as repre-<tei:lb/>senting a separate subfamily, the Cholidyinae subfam. nov. Scutellidium and Sacodiscus are closely<tei:lb/>related and will be called the Scutellidium group of genera, all other genera will be referred to as<tei:lb/>the Tisbe group. These two groups of genera are distinguished primarily by the structure of the<tei:lb/>mouthparts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within the Tisbe group the main characters used for separating the genera are the structure and<tei:lb/>armature of the second antenna, mandible, leg 1 and caudal ramus. Consideration of these<tei:lb/>characters within a phylogenetic framework suggested the following scheme of affinities (Fig. 13).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The main events occurring during the evolutionary radiation of this group of genera are desig-<tei:lb/>nated, A, B and C (in Fig. 13). Event A resulted in the divergence of the ancestral stock into two<tei:lb/>lines, the VB lineage (Volkmannia-Bathyidid) and the TP lineage (Tisbe-Paraidyd). Event A was<tei:lb/>the adoption of a planktonic habit by the VB lineage and the retention of the ancestral benthic<tei:lb/>habit by the TP lineage. The change to a planktonic existence appears to be associated with the<tei:lb/>acquisition of an elongate caudal ramus armed with 9 armature elements, as possessed by all 3<tei:lb/>genera in the VB lineage. The benthic TP lineage typically possess a short caudal ramus bearing<tei:lb/>only 6 or 7 armature elements. The second major event (B) seems to have occurred twice, once in<tei:lb/>each main lineage. This was the divergence from an ancestral stock with a leg 1 endopod comprising<tei:lb/>three large segments of a stock with a reduced third endopod segment. The genera Bathyidia and<tei:lb/>Paraidya both retained large third segments on their leg 1 endopods. The third major event (C)<tei:lb/>was the splitting off from an ancestral stock possessing a reduced third segment on the leg 1<tei:lb/>endopod of a stock in which the separate third segment is lost altogether. This appears to have<tei:lb/>taken place at least twice, probably three times; once in the derivation of the Neotisbella line from<tei:lb/>the ancestral Volkmannia stock and probably twice in the independent separation of the Tisbella<tei:lb/>and Tisbintra lines from the ancestral Tisbe stock.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This scheme of phylogenetic relationships allows for the obvious close relationship of Volk-<tei:lb/>mannia, Neotisbella and Bathyidia (as indicated by their shared derived characters) despite their</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>228</tei:p>
         <tei:p>G. A. BOXSHALL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tisbe Volkmannia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paraidya</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bathyidia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ancestral stock</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 13 The affinities of the seven genera of the Tisbe group within the subfamily Tisbinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>close phenetic similarities to Tisbe, Tisbella and Paraidya respectively. The progressive reduction<tei:lb/>of the third segment of the leg 1 endopod has resulted in the formation of a 2-segmented endopod<tei:lb/>independently in Neotisbella, in Tisbella and in Tisbintra. In the first two genera the endopod is<tei:lb/>relatively short and the distal endopod segment retains the combined armature elements of both<tei:lb/>second (the single inner seta) and third segments (the 3 distal elements). This condition could<tei:lb/>have been derived from an endopod similar to that found in Bathyidia and Paraidya. In Tisbintra<tei:lb/>the endopod is much longer than the exopod and the distal endopod segment possesses 1 inner<tei:lb/>seta and only 1 or 2 distal elements. This condition was probably derived from a more Tisbe-like<tei:lb/>stock.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>REMARKS. Both sexes of this species are easily recognizable and are rarely confused with other<tei:lb/>species. The fine lateral setule present in the axil of the outer margin spine on leg 5 has been<tei:lb/>reported previously in both the male (e.g. Klie, 1913; Haq, 1965) and the female (e.g. Giesbrecht,<tei:lb/>1892; Mori, 1964; Haq, 1965). This setule is not illustrated in either sex by Sars (1921) or in the<tei:lb/>male by Chappuis (1936) and Giesbrecht (1892). It is probable that the setule has been overlooked<tei:lb/>by the latter group of authors. It was even found to be present in both morphs of male E. acuti-<tei:lb/>frons studied by Haq (1965).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>First antenna ($) 7- to 9-segmented, without plumose setae. Second antenna with allobasis and<tei:lb/>2-segmented exopod.          <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Parathalestris clausi (Norman, 1868).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Sars (1905) erected a new genus, Halithalestris, to include the species Harpacticus croni,<tei:lb/>first recorded by Kroyer (1842). One of the major characters used by Sars to establish the new<tei:lb/>genus was the pelagic habits of H. croni. Lang (1948) recognized that Halithalestris was not a<tei:lb/>distinct genus and subsequently referred H. croni to Parathalestris.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parathalestris croni (Kroyer, 1842)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Harpacticus croni Kroyer, 1842 : pi. XLIII, figs 3a-n.<tei:lb/>Thalestris serrulata Brady, 1880 : 133, pi. LIX, figs 2-11.<tei:lb/>Halithalestris croni Sars, 1905 : 118, pi. LXXII.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Cephalosome small, comprising about 50% of length of prosome (Fig. 14A); genital<tei:lb/>complex in $ only subdivided laterally by a suture line. Anal somite markedly notched in middle<tei:lb/>of posterior border (Fig. 14E). Caudal rami divergent, about 3-5-4 times longer than maximum<tei:lb/>width.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First antenna of $ 9-segmented, bearing a large aesthete on segment 4; $ indistinctly 7-seg-<tei:lb/>mented with aesthetes on segments 3 and 4. Second antenna (Fig. 14B) with 1 seta on allobasis;<tei:lb/>exopod segments 1 and 2 with 1 and 4 setae respectively. First segment of maxilliped with 3<tei:lb/>distal setae, terminal claw shorter than second segment.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Both rami of leg 1 (Fig. 14C) similar in length; inner claw on distal segment of endopod about<tei:lb/>2 times longer than outer claw; exopod segment 3 with 4 armature elements. Leg 5 ($) extending<tei:lb/>posteriorly as far as middle of genital complex ; baseoendopod armed with 5 setae and extending<tei:lb/>just beyond mid-point of exopod; exopod oval in outline, about twice as long as wide and armed<tei:lb/>with 6 setae (Fig. 14D). Leg 5 (&lt;$) smaller than in $, baseoendopod with 3 setae and exopod with<tei:lb/>6 setae (Fig. 14F). Leg 6 in ^ represented by 3 setae on lateral lobe of urosome 2 (Fig. 14E).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body length of $ from 2-1 to 2-3 mm and $ about 1*7 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ?, 1 &lt;J; Firth of Forth. BM(NH) registration numbers 1911.11.8.46207-10.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This is one of the largest species of harpacticoid and is easily distinguished by its size,<tei:lb/>small cephalosome and long divergent caudal rami. Brady (1880) first described the male, as<tei:lb/>Thalestris serrulata, and figured the male leg 5. Wells (1970) misinterpreted Brady's figure when he<tei:lb/>redrew the leg 5, as he illustrated only 5 setae on the exopod (Wells, 1970 : fig. 7e $) instead of<tei:lb/>the 6 in Brady's figure.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family CLYTEMNESTRIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus CLYTEMNESTRA Dana, 1848</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Prosome 4-segmented, first thoracic somite fused to head, urosome 5-segmented in<tei:lb/>?, 6-segmented in $\ body rather dorso-ventrally flattened, cephalosome and free thoracic somites</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>232 G. A. BOXSHALL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>with large, conspicuous epimeral plates. Urosome slender; genital complex without subdividing<tei:lb/>suture line. Rostrum large, anteriorly directed. Caudal ramus at least as long as wide, with 6<tei:lb/>armature elements, 2 of which are long in &lt;$.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First antenna 7- or 8-segmented, with several aesthetes. Second antenna comprising a basis, a<tei:lb/>2-segmented endopod and either 1 or 2 plumose setae representing the exopod (Fig. 15F). Man-<tei:lb/>dible reduced to slender blade and palp represented by single minute setule. First maxilla 2-<tei:lb/>segmented, proximal segment with 1 lateral seta, distal segment with 2 apical elements. Second<tei:lb/>maxilla reduced, 2-segmented, bearing 1 proximal seta and a distal endite armed with 2 setae on<tei:lb/>first segment and 3 setae on second segment. Maxilliped long, consisting of 2 segments and a<tei:lb/>terminal claw; showing weak sexual dimorphism with longer terminal claw in &lt;$ (Fig. 15G) than<tei:lb/>in? (Fig. 15D).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 1 with 3-segmented endopod and 1 -segmented exopod. Legs 2-4 each with transversely<tei:lb/>elongate basis and 3-segmented rami : armature formula variable on legs 1 and 2 between species<tei:lb/>but within following limits :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coxa Basis Endopod Exopod</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legl 0-0 0/1-0 0-1; 0-1; 0,2,2 3/4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 20-01-0 0-1 ; 0-2; I, 2, 2 0/1-1 ; 1-1 ; II, 2, 2/3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 3 0-0 1-0 0-1 ; 0-2; I, 2, 3 1-1 ; 1-1 ; III, 2, 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 4 0-0 1-0 0-1; 0-2; I, 2, 2 1-1; 1-1; HI, 2, 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 5 without inner setae on baseoendopod ; free segment elongate with 5 or 6 slender setae.<tei:lb/>Leg 6 in $ represented by an elongate lobe bearing 1 lateral and 2 apical setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Clytemnestra scutellata Dana, 1848.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Lang (1948) in his monograph on the Harpacticoida retained Poppe's (1891) family-<tei:lb/>group name, Pseudopeltiidae, for the genus Clytemnestra which was its type and only genus. This<tei:lb/>action has been followed by several subsequent authors (e.g. Wells, 1970) but it contravenes the<tei:lb/>ICZN Article 1 le as a family-group name must, when first published, be based on the name then<tei:lb/>valid for a contained genus. Thus the family-group name Clytemnestridae, first proposed by Scott<tei:lb/>(1909), is adopted here.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clytemnestra scutellata Dana, 1848</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Goniopelte gracilis Claus, 1891 : 151, pi. I-II.<tei:lb/>Clytemnestra hendorffi Poppe, 1891 : 132, pi. I.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Caudal rami (Figs 15B, J) about 1-8 times longer than greatest width. First antenna<tei:lb/>8-segmented; $ with 1 aesthete on segment 4 and 2 each on segments 5 and 8; relative lengths of<tei:lb/>segments 3 : 10 : 10 : 10 : 12 : 10 : 15 : 30 (Fig. 15C); $ with 2 aesthetes each on segments 4, 5 and<tei:lb/>8; relative lengths of segments 3 : 7 : 14 : 3 : 28 : 5 : 16 : 24 (Fig. 15E). Exopod of second antenna<tei:lb/>(Fig. 15F) represented by 2 plumose setae. Basis of leg 1 (Fig. 15H) with outer margin seta;<tei:lb/>exopod with 4 distal setae. Leg 2 (Fig. 151) exopod segment 1 without outer margin spine;<tei:lb/>endopod segment 1 of legs 2-4 as long as exopod segments 1 and 2 combined. Free segment of<tei:lb/>leg 5 typically with 6 setae in both sexes (Fig. 15K), occasionally with 5 (var. quinquespinosd).<tei:lb/>Body length of? from 1 to 1-24 mm, and of &lt;$ from 1*07 to 1*3 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ?, 1 #: N.E. Atlantic Ocean, 18 N 25 W, 'Discovery' Stn 7089. BM(NH)<tei:lb/>registration numbers 1977.194 (?) and 1977.195 (&lt;J). 1 ?, \ &lt;$: Suez Canal Expedition (Gurney,<tei:lb/>1927). BM(NH) registration number 1928.4.2.136. 10 $$, 2 &amp;?: as C. rostrata, Gulf of Guinea<tei:lb/>(Scott, 1894). BM(NH) registration numbers 1893.4.22.268-275.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species can be distinguished from C. rostrata, the only other species in the genus,<tei:lb/>by the shape of the caudal rami and the segmentation of the first antenna when sorting un-<tei:lb/>dissected specimens. There are other significant differences between the two species, particularly<tei:lb/>in the armature of legs 1 and 2.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Clytemnestra rostrata (Brady, 1883)<tei:lb/>Goniopsyllus rostratus Brady, 1883 : 107, pi. XLII, figs 9-16.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Caudal rami (Fig. 15M) about 1-1-1 times longer than wide. First antenna 7-seg-<tei:lb/>mented ; $ with 1 aesthete on segment 4 and 2 each on segments 5 and 7, relative lengths of seg-<tei:lb/>ments about 3 : 12 : 6 : 10 : 12 : 11 : 46 (Fig. 15N): $ with 2 aesthetes on segments 4, 5 and 7,<tei:lb/>relative lengths of segments about 4 : 7 : 16 : 8 : 14 : 23 : 28 (Fig. 15Q). Exopod of second antenna<tei:lb/>represented by 1 plumose seta. Basis of leg 1 (Fig. ISO) without outer margin seta; exopod with<tei:lb/>3 distal setae. Leg 2 exopod segment 1 with an outer margin spine, exopod segment 3 with only 6<tei:lb/>armature elements compared with 7 in C. scutellata : endopod segment 1 of legs 2-4 almost as<tei:lb/>long as exopod segments 1 and 2 combined. Free segment of leg 5 typically carrying 5 setae in<tei:lb/>both sexes (Fig. 15P), occasionally reduced to 4 setae.<tei:lb/>Body length of $ from 0-60 to 1-00 mm, and &lt; from 0-80 to 0-90 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. Holotype? as Goniopsyllus rostratus: Challenger Expedition (Brady, 1883).<tei:lb/>BM(NH) registration number CC. 46. 1 $: Great Barrier Reef Expedition (Farran, 1936).<tei:lb/>BM(NH) registration number 1948.4.28.120. 7 $$: Gulf of Guinea (Scott, 1894). BM(NH)<tei:lb/>registration numbers 1893.4.22.268-275.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The holotype of C. rostrata was described by Brady (1883) as a male, but re-examination<tei:lb/>of this specimen has shown it to be a female. It possesses a 7-segmented first antenna, with 1<tei:lb/>aesthete on segment 4, and 2 aesthetes on segments 5 and 7. The relative lengths of segments 5, 6<tei:lb/>and 7 are 12 : 9 : 36 respectively (as percentages of the total appendage length). The armature and<tei:lb/>proportional lengths of the segments indicate that this appendage belongs to a female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family MIRACHDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Prosome 4-segmented with first thoracic somite fused to head, urosome 5-segmented in<tei:lb/>$ and 6-segmented in &lt;. Body slender, slightly laterally compressed. Rostrum variable. Caudal<tei:lb/>rami longer than wide. First antenna 7- to 8-segmented in $, 8- to 9-segmented and haplocerate in<tei:lb/>c. Exopod of second antenna 1 -segmented or absent. Mandible with small toothed blades and<tei:lb/>rudimentary palp. First maxilla with several cutting elements on arthrite, rest of appendage<tei:lb/>rudimentary. Second maxilla with small number of endites. Maxilliped well developed, 2-seg-<tei:lb/>mented with third segment apparently fused to short terminal claw. Leg 1 with 3-segmented exopod<tei:lb/>and 2-segmented endopod; legs 2-4 with 3-segmented rami except for leg 2 displaying sexual<tei:lb/>dimorphism with 2-segmented endopod in . Leg 5 ($) comprising a short baseoendopod bearing<tei:lb/>3-5 setae and elongate exopod armed with 6 setae. Leg 5 (&lt;$) with short baseoendopod bearing 2<tei:lb/>or 3 setae, exopod bearing 4 or 6 setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus MIRACIA Dana, 1846</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Cephalosome quite large, rounded anteriorly and provided with a pair of large cuti-<tei:lb/>cular lenses (Fig. 16A). Rostrum inconspicuous. Urosome somites 3-5 (6 in^) each provided with<tei:lb/>a row of spinules ventrally along posterior border. Caudal rami about 3 times longer than wide.<tei:lb/>Fitst antenna 8-segmented in $ carrying an aesthete on segment 4; in 9-segmented, with aesthete<tei:lb/>on segment 5 and geniculate between segments 6 and 7. Second antenna (Fig. 16B) with 1 -seg-<tei:lb/>mented exopod bearing 2 apical plumose setae. Armature formula of legs 1-4 variable.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 5 as in family diagnosis for both sexes. Leg 6 represented in by a small lateral lobe bearing<tei:lb/>3 setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Miracia efferata Dana, 1852.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The armature formula given by Lang (1948) for the genus Miracia applies only to M.<tei:lb/>minor, not M. efferata.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Miracia efferata Dana, 1852</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Cuticular lenses on cephalosome touching. Second antenna (Fig. 16B) with allobasis,<tei:lb/>as basis and first endopod segment completely fused. Armature formula of legs 1-4 as follows :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coxa Basis Endopod Exopod</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legl 0-0 1-1 0-1; 3 1-0; 1-1; 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 2 0-0 1-0 0-1; 0-2; I, 1,2 1-0; 1-1; II, 2, 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg3 0-0 1-0 0-1; 0-2; I, 2, 2 1-0; 1-1; III, 2, 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 4 0-0 1-0 0-1; 0-1; 1,2, 2 1-0; 1-1; III, 2, 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legs 5 (?) with 5 setae on baseoendopod and 6 setae on exopod (Fig. 16C). Leg 5 (&lt;) with 3<tei:lb/>setae on baseoendopod and 6 setae on exopod (Fig. 16D).<tei:lb/>Body length of $ from 1-45 to 2 mm and $ from 14 to 1*6 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 31 ??, 8 &amp;?: N.E. Atlantic Ocean, 18N 25 W, 'Discovery' Stn 7089.<tei:lb/>BM(NH) registration numbers 1977.196-205 (?$) and 1977.206-213 (&amp;?).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Both sexes of M. efferata were a bright bluish-purple colour even after a considerable<tei:lb/>time in preservative. The armature formula of legs 2-4 differs in several respects from that pre-<tei:lb/>sented by Lang (1948) for the genus Miracia. The most significant differences are the presence of<tei:lb/>inner margin setae on endopod segment 1 of legs 2-4 and the presence of 3 outer margin spines<tei:lb/>on exopod segment 3 of legs 3 and 4. Lang's formula was presumably based only on data from<tei:lb/>M. minor Scott, 1894.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Miracia minor Scott, 1894</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Body (Fig. 16E) more slender than in M. efferata (c.f. Fig. 16 A). Cuticular lenses on<tei:lb/>cephalosome not touching. Second antenna apparently with basis and 2-segmented endopod.<tei:lb/>Armature formula of legs 1-4 as follows :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coxa Basis Endopod Exopod</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legl 0-0 1-1 0-1; 3 1-0; 1-1; 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 20-01-0 0-0; 0-2; I, 1, 2 1-0; 1-1; II, 2, 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 3 0-0 1-0 0-0; 0-2; I, 2,2 1-0; 1-1; II, 2, 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 4 0-0 1-0 0-0; 0-1; 1,2,2 1-0; 1-1; II, 2, 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 5 (?) with 4 setae on baseoerdopod, 1 very long and plumose, and with 6 setae on exopod<tei:lb/>(Fig. 16G). Leg 5 ($) with 2 setae on baseoendopod and 4 setae on exopod, 2 distally and 2 on the<tei:lb/>lateral margin (Fig. 16F).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body length of? from 0-90 to 0-93 mm and ^ 0-82 to 0-93 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. Syntype series $$ and^: Gulf of Guinea (Scott, 1894). BM(NH) registra-<tei:lb/>tion numbers 1893.4.22.340 and 1894.1.20.76-87. 1 ?, 1 &lt;$: as Macrosetella oculata, John Murray<tei:lb/>Expedition (Sewell, 1947), BM(NH) registration numbers 1949.12.31.584-5. 1 ?: Gulf of Aden.<tei:lb/>BM(NH) registration number 1911.11.8.43199.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. There is some confusion in the literature over the armature of the leg 5 in both sexes of<tei:lb/>M. minor. This arose because Scott (1894) in his original description illustrated 7 setae on the ?<tei:lb/>leg 5 exopod, and no outer margin seta on the baseoendopod. Examination shows that the<tei:lb/>armature of the $ leg 5 comprises 1 outer margin seta on the baseoendopod and 6 setae on the<tei:lb/>exopod in agreement with Giesbrecht (1895). Scott (1894) also figured the exopod of the $ leg 5<tei:lb/>with 2 inner margin setae and 2 distal setae. The complete male specimen in the syntype series<tei:lb/>shows that in the slide (No. Z.D. 76) prepared by Scott the exopod had been accidentally rotated<tei:lb/>so the 2 outer margin setae (shown in Fig. 14F) appeared to be on the inner margin. Giesbrecht<tei:lb/>(1895) figured the $ leg 5 with 2 outer margin setae and 2 distal setae but most other authors<tei:lb/>(e.g. Owre and Foyo, 1967; Wells, 1970) redrew their illustrations from Scott (1894).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>238 G. A. BOXSHALL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This is the only member of the family Miraciidae without conspicuous cuticular lenses.<tei:lb/>It possesses only a simple eye spot.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SIPHONOSTOMATOIDA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This order as defined bj Kabata (1979) comprises both the Caligoida, containing primarily<tei:lb/>parasites of fishes, and the Cyclopoida Siphonostoma, which are predominantly associated with<tei:lb/>or parasitic upon invertebrate hosts. Although adult and, more commonly, juvenile fish parasitic<tei:lb/>siphonostomatoids are occasionally recorded free in the plankton they are not true holoplanktonic<tei:lb/>forms and are not considered further. Siphonostomatoid copepods belonging to three genera,<tei:lb/>Ratania Giesbrecht, Pontoeciella Giesbrecht and Hyalopontius Sars (= Megapontius Hulsemann),<tei:lb/>have been found in the plankton of the N.E. Atlantic Ocean and can be regarded as members of<tei:lb/>the planktonic community. Species of these three genera are probably associated with planktonic<tei:lb/>invertebrates but no 'hosts' are known at present.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family RATANIIDAE<tei:lb/>Genus RATANIA Giesbrecht, 1891</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Body unmodified; urosome 5-segmented in female, 6-segmented in male. Caudal<tei:lb/>ramus with 6-setae. Rostrum weakly developed. First antenna 5- to 7-segmented ($) and 7- to<tei:lb/>9-segmented (^), with an aesthete on the terminal segment. Second antenna non-prehensile,<tei:lb/>4-segmented and without trace of exopod. Oral cone short. Mandible an elongated blade, dentate<tei:lb/>apically and without palp. First maxilla bilobed; inner lobe with 3 equal setae, outer lobe with 3<tei:lb/>setae and a short naked seta. Second maxilla 2-segmented, distal portion of second segment<tei:lb/>produced into a slightly curved claw. Maxilliped 3-segmented and with terminal claw armed with<tei:lb/>a spinulate seta.<tei:lb/>Legs 1-4 with 3-segmented rami; armature formula for both sexes as follows:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 5 with a free segment armed with 2 short medial and 3 long lateral setae.<tei:lb/>Leg 6 represented by 2 small spines in the female and by a large postero-ventral flap bearing a<tei:lb/>single seta in the male.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Ratania flava Giesbrecht, 1891.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Ratania shows a close affinity to the family Myzopontiidae, but differs from the genera<tei:lb/>of this family, primarily in the absence of an exopod on the second antenna, in the reduced<tei:lb/>number of segments in the first antenna, in the small oral cone and in the structure of the blade<tei:lb/>of the mandible (Heron &amp; Damkaer, 1969).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ratania flava Giesbrecht, 1891</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Female. Prosome about 2-2 times longer than urosome. Ratio of lengths of urosome<tei:lb/>somites and caudal ramus (Fig. 17E) 14: 30: 12: 11 : 16 : 17. Caudal ramus about 1-7 times<tei:lb/>longer than wide.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First antenna 5-segmented; relative lengths of segments (measured along posterior border)<tei:lb/>23 : 7 : 5 : 35 : 30 (Fig. 17F); segmental armature elements 1-6, II-2, III-2 + 1 aesthete, IV-5,<tei:lb/>V-5 + 2 aesthetes. Second antenna (Fig. 17G) with terminal seta about 3 times longer than distal<tei:lb/>segment. Tip of mandible (Fig. 17H) with two dentate areas well separated. Inner lobe of first<tei:lb/>maxilla (Fig. 171) markedly longer than outer lobe. Free segment of leg 5 (Fig. 17E) somewhat<tei:lb/>expanded laterally, setae on leg 5 not conspicuously plumose.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PLANKTONIC COPEPODS OF THE N.E. ATLANTIC</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Body length of male 1-1-2 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 7?$ and 1 &lt;$; 'Discovery' Stn 7089. BM(NH) registration numbers 1977.242-<tei:lb/>248 ($?) and 1977.249 ().</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Saraswathy (1961) reported that many of the segments of the 5-segmented first antenna<tei:lb/>in $ R. flava showed subdivisions. No significant subdivisions were observed in the present<tei:lb/>material, and the segmentation of the first antenna remains a useful character in distinguishing<tei:lb/>between the two species of Ratania.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ratania atlantica Farran, 1926</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Female. Prosome from 1-9 to 2-3 times longer than urosome (Fig. 17 A); relative<tei:lb/>lengths of urosome somites and caudal ramus 14 : 29 : 15 : 10 : 13 : 19. Caudal ramus from 2-3<tei:lb/>to 2-5 times longer than wide.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First antenna (Fig. 17B) 7-segmented, relative lengths of segments 25 : 8 : 4 : 8 : 9 : 13 : 33;<tei:lb/>segmental armature elements 1-7, II-3 + 1 aesthete, III-2, IV-3, V-2, VI-2, VII-11 +2 aesthetes.<tei:lb/>Tip of mandible with two dentate areas separated by small indentation. Inner lobe of first maxilla<tei:lb/>just longer than outer lobe. Free segment of leg 5 not markedly expanded laterally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body length 2-21-2-8 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Prosome about 1-9 times longer than urosome. Relative lengths of urosome somites<tei:lb/>and caudal ramus (Fig. 17C) 10 : 21 : 15 : 13 : 9 : 13 : 19. Caudal ramus about 2-2 times longer<tei:lb/>than wide.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First antenna (Fig. 17D) 9-segmented, relative lengths of segments 16:11:3:8:5:4:16:8:<tei:lb/>19; segmental armature elements 1-4 + 3 aesthetes, II-4, III-2, IV-3; V-l, VI-1, VII-2, VIII-2 + 1<tei:lb/>aesthete, IX-8 + 1 aesthete.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body length 2-42-2-62 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. Holotype $: Bay of Biscay (Farran, 1926). BM(NH) registration numbers<tei:lb/>1926.12.6.40 (spirit) and 1926.12.6.52 (slide of appendages). 2 ?$: Antarctic (between 66 30'<tei:lb/>and 76 S), Terra Nova Stns 276 and 285 (Farran, 1929). BM(NH) registration numbers<tei:lb/>1930.1.1.1330-1333 (spirit) and 1930.7.24.91 (slide of appendages).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The holotype of R. atlantica is in poor condition. The slide of the appendages contains<tei:lb/>one of the first antennae, it is 7-segmented and the relative lengths of the segments are as follows<tei:lb/>24: 11:4: 11: 10: 11: 29. The armature elements remaining on the appendage are in agreement<tei:lb/>with the formula given by Heron &amp; Damkaer (1969). The body length of the holotype, 2-34 mm,<tei:lb/>also serves to distinguish between R. atlantica and the smaller R. flava. The two Antarctic speci-<tei:lb/>mens are poorly preserved, but their large size and the 7-segmented nature of the first antennae of<tei:lb/>one of them confirm that these specimens are R. atlantica.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family PONTOECIELLIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus PONTOECIELLA Giesbrecht, 1895</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Female. Body unmodified (Fig. ISA), urosome 5-segmented. Caudal ramus with 6<tei:lb/>setae, ventral seta strongly spinulate. Rostrum weakly developed. First antenna (Fig. 18C) 8-<tei:lb/>segmented with an aesthete on segment VI. Second antenna (Fig. 18D) non-prehensile, with a<tei:lb/>1-segmented exopod bearing 1 or 2 apical setae. Oral cone long, forming a true siphon (Fig. 18B).<tei:lb/>Mandible (Fig. 18E) a slender, elongate blade without a palp. First maxilla (Fig. 18F) a single</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Fig. 18 Pontoeciella abyssicola: A, holotype female; B, female cephalosome lateral; C, first antenna;<tei:lb/>D, second antenna; E, mandible; F, first maxilla; G, second maxilla; H, maxilliped; I, male; J,<tei:lb/>anterior portion of urosome, lateral; K, first antenna; L, first antenna from another specimen;<tei:lb/>M, second antenna; N, oral cone, lateral; O, second maxilla; P, maxilliped; Q, first leg; R, fifth<tei:lb/>and sixth lees.          <tei:p>242 G. A. BOXSHALL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>lobe with 2 apical setae and (sometimes) a small spinule. Second maxilla (Fig. 18G) 2-segmented,<tei:lb/>distal segment curving through between 65 and 90. Maxilliped (Fig. 18H) 4-segmented.<tei:lb/>Legs 1-4 with 3-segmented rami; armature formula variable but usually as follows:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coxa Basis Endopod Exopod</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 1 0-1 1-0 0-1; 0-2; 1, 2, 3 1-0; 0-1; MI, I, 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 2 0-1 1-0 0-1; 0-2; 1,2, 3 1-1 ; 1-1 ; II, I, 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 3 0-1 1-0 0-1; 0-2; 1, I, 3 0-1; 1-1; II, I, 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg4 0-1 1-0 0-1; 0-2; 1,1,2 0-1 ; 1-1 ; I, I, 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 5 reduced to a single seta.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Body unmodified (Fig. 181); urosome 6-segmented, first somite with ventral swelling<tei:lb/>(Fig. 18J), second somite narrower ventrally, producing slightly flexed appearance in lateral view.<tei:lb/>Ventral seta on caudal ramus thin-walled, not spinulate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First antenna (Figs 18K, L) 6-segmented, the distal segment providing between 75 and 90% of<tei:lb/>the overall length of the appendage; one aesthete present on segment III and one on segment V,<tei:lb/>the latter adhering along the entire length of the distal segment and projecting beyond its tip.<tei:lb/>Second antenna (Fig. 18M) with 1 -segmented exopod and 2-segmented endopod bearing a single<tei:lb/>apical element. Mouth cone (Fig. 18N) short without true siphon. Second maxilla (Fig. 18O),<tei:lb/>distal segment armed with a single naked seta. Maxilliped (Fig. 18P) 4-segmented, terminal claw<tei:lb/>long but weakly developed. Legs 1-4 (Fig. 18Q) as in female. Leg 5 (Fig. 18R) a small lobe fused<tei:lb/>to somite and bearing 4 plumose setae. Leg 6 represented by a single seta.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Pontoeciella abyssicola (Scott, 1894).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The new species described by Ummerkutty (1968), Danodes panikkari, obviously<tei:lb/>belongs to Pontoeciella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pontoeciella abyssicola (Scott, 1894)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>lArtotrogus abyssicolus T. Scott, 1894: 128-129, pi. 12, figs 5-9, pi. 14, figs 11-18.<tei:lb/>Pontoeciella abyssicola Giesbrecht, 1895 : 186.<tei:lb/>Carnegiella gracilis Wilson, 1942 : 176, figs 20-25.<tei:lb/>Danodes plumata Wilson, 1942: 182-183, figs 57-68.<tei:lb/>Danodes panikkari Ummerkutty, 1968 ; 298-304, figs 1-13.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. As for genus (p. 240).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. Holotype ? (as Artotrogus abyssicolus): Gulf of Guinea 1 55' N 5 55' E<tei:lb/>(T. Scott, 1894). BM(NH) registration number 1893.4.22.69a. 4 $?, 1 ^: Great Barrier Reef<tei:lb/>Expedition, Stns 20, 28, 45 and 48 (Farran, 1936). BM(NH) registration numbers 1948.4.28.132-<tei:lb/>135. 92?$, 4 &lt;?: 'Discovery' Stn 7089, 18 N 25 W. BM(NH) registration numbers 1977.250-259<tei:lb/>($$) and 1977.260-263 (^).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is highly variable both in the shape and proportions of the body and in<tei:lb/>the structure and armature of some of the appendages. Female body length varies from 0-7 mm<tei:lb/>(Farran, 1936) to 1-65 mm (Heron &amp; Damkaer, 1969) and body width relative to length ranges<tei:lb/>from 33 to 41 % (Farran, 1936). Variation in appendage structure and armature has been recorded<tei:lb/>from the first antenna to leg 5.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>According to Ummerkutty (1968), in Danodes panikkari the seta representing the female leg 5<tei:lb/>is absent. This difference alone is not sufficient to warrant the establishment of a distinct species,<tei:lb/>because of the variability exhibited by P. abyssicola, especially as this seta is often difficult to<tei:lb/>observe (T. Scott in his original description did not observe this seta although it is still present<tei:lb/>on his holotype specimen). Danodes panikkari is therefore regarded as a junior synonym of<tei:lb/>Pontoeciella abyssicola. The structure illustrated by Ummerkutty (1968, Fig. 7) as the first maxilla<tei:lb/>is not the first maxilla of a Pontoeciella, which is unilobed, and requires re-examination.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Less variation has been recorded in the males of P. abyssicola. However, a comparison of Far-<tei:lb/>ran's (1936, text-fig. 24d) and Wilson's (1942, fig. 20) figures with Fig. 161 shows variation in</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PLANKTONIC COPEPODS OF THE N.E. ATLANTIC 243</tei:p>
         <tei:p>body form, especially in relative lengths of the urosome somites. The relative lengths of segments<tei:lb/>of the first antenna also vary markedly, with the distal segment providing between 75 and 90 %<tei:lb/>of total appendage length. The male leg 5 is absent according to Scott (1894) and Wilson (1942),<tei:lb/>is represented by a single seta according to Farran (1936) or comprises four plumose setae<tei:lb/>(p. 242). Scott's male specimen is no longer extant but Farran's specimen from G.B.R. expedition<tei:lb/>Stn 20 was re-examined and the leg 5 was found to consist of 4 setae as in the 'Discovery' specimen<tei:lb/>illustrated in Fig. 18R. Only the most lateral seta is visible when the urosome is viewed from the<tei:lb/>dorsal aspect.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family MEGAPONTHDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus HYALOPONTIUS Sars, 1909<tei:lb/>Syn. Megapontius Hulsemann, 1965.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Both sexes. Body unmodified. Urosome 5-segmented in female, 6-segmented in male.<tei:lb/>Caudal ramus with 2 lateral, 2 dorsal and 3 apical setae, the latter situated in a concave depression<tei:lb/>in the distal margin. Rostrum well developed, ventrally directed and sometimes truncate distally.<tei:lb/>First antenna 1 1 -segmented; relative lengths of segments similar in all spp. 19:1:2:2:2:5:4:9:<tei:lb/>10: 12: 34; segmental armature usually as follows: 1-6, H-l, III-2, IV-1; V-l, VI-6 + 1 spine,<tei:lb/>VII-1 + 1 spine, VIII-2, IX-2, X-2, XI-13 + 1 aesthete. Spine on segment VI usually pointed<tei:lb/>(Fig. 24E), that on segment VII often blunt (Figs 23D &amp; 24E); aesthete on segment XI located<tei:lb/>near anterior margin about two thirds of distance along segment. Aesthete narrow and seta-like<tei:lb/>proximally, becoming thin- walled and flaccid distally. Second antenna 2- to 3-segmented; distal<tei:lb/>segment armed with a lateral spine, a small hirsute subapical seta and a very long terminal claw<tei:lb/>bearing a row of tiny spinules on its concave margin; exopod 1 -segmented bearing lateral and<tei:lb/>medial naked setae and a sparsely pinnate apical seta.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Oral cone short and well developed, with elaborate buccal tube distally; buccal stylets present.<tei:lb/>Mandible an elongate blade, dentate at tip and without palp. First maxilla bilobed; larger inner<tei:lb/>lobe with 3 apical setae, outer lobe with small spine and a long spinulate seta apically. Second<tei:lb/>maxilla 2-segmented, distal segment curved and dentate towards apex. Maxilliped 3-segmented;<tei:lb/>first segment usually bearing a unilaterally pinnate seta; second segment with a naked seta and a<tei:lb/>row of hairs along inner margin; terminal segment bearing 2 subapical setae and a long apical<tei:lb/>claw armed with a row of tiny hairs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legs 1-4 with 3-segmented rami; armature formula within following range:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coxa Basis Endopod Exopod</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 1 0-1 1-0 0-1; 0-2; 1, 2, 3 (O-I)-l; (0-I)-1; (II-III), 2, 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 2 0-1 1-0 0-1; 0-2; 1,2, 3 1-1 ; 1-1 ; (II-III), I, 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 3 0-1 1-0 0-1; 0-2; 1,2, 3 1-1 ; 1-1 ; (II-III), I, 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 4 0-1 1-0 0-1; 0-2; 1,2, 2 1-1 ; 1-1 ; II, I, 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 5 comprising basal segment armed with an outer seta and free segment bearing 1 apical<tei:lb/>and 2 lateral setae. Leg 6 represented by a single seta in female and by a genital lobe bearing 1<tei:lb/>long seta and 2 spinules in male.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Hyalopontius typicus Sars, 1909.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Sars (1909) described H. typicus in detail and comparison of his description with that<tei:lb/>of Megapontius gigas (Hulsemann, 1965) clearly demonstrates that the two genera, Hyalopontius<tei:lb/>and Megapontius, are synonymous. Sars (1909) placed Hyalopontius in the monotypic Pontoeciel-<tei:lb/>lidae but there are significant differences between these two genera. Hulsemann (1965), with some<tei:lb/>reservations, referred Megapontius to the family Artotrogidae sensu Eiselt (1961). Heptner (1968)<tei:lb/>described a new species, M. pleurospinosus, and erected a new family the Megapontiidae for the<tei:lb/>genus. Although Megapontius is now recognized as a synonym of Hyalopontius the family name is<tei:lb/>unchanged as it was based on a generic name which was valid at the time it was proposed.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>244 G. A. BOXSHALL</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Hyalopontius typicus Sars, 1909<tei:lb/>Megapontius gigas Hulsemann, 1965.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Female. Body relatively squat, about 34 times longer than greatest width (Fig. 19A);<tei:lb/>prosome about 1-8 times longer than urosome. Rostrum rounded at apex. Epimeral plates of free<tei:lb/>thoracic somites 2 and 3 pointed but not markedly produced posteriorly. Relative lengths of<tei:lb/>urosome somites and caudal rami 18 : 27 : 12 : 6 : 14 : 23; first urosome somite without additional<tei:lb/>spinose processes near posterior border; dentate hyaline membrane absent from posterior border.<tei:lb/>Posterior border of genital complex with dentate hyaline membrane. Caudal ramus about<tei:lb/>3-3-2 times longer than wide; lateral setae in distal half of ramus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Relative lengths of first antenna segments 19:2:2:2:3:5:4:7:8:11: 37 (Fig. 19C).<tei:lb/>Second antenna (Fig. 19D) exopod 1-9 times longer than wide; endopod 2-segmented with lateral<tei:lb/>spine on distal segment strongly developed and located about 35-38 % of distance along segment;<tei:lb/>terminal claw longer than rest of appendage. Maxilliped segments 1 and 2 incompletely separated,<tei:lb/>distal segment with long terminal claw, a small naked subapical seta and a lateral seta, relative<tei:lb/>lengths of these 3 elements 61 : 7 : 32 respectively.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legs 1-4 armature formula as for generic diagnosis except:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Exopod</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legl 1-1; 1-1; 11,2,3<tei:lb/>Leg 2 1-1; 1-1; 111,1,5<tei:lb/>Leg 3 1-1; 1-1; 11,1,5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 5 basal segment with small inner spinose process (Fig. 19E); free segment with 1 long apical<tei:lb/>and 2 medium-length lateral setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body length of female 4-87-5-3 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Body similar to that of female; relative lengths of urosome somites and caudal ramus<tei:lb/>16 : 13 : 15 : 12 : 7 : 15 : 22 (Fig. 19F). Appendages as in female (Figs 19H, I).          <tei:p>Body length of males 4-6-5-05 mm.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Fig. 19 Hyalopontius typicus: A, female; B, anterior portion of urosome; C, first antenna; D,<tei:lb/>second antenna; E, fifth leg; F, male urosome; G, caudal ramus; H, maxilliped; I, fifth leg; J,<tei:lb/>sixth leg. Scales 0-5 mm unless otherwise indicated.</tei:p>
