         <tei:p>246 G. A. BOXSHALL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The type material of H. typicus could not be located. It is not in the collections of the<tei:lb/>Musee Oceanographique de Monaco where the other material described in the same paper<tei:lb/>(Sars, 1909) is stored (Testa, pers. comm.). The present 'Discovery' material is identified as H.<tei:lb/>typicus because of the agreement in size and body proportions with the specimen figured by Sars<tei:lb/>(1909), and because of the position of the lateral spine on the distal segment of the second antenna.<tei:lb/>This spine was described by Sars as being in the middle of the segment but his figure shows it to<tei:lb/>be rather more proximal in position. The position of the lateral spine in the 'Discovery' material,<tei:lb/>at 35-38 % of the distance along the margin of this segment, is sufficiently similar for these speci-<tei:lb/>mens to be regarded as conspecific with Sars' material. In contrast, the six new species of Hyalo-<tei:lb/>pontius described below have the lateral seta on the second antenna situated within the proximal<tei:lb/>quarter (25 %) of the distal segment.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are no significant differences between the material described above as H. typicus and<tei:lb/>Megapontius gigas Hulsemann, 1965, which is thus regarded as a synonym.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hyalopontius hulsemannae sp. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Female. Body slender (Fig. 20A), about 4 times longer than greatest width; prosome<tei:lb/>about 1-3 times longer than urosome. Rostrum rounded at tip (Fig. 20B). Epimeral plates of free<tei:lb/>thoracic somite 2 pointed but not markedly produced ; those of free thoracic somite 3 produced<tei:lb/>posteriorly into a slender projection extending almost as far as the posterior border of the first<tei:lb/>urosome somite (Fig. 20C). Relative lengths of urosome somites and caudal ramus 14: 31 : 15 :<tei:lb/>8 : 20 : 12. Dentate hyaline membrane present along posterior margins of urosome somites 1-4.<tei:lb/>First urosome somite with 2 small spinose processes dorso-laterally near posterior border. Caudal<tei:lb/>ramus about 2-1 times longer than wide; lateral setae in distal half of ramus (Fig. 20D).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Relative lengths of first antenna segments; 19 : 2 : 2 : 2 : 2 : 5 : 4 : 9 : 10 : 10 : 35 (Fig. 20E).<tei:lb/>Second antenna (Fig. 20F) exopod about 2 times longer than wide; lateral spine on distal endopod<tei:lb/>segment small, unilaterally plumose and situated about 7 % of the distance along segment. Mandible<tei:lb/>(Fig. 20G) with reduced number of dentate projections at tip. Maxilliped (Fig. 20H) segments 1<tei:lb/>and 2 distinctly divided ; relative lengths of terminal claw, hirsute subapical seta and naked lateral<tei:lb/>seta 77 : 7 : 16: respectively.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legs 1-4 armature formula as for generic diagnosis except:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Exopod</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legl 0-1; 0-1; 11,2, 3<tei:lb/>Leg 2 1-1; 1-1; 111,1,5<tei:lb/>Leg 3 1-1; 1-1; 11,1,5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 5 (Fig. 201) bearing a small blunt inner process on basal segment; free segment with long<tei:lb/>apical and 2 medium-length lateral setae.<tei:lb/>Body length of holotype $ 5-03 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. Holotype ?: N.E. Atlantic Ocean 20 N 21 W, 'Discovery' Stn 9541 22.<tei:lb/>BM(NH) registration number 1977.322.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The species is named after Kuni Hulsemann who provided the first well-illustrated<tei:lb/>account of a species in this genus. This species can be distinguished from other species, except<tei:lb/>H. alatus n. sp., by the absence of an outer margin spine from exopod segment 1 of leg 1. It differs<tei:lb/>from H. alatus primarily in the position of the lateral spine on the distal segment of the second<tei:lb/>antenna, the degree of expansion of the epimeral plates of free thoracic somites 2 and 3 and the<tei:lb/>possession of 3 outer margin spines on exopod segment 3 of leg 2 (as compared to 2 in H. alatus).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hyalopontius alatus sp. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Female. Body slender (Fig. 21 A), about 5-2 times longer than greatest width; prosome<tei:lb/>about 1-3 times longer than urosome. Rostrum rounded at apex. Epimeral plates of free thoracic<tei:lb/>somite 2 produced, those of somite 3 markedly produced posteriorly and expanded laterally</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>

         <tei:p>Hyalopontius spinatus sp. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Female. Body slender (Fig. 22A), about 5-1 times longer than greatest width; prosome<tei:lb/>about 1-2 times longer than urosome. Rostrum truncate at apex (Fig. 22D). Epimeral plates of<tei:lb/>free thoracic somites 1 and 2 markedly produced posteriorly, those of somite 3 pointed but not<tei:lb/>markedly produced. Relative lengths of urosome somites and caudal ramus 14: 32: 14:9: 11: 20.<tei:lb/>First urosome somite with a pair of dorso-lateral spinose processes near the posterior border<tei:lb/>(Figs 22B, C); dentate hyaline membrane present along posterior margins of urosome somites<tei:lb/>1-4. Caudal ramus about 4-4 times longer than wide; lateral setae situated in proximal half of<tei:lb/>ramus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Relative lengths of first antenna segments 17 : 1 : 1 : 2 : 2 : 5 : 3 : 10 : 12 : 13 : 34 (Fig. 22F);<tei:lb/>segmental armature as in generic diagnosis but with additional seta on segment II. Second antenna<tei:lb/>(Fig. 22F) exopod about 2-2 times longer than wide, lateral spine on distal segment small and<tei:lb/>situated about 10% of distance along segment; terminal claw much longer than rest of appendage.<tei:lb/>Mandible (Fig. 22G) with two areas of dentate projections. First maxilla (Fig. 22H) and second<tei:lb/>maxilla (Fig. 221) as in other species of genus. Basal segment of maxilliped (Fig. 22J) with 2 strong<tei:lb/>processes on medial surface; relative lengths of terminal claw, hirsute subapical seta and naked<tei:lb/>lateral seta 83 : 8 : 9 respectively.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is named after Dr Howard Roe who found most of the new Hyalopontius<tei:lb/>material described in this account.          <tei:p>Hyalopontius cinctus sp. nov.</tei:p>

First urosome somite with a pair of<tei:lb/>large blunt processes situated dorso-laterally near posterior margin (Fig. 24B). Caudal ramus<tei:lb/>(Fig. 24C) about 2-4 times longer than wide; lateral setae in distal half of ramus.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Hyalopontius enormis sp. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Female. Body large, squat in appearance (Fig. 25A); about 2-9 times longer than<tei:lb/>greatest width; prosome about 2 times longer than urosome. Rostrum rounded at apex. Smooth hyaline membranes present on posterior margins of<tei:lb/>urosome somites 1-4. First urosome somite without spinose processes. Genital complex very<tei:lb/>broad (Fig. 25B), only 1-1 times longer than greatest width.          <tei:p>Relative lengths of first antenna segments 19:1:1:2:2:6:3:8: 10 :13: 35 (Fig. 25D).<tei:lb/>Second antenna (Fig. 25E) robust, first endopod segment fused to basipod; exopod about 4-6<tei:lb/>times longer than wide ; lateral seta on distal segment of endopod positioned 20 % of distance along<tei:lb/>segment; terminal claw shorter than rest of appendage. First maxilla<tei:lb/>(Fig. 25G) and second maxilla (Fig. 25H, I) as in other members of genus. Maxilliped (Fig. 25J)<tei:lb/>with segments 1 and 2 fused; relative lengths of terminal claw, hirsute subapical seta and naked<tei:lb/>lateral seta 74 : 5 : 21 respectively. Legs 1-4 (Figs 25K, L) as for generic diagnosis except:</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Legl 1-1; 0-1; 11,2,3<tei:lb/>Leg 2 1-1; 1-1; HI,I,5<tei:lb/>Leg 3 1-1; 1-1; 11,1,5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 5 (Fig. 25 M) with small inner process on basal segment; free segment with long apical seta<tei:lb/>and 2 lateral setae of medium length.<tei:lb/>Body length of holotype $ 7-6 mm.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>REMARKS. This is the largest known planktonic siphonostomatoid and can be distinguished from<tei:lb/>other species of the genus by its body proportions, the shape of the genital complex and the<tei:lb/>elongate exopod of the second antenna.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>PLANKTONIC COPEPODS OF THE N.E. ATLANTIC</tei:p>
         <tei:p>255</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 25 Hyalopontius enormis n. sp., holotype female: A, dorsal; B, anterior portion of urosome;<tei:lb/>C, caudal ramus; D, first antenna; E, second antenna; F, tip of mandible; G, first maxilla; H,<tei:lb/>second maxilla; I, tip of second maxilla; J, maxilliped; K, first leg; L, second leg; M, fifth leg.<tei:lb/>Scales O5 mm unless otherwise indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MORMONILLOIDA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genus Mormonilla was first described by Giesbrecht in 1891, but because it exhibits a com-<tei:lb/>bination of podoplean and gymnoplean characters its position in the classification of the Copepoda<tei:lb/>is still uncertain. Giesbrecht (1891, 1892) placed it in a separate family, the Mormonillidae,<tei:lb/>within the Podoplea Ampharthandria, which also included the families Cyclopidae, Harpacticidae</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>256 G. A. BOXSHALL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>and Monstrillidae. The latter three families were raised to subordinal level by Sars (1901). Sars<tei:lb/>(1902) placed Mormonilla in the family Tortanidae of the Calanoida, but later (1913) changed<tei:lb/>this opinion, and stated that the systematic position of the genus is very doubtful though it may<tei:lb/>perhaps be regarded as the type of a very anomalous family of the gnathostomous Cyclopoida.<tei:lb/>Few authors have considered the systematic position of the Mormonillidae since Sars. Rose (1933)<tei:lb/>adopted a cautious approach and placed the Mormonillidae in the Podoplea, but did not assign<tei:lb/>this family to any of the existing suborders.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In a recent work which deals with copepod systematics (Kabata, 1979), a more natural arrange-<tei:lb/>ment of the podoplean line is attained with the recognition of six orders: Harpacticoida,<tei:lb/>Monstrilloida, Misophrioida, Siphonostomatoida, Poecilostomatoida and Cyclopoida. The Mor-<tei:lb/>monillidae appear to be more closely related to the Misophrioida than to any other order, in<tei:lb/>possessing a podoplean arrangement of the body somites and typically gymnoplean mouthparts.<tei:lb/>However, Mormonilla differs from the two genera that comprise the aberrant Misophrioida<tei:lb/>(Misophria Boeck and Benthomisophria Sars) in the absence of a 'heart', the small number of<tei:lb/>segments in the first antenna and the complete absence of the fifth leg. Mormonilla resembles the<tei:lb/>cyclopoid genus Oithona Baird 1843 in general body facies and the structure of the first antenna,<tei:lb/>but the presence of a well-developed exopod on the second antenna suggests that the shared<tei:lb/>characters owe more to convergence than to a true phylogenetic relationship. It is therefore pro-<tei:lb/>posed to raise the family Mormonillidae to ordinal level.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family MORMONILLIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus MORMONILLA Giesbrecht, 1891</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Body slender, cyclopiform (Fig. 26A); with 5-segmented prosome and 4-segmented<tei:lb/>urosome. Genital complex with paired ventral genital openings and spinose areas laterally.<tei:lb/>Caudal ramus longer than urosome, bearing 6 armature elements. First antenna 3- or 4-segmented.<tei:lb/>Second antenna (Fig. 26D) with 8-segmented exopod and 2-segmented endopod. Mandible<tei:lb/>(Fig. 26E) blade with strongly incised teeth; palp comprising large basis fused to endopod and<tei:lb/>1 -segmented exopod; both rami armed with 6 plumose setae. First maxilla (Fig. 26F) with well-<tei:lb/>developed basis; gnathobase small but distinct and bearing 8 armature elements; both exopod<tei:lb/>and endopod 1 -segmented, armed with 6 and 8 setae respectively. Second maxilla (Fig. 26G)<tei:lb/>elongate, 5-segmented; proximal segment with 3 endites, second segment with 1 endite and an<tei:lb/>isolated seta; remaining 3 segments with 1, 1 and 4 armature elements. Maxilliped 2- or 3-seg-<tei:lb/>mented.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legs 1-4 biramous; leg 1 with 2- or 3-segmented rami; leg 2 exopod 2- or 3-segmented,<tei:lb/>endopod 1- or 2-segmented; leg 3 with 1 segmented endopod and 2- and 3-segmented exopod;<tei:lb/>leg 4 with 1 -segmented endopod and 2-segmented exopod.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legs 5 and 6 absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Mormonilla phasma Giesbrecht, 1891.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mormonilla phasma Giesbrecht, 1891</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Widest part of genital complex in anterior third (Figs 26B, C). Lateral seta on caudal<tei:lb/>ramus situated about 33 % of distance along ramus (Fig. 26A). First antenna 3-segmented, relative<tei:lb/>lengths of segments about 56 : 28 : 16. Maxilliped (Fig. 26H) 2-segmented; proximal segment with<tei:lb/>6 medial margin setae, distal segment with 7 setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 1 (Fig. 261) with spinose inner projections on coxa, basis and endopod segments; both<tei:lb/>rami 2-segmented; legs 2-4 with 2-segmented exopods and 1 -segmented endopods; armature<tei:lb/>formula as follows.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PLANKTONIC COPEPODS OF THE N.E. ATLANTIC</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Legl<tei:lb/>Leg 2<tei:lb/>Leg3<tei:lb/>Leg 4</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Exopod<tei:lb/>1-0; III, 2, 3<tei:lb/>0-0; I, 1, 5<tei:lb/>0-0; 0, 1, 4<tei:lb/>0-1; 0,1,3</tei:p>

         <tei:p>258 G. A. BOXSHALL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is most readily distinguished by the position of the lateral seta on the caudal<tei:lb/>ramus when sorting through large samples of Mormonilla. Other significant differences are found<tei:lb/>in the segmentation of the first antennae and legs 1-3.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mormonilla minor Giesbrecht, 1891</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mormonilla minor Giesbrecht, 1891 : 474.<tei:lb/>Mormonilla polaris Sars, 1900 : 120-126, pi. XXXIV.<tei:lb/>Mormonilla atlantica Wolfenden, 1905 : 16.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Widest part of genital complex about at mid-point (Fig. 27B). Lateral seta on caudal<tei:lb/>ramus located about 16 % of distance along ramus (Fig. 27A). First antenna 4-segmented, relative<tei:lb/>lengths of segments about 25 : 28 : 25 : 22 (Fig. 27C). Maxilliped (Fig. 27D) indistinctly 3-seg-<tei:lb/>mented; proximal segment with 7 setae on medial margin, middle segment with 1 seta and distal<tei:lb/>segment with 5 setae. Leg 1 (Fig. 27E) with fringes of strong setules on inner margins of coxa,<tei:lb/>basis and endopod; both rami usually 3-segmented; leg 2 (Fig. 27F) with 3-segmented exopod and<tei:lb/>2-segmented endopod; leg 3 with 3-segmented exopod and 1 segmented endopod; leg 4 with<tei:lb/>2-segmented exopod and 1 -segmented endopod. Armature formula as follows:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coxa Basis Endopod Exopod</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Leg 2 0-0 0-0 0-0; 0,2,1 0-0; 0-1; I, 1, 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 3 0-0 0-0 0, 2, 1 0-0; 0-1; 0, 1, 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leg 4 0-0 0-0 0,2, 1 0-1; 0, 1,3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body length of female from 1-2 to 1-38 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 274?$: N.E. Atlantic Ocean, 18 N 25 W, 'Discovery' Stn 7089. BM(NH)<tei:lb/>registration numbers 1977.282-291.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The segmentation of the first pair of swimming legs is rather variable with the leg 1<tei:lb/>endopod being either 2- (Giesbrecht, 1891, 1892) or 3-segmented (Sars, 1900; Wolfenden, 1905).<tei:lb/>This variation appears to reflect merely the degree of separation of the two distal segments and is<tei:lb/>not regarded as significant (Farran, 1908).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Species depth distributions</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The depth distribution data for all of the species recorded from the 'Discovery' Station 7089<tei:lb/>Day and Night series are given in Table 3. The vertical migration patterns of the more abundant<tei:lb/>species are discussed below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aegisthus mucronatus: During the day female A. mucronatus were found between 210 and<tei:lb/>790 m and over 80% of the population was concentrated at 210-290 m. At night the depth range<tei:lb/>was greater, 25-785 m, and there was some evidence of both upward and downward night scatter-<tei:lb/>ing as 89% of the population was distributed between 110 and 400 m. The data for the males<tei:lb/>(Table 3) also provide some evidence of an upward vertical migration at night.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aegisthus aculeatus: This species was distributed quite uniformly between 700 and 1220 m in<tei:lb/>the daytime. During the night the depth range was virtually the same although a small number of<tei:lb/>specimens was recorded at 505-700 m. The population appeared to be more concentrated at<tei:lb/>night as 86% of individuals were found between 800 and 1010 m. A. aculeatus was the dominant<tei:lb/>harpacticoid between 700 and 1250 m whilst its congener, A. mucronatus, was dominant in the<tei:lb/>11 0^500 m depth range. There was little vertical overlap between the distribution of these two<tei:lb/>species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Miracia efferata: M. efferata was found only within the upper 100 m of the water column both<tei:lb/>day and night and there is little evidence of any diurnal change in depth distribution.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Other harpacticoid species: The remaining species occurred in small numbers within the follow-<tei:lb/>ing depth ranges: Macrosetella gracilis, 55-300 m; Clytemnestra scutellata, 10-60 m; Microsetella</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PLANKTONIC COPEPODS OF THE N.E. ATLANTIC</tei:p>
         <tei:p>259</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 27 Mormonilla minor: A, female urosome; B, genital complex, ventral; C, first antenna;<tei:lb/>D, maxilliped; E, first leg; F, second leg. Scales 0*1 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>norvegica, 0-290 m; Neotisbella gigas, 300-900 m; Volkmannia forficula, 4 1 0-900 m; Bathyidia<tei:lb/>remota 1000-1250 m and Volkmannia attenuata 3760-3920 m.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pontoeciella abyssicola: Females were recorded between 112 and 600m during the day, with<tei:lb/>about 57% of the population distributed above 400 m. At night the depth range was 110-700 m<tei:lb/>and over 76 % of the population was concentrated above 400 m. This indicates that an upward<tei:lb/>vertical migration of at least part of the population had occurred.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Other siphonostomatoid species: Small numbers of Ratania flava were found between 20 and<tei:lb/>200 m. The species of Hyalopontius were recorded from the following depths: H. typicus, 2500-<tei:lb/>3100 m and 3000-3500 m; H. hulsemannae, 3740-3870 m; H. alatus, 3000-3500 m; H. spinatus,<tei:lb/>3830-4060 m; H. roei, 3000-3500 m; H. cinctus, 3000-3500 m and H. enormis 3000-3500 m.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mormonilla phasma: This species occurred primarily between 410 and 1250 m, with only occa-<tei:lb/>sional specimens taken in shallower hauls. The day and night depth distributions were similar<tei:lb/>with between 70 and 75 % of the population concentrated at 410-700 m in the shallow mesopelagic<tei:lb/>zone.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>260</tei:p>
         <tei:p>G. A. BOXSHALL</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>262 G. A. BOXSHALL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mormonilla minor : M. minor has an almost identical depth distribution to that of M. phasma.<tei:lb/>The depth range is basically 410-1220 m with isolated records from shallower hauls. The distribu-<tei:lb/>tion is slightly more concentrated in the 410-700 m depth zone with between 86 and 95% of the<tei:lb/>population occurring there.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The similarity between the depth distributions of the two species of Mormonilla is remarkable<tei:lb/>because the other two pairs of closely related forms found in the mesopelagic zone (i.e. the two<tei:lb/>species ofAegisthus and the two forms of Oncaea ornata Giesbrecht) both exhibit a marked degree<tei:lb/>of vertical segregation (see Boxshall, 1911 a for Oncaea ornata).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I am grateful to Dr Howard Roe (Institute of Oceanographic Sciences) for arranging the loan 01<tei:lb/>this material and for providing other relevant data. I would also like to thank Dr Roger Lincoln<tei:lb/>for reading and commenting on the manuscript and Miss Ann Gurney for her help in the prepara-<tei:lb/>tion of the manuscript. Dr Brigitte Volkmann (Istituto di Biologia del Mare, Venezia) examined<tei:lb/>some of the tisbid material and I am very grateful for her detailed comments and advice. I would<tei:lb/>also like to thank Dr G. Deevey for allowing me to examine her specimen of Bathyidia remota.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>The Museum publishes some 10-12 new titles each year on subjects<tei:lb/>including zoology, botany, palaeontology and mineralogy.<tei:lb/>Besides being important reference works, many, particularly among<tei:lb/>the handbooks, are useful for courses and students' background<tei:lb/>reading.</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology, and<tei:lb/>an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready. Volumes will contain about<tei:lb/>three hundred pages, and will not necessarily be completed within one calendar year.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subscription orders and enquiries about back issues should be sent to : Publications Sales,<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London SW7 5BD, England.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History), 1979</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>Towards a phyletic classification of the 'genus'<tei:lb/>Haplochromis (Pisces, Cichlidae) and related taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Part I.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Peter Humphry Greenwood</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Department of Zoology, British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London SW7 5BD</tei:p>

         <tei:p>265</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>266 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pharyngochromis gen. nov. . ......... 310</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Appendix 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A replacement 'generic' name for the Lake Malawi 'Haplochromis' species . . 317<tei:lb/>Appendix 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The taxonomic status of the genus Limnotilapia Regan, 1920 . . . . 317</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements ............ 319</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Index 321</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As currently recognized, the genus Haplochromis Hilgendorf encompasses over 300 species, some<tei:lb/>doubtless nominal but the majority of apparent biological validity (see Fryer &amp; lies, 1972;<tei:lb/>Greenwood, 19740). It is the most speciose African taxon in the family Cichlidae and, next to the<tei:lb/>genus Sarotherodon has the widest distribution in the continent, extending from Tunisia in the<tei:lb/>north to Namibia (South West Africa) in the south. It is, however, virtually absent from west<tei:lb/>Africa, being represented there by only one or two species from Nigeria.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amongst its numbers, indeed contributing the greatest number of species, are the well-known<tei:lb/>Haplochromis flocks of Lakes Victoria and Malawi (Trewavas, 1935; Fryer &amp; lies, 1972;<tei:lb/>Greenwood, 19740), together with the smaller and less studied flocks of Lakes Edward, George,<tei:lb/>Turkana (Rudolf), Albert and Kivu (see Regan, 19210; Poll, 1932; Trewavas, 1933; Trewavas,<tei:lb/>1938; Greenwood, 1973, 19746).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is amongst the species of these various lacustrine flocks that one encounters the great range<tei:lb/>of anatomical, dental and morphological differentiation usually associated with the genus. The<tei:lb/>fluviatile species appear to be less diversified, but even here there is more diversity than is realized<tei:lb/>at first.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>With this wide range of anatomical and morphological variation it is not surprising that the<tei:lb/>present concept of the genus, both in morphological and in phyletic terms, is very ill-defined. In-<tei:lb/>deed, the concept of Haplochromis seems to be based entirely on some intuitive appreciation of<tei:lb/>'overall similarity' amongst its constituent species. There has been, so far, no real attempt to<tei:lb/>test the validity of the implicit monophyly of these species. The recognizable and often noted<tei:lb/>intrageneric variability in Haplochromis has, until recently, not been seen as an analytical taxo-<tei:lb/>nomic tool because thinking amongst systematists working on cichlids has been dominated by a<tei:lb/>'size of the morphological gap' approach to supraspecific classification.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A reappraisal of the situation with this variation seen in terms of derived (apomorph) and<tei:lb/>primitive (pleisomorph) character states has not been applied to the genus as a whole (but see<tei:lb/>Greenwood, 19740, for the Lake Victoria species). It is this basically Hennigian approach (Hennig,<tei:lb/>1966) that I have attempted to apply to the problem. Its use, I believe, does allow one to produce<tei:lb/>a more realistic classification of the species now lumped together in Haplochromis, or separated<tei:lb/>from that genus because of their showing an extreme manifestation of features already indicated<tei:lb/>in species still retained in Haplochromis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The taxon Haplochromis was first introduced by Hilgendorf (1888), as a subgenus of Chromis,<tei:lb/>for his new species aptly named 'obliquidens' (see Greenwood, 19560). The fine, closely packed<tei:lb/>and multiseriate teeth of ' obliquidens\ with their protracted and obliquely truncate crowns (see<tei:lb/>Fig. 7B), provided the diagnostic features for Hilgendorf 's subgenus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No further species were added to Haplochromis until Boulenger (1906) elevated the taxon to<tei:lb/>generic rank and included in it six new species from Lake Victoria and the Victoria Nile. Boulenger<tei:lb/>gave no reasons for raising Hilgendorf's subgenus to a full genus, nor did he attempt to define<tei:lb/>Haplochromis so as to accommodate the new species, none of which had teeth like those of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT 267</tei:p>
         <tei:p>H. obliquidens. A footnote to the paper (Boulenger, 1906 : 443) might be interpreted as a generic<tei:lb/>definition, but it is completely inadequate and rather confusing, merely noting that '. . . in<tei:lb/>addition to the character of the dentition, intermediate between Paratilapia and Tilapia, the<tei:lb/>fishes of this genus differ from the latter in usually having a considerable portion of the maxillary<tei:lb/>bone exposed when the mouth is fully closed'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The following year Boulenger (1907 : 495) did provide a formal definition of Haplochromis, in<tei:lb/>which genus he then synonymized Pffefer's (1893) genus Ctenochromis and Pellegrin's (1903)<tei:lb/>Astatoreochromis (now recognized as a distinct genus, see Greenwood, 1959a; Poll, 1974 and<tei:lb/>p. 285 below). This definition is, however, very vague and so worded that it is impossible to<tei:lb/>distinguish Boulenger 's concept of Haplochromis from that of his redefined Paratilapia Bleeker.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The situation remained virtually unchanged, except for the addition of several more species,<tei:lb/>with the publication of the third volume in Boulenger's Catalogue of African Freshwater Fishes<tei:lb/>(1915) in which he again comments that some Haplochromis species '. . . vary to such an extent<tei:lb/>in their dentition that [they] might be referred to Tilapia and others to Paratilapia'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Regan's (1920, 19220) fundamental studies on the osteology of African Cichlidae, and his<tei:lb/>consequent revision of Boulenger's genera, resulted in many more species being included in<tei:lb/>Haplochromis (which then became the '. . . largest African genus', Regan, 1920 : 45). In his 1920<tei:lb/>paper Regan also defined (in a footnote) several genera which, although apparently related to<tei:lb/>Haplochromis, differed from that genus in various dental features, both oral and pharyngeal.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Surprisingly, in the light of these other generic definitions, Regan was content to include in<tei:lb/>Haplochromis a majority of species whose dental characters were quite unlike those of the type<tei:lb/>species. In effect, Regan's redefinition of Haplochromis in these and subsequent papers (especially<tei:lb/>those of 192 la &amp; b and 1922a &amp; 6) was only a slight improvement of that provided by Boulenger.<tei:lb/>Haplochromis remained a polymorphous assemblage of species showing a wide range of dental<tei:lb/>and other anatomical peculiarities, only united by having a particular kind of cranial apophysis<tei:lb/>for the upper pharyngeal bones. Since a similar apophysis occurs in other taxa defined by Regan,<tei:lb/>the monophyletic origin of Hapolchromis was not established.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>That Regan was aware of his system's shortcomings is shown by remarks in his papers on the<tei:lb/>cichlids of Lakes Malawi (19216) and Victoria (19226). For example, regarding the Haplochromis<tei:lb/>of Lake Victoria he wrote (Regan, 19226 : 158): 'The species of Haplochromis exhibit almost as<tei:lb/>great a diversity as in Nyassa, yet there are certain features which enable one to say almost at a<tei:lb/>glance to which lake a species belongs', and on page 160: 'From what has been said above as to<tei:lb/>the evolution and relationships of the Cichlidae of Victoria, it will be evident that I do not regard<tei:lb/>the classification here proposed as entirely satisfactory'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Regarding the species of Lake Malawi, Regan (19216 : 686) has this to say: '. . . the absence of<tei:lb/>evident relationship to species found elsewhere leads to the conclusion that the Nyassa species<tei:lb/>are a natural group and may, perhaps, have evolved in the lake from a single ancestral form'.<tei:lb/>Regrettably, Regan does not elaborate on his remark about the absence of evident relationship<tei:lb/>to species found elsewhere, particularly since a year later he was to place the majority of Lake<tei:lb/>Victoria species in the same genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>When revising the Lake Victoria species, Regan (19226) divided the Haplochromis into five<tei:lb/>subgenera, Neochromis for //. nigricans and H. nuchisquamulatus, Bayonia for H. xenodon (now<tei:lb/>considered a synonym of Macropleurodus, see Greenwood, 19566), Haplochromis for H. obliqui-<tei:lb/>dens, and Ctenochromis for the remaining 42 species. These latter were characterized by their<tei:lb/>having conical or bicuspid teeth separated by an interspace from the smaller inner teeth, the<tei:lb/>other subgenera having variously specialized crown forms to the teeth. Regan disregarded, or<tei:lb/>perhaps failed to appreciate the principal diagnostic feature which Pfeffer (1893) used to diagnose<tei:lb/>Ctenochromis, namely the very small scales on the thoracic region. Both Pfeffer and Regan over-<tei:lb/>looked other diagnostic features in Ctenochromis pectoralis (type species of the genus), none of<tei:lb/>which is found in any of the 42 Victoria species placed in Regan's Ctenochromis subdivision of<tei:lb/>that flock (see p. 287 below). Recent research (summarized in Greenwood, 1974a) also indicates<tei:lb/>that these 42 species, and about an equal number described since Regan's 1922 revision, can be<tei:lb/>subdivided into several distinct groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>268 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Similar arguments can be marshalled against Regan's (I922a : 253) statement that '. . . the<tei:lb/>species (of Haplochromis) not peculiar to the Great Lakes all belong to the subgenus Ctenochromis,<tei:lb/>Pfeffer . . .'; this aspect of the problem will be discussed later.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Since Regan's time, no real attempts have been made to subdivide the genus (which now<tei:lb/>contains almost double the number of species known to Regan). Some species have been separated<tei:lb/>off as mono- or oligotypic genera, but these actions have in no way simplified the problem either<tei:lb/>taxonomically or phylogenetically, and the genus has still not been shown to be a monophyletic<tei:lb/>unit.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clearly, to test the phylogenetic integrity of such a large, ill-defined taxon will require much<tei:lb/>detailed and critical analysis. The present paper must be looked upon as a tentative first step in<tei:lb/>that direction. I shall limit my detailed analysis to those Haplochromis species which I have<tei:lb/>studied in some depth, viz. the species flock of Lake Victoria (which contains the type species,<tei:lb/>H. obliquidens) and those of Lakes Turkana, Albert, Edward and George, together with the few<tei:lb/>Haplochromis occurring in Lake Tanganyika, and the purely fluviatile species from Africa and<tei:lb/>the Middle East. Also included are the Haplochromis-\ike riverine genera Orthochromis Green-<tei:lb/>wood, Serranochromis Regan and Rheohaplochromis Thys van den Audenaerde, and the partly<tei:lb/>lacustrine Astatoreochromis Pellegrin. Unfortunately, I have been unable, through lack of first-<tei:lb/>hand knowledge, to include the Lake Malawi Haplochromis flock. However, I trust that the<tei:lb/>results of my analysis of these other Haplochromis species will enable workers on the Malawi<tei:lb/>fishes to review the species of that lake in a new light.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>My review of anatomical, osteological and morphological features, including details of<tei:lb/>secondary sexual markings and coloration, has yielded one particularly significant (but not<tei:lb/>surprising) result; there is, apparently, not one deiived feature shared only by the 190 species<tei:lb/>examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The commonly occurring tooth form, an unequally bicuspid tooth, is found in several other<tei:lb/>genera, as is the unicuspid and caniniform type. Even some of the specialized dental types seem<tei:lb/>to have evolved independently in other genera, these genera, and those in which bi- and unicuspid<tei:lb/>teeth also occur, each being recognizable on the basis of derived features not shared<tei:lb/>by Haplochromis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The structure of the cranial apophysis for the upper pharyngeal bones (see Regan, 1920) is<tei:lb/>probably a derived feature (see Greenwood, 1978), but again it is a feature widely distributed<tei:lb/>amongst several genera whose close affinity with Haplochromis cannot be established. At best the<tei:lb/>pharyngeal apophysis can be used as an indicator of relationship at a more distant level than the<tei:lb/>'generic' one (see Greenwood, 1978).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No derived features of the anatomy or the squamation are universally shared amongst all the<tei:lb/>species although, as with various other characters, distinct groups can be defined within<tei:lb/>Haplochromis on the basis of shared derived features.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The anal fin markings found in adult male Haplochromis, the so-called anal ocelli or egg-<tei:lb/>dummies (see Wickler, 1962a &amp; b\ Trewavas, 1973), have been considered a unique feature of the<tei:lb/>genus. Trewavas (1973 : 34) expressed the generally held view on these markings when she wrote<tei:lb/>'. . . within their endless diversity the species of Haplochromis have almost universally in common<tei:lb/>a feature of the colour-pattern, the well-known ocellar spots on the anal fin of the male' (italics<tei:lb/>mine). Certainly such ocellar markings are present in all the described species of Haplochromis<tei:lb/>from Lake Victoria, Edward, George and Kivu, and probably in those from Lake Turkana as<tei:lb/>well. But, true ocelli (i.e. a central coloured spot with a clear surround) are not found in the<tei:lb/>species of Lake Albert, in the majority of species occurring in the rivers, nor even in many of<tei:lb/>the Lake Malawi species (see figs in Axelrod &amp; Burgess, 1977). Coloured markings do occur on<tei:lb/>the anal fins of these fishes (sometimes in both sexes), but are in the form of spots without a<tei:lb/>clear surround, often smaller than the true ocellar type, sometimes more numerous and covering<tei:lb/>the greater part of the fin, sometimes only as one or two spots, or, less commonly, similar in<tei:lb/>number (3-5) and linear arrangements to the true ocellar type.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clearly, the presence of ocellar anal markings cannot be considered a character of Haplochromis<tei:lb/>as that genus is currently conceived, and the value of anal markings per se as an indicator of<tei:lb/>phyletic relationship must be reassessed.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT 269</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although a monophyletic origin for the 'genus' Haplochromis cannot be established, it is<tei:lb/>possible to recognize several seemingly monophyletic lineages (reconstructed on the basis of<tei:lb/>synapomorphic characters) amongst the species of Lake Victoria (Greenwood, 19740 and un-<tei:lb/>published). None of the six major lineages recognized in that lake, however, could be interrelated<tei:lb/>on a sister-group basis (although sister-groups could be recognized within five of the lineages<tei:lb/>themselves). In other words, the synapomorphic features of each lineage are superimposed on a<tei:lb/>basic, plesiomorphic 'bauplan' shared by all*.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A similar picture emerges when the fluviatile species, and those from Lakes Albert, Turkana<tei:lb/>and Tanganyika are examined closely. That is, one can postulate a number of lineages (some<tei:lb/>containing both fluviatile and lacustrine members), but none can be further interrelated on the<tei:lb/>basis of synapomorphic features.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>With the possible exception of their occurrence in two species (one from Lake Victoria, the<tei:lb/>other from Lake George), none of the apomorph features used to delineate these lineages has<tei:lb/>been observed amongst the 'Haplochromis' species of Lakes Victoria, Edward, George and Kivu.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although no apomorph character has been found to unite all the species of Lakes Victoria,<tei:lb/>Edward, George and Kivu, and thus suggest their common ancestry, species from the different<tei:lb/>lakes can be grouped into common lineages each of presumed monophyletic origin. For that<tei:lb/>reason the 'Haplochromis'' of Lakes Edward, Kivu and George will be treated together with those<tei:lb/>of Victoria in a forthcoming paper (except for those species which are now referred to the redefined<tei:lb/>genus Haplochromis, see p. 280).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>To summarize, the so-called Haplochromis species of Africa (excepting those of Lake Malawi<tei:lb/>which are not included in this review) can be split into a number of major lineages. Most of these<tei:lb/>lineages are characterized by derived features unique to its members.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The different lineages cannot be interrelated on a sister-group basis for want of ascertainable<tei:lb/>synapomorphic features which would permit the recognition of their sister-group status. I use<tei:lb/>the qualification 'most of these' because one of the groups cannot be defined on the basis of<tei:lb/>even a single shared apomorph character. This is the group in which must be placed the widespread<tei:lb/>H. bloyeti species complex of east Africa (see Greenwood, 1971, 19740) and, probably, certain of<tei:lb/>the generalized endemic species of Lake Victoria, Edward and Kivu ; it is recognized merely on<tei:lb/>the overall similarity (and plesiomorphy) of its constituent species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wherever breeding habits are known, members of the various lineages described in this paper<tei:lb/>are female mouth brooders, and all have a 'Haplochromis' -type cranial apophysis for the upper<tei:lb/>pharyngeal bones (Greenwood, 1978), features shared with the 'Haplochromis' and several<tei:lb/>seemingly related species in Lake Malawi (Trewavas, 1935; Greenwood, 1978). Oral brooding<tei:lb/>and its associated spawning behaviour, as compared with substrate spawning and brood-care, is<tei:lb/>a derived condition; the 'Haplochromis'' -type apophysis would also seem to be a derived feature.<tei:lb/>One may therefore hypothesize a shared common ancestry, at some point, both for the lineages<tei:lb/>described below and for those which eventually will be recognized amongst the Lake Malawi<tei:lb/>haplochromine species (i.e. those with a 'Haplochromis'-type pharyngeal apophysis and, probably<tei:lb/>species with a 'Tropheus'-type apophysis as well; see Greenwood, 1978).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For the moment, however, and until it is possible to interrelate dichotomously the various<tei:lb/>lineages on a sister-group basis, one is faced with a series of unresolved dichotomies (see, for<tei:lb/>example, the problem discussed on p. 313). In classifying this assemblage I have followed the<tei:lb/>convention suggested by Nelson (1972), namely that the taxa (i.e. the individual lineages) be<tei:lb/>given equal rank. At this stage in our knowledge of supraspecific relationships amongst African<tei:lb/>cichlids, generic rank would seem to be the most appropriate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Methods and materials</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Methods</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In essence I have attempted to break up the 'genus' Haplochromis into a number of monophyletic</tei:p>
         <tei:p>* It has been assumed (on the basis of overall morphological similarity between the least specialized members of<tei:lb/>each lineage) that the endemic Haplochromis species of Lake Victoria are of monophyletic origin (Greenwood,<tei:lb/>1974a). Since no apomorph feature unique to the Victoria species has yet been found, that hypothesis is without<tei:lb/>formal support.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>270 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>lineages, the members of each lineage being related by their relative recency of common ancestry.<tei:lb/>Recency of common ancestry, in turn, is recognized by members of a lineage possessing derived<tei:lb/>(apomorph) characters which are not shared with other species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Determining the primitive (plesiomorph) or derived status of characters in the Cichlidae is at<tei:lb/>present a very difficult task. No guidance is available from the entirely inadequate fossil record,<tei:lb/>and the family's nearest living relatives have yet to be recognized. Comparisons between different<tei:lb/>character states (outgroup comparison, see Hecht &amp; Edwards, 1977) ideally should be carried out<tei:lb/>across the whole family. As there are well over 600 nominal species in Africa and America, few<tei:lb/>of which have been studied in the detail necessary for proper phyletic analysis, the level of out-<tei:lb/>group comparisons employed in this paper is, perforce, a low one.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All comparisons have been restricted to African taxa, in particular to species and lineages<tei:lb/>within the group having a 'Haplochromis' -type of pharyngeal apophysis. This decision was made<tei:lb/>on the assumption that all such taxa were derived from a common ancestor, albeit a distant one,<tei:lb/>and that the 'Haplochromis'-type apophysis, relative to the ' Ti lap la" -type, is itself a derived<tei:lb/>character. The most detailed comparisons, of course, have been those made between species<tei:lb/>comprising the lineages discussed in this paper.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Outgroup comparisons have also been made with species having a 'Tilapia'-type apophysis, in<tei:lb/>particular the lineages represented by the genera Sarotherodon and Tilapia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>When comparisons were made with Haplochromis from Lake Victoria, the Victorian lineages<tei:lb/>were those discussed in Greenwood (1974a). Since no such breakdown is available for the endemic<tei:lb/>Haplochromis of Lake Malawi or for the endemic genera with a 'Haplochromis'' -type apophysis<tei:lb/>in Lake Tanganyika, these various taxa were not involved in the analysis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The particular characters and character transformations studied are those which, after a<tei:lb/>preliminary survey of the taxa involved*, seemed to be most likely to yield information on their<tei:lb/>derived or primitive states within the material available and within the limits of the tests which<tei:lb/>could be applied to the conclusions reached.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As might be expected, the principal test was that of the distribution of a character state amongst<tei:lb/>the species compared. The state having the widest occurrence is assumed to be the most primitive<tei:lb/>one, that with the most circumscribed distribution the derived one (the so-called commonality<tei:lb/>principle of Schaeffer, Hecht &amp; Eldredge, 1972).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The characters finally selected, and a few others that deserve comment, can now be discussed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(/') Squamation. All Haplochromis have the scales on the chest region (the area anterior to a line<tei:lb/>through the pelvic and pectoral fin insertions, and ventral to a horizontal line through the ventral<tei:lb/>part of the pectoral fin insertion) smaller than those on the ventral and ventrolateral parts of the<tei:lb/>body. The common condition is that in which the size change between the scales of the two regions<tei:lb/>is a gradual one, see Fig. 1 ; even when, as in H. squamulatus of Lake Victoria, the chest scales are<tei:lb/>noticeably small, the size change is still gradual (see fig. 17 in Greenwood, 1967). The less frequent<tei:lb/>condition is that in which the size transition (usually along the line between pectoral and pelvic<tei:lb/>fin insertions, but sometimes a little further posteriorly) is abrupt ; since in these fishes the chest<tei:lb/>scales are generally small and numerous, the chest squamation is noticeably distinct from that<tei:lb/>of the belly and ventral flank regions (Figs 2 &amp; 3).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A totally scaled chest, irrespective of squamation pattern, is the usual condition; circum-<tei:lb/>scribed, bilaterally symmetrical naked patches are uncommon and are confined to species showing<tei:lb/>an abrupt size transition in thoracic-abdominal scale sizes. A completely naked chest is the most<tei:lb/>uncommon condition and would seem to be the end point in the apomorphic morphocline:<tei:lb/>abrupt size change -^ bilateral naked patches * completely naked chest.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although the ventral body scales extending posteriorly from the pelvic fin insertions to the<tei:lb/>anus are smaller than those on the lateral and ventrolateral aspects of the flanks, the size gradation<tei:lb/>between the two fields is generally gradual. However, in a few species the ventral (belly) scales are<tei:lb/>much reduced in size and thus are clearly demarcated from the flank scales above them. This</tei:p>
         <tei:p>* The Haplochromis species of Lakes Victoria, Albert, Turkana, Tanganyika, Edward, George and Kivu, of the<tei:lb/>African rivers and those of Syria and Israel, and the species of Serranochromis, Rheohaplochromis, Orthochromis,<tei:lb/>Astatoreochromis, Macropleiirodus, Platytaeniodus and Hoplotilapia, a total of some 390 species.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT 271</tei:p>
         <tei:p>condition is correlated with an equally marked and abrupt size reduction in the scales on the<tei:lb/>chest, so that the tiny abdominal scales appear as a posterior and ventrolateral extension of those<tei:lb/>on the chest (Fig. 3). Such an arrangement is also considered to be a derived condition.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Surprisingly, in a group of species where most morphological features appear as elements in a<tei:lb/>continuum of differentiation, the various scale patterns discussed above are very trenchantly<tei:lb/>separated from one another. The few intermediate specimens I have observed are clearly individual<tei:lb/>rather than populational or specific variants.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As with the chest, a completely scaled cheek is the common condition, the scales being arranged<tei:lb/>in three or four horizontal rows. Reduced squamation is encountered infrequently, but ranges<tei:lb/>from a narrow naked band (one or two rows deep) along the ventral margin, to an almost com-<tei:lb/>pletely naked cheek with only the suborbital row, or part of that row, persisting.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10mm<tei:lb/>Fig. 1 Thoracic-abdominal scale transition in Astatotilapia nubila; left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>On the principle of commonality (Schaeffer et al, 1972), strongly ctenoid body scales should be<tei:lb/>looked upon as the primitive condition, and an increase in the area of the body covered by<tei:lb/>cycloid or reduced ctenoid scales should be considered the derived one*.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Some uncertainty about this conclusion could be raised by the situation in Hemichromis, also<tei:lb/>a ' Haplochromis'' group species (see Regan, \922a). Here the scales are mostly cycloid with a few<tei:lb/>weakly ctenoid ones confined to the anterior part of the body ; that is, a presumably derived<tei:lb/>condition. But Hemichromis species are substrate spawners and brood guarders, a presumed<tei:lb/>primitive condition amongst African cichlids. Since certain other characters in Hemichromis are<tei:lb/>apparently derived ones (the unicuspid outer teeth, the number of inner tooth rows (one or none),<tei:lb/>and the form of the upper jaw), the cycloid scales may have evolved independently in the lineage.<tei:lb/>On the other hand, the presence of cycloid scales in 'Tilapia' group species (see footnote), some<tei:lb/>of which are also substrate spawners and all of which have an apparently plesiomorph type of<tei:lb/>pharyngeal apophysis (see Greenwood, 1978), would appear to strengthen the argument for<tei:lb/>considering cycloid scales as primitive features. In the face of such contradictory observations it<tei:lb/>would seem advisable not to use this type of scale ornamentation in phyletic analysis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All the Haplochromis and Haplochromis group species used in this review (see footnote p. 270)<tei:lb/>have less than the proximal two-thirds of the caudal fin covered by small scales; usually only the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>* Most taxa in the "Tilapid 1 group, as defined by apophyseal structure (see Greenwood, 1978), have cycloid scales,<tei:lb/>although some have a few weakly ctenoid scales on the anterior part of the body).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>272</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 2 Thoracic-abdominal scale transition in Thoracochromis wingatii; left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5mm<tei:lb/>Fig. 3 Thoracic-abdominal scale transition in Orthochromis polyacanthus; left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>proximal half is covered. In contrast, all the endemic lacustrine species from Lake Malawi have<tei:lb/>the entire fin densely scaled (Trewavas, 1935). The partly scaled condition is assumed to be the<tei:lb/>plesiomorph one.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(//') Dentition. Outer tooth row in both jaws. The most frequently occurring tooth form (Fig. 4)<tei:lb/>is that with an unequally bicuspid crown, moderately distinct neck and relatively stout body<tei:lb/>firmly attached to the underlying bone. Neither cusp is strongly compressed, their tips are acute<tei:lb/>or subacute and lie in or but slightly outside a vertical drawn through the corresponding outer<tei:lb/>margin of the tooth's body. Such teeth, apart from providing the definitive dental form in many</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT 273</tei:p>
         <tei:p>species, also precede the definitive tooth type in species having unicuspid teeth in adult fishes,<tei:lb/>and also, in at least some species, precede the definitive types when these are much modified<tei:lb/>versions of the basic bicuspid (e.g. in H. obliquidens). Unfortunately, ontogenetic data on tooth<tei:lb/>replacement are not available for many species, so the generality of the latter observation is<tei:lb/>unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Because of its common occurrence and its primary position in the ontogenetic sequence of<tei:lb/>tooth replacement, the unequally bicuspid tooth is taken to be the plesiomorph dental type.<tei:lb/>Bicuspid teeth in which there is a differential growth of one cusp (usually the larger one) or equal<tei:lb/>development of both cusps are considered to be derived features, as are unicuspid teeth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As mentioned above, most taxa having a definitive outer row dentition composed of unicuspid<tei:lb/>teeth also have an ontogenetically earlier one of bicuspids (usually persisting until an individual<tei:lb/>fish is between 80 and 100 mm standard length). Any shift forward in the time or body size at<tei:lb/>which the definitive unicuspid teeth appear can therefore be interpreted as being a derived<tei:lb/>condition.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 4 Outer row jaw teeth (premaxillary) of Astatotilapia flaviijosephi.<tei:lb/>A. Labial view. B. Lateral view (posterior aspect).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>From one to six (rarely as many as twelve) enlarged and unicuspid teeth occur posteriorly on<tei:lb/>the premaxilla, even when the other teeth on that bone are bicuspids. The replacement of these<tei:lb/>unicuspids by teeth similar to those on the rest of the premaxilla must be considered a derived<tei:lb/>condition.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Inner row teeth. Here, on the grounds of common occurrence, small, tricuspid teeth must<tei:lb/>represent the primitive condition. As with the outer teeth, there can be an ontogenetic succession<tei:lb/>of teeth types, tricuspids or a mixture of tri- and bicuspids preceding unicuspids. Occasionally<tei:lb/>some or all inner rows are composed of highly modified bicuspid types resembling, albeit on a<tei:lb/>smaller scale, those of the outer row (e.g. Haplochromis obliquidens and Macropleurodus bicolor;<tei:lb/>see Greenwood, 1974a).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The presence of inner teeth other than tricuspids is a derived condition. Since most commonly<tei:lb/>there are from 2 to 3 rows of inner teeth, any increase or decrease in the number of rows must<tei:lb/>also indicate an apomorph condition.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Hi) The lower pharyngeal bone and its dentition. The most commonly encountered form of lower<tei:lb/>pharyngeal bone has an approximately equilateral, triangular dentigerous surface, is not noticeably<tei:lb/>thickened or robust, and has its anterior blade-like portion neither noticeably elongate nor short<tei:lb/>(Fig. 5).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The teeth are arranged anteroposteriorly in about 30 to 50 rows, with those in the two median<tei:lb/>and in the posterior transverse row stouter than the others but, like them, retaining an unequally<tei:lb/>bicuspid crown in which the minor cusp is a near horizontal shoulder and the major one is weakly<tei:lb/>falciform and vertically aligned.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Apomorphic derivations from this basic type include changes in overall outline shape of the<tei:lb/>dentigerous area (Fig. 14), elongation of the anterior blade, increase or decrease in the number<tei:lb/>of tooth rows, an increase or, less commonly, a decrease in the number of rows of coarser teeth</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>274</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 20 &amp; 8), and changes in crown morphology of the teeth (generally a process of molarization<tei:lb/>associated with a general coarsening of tooth form; see Fig. 18B).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(iv) Neurocranial morphology. Modal neurocranial form (and thus the presumed plesiomorph<tei:lb/>condition) is best appreciated from a drawing (Fig. 6).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Salient features are the moderately high supraoccipital crest (c. three-quarters of the depth of<tei:lb/>the otic skull region measured from roof to ventral parasphenoidal face, but excluding the<tei:lb/>pharyngeal apophysis); the preorbital skull profile (from vomerine tip to the anterior point of the<tei:lb/>supraoccipital crest) rising at an angle of cA5, its outline gently curved and its ethmovomerine<tei:lb/>region sloping forwards and downwards at a slight angle; the preotic part of the skull (measured<tei:lb/>from the vomerine tip to the anterior vertical wall of the prootic bone) comprising some 55-60 %<tei:lb/>of the total length of the neurocranium, and the otic region of the skull not inflated. The pharyngeal<tei:lb/>apophysis is not enlarged, and the prootic does not contribute to the articular surface (Greenwood,<tei:lb/>1978).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 5 Lower pharyngeal bone of Astatotilapia bloyeti. A. Occlusal view.<tei:lb/>B. Right lateral view (bone aligned vertically).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Derivative conditions include elongation of the preotic part of the skull (to about 70% of the<tei:lb/>neurocranial length) correlated with a flattening of the preorbital skull profile (Fig. 13); narrowing<tei:lb/>of the otic region, and in some variants a relative lowering of the supraoccipital crest; the reten-<tei:lb/>tion of a basic skull form in the otic region but a marked increase in the slope of the ethmovomerine<tei:lb/>region (in some species almost to the vertical) and a correlated increase in the slope and curvature<tei:lb/>of the preorbital skull profile; the retention of basic otic and ethmovomerine regions but the<tei:lb/>elevation of the preorbital skull roof so that the neurocranium becomes higher and more angular<tei:lb/>in outline (see Greenwood, 1974a, for further analysis and figures).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Departure from the plesiomorph condition for the pharyngeal apophysis is always associated<tei:lb/>with an hypertrophy of the upper and lower pharyngeal bones and their dentition (see Greenwood,<tei:lb/>19650, 19740, 1978).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(v) Anal fin markings (egg-dummies) in male fishes. Reference has already been made (p. 268) to<tei:lb/>the variety of these markings in Haplochromis. (See Wickler, 19620 &amp; b, 1963 for a discussion of<tei:lb/>their importance in the breeding biology of these fishes).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Regrettably there is little information about these markings in live fishes, and what has been<tei:lb/>recorded is often insufficiently detailed to be of value. For instance, it is important to know if the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT</tei:p>
         <tei:p>275</tei:p>
         <tei:p>markings are merely coloured spots, whether each spot has a contrasting border, or whether it is<tei:lb/>truly an ocellus with a wide and translucent surround. The number and distribution of the<tei:lb/>markings are also important data. My own observations on live fishes from different parts of<tei:lb/>Africa, and on preserved material as well, all suggest that the anal markings (or their absence)<tei:lb/>may be of considerable value in helping to define lineages. But, because of a paucity of informa-<tei:lb/>tion for many species considered below it has proved impossible to use the character fully in<tei:lb/>this study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It seems reasonable to assume that the egg-dummy markings (using that term in its widest<tei:lb/>sense and not just for true ocelli) were derived from coloured streaks and spots like those that<tei:lb/>are an almost universal feature on the dorsal fins of cichlids (see Wickler, 19620). The first steps<tei:lb/>in the evolution of egg-dummies from a maculate colour pattern would involve a slight reduction<tei:lb/>in the number of spots and a consequent increase in the space between them, and the intensifica-<tei:lb/>tion or alteration of their colour so as to differentiate the anal spots from those in the dorsal<tei:lb/>fin. The end point in this process of differentiation seemingly would be reached with the develop-<tei:lb/>ment of ocellar spots.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5mm<tei:lb/>Fig. 6 Neurocranium of Astatotilapia bloyeti; left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In species with true ocellar egg-dummies (e.g. the Haplochromis of Lake Victoria; see<tei:lb/>Greenwood, 1974a, especially plate I) the number of spots is reduced to modes of 3 or 4, the<tei:lb/>coloured centre of each spot is ovoid in outline, generally has a narrow black or dark border and<tei:lb/>is surrounded by a clear zone of fin membrane; other spots and markings on the fin are suppressed,<tei:lb/>although the greater part of the fin may have a coloured flush. The result is a most distinctive<tei:lb/>mark, with an illusion of three dimensionality, that is readily distinguished from any other fin<tei:lb/>or body markings.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are, of course, other kinds of anal marking which, in their appearance, size and distri-<tei:lb/>bution on the fin, are intermediate between the supposed plesiomorph type (numerous, non-<tei:lb/>ocellate spots) and the presumed apomorph kind described in the last paragraph. Their possible<tei:lb/>phylogenetic importance will become apparent when more information is available not only on<tei:lb/>their appearance in live animals, but also on their functional role in mate recognition, courtship<tei:lb/>and spawning.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For the moment one can assume that the ocellar spots represent the apomorph condition and<tei:lb/>that the multiple spot type of anal marking is the plesiomorph one. Those Haplochromis-\ike<tei:lb/>species apparently without any spatially or chromatically differentiated anal markings (e.g.<tei:lb/>Orthochromis malagaraziensis; Greenwood, 1954) provide a particular problem because we know<tei:lb/>nothing of their reproductive behaviour. Thus the absence of 'egg-dummies' cannot necessarily<tei:lb/>be construed as representing a plesiomorph condition in these species.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>276 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(vi) Vertebral numbers. The modal range of total vertebral counts (excluding the fused P<tei:lb/>urostylar element) is 27-29 (comprising 12-14 abdominal and 15 or 16 caudal centra). On the<tei:lb/>grounds of its being the modal number, it is taken to be the plesiomorph condition.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Apomorphic deviations occur amongst the Haplochromis species of Lake Victoria where a few<tei:lb/>species show a higher modal count (30-32); these are all long-bodied piscivorous predators and<tei:lb/>the increase in the number of vertebrae occurs in the caudal section of the column. Parenthetically,<tei:lb/>it may be noted that Lake Malawi Haplochromis species with more than 32 vertebrae also show<tei:lb/>an increase in the number of caudal elements.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The most marked increase in vertebral numbers (apart from that in some Malawi species) is<tei:lb/>found in the genus Serranochromis. Here the modal counts are 33 and 34 (abdominal modes<tei:lb/>16-17, caudal modes also 16 and 17), with an increase in the number of abdominal rather than<tei:lb/>the caudal elements as was the situation in the Victoria and Malawi Haplochromis species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A similar increase in the number of abdominal vertebrae is also found in the seven Zambezi<tei:lb/>species of so-called Haplochromis revised by Bell-Cross (1975). In these species there is, however,<tei:lb/>a reduction in the number of caudal vertebrae as compared both with Serranochromis and with<tei:lb/>the plesiomorphic Haplochromis condition (14 and 15 in the Zambezi species, 16 and 17 in the<tei:lb/>others). In consequence, the modal total count (29-32) for the Zambezi fishes overlaps that of<tei:lb/>the plesiomorph Haplochromis type.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For want of falsifying evidence, the Serranochromis and 'Zambezi Haplochromis' conditions<tei:lb/>are both considered to be apomorphic ones.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In some Haplochromis-like genera, certain species have low counts for caudal vertebrae, but<tei:lb/>modal ones for the abdominal elements (see p. 290); probably these taxa, in the phyletic context<tei:lb/>of their particular lineages (and for this particular character), should be considered derived<tei:lb/>(i.e. autapomorphic).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(v/7) Caudal fin skeleton. Vandewalle (1973) has provided a summary of the caudal fin skeleton<tei:lb/>in 108 cichlid species, mostly African. He shows that, overall, there is a remarkable constancy in<tei:lb/>this feature but that in some species individual hypural elements may fuse (especially hypural 1<tei:lb/>with 2, and 3 with 4; the fifth hypural is always free except in one species (see p. 292) - Vandewalle<tei:lb/>finds no instance of fusion between all hypurals).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>My own observations generally confirm those of Vandewalle, but strongly indicate that, with<tei:lb/>one possibly exceptional lineage (see p. 297), hypural fusion is an individual and not a specific<tei:lb/>or lineage trait. It is thus of very restricted value as an indicator of phyletic affinities, as is the<tei:lb/>organization of the whole caudal fin skeleton amongst the taxa examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(v//7) Number of dorsal and anal fin rays. Amongst the Haplochromis species and related taxa<tei:lb/>reviewed (see footnote p. 270) the modal numbers of dorsal fin rays are 15 and 16, and of branched<tei:lb/>rays 9 and 10. Except for obvious individual variants, and two species of Astatoreochromis, all<tei:lb/>these taxa have 3 spinous rays in the anal fin and, modally, 8 or 9 branched rays.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>If, on the principle of commonality, these numbers are taken to be the basic (i.e. plesiomorph)<tei:lb/>counts, then modal ray counts for either fin that are higher or lower should be considered derived<tei:lb/>features.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(/*) Gill rakers. There is a fairly narrow range of both gill raker numbers and shapes (counts and<tei:lb/>observations restricted to the outer row of gill rakers on the lower part of the first gill arch). In<tei:lb/>most species the rakers are relatively robust, simple structures (with sometimes the upper 2 or 3<tei:lb/>of the series flattened and bi-, tri- or even polyfid), of moderate length and numbering from 7 to<tei:lb/>12 (modal counts 8 and 9).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Materials</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All the BMNH material (spirit specimens, alizarin preparations, dry skeletons and radiographs)<tei:lb/>of all the taxa named in this paper has been examined, as have the Museum's collections of<tei:lb/>Haplochromis species from Lakes Victoria, Edward, George and Kivu, and selected specimens from<tei:lb/>the collection of Lake Malawi Haplochromis species and related genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT</tei:p>
         <tei:p>277</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In addition, the following specimens, borrowed from other institutions, have also been studied<tei:lb/>(and radiographed).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis albolabris (Holotype)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis angusticeps</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis bakongo (Paratypes)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis buysi (Holotype)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis darlingi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis fasciatus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis giardi (Holotype)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis luluae (Paratypes)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis oligacanthus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis polli (Paratypes)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis stappersi</tei:p>

         <tei:p>ANSP 54369-76<tei:lb/>RMAC 16945-947<tei:lb/>WHP1219<tei:lb/>AM/P2461<tei:lb/>RMAC 48407-4 15<tei:lb/>MHN A2754<tei:lb/>ANSP 5 1759-62<tei:lb/>RMAC 167930-931<tei:lb/>RMAC 99403-404<tei:lb/>RMAC uncatalogued<tei:lb/>RMAC 163991<tei:lb/>RMAC 1346<tei:lb/>IRSN 1809-1960<tei:lb/>AM/P951<tei:lb/>AM/P952<tei:lb/>AM/P1425-6<tei:lb/>AM/P1298<tei:lb/>ZMH402<tei:lb/>ZMH403</tei:p>
         <tei:p>AM/P, Albany Museum; ANSP, Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia; IRSN, Institut<tei:lb/>Royal des Sciences Naturelles de Belgique; H, Zoologisches Museum, Hamburg; MNH, Museum<tei:lb/>National d'Histoire Naturelle, Paris; RMAC, Musee Royal de 1'Afrique Centrale, Tervuren;<tei:lb/>WH, Windhoek Museum; ZMH, Zoologisches Museum, Berlin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Classification</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Applying the methodology and reasoning discussed above and in the Introduction, nine lineages,<tei:lb/>here given generic rank, may be recognized amongst the taxa studied. With the exception only of<tei:lb/>Chetia, each of these genera now contains species that were previously placed in Haplochromis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Unless indicated otherwise, all the genera have a cranial apophysis for the upper pharyngeal<tei:lb/>bones formed from the parasphenoid and basioccipital (see 'Haplochromis'' -type apophysis in<tei:lb/>Greenwood, 1978) and a caudal fin scaled on its proximal half or less.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All vertebral counts quoted exclude the fused PU! and Ui centra, and may thus be lower than<tei:lb/>those used by some other authors; abdominal vertebrae are identified as those bearing pleural<tei:lb/>ribs (including, of course, the first two vertebrae that have no ribs), and the caudal centra as<tei:lb/>those without ribs but, except occasionally the first (anterior) centrum, with a haemal arch.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Since the genus Haplochromis is now restricted to five species (see p. 280), difficulties arise<tei:lb/>when reference is made either to species formerly included in that genus, but which have not yet<tei:lb/>been assigned to other genera, or to the former concept of the genus Haplochromis. To avoid<tei:lb/>confusion, I have adopted the convention proposed and used by Patterson &amp; Rosen (1977 : 163)<tei:lb/>for dealing with such situations. Namely, to prefix the species name with its former generic name<tei:lb/>cited between quotation marks, i.e. 'Haplochromis' nigricans or '//' nigricans. When reference is<tei:lb/>made to the former concept of the genus the generic name alone, but in quotation marks, is used.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Lake Victoria 'Haplochromis' species will be reviewed in a paper now in preparation;<tei:lb/>until its publication these species can be referred to by using the old generic name in quotes. As<tei:lb/>a temporary expedient for general use until such times as the Lake Malawi 'Haplochromis' are<tei:lb/>revised, a purely formal generic name for these species is proposed on p. 317.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Species mentioned in this paper are listed in the index on p. 321 under their former generic<tei:lb/>names (usually Haplochromis}, with a reference first to the page on which they are listed in their<tei:lb/>new generic grouping, and secondly to the page on which that genus is described.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>278 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the generic descriptions, presumed apomorph (i.e. derived) character states are italicized.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The generic revision which follows is arranged in two parts. After redefining the genus Haplo-<tei:lb/>chromis Hilgendorf, 1888, the first section will deal with "Haplochromis" species from Lakes<tei:lb/>Turkana, Albert, Tanganyika and Mweru, and with those from the Nile and Zaire river drainage<tei:lb/>systems, and the rivers of Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genera Onhochromis Greenwood, 1954, and Astatoreochromis Pellegrin, 1903, will also be<tei:lb/>considered in this section of the paper.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The second section (p. 299) will be concerned with the genera Serranochromis Regan 1920 and<tei:lb/>Chetia Trewavas, 1961, together with those ' Haplochromis" species from the Zambesi, Limpopo<tei:lb/>and Angola river systems, which were thought to be related to Serranochromis and Chetia (see<tei:lb/>Trewavas, 1964).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Section I</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HAPLOCHROM1S Hilgendorf, 1888</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE SPECIES: Chromis (Haplochromis) obliquidens Hilgendorf, 1888 (type specimens in the<tei:lb/>Humboldt Museum, Berlin).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Description</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body relatively deep (depth 35-40% of standard length).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Squamation. Scales on the body below the lateral line, and behind a line through the pectoral<tei:lb/>and pelvic fin insertions, are ctenoid; those above the upper lateral line and on the head and<tei:lb/>chest are cycloid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The small scales on the chest grade imperceptibly in size with those on the ventrolateral and<tei:lb/>ventral aspects of the flanks (p. 270).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cheek and chest fully scaled.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lateral line with 29-34 scales (modal range 30-32) ; all but the last 3 or 4 scales of the upper<tei:lb/>lateral line are separated from the dorsal fin base by at least two scales of approximately equal<tei:lb/>size.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neurocranium. The skull is of a generalized type (see p. 274; Fig. 6, and Greenwood, 19740),<tei:lb/>its ethmovomerine region having only a slight downward slope, the dorsal surface of the vomer<tei:lb/>sloping in the same plane and at the same angle as the anterior part of the skull roof; the preotic<tei:lb/>part of the skull comprises some 55-60% of the total neurocranial length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vertebral numbers: 28-30 (modes 28 and 29), comprising 12-14 (mode 13) abdominal and<tei:lb/>15 or 16 caudal elements.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dentition. The outer teeth in both jaws are weakly bicuspid or unicuspid, the crown of the tooth<tei:lb/>compressed and noticeably expanded relative to its slender, cylindrical neck and body (Fig. 7). The<tei:lb/>major cusp in bicuspid teeth is very much larger than the minor one, which is often little more than<tei:lb/>a slight, obliquely truncated basal point on the posterior margin of the anteriorly protracted and<tei:lb/>slightly incurved (i.e. buccally directed) major cusp. The compressed, anteriorly protracted and<tei:lb/>dorsoventrally expanded major cusp gives to the tooth, be it bi- or unicuspid, the appearance of<tei:lb/>having an obliquely truncated crown. The tip of this cusp lies outside the vertical formed by the<tei:lb/>anterior margin of the tooth's body.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All outer teeth, save in some species for a few posterior teeth on the premaxilla, are moveably<tei:lb/>attached to the underlying bone.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In some species the posterior one to six teeth on the premaxilla are unicuspid or acutely<tei:lb/>bicuspid, and are stouter and larger than the others in that series; these posterior teeth in other<tei:lb/>species of the genus closely resemble, in size and cusp morphology, their anterior congeners.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Teeth forming the inner rows in both jaws mostly are small and tricuspid, but in some species<tei:lb/>the anterior and anterolateral teeth in the outermost row may be identical with those of the outer<tei:lb/>row. The inner teeth are arranged so as to form a tooth band that is wide anteriorly and antero-<tei:lb/>laterally, but narrow posterolaterally. This is effected by an increase in the tooth rows from the<tei:lb/>primitive state of two or three to the derived condition of from 4 to 6.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower jaw is relatively slender in lateral aspect and not noticeably deepened posteriorly; the<tei:lb/>length of its dentigerous surface is equal or about equal to the greatest depth of the dentary (as</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT</tei:p>
         <tei:p>279</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 7 Outer row jaw teeth (premaxillary) in various Haplochromis species;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>a. labial view, b. lateral (posterior) view. A. H. annectidens.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. H. obliquidens. C. H. Umax. D. H. astatodon.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>measured vertically from the posterior tip of its ascending coronoid process to the ventral margin<tei:lb/>of the bone).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower pharyngeal bone and dentition. The dentigerous surface of the bone is triangular and<tei:lb/>approximately equilateral in outline (Fig. 8). The teeth, except for those forming the posterior<tei:lb/>transverse row, are slender with the greater part of the cusp protracted and curved posteriorly<tei:lb/>so that most of the occlusal surface lies nearly parallel with the surface of the pharyngeal bone.<tei:lb/>(The absence of a distinctly coarser median series of teeth probably is a derived feature; see p. 273.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal fin with 14-16 (modes 15 and 16) spinous and 8-10 (mode 9) branched rays.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal fin with 3 spinous and 7-10 (mode 9) rays.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal fin skeleton without fusion between any of the hypural elements; none of the species<tei:lb/>reviewed here was examined by Vandewalle (1973).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal fin truncate or subtruncate, the posterior margin straight or weakly emarginate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pelvic fins with the first branched ray the longest.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal fin markings. True ocellar egg dummies (see p. 274), usually 3 or 4 in a single row, are<tei:lb/>present in adult males. Some females may have a similar number of small, non-ocellate spots<tei:lb/>present in the same position on the fin.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>280</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gill rakers are moderately slender, with 8-10 (mode 9), rarely 7, present on the outer row on<tei:lb/>the lower part of the first gill arch.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contained species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis obliquidens Hilgendorf, 1888 (Type species). Lake Victoria (see Greenwood, 19560).</tei:p>
