         <tei:p>Haplochromis lividus Greenwood, 1956. Lake Victoria (see Greenwood, 1956a).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis annectidens Trewavas, 1933. Lake Nabugabo (see Greenwood, 19656).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis Umax Trewavas, 1933. Lakes Edward and George (see Greenwood, 1973).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis astatodon (part) Regan, 1921. Lake Kivu. When reviewing this species 1 found<tei:lb/>that two distinct types of outer jaw dentition are represented amongst the 1 3 specimens and one<tei:lb/>skeleton on which Regan (192 la) based his original description of the species. That there are two<tei:lb/>types of teeth represented in this sample is implicit in Regan's comment that the dental morpho-<tei:lb/>logy of H. astatodon is annectant between that of H. obliquidens and the simple bicuspid tooth<tei:lb/>found in many of Lake Victoria ' Haplochromis' species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 8</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower pharyngeal bone of H. lividus. A. Occlusal view.<tei:lb/>B. Right lateral view (bone aligned vertically).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Six of the syntypical specimens (BMNH reg. nos 1906.9.6 : 124-129) have outer teeth re-<tei:lb/>markably like those of H. obliquidens. That is, the crown is obliquely truncate and greatly pro-<tei:lb/>duced (Fig. 7D), the neck and body fine, and the teeth are moveably implanted in the gum tissue.<tei:lb/>However, in these specimens a minute second cusp is present on many of the anterior and antero-<tei:lb/>lateral teeth, a condition seen only amongst some of the posterior teeth in H. obliquidens. These<tei:lb/>particular specimens of H. astatodon also resemble H. obliquidens in having many teeth in the<tei:lb/>outermost of the multiseriate inner rows enlarged and often obliquely cuspidate; the inner teeth,<tei:lb/>like those in H. obliquidens, being small and tricuspid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The pharyngeal dentition in those specimens is also like that in H. obliquidens, but the two<tei:lb/>species differ in certain morphometric features and thus would seem to represent distinct species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The eight other syntypical specimens of H. astatodon (BMNH reg. nos 1906.9.6:130-132;<tei:lb/>1977.5.2:1-4 (the material was originally under-registered, hence the lot registered in 1977)), and<tei:lb/>a skeleton (BMNH reg. no. 1906.9.6:133) have distinctly bicuspid teeth in which the major cusp,<tei:lb/>although somewhat obliquely truncate, is neither protracted nor expanded, nor is it markedly<tei:lb/>compressed; the minor cusp is not so greatly reduced as it is in the other syntypical specimens<tei:lb/>of H. astatodon, or in H. Umax, H. annectidens and H. obliquidens.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT 281</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The tooth form and dental arrangement in these aberrant syntypes does, however, approach<tei:lb/>closely that found in ' Haplochromis' nuchisquamulatus of Lake Victoria and '//'. aeneocolor of<tei:lb/>Lake George (see Greenwood, \956a and 1973 for the species respectively).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Because of this marked difference in dental morphology I am restricting the name 'astatodon'<tei:lb/>to the six syntypes (BMNH reg. nos 1906.9.6:124-129) with H. obliquidens-Yike teeth, and have<tei:lb/>selected specimen 1906.9.6:125 as the lectotype. The eight specimens with ' nuchisquamulatus' '-like<tei:lb/>teeth will be dealt with in a subsequent paper.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diagnosis and discussion</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The lineage here recognized as the genus Haplochromis is characterized by having obliquely<tei:lb/>truncate and protracted crowns to the outer jaw teeth, an increase in the number of rows of inner<tei:lb/>teeth in both jaws (some of these teeth also having obliquely truncate crowns), and all jaw teeth<tei:lb/>moveably articulated with the underlying bone. The species are also characterized by their fine<tei:lb/>lower pharyngeal teeth, and the presence of truly ocellar egg-dummies on the anal fin of adult<tei:lb/>males. In their gross morphology, and in most aspects of their osteology and anatomy (the<tei:lb/>greatly elongate intestine excepted), the species retain a generally unspecialized level of<tei:lb/>organization.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dental features similar to those of Haplochromis do occur in other African Cichlidae, for<tei:lb/>example Cyathochromis obliquidens Trewavas (1935) of Lake Malawi, but are associated with<tei:lb/>characters which indicate that these other taxa do not share a recent common ancestry with<tei:lb/>Haplochromis. Since all the taxa are grazers on epilithic or epiphytic algae their dental similarities<tei:lb/>must be considered the results of convergent evolutionary trends.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within the genus Haplochromis, H. obliquidens and H. astatodon have what appears to be the<tei:lb/>most specialized (i.e. derived) form of teeth, and H. Umax the least specialized teeth (see Fig. 7C).<tei:lb/>The common ancestor could well have been a species with a 'limax'-like dentition.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In a preliminary phyletic analysis of the Lake Victoria 'Haplochromis' species flock (Greenwood,<tei:lb/>1974a), '//'. nigricans was considered to be the sister species of H. lividus and H. obliquidens, and<tei:lb/>'H '. nuchisquamulatus the sister species of the other three species combined. My recent investi-<tei:lb/>gations now suggest, however, that '//.' nigricans (together with species from Lakes Edward,<tei:lb/>George and Kivu) form a distinct monophyletic lineage which cannot be related to Haplochromis<tei:lb/>(as here defined) on the basis of shared derived characters. Neither, on those grounds, can<tei:lb/>'//.' nuchisquamulatus be considered the sister group of Haplochromis, But, it cannot be denied<tei:lb/>that 'H.' nuchisquamulatus (and at least two other species, including the atypical H. astatodon<tei:lb/>noted above) do have a tooth morphology approaching that of Haplochromis (in particular<tei:lb/>H. Umax). Tooth form in these species is what might be expected as an early stage of differentia-<tei:lb/>tion from the primitive bicuspid type in a morphocline leading to the 'obliquidens' type. More<tei:lb/>research is needed before any possible relationship between the five Haplochromis species and<tei:lb/>the '//.' nuchisquamulatus complex can be clarified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ASTATOTILAPIA Pellegrin, 1903</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE SPECIES: Labrus desfontainii Lacepede, 1803 (type specimens, once in the Paris Museum but<tei:lb/>now apparently lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Description</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body relatively deep (35-40% of standard length).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Squamation. Over most of the body the scales are ctenoid, the ctenii generally strong and<tei:lb/>extending around the greater part of the scale's free margin ; scales above the upper lateral line<tei:lb/>may be less strongly ctenoid than those below it, and in three species are partly or entirely cycloid.<tei:lb/>Scales on the nape and cheek are cycloid, as may be those on the chest, which is always com-<tei:lb/>pletely scaled.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The chest scales show a gradual size transition with those on the ventral and ventrolateral<tei:lb/>aspects of the flanks (see Fig. 1); in some species the chest scales are not noticeably small, but in<tei:lb/>A. flaviijosephi, A. dolorosa and A. desfontainesi these scales are distinctly smaller (and in<tei:lb/>A. calliptera somewhat smaller) than are the chest scales in other species of the genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>282 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The cheek is fully scaled, usually with 3 (less commonly 2 or 4) horizontal scale rows.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The lateral line has from 28 to 30 scales (31-33 in A. desfontainesi), all but the last 1 to 4 scales<tei:lb/>of the upper lateral line separated from the dorsal fin base by two or more scales of approxi-<tei:lb/>mately equal size. Astatotilapia swynnertoni is exceptional in having the last 6-8 scales of the<tei:lb/>upper lateral line separated by less than two scales of equal size.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neurocranium. The skull is of the generalized haplochromine type (see Greenwood, 1974a:<tei:lb/>58-59, and p. 274 above). The preotic portion of the skull is not protracted (comprising some<tei:lb/>55-60% of the neurocranial length), and the ethmovomerine region is short, sloping upwards at a<tei:lb/>slight angle. The dorsal skull roof may be straight or very slightly convex anterodorsal to the<tei:lb/>orbit. The supraoccipital crest is not reduced in length; its anterior border continues the line<tei:lb/>formed by the dorsal surface of the ethmovomerine region and the orbital part of the skull roof.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The ventral apophysis for the upper pharyngeal bones (see p. 274) is slightly enlarged in one<tei:lb/>species (A.flaviijosephi). The otic region of the skull is relatively deep, and is not inflated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vertebral numbers: 27-30, rarely 26 (modes 28 and 29), comprising 12-14 (mode 13) abdominal<tei:lb/>and 14-16 (mode 15) caudal elements. The apophysis for the retractor dor sails pharyngeal muscles<tei:lb/>is small, and situated on the third vertebra.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dentition. In fishes less than 70 mm standard length unequally bicuspid teeth (Fig. 4) pre-<tei:lb/>dominate in the outer row of both jaws. The crown in these teeth is not noticeably compressed,<tei:lb/>neither is it clearly demarcated from the neck of the tooth (cf. Haplochromis, p. 278). Except in<tei:lb/>two species, the cusps are acutely pointed and both lie within the verticals formed by the anterior<tei:lb/>and posterior margins of the tooth's body; in A. calliptera and A. swynnertoni, however, at least<tei:lb/>the major cusp is somewhat obliquely truncate. Unlike Haplochromis, the outer teeth in Astato-<tei:lb/>tilapia are firmly attached to the bone.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Even in specimens less than 70 mm SL some weakly bicuspid teeth and some unicuspids are<tei:lb/>found in both jaws. In larger specimens the unicuspid type predominates. The proportion of<tei:lb/>uni- to bicuspid teeth increases with the size of the individual; A. dolorosa, known only from the<tei:lb/>holotype, a fish 95 mm SL, has only unicuspid teeth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All species, and specimens of all sizes, have the posterior 3-12 teeth in the premaxilla enlarged<tei:lb/>and unicuspid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Teeth forming the inner rows are generally tricuspid and small; some weakly bicuspid or even<tei:lb/>unicuspid teeth may occur in these rows, particularly in larger fishes. There are 1-3 (usually 2)<tei:lb/>rows of teeth anteriorly and anterolaterally in both jaws, a single row posteriorly and postero-<tei:lb/>laterally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower jaw is not foreshortened, nor is it noticeably deepened posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower pharyngeal bone and dentition. The dentigerous surface is apparently equilateral in all<tei:lb/>species. Except in A.flaviijosephi, all the teeth are compressed, slender and cuspidate, with only<tei:lb/>those teeth in the two median and the posterior transverse row somewhat coarser than the others.<tei:lb/>Cusp form is essentially similar to that in Haplochromis but the crown is not so markedly pro-<tei:lb/>duced as in that genus (cf. p. 279 above). In A.flaviijosephi, the teeth forming the median rows<tei:lb/>are enlarged, with molariform or submolariform crowns; some teeth in the lateral rows also are<tei:lb/>somewhat enlarged and have submolariform crowns. The lower pharyngeal bone, as compared<tei:lb/>with that in the other species, is stouter.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal fin with 14-16 (mode 15), rarely 13, spinous rays and 8-11 (modes 9 and 10) branched<tei:lb/>rays.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal fin with 3 spinous and 7-10 (modes 8 and 9) branched rays; specimens of A. desfontainesi<tei:lb/>with 4 spines have been recorded.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal 'fin skeleton. Astatotilapia burtoni (1 specimens radiographed) and A. nubila (9 specimens)<tei:lb/>show no hypural fusion, but the other 7 species all yielded certain individuals with some degree<tei:lb/>of fusion in either the upper or the lower set of hypurals, or far less frequently, in both sets.<tei:lb/>It must be stressed, however, that these observations were made principally from radiographs and<tei:lb/>that these can be difficult to interpret with accuracy if the hypurals are closely apposed to one<tei:lb/>another. Vandewalle (1973) reports no fusion in the two specimens of A. burtoni he examined.<tei:lb/>(It is not possible to tell from his paper whether these were radiographed or dissected specimens.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal fin strongly subtruncate to rounded.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT 283</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pelvic fin with the first branched ray longest.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal fin markings in male fishes. True ocellar markings are present, usually 2-4 in number<tei:lb/>(but as many as 9 in large specimens of some species) arranged in one or less commonly in two<tei:lb/>rows, the number of rows positively correlated with the number of ocelli and the size of the<tei:lb/>specimen. The row or rows of ocelli run along a line situated approximately midway between<tei:lb/>the base and the distal margin of the fin. This linear arrangement (and that in Haplochromis}<tei:lb/>contrasts strongly with the near random arrangement of the anal spots in Serranochromis and<tei:lb/>Chetia (see pp. 302 and 308 respectively).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No information is available on the occurrence of anal spots (not ocelli, see p. 275) in the females<tei:lb/>of Astatotilapia species, except that 3 or 4 linearly arranged spots do occur in A. nubila from<tei:lb/>Lakes Victoria and George. Trewavas (1973), however, records seeing ripe female A. nubila and<tei:lb/>A. bloyeti with male-type ocelli on the anal fin, a phenomenon I never encountered when working<tei:lb/>with these species in the field.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Where breeding habits are known, Astatotilapia species are female mouthbrooders. Indeed,<tei:lb/>A. burtoni is the species on which Wickler (19626) developed his dummy-egg theory to explain<tei:lb/>the function of anal ocelli in spawning.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gill rakers of various shapes, from short and stout to moderately long and slender; 8 or 9, less<tei:lb/>commonly 7, in the outer row on the lower part of the first gill arch.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contained species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Astatotilapia desfontainesi (Lacep.) 1803 (Type species)*; as restricted by Regan (19220) to</tei:p>
         <tei:p>specimens from Tunisia and Algeria.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Astatotilapia flaviijosephi (Lortet), 1883. Israel and Syria. See Trewavas (1942) and Werner<tei:lb/>(1976) for redescription and biology.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Astatotilapia bloyeti (Sauv.), 1883. The type specimens are from Kandoa (Great Ruaha system),<tei:lb/>Tanzania. Regan (\922a) included three other species in the synonymy of A. bloyeti, viz.<tei:lb/>Ctenochromis strigigena Pfeffer, 1 893, Tilapia sparsidens Hilgendorf, 1903 and Paratilapia kilossana<tei:lb/>Steindachner, 1916. For the purposes of this revision I have accepted Regan's synonymy, but<tei:lb/>much more research is needed into the alpha level taxonomy of fluviatile haplochromine cichlids<tei:lb/>in eastern and southern Africa before the species can be defined adequately. 1 have examined<tei:lb/>material from many localities in Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania, and also from Lake Chad and<tei:lb/>the Upper Niger. This material would seem to represent a taxon closely similar, if not identical,<tei:lb/>to A. bloyeti, at least on anatomical and morphometric characters. However, judging from colour<tei:lb/>notes made on certain specimens from Tanzania there are strong indications that at least some<tei:lb/>populations are distinguishable on the basis of male coloration.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>An apparently undescribed species recently distributed by the aquarium trade under the name<tei:lb/>'Nigerian mouthbrooder' or 'Nigerian H. burtoni' probably should be included in the A. bloyeti<tei:lb/>complex, as should an undescribed species from the Malagarasi river (personal observations).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Until the necessary revision of these 'species' and populations has been carried out, the different<tei:lb/>taxa involved can be referred to as the 'A. bloyeti complex' (see Greenwood, 1971). Its distribution<tei:lb/>includes rivers, streams and certain lakes in Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Nigeria and, probably<tei:lb/>the Nile.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Astatotilapia nubila (Blgr.), 1906. Lakes Victoria, Kioga, Edward, George, Nabugabo, Kachira,<tei:lb/>Nakavali and Kijanebalola, and river systems in Uganda which are connected with these lakes<tei:lb/>(see Trewavas, 1933; Greenwood, 19656 and 1973). The species has been widely distributed in<tei:lb/>Uganda (and possibly Kenya and Tanzania as well) as a result of fishfarming and dam stocking<tei:lb/>activities; its natural distribution is that listed in the first sentence.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Astatotilapia dolorosa (Trewavas), 1933. Known only from the holotype, a specimen collected<tei:lb/>from the Chambura river which flows into the Kazinga channel connecting Lakes Edward and<tei:lb/>George.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>* The emended spelling of the trivial name, \lesjontainesi\ was first used by Boulenger (1899). Since Lacepede<tei:lb/>intended that the species be named for M. Desfontaines, Boulenger's emendation, although not explained, would<tei:lb/>seem to be justified.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>284 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Astatotilapia burtoni (Gunther), 1893. Lake Tanganyika and rivers associated with that lake<tei:lb/>(see Poll, 1956). The specimens recorded from Lake Kivu by Boulenger (1915) were misidentifi-<tei:lb/>cations (see Regan, 192 la).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Astatotilapia stappersi (Poll), 1943. Rivers associated with Lake Tanganyika, see Poll (1956).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Astatotilapia swynnertoni (Blgr.) 1907. Lower Buzi river, Mozambique.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Astatotilapia calliptera (Gunther), 1893. Lakes Malawi and Chilwa; '. . . coastal rivers as far<tei:lb/>as the Save river, Mocambique' (Bell-Cross, 1976); Busi and lower Sabi-Lundi systems; Lower<tei:lb/>Zambezi and Pungwe systems.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Jubb (1967a) treats A. swynnertoni as a synonym of this species, but gives no reason for so<tei:lb/>doing. Judging from the material I have examined, I would consider the two species to be distinct.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Incertae sedis: Chetia brevis Jubb, 1968. The presence of 3 or 4 true ocellar markings on the anal<tei:lb/>fin would seem to exclude this species from the genus Chetia (see p. 307 below, and p. 274 above),<tei:lb/>as would the predominance of ctenoid over cycloid scales on the body, and the retention of<tei:lb/>bicuspid teeth as the predominant tooth form in specimens as large as 90 mm standard length<tei:lb/>(see p. 273).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The inclusion of Chetia brevis in Astatotilapia is, however, very tentative and may well be<tei:lb/>altered when the phylogeny and systematics of the 'Angolan Haplochromis' species are revised<tei:lb/>(see p. 312).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diagnosis and discussion</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genus Astatotilapia is distinguished from the other fluviatile ' Haplochromis' group species by<tei:lb/>the following combination of characters : male anal fin markings are true ocelli, large and usually<tei:lb/>numbering from 3 to 6, and are arranged in a single or, less frequently, a double row (the number<tei:lb/>of ocelli and hence the number of rows correlated positively with the size of the fish); scales on<tei:lb/>the chest region not sharply size-demarcated from those on the ventrolateral and ventral aspects<tei:lb/>of the body; chest and cheek fully scaled; most body scales are ctenoid, the ctenii on each scale<tei:lb/>not restricted to a narrow median arc on the scale's free margin but distributed along almost the<tei:lb/>entire free margin ; most teeth in the outer row of both jaws are bicuspid, the cusps of unequal<tei:lb/>size, but the minor one never minute. The major cusp is acute or, rarely, somewhat obliquely<tei:lb/>truncate but not protracted (cf. Figs 4 and 7). A few stout unicuspid teeth occur posteriorly in<tei:lb/>the premaxilla of fishes at all sizes, and some may also be present anteriorly, in both jaws, of<tei:lb/>fishes &gt; 80 mm SL ; the inner teeth usually are tricuspid (occasionally some are weakly bicuspid<tei:lb/>or unicuspid) and are arranged in two rows anteriorly and anterolaterally; 27-30 (rarely 26)<tei:lb/>vertebrae, of which 12-14 (mode 13) are abdominal, and 14-16 (mode 15) are caudal elements;<tei:lb/>pelvic fin with the first branched ray the longest.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Apart from the ocellar anal fin markings, none of these characters can be considered derived,<tei:lb/>and the anal ocelli are an apomorphic feature shared with Haplochromis and most, if not all<tei:lb/>' Haplochromis'' species from Lakes Victoria, Edward, George and Kivu, and some species from<tei:lb/>Lake Malawi as well. Thus, the possibility cannot be overruled that Astatotilapia is a non-<tei:lb/>monophyletic assemblage.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The absence of other synapomorphic features shared with the genera described in this paper<tei:lb/>at least indicates that no members of Astatotilapia are closely related to any one of those lineages<tei:lb/>(as was implied when, hitherto, most were placed in the genus Haplochromis).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The relationship of Astatotilapia to Haplochromis as now redefined is obscure. Both lineages<tei:lb/>share the apomorphic feature of anal ocelli, suggesting that both share a more recent common<tei:lb/>ancestry than either lineage does with any taxa not having this feature. Uncertainty also exists<tei:lb/>about the relationship between Astatotilapia and the anal ocelli-bearing lineages of Lakes Victoria,<tei:lb/>Edward, George and Kivu, and for that matter some of the anatomically generalized 'Haplo-<tei:lb/>chromis' species of Lake Malawi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Any member of the Astatotilapia line with acutely bicuspid teeth (except, because of its speciali-<tei:lb/>zed pharyngeal mill, A. flaviijosephi) could, on purely morphological grounds, be taken to<tei:lb/>represent the ancestral species for many lineages within the Victoria-Edward-Kivu species flock<tei:lb/>(see Greenwood, 1974a). It is, indeed, likely that a number of generalized but endemic species<tei:lb/>from that flock will have to be included in Astatotilapia, as may some from Lake Malawi.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT 285</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Relationships within the Astatotilapia lineage cannot be indicated at present, partly because no<tei:lb/>intragroup synapomorphies are apparent and partly because the species are as yet poorly defined<tei:lb/>and understood (see p. 283).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Astatotilapia, like Thoracochromis (see p. 290) has a wide geographical distribution (one, indeed<tei:lb/>that extends beyond Africa into the Middle East). Both genera occur in north Africa, although<tei:lb/>Astatotilapia does not apparently occur in the Nile drainage (except in Lakes Victoria and Kioga) ;<tei:lb/>Thoracochromis, on the other hand, is widely distributed in the Nile system but is poorly represen-<tei:lb/>ted, if at all, in Lake Victoria, and does not extend so far into southern Africa as does Astatotilapia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In general, it could be said that Astatotilapia is a lineage of eastern and southern Africa, with<tei:lb/>outliers in the northeast (A.flaviijosephi) and northwest (Algeria and Tunisia), and Thoracochromis<tei:lb/>a lineage of north, central and western Africa. Since the phyletic integrity of both lineages is<tei:lb/>uncertain (see above, and p. 294), and because large parts of the Zaire system are poorly known,<tei:lb/>this difference may be more artefactual than real.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ASTATOREOCHROMIS Pellegrin, 1903</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE SPECIES: Astatoreochromis alluaudi Pellegrin, 1903 (type specimens in the Paris Musuem).<tei:lb/>For synonymy see Greenwood (19590) and discussion below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Discussion</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pellegrin (1903) distinguished Astatoreochromis (then monotypic) from similar ' Haplochromis' -<tei:lb/>group species and genera principally on its having 5 or 6 anal and 18 or 19 dorsal fin spines. The<tei:lb/>type species is from Lake Victoria, but later, specimens were collected from Lakes Edward and<tei:lb/>George, the Victoria Nile and Lakes Kioga, Nakavali and Kachira (see Greenwood, 19590).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Redescriptions based on this enhanced material added to the number of diagnostic features,<tei:lb/>at least with respect to the ' Haplochromis' species of Lakes Edward and Victoria (Greenwood,<tei:lb/>19590). Amongst those features are the rounded caudal fin, the high number and multiserial<tei:lb/>arrangement (3 or 4 rows) of the anal ocelli in male fishes, the unusual coloration (golden over-<tei:lb/>lain with olivaceous green, the median fins olive-yellow, flushed with maroon and margined with<tei:lb/>black), and the lack of sexual dimorphism in basic body and fin colours. This material also ex-<tei:lb/>tended the known range of dorsal fin spine numbers (16-20) as well as those of the anal fin (4-6).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The species Astatoreochromis alluaudi is further characterized by its strongly hypertrophied<tei:lb/>crushing pharyngeal dentition and bones (with a correlated hypertrophy of the cranial apophysis<tei:lb/>for the upper pharyngeal bones; see Greenwood, 19590 and 19650). A similar degree of pharyn-<tei:lb/>geal hypertrophy does, of course, occur in at least five other species from Lakes Victoria, Edward<tei:lb/>and George (Greenwood, 1960 : 270-279; 1973 : 172-177 ; Greenwood &amp; Barel, 1978 : 164-179),<tei:lb/>but these species differ from A. alluaudi in several features, all of which suggest that A. alluaudi<tei:lb/>represents a distinct phyletic lineage.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The principal diagnostic characters for Astatoreochromis are not easily assessed on a basis of<tei:lb/>their apo- or plesiomorphy. The enlarged pharyngeal mill clearly is a derived feature, but is one<tei:lb/>that has evolved independently in at least two ' Haplochromis' lineages (see Greenwood, 19740,<tei:lb/>and p. 279 above) ; it is thus of little value in assessing relationships at the level with which we<tei:lb/>are here concerned.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As yet too little is known about the evolution and phyletic distribution of anal ocelli (and other<tei:lb/>anal fin markings) to say whether the increased number and multiserial arrangement in Astatoreo-<tei:lb/>chromis is a derived feature. The basis for comparison here is with the fewer ocelli and their uni-<tei:lb/>or biserial arrangement in Haplochromis, Astatotilapia and the Lake Victoria ' 'Haplochromis'<tei:lb/>species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The absence of sexually dimorphic coloration in Astatoreochromis is a most unusual feature<tei:lb/>amongst 'Haplochromis' -like taxa, but would seem, a priori, to be a primitive rather than a derived<tei:lb/>feature (although its correlation with the increased number of anal ocelli and thus, possibly its<tei:lb/>degree of relative importance in breeding behaviour, cannot be interpreted without appropriate<tei:lb/>ethological studies).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Only the increased number of anal and dorsal fin spines (but, it should be noted, not the total<tei:lb/>number of rays in these fins) would seem to be derived features.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>286 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the absence of other and synapomorphic characters, however, it is impossible to use fin<tei:lb/>spines numbers to suggest any possible close phyletic affinities for Astatoreochromis. For example,<tei:lb/>the squamation pattern in the genus is of the supposedly plesiomorph type, and this would seem<tei:lb/>to rule out any possible relationship with the Orthochromis lineage (see p. 295) in which there is<tei:lb/>also a marked trend towards increased numbers of dorsal and anal fin spines. Orthochromis, it<tei:lb/>may be added, does not have anal ocelli or, apparently, any other anal fin markings in the males<tei:lb/>(the breeding habits of no Orthochromis species are recorded).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>That Astatoreochromis may be related (possibly as the derived sister-group) to some of the<tei:lb/>'Haplochromis' species with enlarged pharyngeal mills, cannot be completely discounted; but,<tei:lb/>equally there is little unequivocal evidence to support such an hypothesis (see above).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For the moment, then, Astatoreochromis is maintained as a distinct lineage because of its<tei:lb/>various distinctive features, taken in combination, and because its sister-group relationship to<tei:lb/>any other lineage cannot be hypothesised on the basis of uniquely shared derived characters.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Recently, Poll (1974) added a second species (Haplochromis straeleni Poll, 1944, from the<tei:lb/>Lukuga and Ruzizi rivers, Zaire) to the genus Astatoreochromis. This step was taken because some<tei:lb/>specimens of straeleni have 4 anal spines (i.e. 2 of the 7 specimens known), because of close<tei:lb/>similarities in overall coloration and in the pattern and number of anal ocelli, and because<tei:lb/>straeleni has a relatively enlarged lower pharyngeal bone with some molariform teeth (see fig. 1 ,<tei:lb/>Poll, 1974). The species also has, as compared with Astatotilapia and the Lake Victoria 'Haplo-<tei:lb/>chromis'' species, more dorsal fin spines (17 or 18) but the same number of branched rays in that<tei:lb/>fin (8 or 9); in other words, the Astatoreochromis condition (see above). Furthermore, according<tei:lb/>to Poll's account, there is no sexually dimorphic coloration in '//.' straeleni.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There is another ' Haplochromis' species, '//'. vanderhorsti Greenwood, 1954 (Malagarasi river,<tei:lb/>Tanzania) which closely resembles straeleni in all the characters under consideration, differing<tei:lb/>only in its slightly lower dorsal fin spine count (16 or 17), and in none of the 54 specimens exa-<tei:lb/>mined having 4 anal fin spines; its lower pharyngeal bone and dentition are more massive than<tei:lb/>those of straeleni (i.e. like the condition in A. alluaudi of the same size). The resemblances between<tei:lb/>'//.' vanderhorsti and A. alluaudi, and those between '//.' straeleni and '//.' vanderhorsti have been<tei:lb/>noted already (Greenwood, 1954 : 405-407; \959a : 166-167), but were not analysed in terms of<tei:lb/>their apo- or plesiomorphy, and no conclusion was reached about the interrelationships of the<tei:lb/>species or their formal taxonomic status.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Apart from the increased number of dorsal fin spines (and the four-spined individuals of<tei:lb/>'//.' straeleni), the only other shared, and probably derived, characteristic common to the three<tei:lb/>species is the enlarged lower pharyngeal bone and its at least partly molariform teeth (again a<tei:lb/>trend character, least developed in straeleni, most developed in Astatoreochromis alluaudi, and<tei:lb/>one which is known to have evolved independently in several haplochromine lineages). But,<tei:lb/>taking into account the virtually identical, non-sexually dichromatic coloration of the three<tei:lb/>species (and the ubiquity of sexual dichromatism alongst fluviatile haplochromines) the most<tei:lb/>parsimonious solution would be to consider alluaudi, straeleni and vanderhorsti as being more<tei:lb/>closely related to one another than any one of them is to any other lineage.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>On these grounds I would agree with Poll's (1974) inclusion of'//.' straeleni in Astatoreochromis<tei:lb/>and would now include '//.' vanderhorsti in that genus as well.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contained species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Astatoreochromis alluaudi Pellegrin, 1903 (Type species). Lakes Victoria, Kioga, Edward, George,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nabugabo, Kachira, and Nakavali; rivers and streams associated with these lakes. The species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>has been widely distributed in Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania as a biological control agent against</tei:p>
         <tei:p>snails (McMahon, Highton &amp; Marshall, 1977). For a full description of the species see Greenwood</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(1959a), and for evidence invalidating the two subspecies described in that paper see Greenwood</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(19650).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Astatoreochromis straeleni (Poll), 1944. Lukuga and Ruzizi rivers, Lake Tanganyika drainage.<tei:lb/>See Poll (1974) for a redescription of the species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Astatoreochromis vanderhorsti (Greenwood) 1954. Malagarasi river and swamps, Lake<tei:lb/>Tanganyika drainage.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT</tei:p>
         <tei:p>287</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CTENOCHROMIS Pfeffer, 1 893</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE SPECIES: Ctenochromis pectoralis Pfeffer, 1893 (type specimens in Hamburg Museum and<tei:lb/>BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Description</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body relatively deep to relatively slender (depth 30-40 % of standard length).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Squamation. Scales on the body below the upper lateral line are strongly to moderately ctenoid<tei:lb/>(weakly ctenoid in one species, C. horii}, becoming cycloid over the posterior half of the body.<tei:lb/>Scales above the upper lateral line show the same range of ctenoidy or are all cycloid, the kind<tei:lb/>of scale being constant intraspecifically and positively correlated with those below the lateral line.<tei:lb/>Scales on the head and, when present, on the cheek, are cycloid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3mm<tei:lb/>Fig. 9 Thoracic-abdominal scale transition in Ctenochromis pectoralis. Left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The cheek always has a naked area along its ventral margin; in one species this area is less than a<tei:lb/>scale row in depth, in two others it is from 1 to 3 horizontal scale rows deep, and in a fourth virtually<tei:lb/>the whole cheek is naked, a few scales remaining immediately below and, or, behind the orbit.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Along or slightly behind a line joining the pectoral and pelvic fin bases there is an abrupt size<tei:lb/>transition between the very small scales on the chest and the much larger scales on the lateral and<tei:lb/>ventrolateral aspects of the body (Fig. 9).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The chest has a well circumscribed naked patch on each side of the body (Fig. 9), the two patches<tei:lb/>joined in some species by a ventral naked area. The size of the naked patch shows some interspecific<tei:lb/>variability, from a small and ventrolaterally situated area, to one covering most of the lateral and<tei:lb/>ventrolateral (but not the medial) aspects of the chest.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are 27-33 scales in the lateral line series (modal numbers 30 and 31 for the two species<tei:lb/>from Tanzania, and 28-30 for the three Zaire river system species (see p. 290 below)) ; the last 8-12<tei:lb/>(usually 8 or 9) pored scales in the upper lateral line are separated from the dorsal fin base by less<tei:lb/>than two scales of approximately equal size.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neurocranium. The neurocranium is apparently of the generalized type (see Fig. 6), but in at<tei:lb/>least one species (C. horii; Fig. 10) its preotic region is more elongate (c. 68-70% of neurocranial<tei:lb/>length) and in others the preorbital region is slightly vaulted. Since little skeletal material is<tei:lb/>available these remarks are based mainly on radiographs and should be checked on actual<tei:lb/>skeletons.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>288 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vertebral numbers: 25-29 (modal range 27-28), comprising 12 or 13 abdominal and 13-17<tei:lb/>caudal elements (see p. 290 below).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dentition. The outer teeth are unequally bicuspid, or, in two species, subequally bicuspid, are<tei:lb/>relatively stout and firmly attached to the underlying bone. Some posterior premaxillary teeth (as<tei:lb/>many as 16 on each side in C. horii) are unicuspid, caniniform and relatively larger than the pre-<tei:lb/>ceding bicuspids. The crowns of the bicuspid teeth are not noticeably compressed, nor are they<tei:lb/>sharply demarcated from the shaft of the tooth; the cusps are acutely pointed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The inner teeth are small and tricuspid, and arranged in 2 or 3 series anteriorly and antero-<tei:lb/>laterally, but a single series posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 10 Neurocranium of Ctenochromis horii; left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower jaw. The dentary is relatively slender in lateral aspect, and not greatly deepened<tei:lb/>posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower pharyngeal bone and teeth. The dentigerous surface is either triangular and subequilateral<tei:lb/>(slightly broader than long) in outline, or noticeably broader than long (c. 1 times; Fig. 1 1). The<tei:lb/>teeth are cuspidate and compressed, those in the median and the posterior transverse row some-<tei:lb/>what stouter than the others (the degree of stoutness, especially of teeth in the two median rows,<tei:lb/>shows a positive correlation with the fish's size).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal fin with 14-17 (modes 15 and 16) spinous and 8-10 (mode 9) branched rays. The holo-<tei:lb/>type of C. oligacanthus (Regan) has only 12 spines, but all other specimens have 15.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal fin skeleton. Because few dry skeletons or alizarin preparations are available, informa-<tei:lb/>tion on the caudal skeleton has been obtained mainly from radiographs. The difficulty of differen-<tei:lb/>tiating between fused and closely apposed hypural elements as seen in radiographs makes these<tei:lb/>observations of limited value.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ctenochromis pectoralis (10 specimens radiographed) has all five hypurals free.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. horii. Seven specimens (radiographed) have hypurals 1 and 2, and 3 and 4 fused, as does<tei:lb/>the dry skeleton examined. Two other specimens (radiographed) have hypurals 1 and 2 free, but<tei:lb/>3 and 4 fused. Vandewalle (1973) found no fused hypurals in the two specimens he examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. polli (2 specimens radiographed) has all hypurals free.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. oligacanthus. Of the three specimens radiographed, one (the holotype) has all hypurals free,<tei:lb/>one has hypurals 1 and 2 free but 3 and 4 fused, and the third has hypurals 1 and 2, and 3 and 4<tei:lb/>fused.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal fin is markedly subtruncate, almost rounded in some species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pelvic fin with the first branched ray the longest.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal fin markings in male fishes. Where known (3 of the 5 species) from preserved and, or, living<tei:lb/>specimens, these are in the form of one or two (rarely three) brilliant white or yellow spots, with-<tei:lb/>out a dark margin and without a clear surround (cf. Haplochromis and Astatotilapia, p. 279 and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT</tei:p>
         <tei:p>289</tei:p>
         <tei:p>p. 283 respectively). The spot or spots may be on the anterior or the posterior part of the soft<tei:lb/>fin with, apparently, their position constant intraspecifically. For a colour picture of C. polli see<tei:lb/>Voss (1977 : 74).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gill rakers short and stout in all species except C. horii where they are long and slender ; there<tei:lb/>are 7-9 rakers in the outer row on the first gill arch, except in C. horii where there are 10-13.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contained species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ctenochromis pectoralis Pfeffer, 1893 (Type species). Known only from streams in south eastern</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tanzania, near Korogwe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 11 Lower pharyngeal bone of Ctenochromis polli. A. Occlusal view.<tei:lb/>B. Right lateral view (bone aligned vertically).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ctenochromis horii (Giinther), 1893. Lake Tanganyika and the coastal reaches of associated<tei:lb/>rivers. See Poll (1956) for a detailed description and notes on biology.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ctenochromis polli (Thys van den Audenaerde), 1964. Pool Molebo (Stanley Pool) and the<tei:lb/>lower Zaire river. For coloured plate see Voss (1977). For notes regarding specimens formerly<tei:lb/>identified as H.fasciatus see p. 293.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ctenochromis oligacanthus (Regan) 1922. Ubangi river, an affluent of the Zaire river. The holo-<tei:lb/>type and sole specimen available to Regan has only 12 dorsal fin spines and 9 branched rays; the<tei:lb/>two additional specimens I have examined have 1 5 spines and 9 branched rays.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ctenochromis luluae (Fowler), 1931. Lulua river, Kasai drainage system, lower Zaire. I have<tei:lb/>examined four paratypes, and on the basis of that material would consider the species to be dis-<tei:lb/>tinct from C. polli and C. oligacanthus (the other two Ctenochromis from the lower Zaire drainage),<tei:lb/>and from C. pectoralis and C. horii.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diagnosis and discussion</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Members of the genus Ctenochromis are characterized by the abrupt size transition between the<tei:lb/>very small chest scales and the larger scales on the ventrolateral aspects of the anterior flanks, by<tei:lb/>a naked area on either side of the chest, and by a failure of the cheek squamation to reach the<tei:lb/>ventral margin of the cheek. (In one species, C. horii, the entire suborbital region of the cheek<tei:lb/>is scaleless in some individuals and in others there is, at most, no more than a single scale row<tei:lb/>below and behind the orbit.) In three of the five species the anal fin markings of male fishes are<tei:lb/>in the form of one or two (rarely three), relatively small and simple, non-ocellate spots ; no infor-<tei:lb/>mation is available on the other two species.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>290 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Virtually nothing is known about the biology of Ctenochromis species, which are, with the<tei:lb/>exception of C. horii, very poorly represented in study collections. Four of the five species are<tei:lb/>fluviatile and reach a small adult size (80 mm standard length); their feeding and breeding habits<tei:lb/>are unknown. The fifth species, C. horii, is essentially lacustrine, reaches a larger adult size<tei:lb/>(185 mm SL) and is at least partly piscivorous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The geographical range of Ctenochromis extends from Tanzania in the east to the Zaire drainage<tei:lb/>(including Lake Tanganyika) in the west and lies between the latitudinal limits of c. 3 N and 8 S.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Various apomorph features shown by Ctenochromis suggest its relationships with two other<tei:lb/>genera; this problem will be discussed later (see p. 313).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Intrageneric relationships are difficult to determine, partly because the small size of some<tei:lb/>specimens limited the amount of anatomical information that could be obtained, partly because of<tei:lb/>the mosaic interspecific distribution of certain presumed apomorph characters, and partly because<tei:lb/>other characters form part of a morphoclinal continuum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$oth C. pectoralis (eastern Tanzania) and C. horii (Lake Tanganyika) have, relative to C. polli<tei:lb/>and C. oligacanthus, higher caudal vertebral counts (15-17, modes 16 and 17, cf. 13 and 14) and<tei:lb/>higher lateral line scale counts (29-33, modes 30 and 31, cf. 27-29, mode 28); these features<tei:lb/>should probably be considered plesiomorph ones (see p. 276 ). Ctenochromis pectoralis has relative-<tei:lb/>ly small naked patches on the chest (Fig. 9), and only the lower part of the cheek is scaleless.<tei:lb/>In comparison, C. horii has a large naked area on the chest and almost the entire cheek is without<tei:lb/>scales; the neurocranium in this species departs somewhat from the basic type found in C. pectora-<tei:lb/>lis (see Fig. 10 and p. 287) in having larger preorbital and preotic proportions, and individuals<tei:lb/>reach a larger size than in C. pectoralis. On these grounds I would consider C. horii to be the<tei:lb/>derived sister species of C. pectoralis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ctenochromis polli (Stanley Pool and the lower Zaire river) and C. oligacanthus (Ubangi river,<tei:lb/>Zaire drainage) both have a reduced number of caudal vertebrae (13 or 14), fewer lateral line<tei:lb/>scales (27-29) and fewer branched anal fin rays (6 or 7 cf. 8 or 9 in C. pectoralis; C. horii with 7<tei:lb/>(mode) or 8 anal rays occupies an intermediate position).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The third lower Zaire species, Ctenochromis luluae (Lulua river), however, also has an inter-<tei:lb/>mediate number of anal fin rays (7 or 8, mode 8), of lateral line scales (28-30) and of caudal<tei:lb/>vertebrae (15).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The outer jaw teeth in C. polli, C. luluae and C. oligacanthus are similar and differ from the<tei:lb/>basic, unequally bicuspid type found in C. horii and C. pectoralis in having the cusps subequal in<tei:lb/>size, with the tip of the smaller cusp directed away from the near vertical larger cusp. In both<tei:lb/>C. polli and C. oligacanthus the dentigerous surface of the lower pharyngeal bone is noticeably<tei:lb/>broader than long, whereas in C. pectoralis and C. horii its length and breadth are approximately<tei:lb/>equal (see Fig. 11); the bone in C. luluae has proportions that are intermediate between these<tei:lb/>two types. Finally, the naked area of the chest in C. oligacanthus is much larger than in C. polli,<tei:lb/>but a greater area of the cheek is scaled in the former species. Most of the cheek is scaled in<tei:lb/>C. luluae, and the naked chest area is intermediate between that of C. polli and C. oligacanthus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>On the basis of their dental morphology I would suggest that C. polli, C. luluae and C. oliga-<tei:lb/>canthus together form the sister group to C. pectoralis and C. horii; C. pectoralis would seem to<tei:lb/>be the least derived taxon of the lineage.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As a postscript to this discussion it may be mentioned (with the reservations noted on p. 282)<tei:lb/>that hypural fusions in Ctenochromis species are relatively common, and certainly commoner<tei:lb/>than in Haplochromis, Astatotilapia and the ' Haplochromis' species of Lake Victoria (see p. 276<tei:lb/>above, and Greenwood, 19746 : 159).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>THORACOCHROMIS gen. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE SPECIES: Paratilapia wingatii Boulenger, 1902 (see Greenwood, 1971 for a redescription of<tei:lb/>the species).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ETYMOLOGY. The name is derived from the latinized Greek word for a breastplate + chromis, a<tei:lb/>name when used in such a combination now associated with many genera of African Cichlidae;</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT 291</tei:p>
         <tei:p>it refers to the small and clearly size-demarcated scales on the thoracic region of species in this<tei:lb/>lineage.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Description</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body form ranging from relatively deep to relatively slender (depth 30-40% of standard length).<tei:lb/>Squamation. In the majority of species, the scales on the body above and below the upper<tei:lb/>lateral line, and behind a line through the pectoral and pelvic fin insertions, are ctenoid. A few<tei:lb/>species have cycloid scales above the upper lateral line, and weakly ctenoid scales below it. Scales<tei:lb/>on the cheek, head and chest are cycloid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The scales on the chest are small to very small and meet, with an abrupt change in size, the larger<tei:lb/>scales on the lateral and ventrolateral aspects of the flanks (Fig. 2). Generally the line of this<tei:lb/>abrupt size change lies approximately between the insertions of the pectoral and pelvic fins, but<tei:lb/>may be a little behind or, less frequently, a little before that level. The chest is always completely<tei:lb/>scaled, although in two species the scales are so small and deeply embedded that the area appears<tei:lb/>to be naked.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The cheek is completely or almost completely scaled (in two species there is a very narrow,<tei:lb/>horizontal naked strip along the ventral margin, and in several other species there is a naked<tei:lb/>embayment at the anteroventral angle of the cheek squamation).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are 29-32 (modal range 30-32) scales in the lateral line series; about the last eight pore-<tei:lb/>bearing scales of the upper lateral line are separated from the dorsal fin base by not more than one<tei:lb/>large and one much smaller scale.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neurocranium. Most Thoracochromis species have a skull form that departs but slightly from<tei:lb/>the type found in Ctenochromis (see p. 287). That is, a generalized type (see p. 274) in which the<tei:lb/>preotic region of the neurocranium comprises some 65-70 % of the total neurocranial length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The most marked departure from this skull form is seen in two species, Th. bullatus (Lake<tei:lb/>Albert) which has a greatly inflated otic capsule and somewhat enlarged lateral line sensory<tei:lb/>canals, and Th. macconneli (Lake Turkana) where the sensory canals are hypertrophied and the<tei:lb/>braincase is shallower.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thoracochromis demeusii (Zaire) deviates in a different way; here the supraoccipital crest is<tei:lb/>deepened, extends further anteriorly than in the other species and has a steeper slope to its<tei:lb/>anterior margin. These features may all be associated with the pronounced dermal hump develop-<tei:lb/>ed in the nuchal region of this species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vertebral numbers: 26-31 (modes 28 and 29), comprising 12-14 (modes 12 and 13) abdominal<tei:lb/>and 13-17 (modes 14 and 17) caudal elements. With one exception (Th. moeruensis) the lower<tei:lb/>modal counts for caudal vertebrae are found in fluviatile species from the Zaire river drainage<tei:lb/>system, the higher ones in species from Lakes Turkana, Albert, George and Mweru.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dentition. Unequally bicuspid or unicuspid, caniniform outer teeth are the the most frequently<tei:lb/>occurring types. The crown in bicuspids is not noticeably compressed, and the cusps are acutely<tei:lb/>pointed. Unicuspid teeth may be recurved or almost straight; where the material covers a suffi-<tei:lb/>ciently wide size range of specimens it shows that the unicuspid dentition is preceded by a bicuspid<tei:lb/>one. Fishes in all species with a bicuspid definitive dentition have a few (1-6) unicuspids pos-<tei:lb/>teriorly on the premaxilla, these teeth generally being larger than the anterior bicuspids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In two species (Th. fasciatus and Th. loati} the outer teeth, although unequally bicuspid, have<tei:lb/>the major cusp obliquely truncate, somewhat protracted and relatively compressed; the minor<tei:lb/>cusp is much reduced and is also obliquely truncate. Thus there is a close resemblance between<tei:lb/>these teeth and those in Haplochromis lividus and H. Umax (see Fig. 7C and p. 281 above; also<tei:lb/>Greenwood, 1971 : 360, fig. 5).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The inner teeth generally are tricuspid and in both jaws are arranged in 2 or 3 series anteriorly<tei:lb/>and laterally, but in a single series posteriorly. In those species with unicuspid outer teeth at least<tei:lb/>the outermost row of the inner series contains some unicuspids, a mixture of tri- and unicuspids,<tei:lb/>or it may be composed entirely of unicuspids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower jaw relatively slender in lateral outline and not obviously deepened posteriorly.<tei:lb/>Lower pharyngeal bone and teeth. With respect to the outline shape of the dentigerous area,<tei:lb/>two fairly distinct types of pharyngeal bone occur in this genus. One type (found in species of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>292</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the Zaire drainage, including Th. moeruensis but excluding 77?. demeusii) has the surface clearly<tei:lb/>broader than long (Fig. 12). The second type (in species from Lakes Turkana, Albert and George)<tei:lb/>has its dentigerous surface only slightly broader than long, i.e. about 1 \ times.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In all species the median tooth rows are noticeably coarser than their lateral congeners, and<tei:lb/>are even coarser than those in the posterior transverse row. Some species have stout and molari-<tei:lb/>form or submolariform teeth in the median rows, and in three other species (77?. albertianus,<tei:lb/>Th. mahagiensis and Th. pharyngalis) teeth lateral to the median rows are also enlarged and<tei:lb/>submolariform to molariform, (see Trewavas, 1938 : 441 and 444; Poll, 1939 : 47; Greenwood,<tei:lb/>1973 : 213). Associated with this enlargement of the dentition (especially in Th. mahagiensis and<tei:lb/>TV/, pharyngalis) the lower pharyngeal bone is markedly thickened.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 12 Lower pharyngeal bone of Thoracochromis bakongo. A. Occlusal view.<tei:lb/>B. Right lateral view (bone aligned vertically).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Teeth other than the enlarged ones are compressed and cuspidate in all species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal fin with 13-16 (modal range 14-16), rarely 17, spinous and 8-10 (modes 9 and 10),<tei:lb/>rarely 1 1 , branched rays.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal fin with 3 spines and 6-10 (modal range 7-9) branched rays.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal fin skeleton : the distribution of fused hypural elements amongst Thoracochromis<tei:lb/>species, as determined mainly from radiographs, is as follows:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(i) Lake Albert species, and those from the Nile and Lake George: no fusion in Th. wingatii<tei:lb/>(holotype), 77?. albertianus (6 specimens), 77?. mahagiensis (1), 77?. avium (holotype), Th. bullatus<tei:lb/>(13), 77?. loati (16) and Th. petronius (12); some specimens in most species have certain hypurals<tei:lb/>very closely apposed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(ii) Lake Turkana. 77?. rudolfianus has all hypurals free in 28 specimens examined, but hypurals<tei:lb/>1 and 2 are closely apposed or perhaps fused in two others; 77?. turkanae (4 specimens) has all<tei:lb/>hypurals free; in 77?. macconneli 6 of the 26 specimens examined have all hypurals free, 4 have<tei:lb/>hypurals 1 and 2, and 4 and 5 fused, 1 1 have hypurals 1 and 2, and 3 and 4 fused, but hypural<tei:lb/>5 free, and 5 have only hypurals 1 and 2 fused.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(iii) Lower Zaire drainage, and Lake Mweru. Th. moeruensis has hypurals 1 and 2, and 3 and 4<tei:lb/>fused (6 specimens). 77?. demeusii (holotype) has all free; Th.fasciatis (6 syntypes) has all free, as<tei:lb/>does 77?. bakongo (3 specimens); Th. stigmatogenys has 2 specimens with hypurals 3 and 4 fused,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT 293</tei:p>
         <tei:p>and 4 others with all hypurals free. Vandewalle (1973) reports no fusion in the two species he<tei:lb/>examined, namely, Th. bakongo and Th.fasciatus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal fin subtruncate to almost rounded, most species being in the latter category.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pelvic fin with the first branched ray the longest.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal fin markings. Regrettably little information is available on this character, either from live<tei:lb/>or preserved specimens. True ocellar spots (3-8 in number) are present in Th. petronius (Lake<tei:lb/>George) and apparently in the three species from Lake Turkana, although the clear surround in<tei:lb/>these latter species is much narrower than in the ocelli of Haplochromis and Astatotilapia. The<tei:lb/>four species from Lake Albert and the Nile for which data are available (i.e. Th. albertianus,<tei:lb/>Th. bullatus, Th. wingatii and Th. loati) do not appear to have any clear area around the small,<tei:lb/>coloured or white spots, which are relatively large, well defined and number from 1 to 3. However,<tei:lb/>these observations were made on preserved material only and, since the whole fin is somewhat<tei:lb/>pigmented, a narrow hyaline surround could well be overlooked.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No information is available for the remaining species (Lake Mweru and the Zaire river<tei:lb/>drainage).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gill rakers are of various shapes, with 6-12 (modal range 7-9) in the outer row on the first gill<tei:lb/>arch.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contained species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thoracochromis wingatii (Blgr.), 1902, type species; see Greenwood (1971) for a redescription and</tei:p>
         <tei:p>definition of the species. Upper Nile (Bahr-el-Jebel) and probably Lake Albert also.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thoracochromis loati (Greenwood), 1971. Upper Nile (Bahr-el-Jebel) and Lake Albert.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thoracochromis rudolfianus (Trewavas), 1933. Lake Turkana.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thoracochromis turkanae (Greenwood), 1974. Lake Turkana.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thoracochromis macconneli (Greenwood), 1974. Lake Turkana.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>See Greenwood (19746) for notes on the biology of the last three species, and for comments<tei:lb/>on their relationships.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thoracochromis albertianus (Regan), 1929. Lake Albert.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thoracochromis mahagiensis (David &amp; Poll), 1937. Lake Albert (see also Greenwood, 1971 :<tei:lb/>356).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thoracochromis avium (Regan), 1929. Lake Albert. I follow Trewavas (1938) in considering<tei:lb/>Haplochromis lanceolatus David &amp; Poll, 1937, a synonym of this species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thoracochromis petronius (Greenwood), 1973. Lake George, Uganda.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thoracochromis pharyngalis (Poll), 1939. Lake Edward. See Greenwood (1973 : 213) for a dis-<tei:lb/>cussion on the relationship of this species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thoracochromis moeruensis (Blgr.), 1899. Lake Mweru.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thoracochromis demeusii (Blgr.), 1899. Lower Zaire river. See Thys van den Audenaerde (1964)<tei:lb/>for a redescription of the species and for other data; this author considers that the presumed type<tei:lb/>locality (Bangala country, Upper Congo) is in error.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thoracochromis bakongo (Thys van den Audenaerde), 1964. Kasai drainage to the lower Zaire<tei:lb/>river.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thoracochromis fasciatus (Perugia), 1892. Lower Zaire drainage at Vivi (538' S, 1330' E; see<tei:lb/>Thys van den Audenaerde, 1964). At present I am restricting the concept of this species to the<tei:lb/>six syntypical specimens in the BMNH collections (reg. nos 1898.12.12:1-6). Certain other speci-<tei:lb/>mens in the BMNH collections identified as fasciatus, and at least part of the material on which<tei:lb/>Thys van den Audenaerde (1964) based his redescription of the species, are referable to one or<tei:lb/>possibly two other species. These, or this, species differ from the syntypes of fasciatus in dental<tei:lb/>characters and in having a graded rather than an abrupt size change between the chest and ventro-<tei:lb/>lateral flank scales (i.e. they cannot be referred to the genus Thoracochromis; see p. 291 above).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Three further specimens in the BMNH collections (reg. nos 1899.9.6:2-4, ex Stanley Pool)<tei:lb/>which were included in fasciatus by Boulenger (1915 : 215-216) do, however, show an abrupt<tei:lb/>size change in the scales of this region. All 3 specimens are now in a very poor state of preservation<tei:lb/>but, judging from certain morphometric characters and also from their dental morphology, it<tei:lb/>seems that they should be identified as Ctenochromis polli (see p. 289).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>294 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Regan (1922a) tentatively included Paratilapia toddi Blgr., 1905 (Kasai river, Zaire drainage) in<tei:lb/>the synonymy offasciatus. Regan's concept offasciatus was essentially that of Boulenger (1915)<tei:lb/>since his study material included the misidentified specimens noted above. The only known<tei:lb/>specimen of Paratilapia toddi, the holotype, is considerably larger (127-0 mm SL) than any<tei:lb/>member of a known Thoracochromis species, and has the general facies and external cranial<tei:lb/>morphology of a Serranochromis-like fish (see Trewavas (1964) who, indeed, thought that P. toddi<tei:lb/>might be related to Serranochromis). However, the holotype of P. toddi does show an abrupt size<tei:lb/>transition between the scales of the chest and flanks, and it also has a low number of caudal<tei:lb/>vertebrae (13) and a low branched anal fin ray count (7), features shared with some species of<tei:lb/>Thoracochromis (see p. 291 above). On the other hand, there are several features of P. toddi that<tei:lb/>are not encountered in any member of that genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Until more specimens are available it would seem best to treat P. toddi as a taxon incertae sedis;<tei:lb/>it certainly cannot be considered a synonym of Thoracochromis fasciatus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thys van den Audenaerde (1964) considers Boulenger 's (1899) Chromis monteiri (from Boma)<tei:lb/>to be a synonym of fasciatus. Regrettably the holotype (and unique) specimen of C. monteiri<tei:lb/>cannot now be found and so a comparison between it and the syntypes of Th. fasciatus could not<tei:lb/>be made. But, judging from Boulenger's original description and figure, it seems highly improbable<tei:lb/>that the specimens are from the same species. The possibility that monteiri holotype and some of<tei:lb/>the misidentified fasciatus material are conspecific cannot, however, be overlooked.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diagnosis and discussion</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Members of the genus Thoracochromis are characterized by the abrupt size transition between<tei:lb/>the small chest scales and the much larger scales on the ventrolateral and ventral aspects of the<tei:lb/>flanks. This is, apparently, the only derived character shared by all members of the lineage.<tei:lb/>Several other derived features are, however, found in member species. For example, the obliquely<tei:lb/>truncate tooth cusps in Th. loati and Th. fasciatus, the enlarged pharyngeal mills in 77?. mahagiensis,<tei:lb/>Th. albertianus and Th. pharyngalis, the bullate otic region in 777. bullatus, the hypertrophied<tei:lb/>cephalic lateral line canals in Th. macconneli (and probably its near-dwarf males as well; see<tei:lb/>Greenwood, 19746) and, finally, the short but broad lower pharyngeal bone in most species from<tei:lb/>the lower Zaire system. But, the restricted distribution of these apomorphic characters amongst<tei:lb/>the species obliges one to rank them either as autapomorphies or as low level synapomorphies<tei:lb/>suggesting possible intrageneric relationship (if, in the latter case, it can be shown that the<tei:lb/>characters have not evolved independently, an impossible task when there are no other features<tei:lb/>on which to establish intrageneric relationships).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Even the single synapomorphy used to define the lineage as a whole, the abrupt thoracic-<tei:lb/>flank scale size transition, is shared with Ctenochromis (p. 287) and Orthochromis (p. 296 below).<tei:lb/>The two latter lineages, however, have each their own derived features which can be interpreted<tei:lb/>as indicators of their monophyletic origin and thus their phyletic distinctiveness.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The possible interrelationships of Thoracochromis, Ctenochromis and Orthochromis are con-<tei:lb/>sidered later (p. 313).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thoracochromis has a wide but disjunct geographical distribution. In the north there are three<tei:lb/>species endemic to Lake Turkana, and two others in the Nile, both of which also occur with the<tei:lb/>three endemic species in Lake Albert. There is one species in Lake George, another in Lake Edward<tei:lb/>(with the possibility that the George species also occurs in Edward) and possibly a third in Lake<tei:lb/>Victoria.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Much further south (and a little to the west) there is one species in Lake Mweru, and a group<tei:lb/>of five species apparently confined to the lower Zaire drainage.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>From an historical viewpoint (Greenwood, 19746) the species of the Nile, Lake Turkana and<tei:lb/>Lake Albert could well be closely related and could also be related to the species from Lakes<tei:lb/>Edward and George. Indeed, 77?. mahagiensis (Lake Albert) and 777. pharyngalis (Lake Edward)<tei:lb/>have three apparently derived characters in common, viz. hypertrophied pharyngeal mills, a low<tei:lb/>number of gill rakers (as compared with other species from Lake Albert) and a reduced cheek<tei:lb/>squamation; and again, 777. bullatus (Lake Albert) and 77?. macconneli (Lake Turkana) both have</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT 295</tei:p>
         <tei:p>hypertrophied cranial lateral line systems, although in this instance, since both species live in deep<tei:lb/>waters, the resemblance could be the result of parallel evolution.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The lower Zaire species, with the exception of Th. demeusii, have distinctly broad and short<tei:lb/>lower pharyngeal bones (that of Th. demeusii is but slightly broader than long and resembles the<tei:lb/>bone found in all other Thoracochromis species). Thoracochromis moeruensis, a geographically<tei:lb/>isolated Zairean species from Lake Mweru, also has a short and broad lower pharyngeal bone,<tei:lb/>suggesting its possible relationship with the lower Zaire species group (perhaps, geographically<tei:lb/>speaking, through some past linkage via the Kasai drainage system).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>More collecting in the Zaire river system, especially its middle reaches, and more information<tei:lb/>about the northern (i.e. Nile, Turkana, Albert) species is needed before any of these suggested<tei:lb/>intralineage groups can be developed further, and indeed before the phyletic integrity of the whole<tei:lb/>lineage can be tested adequately. Data on live coloration, anal fin markings and cranial osteology<tei:lb/>are particularly needed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The absence, save for two or possibly three species of Thoracochromis from the Lake Victoria-<tei:lb/>Edward-George-Kivu cichlid flock (totalling some 200 species), is of particular zoogeographical<tei:lb/>interest, especially when it is recalled that in Lakes Turkana and Albert species of Thoracochromis<tei:lb/>are the only 'Haplochromis' -group taxa represented. Likewise one may note the predominance of<tei:lb/>Thoracochromis, Ctenochromis and Orthochromis species in the Zaire river system.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ORTHOCHROM1S Greenwood, 1954</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE SPECIES: Haplochromis malagaraziensis David, 1937 (type specimens in the Musee Royal de<tei:lb/>1'Afrique Centrale, Tervuren).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synonymy</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rheohaplochromis Thys van den Audenaerde, D. F. E. (1963), Revue Zool. Bot. afr. 68, 1-2 : 145<tei:lb/>(as a subgenus of Haplochromis); idem (1964), Revue Zool. Bot. afr. 70, 1-2 : 169 (raised to<tei:lb/>generic rank). No type species by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>When discussing the affinities of Rheohaplochromis, Thys van den Audenaerde (1964: 169)<tei:lb/>mentions my observations (in Un.} that the genus showed strong affinities with Orthochromis.<tei:lb/>Although agreeing with my remarks, Thys van den Audenaerde considered that '. . . Pecaillure<tei:lb/>nuchale et ventrale vraiment miniscule des Rheohaplochromis (polyacanthus et torrent/cola) nous<tei:lb/>semble un caractere suffisamment important pour maintenir ces especes dans un genre separe . . .'.<tei:lb/>I would argue that the suite of derived characters shared by these species and the two other species<tei:lb/>discussed below (including O. malagaraziensis} are a stronger argument in favour of their in-<tei:lb/>clusion in a single lineage of presumed monophyletic origin (i.e. within the scope of this revision,<tei:lb/>a genus see p. 269 above).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thys van den Audenaerde's supplementary argument for placing the species polyacanthus and<tei:lb/>torrenticola together in a separate genus (because of their overlap in distribution as compared<tei:lb/>with the allopatric distribution of the other Zaire haplochromine species) might well be used to<tei:lb/>explain the presence of derived features shared only by polyacanthus and torrenticola, but it<tei:lb/>seems to have little bearing on the problem of determining their overall phyletic relationships.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In an earlier paper, Thys van den Audenaerde (1963) considered that the small ventral and<tei:lb/>nuchal scales, and the rounded pelvic fins, of polyacanthus and torrenticola could be ecopheno-<tei:lb/>typic features associated with their rheophilic habits. In support of his contention he mentions<tei:lb/>similar features in Steatocranus, an unrelated taxon (see Greenwood, 1978). This argument of<tei:lb/>ecophenotypically evolved characters could also be used to explain the similar scale and fin<tei:lb/>characters in the two other species I would include in the same lineage as polyacanthus and<tei:lb/>torrenticola. But, to me, it would seem more parsimonious to conclude that, although the features<tei:lb/>possibly have selective advantage in a torrential habitat, their association in a number of species<tei:lb/>sharing other derived features is more likely to be indicative of common ancestry than of repeated<tei:lb/>parallel evolution. Since Steatocranus may well be a member of a much more distantly related<tei:lb/>branching within the African Cichlidae (see Greenwood, 1978), the similarity in scale and fin</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>296 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>organization in that instance would, I agree, be the result of convergence (and thus indicative<tei:lb/>of the characters having adaptive value in that type of habitat).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Description</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body elongate and slender (its depth 25-30% of standard length); dorsal head profile strongly</tei:p>
         <tei:p>decurved, eyes generally suprolateral in position, giving the fish a somewhat goby-like appearance.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Squamation. Scales on the head and on the body above the upper lateral line are cycloid or<tei:lb/>weakly ctenoid, or cycloid over the anterior third of the upper body and ctenoid over the posterior<tei:lb/>two-thirds. Scales below the upper lateral line are ctenoid except on the chest and belly, where<tei:lb/>they are cycloid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The chest is naked or scaled (if the latter there is sometimes a small naked area on one or both<tei:lb/>sides of the body); the chest scales, when present, are very small, as are the scales on the ventral<tei:lb/>and ventrolateral body surface as far posteriorly as the anus (Fig. 3).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The small ventral body scales have an abrupt size transition with the moderatley larger scales on<tei:lb/>the ventrolateral aspects of the flanks. When the entire chest is scaled, the small scales of that<tei:lb/>region extend posteriorly beyond a line joining the pectoral and pelvic fin insertions (Fig. 3). There is<tei:lb/>also a sharply defined size difference between the larger ventrolateral body scales and the small<tei:lb/>thoracic ones, the line of size demarcation curving gently in a posteroventral direction to merge with<tei:lb/>the demarcation line separating the belly and ventrolateral flank scales (Fig. 3). In effect, the corslet<tei:lb/>of small scales covering the chest trails backwards to the anus (cf. Ctenochromis and Thoracochromis<tei:lb/>where the corslet is confined to an area anterior to the pelvic-pectoral fin insertions). Even when<tei:lb/>the major part of the chest is naked, there is a patch of small scales between and somewhat<tei:lb/>posterior to a line through the pelvic and pectoral fin insertions; as in the other species, these<tei:lb/>small scales are sharply demarcated from the larger ones on the flank.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The nuchal scales in two species (O. polyacanthus and O. torrenticold) are very small and deeply<tei:lb/>embedded.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are 30-35 (modal range 30-32) scales in the lateral line, all the pore-bearing scales of the<tei:lb/>upper lateral line being separated from the dorsal fin base by not more than one large and one small<tei:lb/>scale (cf. Ctenochromis and Thoracochromis where only the last few scales of the upper lateral<tei:lb/>line are separated from the dorsal fin by less than two scales of equal size).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The cheek is naked or, if scaled, has a distinct naked area along its entire ventral border; in<tei:lb/>some individuals with otherwise naked cheeks, a few irregularly arranged scales may occur<tei:lb/>posterodorsally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neurocranium. The skull in Orthochromis differs from the generalized type in having a relatively<tei:lb/>low and short supraoccipital crest, and in having the skull roof anterior to the supraoccipital crest<tei:lb/>gently rounded (not concave or flat as is the generalized skull) ; the entire neurocranium is relatively<tei:lb/>narrow, most noticeably in the interorbital region, and the preorbital skull profile slopes downwards<tei:lb/>at a steep angle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vertebral numbers: 27-30 (modal range 28-30), comprising 12 or 13 (mode 13) abdominal and<tei:lb/>14-17 (mode 17) caudal elements.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dentition. The outer teeth in both jaws are either bicuspids (generally with the shaft of the tooth<tei:lb/>curved buccally) or slender unicuspids (in which case small fish have bicuspid teeth). Some slender<tei:lb/>unicuspids are present posteriorly in the premaxilla of all species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Inner row teeth are small and tricuspid (with some unicuspids present when the teeth of the<tei:lb/>outer row are predominantly unicuspids), are arranged in 2 or 3 series anteriorly and laterally,<tei:lb/>and in a single row posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower jaw appears foreshortened in lateral view because its posterior region (angulo-articular bone<tei:lb/>and the cor onoid process of the dentary) are deepened relative to the generalized condition seen,<tei:lb/>for example in Astatotilapia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower pharyngeal bone and dentition. The dentigerous surface of the lower pharyngeal bone is<tei:lb/>somewhat broader than it is long (c. 1 times), but is not sufficiently broad to give the bone an<tei:lb/>overall short and broad appearance. The teeth are compressed and cuspidate, those of the two<tei:lb/>median rows showing some interspecific variation in form, from not as coarse or slightly coarser</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT 297</tei:p>
         <tei:p>than the lateral teeth, to being markedly coarser; teeth forming the posterior transverse row are<tei:lb/>coarse (but cuspidate) in all species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal fin with 16-20 (modes 17 and 18) spinous and 9-1 1 (modes 9 and 10) branched rays.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal fin with 3 or, in one species, 4 spines, and 7-10 branched rays.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal fin skeleton. The occurrence of fused hypural elements (as determined from radio-<tei:lb/>graphs, and in the case of O. malagaraziensis an alizarin preparation) is as follows : in O. mala-<tei:lb/>garaziensis (7 specimens, including 1 paratype), O. polyacanthus (11) and O. machadoi (2),<tei:lb/>hypurals 1 and 2, and 3 and 4 are fused, but in O. torrenticola (2) none is fused although all are<tei:lb/>closely apposed to one another in each half of the skeleton. Vandewalle (1973) records no fusion<tei:lb/>in the specimen of O. torrenticola he examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal fin is moderately to strongly subtruncate (almost rounded).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pelvic fin with the second, or the second and third branched rays the longest, thus giving the fin a<tei:lb/>rounded rather than an acute distal margin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal fin markings in male fishes. No discrete, egg-dummy-like markings have been described for<tei:lb/>any Orthochromis species, nor are any visible in the preserved material examined ; certainly none<tei:lb/>was visible in the live specimens of O. malagaraziensis I examined (Greenwood, 1954). In some<tei:lb/>species the fin is without any form of maculate colour pattern so that if egg-dummies were present<tei:lb/>they should be visible. Orthochromis torrenticola does have a maculate anal fin (the spots arranged<tei:lb/>in oblique rows) and Thys van den Audenaerde (1963) reports that males have more densely<tei:lb/>spotted fins that do females.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Observations on live O. malagaraziensis suggest that sexually dimorphic coloration in that<tei:lb/>species may be confined to differences in the colour of the lips, anal fin, and branchiostegal<tei:lb/>membrane (Greenwood, 1954).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gill rakers relatively slender but short, 6-9 (modes 7 and 8) in the outer row on the lower part<tei:lb/>of the first gill arch.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contained species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Orthochromis malagaraziensis (David), 1937. Malagarasi river (Burundi and Tanzania); see</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Greenwood (1954) for a redescription of the species and notes on its biology.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Orthochromis polyacanthus (Blgr.), 1899. Lake Mweru, Upper Zaire river (Stanley Falls and<tei:lb/>Stanleyville, and certain affluent rivers (see Thys van den Audenaerde, 1963)). I have, for the<tei:lb/>moment, accepted Regan's (19220) synonymy of Boulenger's (1902) Tilapia stormsi with this<tei:lb/>species; however, a review of material in the BMNH suggests that Regan's opinion may not be<tei:lb/>correct.</tei:p>
