         <tei:p>Orthochromis torrenticola (Thys van den Audenaerde), 1963. Lufira river (Upper Zaire river<tei:lb/>drainage).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Orthochromis machadoi (Poll), 1967. Cunene river, Angola.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diagnosis and discussion</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Members of the genus Orthochromis are characterized, principally, by the abrupt size change<tei:lb/>between the large scales on the ventrolateral aspects of the flanks and the small scales of the chest<tei:lb/>and belly, by the curved and posteroventrally directed line of size demarcation between these scales,<tei:lb/>and the union of this line with that separating the very small scales on the belly from the larger<tei:lb/>scales on the flanks, see Fig. 3. The very small belly scales, extending backwards to the anus,<tei:lb/>are another characteristic feature. Also characteristic (when taken in combination with those<tei:lb/>characters listed above) is the absence or extensive reduction of the cheek squamation, the<tei:lb/>posteriorly deepened lower jaw, the increased number of spinous rays in the dorsal fin (without a<tei:lb/>corresponding reduction in the number of branched rays, this comparison being based on the<tei:lb/>modal counts for branched rays in Ctenochromis and Thoracochromis], the elongate second or<tei:lb/>second and third branched rays in the pelvic fin and, apparently, the absence of egg-dummy-like<tei:lb/>markings on the anal fin of adult males.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Other diagnostic features are reviewed on pp. 295-296 above; the high frequency of hypural<tei:lb/>fusion, affecting both the upper and lower halves of the caudal fin skeleton, is particularly note-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>298 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>worthy but requires confirmation from larger samples and the use of skeletal rather than radio-<tei:lb/>graphed material.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The absence of egg-dummy-like markings on the anal fin also requires confirmation from<tei:lb/>observations made on live specimens (their absence in O. malagaraziensis, however, seems<tei:lb/>certain; Greenwood (1954)). This is a most unusual feature amongst 'Haplochromis' -group<tei:lb/>species, and may imply that the courtship and breeding habits of Orthochromis species are also<tei:lb/>unusual for the group. Until something is known about these habits in Orthochromis it is impossible<tei:lb/>to determine whether the absence of egg-dummies is to be considered a primitive or a derived<tei:lb/>feature for the genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I am unable to demonstrate any clear-cut interspecific relationships within the Orthochromis<tei:lb/>lineage. Orthochromis machadoi (Cunene river) is probably the least derived member. It has a<tei:lb/>partly scaled cheek, the chest is either entirely scaled or, as in one specimen, it can have a small<tei:lb/>scaleless area unilaterally, the ventral (belly) body scales are relatively large and, finally, in its<tei:lb/>general facies the species has not fully achieved the elongate goby-like body form seen in the other<tei:lb/>species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In his original description of O. machadoi, Poll (1967) argues that the species is closely related<tei:lb/>to Pseudocrenilabrus philander (Weber) an opinion I cannot accept (especially since Poll's views<tei:lb/>are, it seems, largely based on supposed similarities in coloration). Anatomically, and with regard<tei:lb/>to their squamation patterns, the taxa are quite distinct.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The preserved colours of O. machadoi, on the other hand, are like those of O. malagaraziensis.<tei:lb/>Both species have all the body scales (except on the chest and belly) narrowly outlined in black,<tei:lb/>giving the body an overall 'diamond-mesh pattern; they also have a distinctive and vertically<tei:lb/>elongate dark blotch at the base of the caudal fin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In O. torrenticola this diamond-mesh pattern is very faint but general over the body, whereas<tei:lb/>in O. polyacanthus it is restricted to a pair of narrow bands, one situated midlaterally, the other<tei:lb/>following the upper lateral line. Orthochromis torrenticola retains the caudal spot which is lost in<tei:lb/>O. polyacanthus. Both species have the body crossed by several closely spaced vertical bands. The<tei:lb/>apo- or plesiomorph states of these colour patterns cannot be determined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Orthochromis torrenticola and O. polyacanthus have minute scales on the dorsal surface of the<tei:lb/>head and nuchal region (in O. machadoi and O. malagaraziensis these scales are only slightly<tei:lb/>smaller than those on the dorsal body surface), and the scales on the thoracic region are relatively<tei:lb/>smaller than in the other two species, especially O. machadoi. In other words, O. torrenticola and<tei:lb/>O. polyacanthus share derived features in their squamation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>If these various characters can be taken as indicators of relationship, then O. machadoi and<tei:lb/>O. malagaraziensis would be sister species, as would O. torrenticola and O. polyacanthus. But, one<tei:lb/>must set against these similarities the fact that the chest and cheek are naked (or largely naked)<tei:lb/>in O. malagaraziensis and O. torrenticola, and that both species have similar general facies<tei:lb/>(sharply decurved anterior head profile, elongate body and a suprolateral eye), all features which<tei:lb/>would appear to be derived rather than plesiomorph ones. The four anal spines in O. torrenticola<tei:lb/>must be considered an autapomorphic feature and as such cannot be used to assess relationships.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Orthochromis, Ctenochromis and Thoracochromis share one derived feature, the abrupt size<tei:lb/>transition between chest and body scales, and thus are presumed to be derived from a common<tei:lb/>ancestor also possessing this feature. However, no synapomorph character can be found to indi-<tei:lb/>cate which two of the three genera are more closely related to one another.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Since Thoracochromis has only one apomorph feature (chest-body scale size transition), a<tei:lb/>character shared by all three taxa, it can on that basis be considered to represent the least derived<tei:lb/>member of the group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ctenochromis and Orthochromis both exhibit, but do not share, a number of derived features<tei:lb/>which must, therefore, be considered autapomorphic for the lineage in which they occur (and<tei:lb/>define). If one were to consider 'trend' characters, for example a tendency to reduce cheek and<tei:lb/>chest squamation, then Ctenochromis and Orthochromis could be said to share some derived<tei:lb/>features not shared with Thoracochromis. But, I can find no trenchant synapomorphic character<tei:lb/>that would allow one to establish an unequivocal sister-group relationship between the two taxa.<tei:lb/>It is for this reason that I have given each lineage in this ultimately monophyletic assemblage the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMJS GENERIC CONCEPT 299</tei:p>
         <tei:p>status of a genus (see p. 269) rather than ranking Orthochromis and Ctenochromis as subgenera<tei:lb/>(i.e. implicit sister-groups) on the grounds of their having shared and presumed apomorph 'trend'<tei:lb/>characters.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Section II</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although several of the species dealt with in this section have previously been referred to the<tei:lb/>genus Haplochromis (see Bell-Cross, 1975), at least one author (Trewavas, 1964) has suggested<tei:lb/>that these same species, together with the genera Serranochromis and Chetia, are more closely<tei:lb/>related to one another than to any of the species already accounted for. In part I would agree<tei:lb/>with Trewavas' groupings, but the available evidence does not allow one to substantiate, in their<tei:lb/>entirety, the relationships indicated in her phyletic diagram (Trewavas, 1964 : fig. 1), nor is it<tei:lb/>possible to determine the relationships of these 'southern' taxa with the more northern 'Haplo-<tei:lb/>chromis' -group genera considered in Section I.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SERRANOCHROMIS Regan, 1920</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE SPECIES. Chromys thumbergi Castelnau, 1861 (neotype, designated by Trewavas (1964), in<tei:lb/>BMNH collections).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I have united several species (those previously placed in this genus by Trewavas (1964) and<tei:lb/>others placed in Haplochromis by Bell-Cross (1975)) into one lineage (= genus) because all share<tei:lb/>the following apparently derived features: (i) A high number of abdominal vertebrae, 16-18, rarely<tei:lb/>15 or 19 (modal numbers 16 and 17). (ii) A large number of gill rakers, 9-15 (modal range 10-13)<tei:lb/>in the outer row on the lower part of the first gill arch, (iii) A high number of branched fin rays<tei:lb/>in the dorsal fin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In addition, members of this lineage reach a large adult size, all have cycloid or a mixture of<tei:lb/>cycloid and weakly ctenoid scales (the ctenii confined to a small median sector on the scale's<tei:lb/>posterior margin) in which the cycloid kind predominate, and the anal fin markings (egg-dummies)<tei:lb/>in males are numerous, small and non-ocellate (in some species differing little in size, shape or<tei:lb/>colour from the spots on the soft part of the dorsal fin). It is not, however, possible to assess the<tei:lb/>primitive or derived states of these features which, therefore, are of no direct value in assessing<tei:lb/>phylogenetic affinities, (but see p. 274 regarding egg-dummies.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two sublineages, each based on shared derived features common to their constituent species,<tei:lb/>can be recognized within the genus Serranochromis, and these are given subgeneric rank.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subgenus SERRANOCHROMIS Regan, 1920<tei:lb/>TYPE SPECIES. Chromys thumbergi Castelnau, 1861.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Description</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The body form varies from deep to moderately slender (body depth 30-45 % of standard length).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Squamation. The scales on the head, chest, cheek and above the upper lateral line are cycloid,<tei:lb/>those elsewhere on the body mostly cycloid. When ctenoid scales are present these are weakly<tei:lb/>ctenoid, with the ctenii confined to a short median sector on the free margin of the scale.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The scales on the chest (which may be relatively small) show a gentle size gradation with those<tei:lb/>on the lateral and ventrolateral aspects of the flanks; the chest is always fully scaled.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The cheek is fully scaled, with from 3 (rare) to 11 horizontal rows of scales (usually 5-9 rows}.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are 35-41, rarely 34 scales in the lateral line, all but the last 2 or 3 pore-bearing scales of<tei:lb/>the upper lateral line are separated from the dorsal fin origin by two scales of approximately the<tei:lb/>same size.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neurocranium. The skull has a protracted preotic region (comprising some 65-70 % of the total<tei:lb/>neurocranial length), especially noticeable in the ethmovomerine region which comprises c. 27-33%<tei:lb/>of the total neurocranial length. The ethmovomerine part of the skull is almost horizontally aligned,<tei:lb/>its dorsal surface sloping at a small angle (Fig. 13). The supraoccipital crest is variously developed,<tei:lb/>high in some species, relatively lower in others but never shallow relative to the total skull<tei:lb/>proportions.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>300 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vertebral numbers and apophysis for the dorsal retractor muscles of the upper pharyngeal<tei:lb/>bones. There are 31-36 vertebrae, comprising 16-18, rarely 15 or 19 (modes 16 and 17) abdominal<tei:lb/>and 16-18, rarely 15 (modes 16 and 17) caudal elements. Such a high number of both caudal and<tei:lb/>abdominal vertebrae is rarely encountered amongst ' Haplochromis' '-group cichlids, and is unique<tei:lb/>amongst the fluviatile taxa (see, also p. 313 below).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>An apophysis for the origin of the dorsal retractor muscles of the upper pharyngeal bones is<tei:lb/>developed on the ventral face of either the 3rd or 4th abdominal vertebra; although the apophysis<tei:lb/>does occur on the 4th vertebra in other 'Haplochromis' -group taxa, it is usually confined to the<tei:lb/>3rd centrum (see Trewavas, 1964 for comments on this feature).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10mm<tei:lb/>Fig. 13 Neurocranium of Serranochromis (Serranochromis) robustus; left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dentition. The teeth in both the inner and the outer rows of the jaws are unicuspid, even in the<tei:lb/>smallest (29 mm SL) specimens examined. Other l Haplochromis '-group species in which the adult<tei:lb/>dentition is a unicuspid one (and for which specimens less than 100 mm SL are available), have<tei:lb/>bicuspid outer teeth, and usually tri- or bicuspid inner teeth, in fishes less than 80-100 mm standard<tei:lb/>length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The inner teeth are arranged in a single (rarely a double) row; when two rows are present, these<tei:lb/>are confined to the anteromedial part of the jaw, the series continuing posteriorly as a single row. In<tei:lb/>many species the inner teeth of the lower jaw are confined to a narrow, anteromedial arc. The<tei:lb/>majority of 'Haplochromis' -group taxa have a more extensive inner dental pattern, with the teeth<tei:lb/>arranged in at least 2 (and usually 3) rows over the anteromedial and anterolateral parts of the<tei:lb/>jaw bones.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower pharyngeal bone and teeth. With regard to its outline shape when viewed occlusally, two<tei:lb/>kinds of pharyngeal bone can be recognized (Fig. 14). In one, the commoner type, the bone is long<tei:lb/>and narrow, the dentigerous surface having the outline of an isosceles triangle (Fig. 14A &amp; B). The<tei:lb/>second type (found in two species) is relatively broader and its dentigerous surface, although still<tei:lb/>slightly broader than long (c. \\ times) is more nearly equilateral (Fig. 14C).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Irrespective of the bone's outline shape, the teeth (except those in the two median rows) are<tei:lb/>fine and either simply pointed or with a weakly developed shoulder anterior to the pointed cusp.<tei:lb/>The two median and the posterior transverse rows are made up of stouter teeth, those in the<tei:lb/>median rows are relatively the stouter and have the shoulder more clearly demarcated than it is<tei:lb/>in the outer teeth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Jaws. The lower jaw is relatively slender in lateral view (Fig. 15B) and is not noticeably deepened<tei:lb/>posteriorly (angulo-articular region). The premaxillae have, in most species, long ascending pro-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT</tei:p>
         <tei:p>301</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 14 Lower pharyngeal bones of various Serranochromis (Serranochromis)<tei:lb/>species, seen in occlusal view. A. Serranochromis (S.) thumbergi.<tei:lb/>B. S. (S.) robustus. C. S. (S.) macrocephalus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>cesses (Fig. 15 A) which, in the entire fish, extend to the level of the midpoint of the dorsal orbital<tei:lb/>margin or even further dorsoposteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal fin: with 13-18 (modes 15 and 16) spinous, and 13-16 (usually 14-16) branched rays (a<tei:lb/>high branched ray count when compared with that in other fluviatile haplochromine taxa).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal fin: with 3 spines and 9-73 (modes 10 and 11) branched rays (again, a high branched ray<tei:lb/>count).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal fin skeleton. No hypural fusion was noted in any of the radiographed material examined,<tei:lb/>i.e. S. macrocephalus (12 specimens), S. spei (1), S. robustus (14), S. longimanus (4), S. angusticeps<tei:lb/>(17), S. stappersi (1), S. meridionalis (1). No fusion was reported by Vandewalle (1973) in the<tei:lb/>S. macrocephalus (1) or S. robustus (1) he examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>302 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal fin: subtruncate (slightly emarginate in one species) to weakly rounded.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pelvic fin: with the first branched ray the longest.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal fin markings in male fishes. Most species have many small, generally circular spots without<tei:lb/>a clear surround and covering a large area of the soft anal fin, sometimes extending onto the<tei:lb/>spinous part as well. In their size and shape these spots are similar to those on the soft part of the<tei:lb/>dorsal fin and on the caudal fin. An exception to these generalizations is S. spei which has fewer<tei:lb/>and larger (but non-ocellate) spots covering the greater part of the soft fin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>From the little information available on live coloration it seems possible that the anal spots<tei:lb/>may differ slightly from the dorsal fin spots in colour and intensity, but this requires confirmation.<tei:lb/>(For coloured illustrations, see Jubb (1967a, pis 41-44) and Bell-Cross (1976: pis 26-28).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 15 Jaws of Serranochromis (S.) robustus; left lateral view.<tei:lb/>A. Premaxilla, B. Lower jaw.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trewavas (1964) reports that similar spots are present on the anal fin of females, but are grey<tei:lb/>rather than red, yellow or orange as in males.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Where breeding habits are known, the species are female mouthbrooders.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gill rakers are of various forms, from short and stout to moderately slender; there are 9-13<tei:lb/>(modal range 10-12) rarely 8 rakers in the outer row on the lower part of the first gill arch.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contained species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>See Trewavas (1964) for detailed descriptions, figures, etc.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis (S.) robustus (Giinther), 1864. Lake Malawi, Upper Shire river; Mossamedes;<tei:lb/>Okavango; Upper Zambesi; Kafue river; Luangwa system (tributary of the Middle Zambesi);<tei:lb/>Bangweulu region; Luembe river, Kasai system (see Poll, 1967); possibly also in Lake Mweru and<tei:lb/>the Lualaba system.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis (S.) thumbergi (Castelnau), 1861 (Type species). Mossamedes; Okavango river<tei:lb/>and Lake Ngami; rivers Kafue and Luansemfwa (Luangwa system); Bangweulu region; Upemba<tei:lb/>basin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis (S.) macrocephalus (Blgr.), 1899. Mossamedes; Okavango river; Lake Cameia<tei:lb/>(on an Angolan tributary of the Upper Zambesi); Upper Zambesi; Kafue river; Luansemfwa<tei:lb/>river, Luangwa system; Luapula river; Lake Mweru; Lulua river; Angolan Kasai.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis (S.) angusticeps (Blgr.), 1861. Mossamedes; Okavango river and Lake Ngami<tei:lb/>region, Upper Zambesi; Kafue river; Bangweulu region; Luapula river; possibly Lake Mweru<tei:lb/>(see also Poll, 1967).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis (S.) longimanus (Blgr.), 1911. Okavango river and the Upper Zambesi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis (S.) stappersi Trewavas, 1964. Lake Mweru and the lower Luapula river.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis (S.) spei Trewavas, 1964. Lake Kafakumba (2340' E, 940' S) on a tributary<tei:lb/>of the Kasai system; Lake Kabongo in the Lake Upemba depression.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT 303</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis (S.} janus Trewavas, 1964. Malagarasi swamps (Malagarasi river), Tanzania.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis (S.) meridionalis Jubb, 1967. Incomati river system, Transvaal, South Africa<tei:lb/>(see Jubb, 19676).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dr Trewavas (1964) has discussed the possible affinities of these species (except S. meridionalis)<tei:lb/>at what should now be considered an intra-subgeneric level. Until more material is available for<tei:lb/>anatomical studies no further comment would be worthwhile. The relationships of the subgenus<tei:lb/>with its sister-group (Sargochromis), and of the genus as a whole, will be considered below (p. 306).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 16 Neurocranium of Serranochromis (Sargochromis) codringtoni; left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subgenus SA RGOCHROMIS Regan, 1920.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE SPECIES: Paratilapia codringtoni Blgr., 1908 (type specimen in the collections of the BMNH,<tei:lb/>see Bell-Cross, 1975).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Description</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body deep and stout (depth 35-50% of standard length).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sargochromis differs from the nominate subgenus in the following characters :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Squamation. There are fewer lateral line scales (28-34, modes 30 and 31, cf. 35-41 rarely 34).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neurocranium. Although basically of the same type as that in Serranochromis, most Sargo-<tei:lb/>chromis species have a somewhat shorter ethmoid region (but similar preotic skull proportions),<tei:lb/>a deeper otico-occipital region and, in some species, a more robust apophysis for the upper<tei:lb/>pharyngeal bones (Fig. 16). This latter character is positively correlated with the degree of<tei:lb/>enlargement of the pharyngeal bones and the extent to which their dentition is molarized (see<tei:lb/>Greenwood, 19650 and 1978). The more massive the pharyngeal bones the greater is the relative<tei:lb/>contribution of the basioccipital to the articular surface of the apophysis, and in those species<tei:lb/>with the largest bones the prootic also contributes to that surface.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vertebral numbers. There are fewer caudal vertebrae (12-16, modal numbers 14 and 15), and<tei:lb/>hence a lower total count (28-32, mode 31). The number of abdominal vertebrae, however, is high<tei:lb/>in both subgenera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Jaws. The dentary differs from that in Serranochromis in being relatively more foreshortened<tei:lb/>and thus deeper (Fig. 17). The premaxillary ascending processes do not extend beyond about the<tei:lb/>midpoint of the anterior orbital margin (beyond that point in most Serranochromis}.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dentition. Unlike small specimens of Serranochromis, small Sargochromis do have some<tei:lb/>bicuspid inner and outer teeth (at least some specimens &lt; 10-15 cm, depending on the species,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>304 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>have predominantly bicuspid outer teeth). The dental pattern is similar in both subgenera, save<tei:lb/>that S. (Sargochromis) thysi has 4 inner series in both jaws.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower pharyngeal bone and teeth. The bone shows some interspecific variation in outline shape<tei:lb/>(Fig. 1 8) but is always relatively broader than in Serranochromis, and thus the dentigerous surface<tei:lb/>more closely approximates to the equilateral. In only one species, 5". (Sargochromis} greenwoodi<tei:lb/>(Fig. ISA), are there no markedly enlarged median teeth. Most of the other species have some<tei:lb/>enlarged, often submolariform, teeth in addition to those forming the two median rows. Generally<tei:lb/>these enlarged teeth are restricted to a central patch, several tooth rows wide, in the posterior<tei:lb/>(oesophageal) dentigerous field. Two species, S. (Sargochromis) codringtoni and 5". (Sa.) giardi,<tei:lb/>have most of the pharyngeal dentition composed of coarse, molariform or submolariform teeth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 17 Jaws of Serranochromis (Sargochromis) codringtoni', left lateral view.<tei:lb/>A. Premaxilla, B. Lower jaw.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bell-Cross (1975 : fig. 1) described intrapopulational differences in the extent to which the<tei:lb/>pharyngeal dentition is enlarged.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Most Sargochromis species have the lower pharyngeal bone coarser than it is in the nominate<tei:lb/>subgenus, and markedly so when the pharyngeal dentition is hypertrophied.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal fin has a lower modal branched ray count (12 or 13 cf. 14-16 in Serranochromis) but<tei:lb/>there is an extensive overlap in the total ranges (11-16 cf. 13-16). There is also a broad overlap<tei:lb/>in spinous ray counts, although the higher numbers (17 and 18) recorded for the nominate sub-<tei:lb/>genus have not been reported for Sargochromis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal fin markings are essentially the same in both subgenera. For colour illustrations see<tei:lb/>Jubb (1967a : pis 40 and 45); Bell-Cross (1976 : pis 17 and 18).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal fin skeleton. No hypural fusion was seen in the radiographs of S. (Sa.) coulteri, S. (Sa.)<tei:lb/>greenwoodi, and S. (Sa.) codringtoni (1 specimen each); in 5. carlottae one specimen has hypurals<tei:lb/>3 and 4 fused but two other fishes show no fusion. Of the two S. (Sa.) mellandi examined, one<tei:lb/>has hypurals 3 and 4 fused, but the other has none fused. Vandewalle (1973) records S. (Sa.)<tei:lb/>mellandi as having either no fusion (4 specimens) or hypurals 3 and 4 fused (2 specimens).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal fin strongly subtruncate to virtually rounded.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gill rakers are more numerous in Sargochromis (9-15, modal numbers 12 and 13).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contained species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For a systematic review and notes on the ecology and distribution of the first seven species listed</tei:p>
         <tei:p>below see Bell-Cross (1975).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis (Sa.) greenwoodi (Bell-Cross), 1975. Upper Zambesi; Kafue system; Okavango<tei:lb/>system.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis (Sa.) coulteri (Bell-Cross), 1975. Upper Cunene system.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT</tei:p>
         <tei:p>305</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 18 Lower pharyngeal bone of : A. Serranochromis (Sargochromis)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>greenwoodi in a. Occlusal, and b. Right lateral view (bone aligned vertically).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. S. (Sa.) codringtoni; occlusal view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis (Sa.) mortimeri (Bell-Cross), 1975. Upper Zambesi; Kafue river (above the<tei:lb/>Lufwanyama-Kafue confluence); part of the Mulungishi river (a Middle Zambesi tributary).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis (Sa.) mellandi (Blgr.), 1905. Chambesi river and Lake Bangweulu; the Luapula<tei:lb/>river and Lake Mweru; Lake Calundo, Angola (see Poll, 1967).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis (Sa.) carlottae (Blgr.), 1905. Upper Zambesi; Okavango and Kafue systems.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis (Sa.) codringtoni (Blgr.), 1905 (Type species of the subgenus). Upper and Middle<tei:lb/>Zambesi rivers (including the larger tributaries); Kafue and Okavango river systems.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis (Sa.) giardi (Pellegrm), 1904. Middle and lower regions of the Upper Zambesi;<tei:lb/>the Okavango and the plateau section of the Kafue river; one record from the Cunene system.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis (Sa.) thy si (Poll), 1967. Luembe river, Angola.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>306 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diagnosis and discussion</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Members of both subgenera comprising the genus Serranochromis are characterized by having a<tei:lb/>high modal number of abdominal vertebrae (16 or 17, rarely 15 or 19, modes 16-18) and thus a<tei:lb/>high total vertebral count (29-36), a high number of gill rakers in the outer row on the lower part<tei:lb/>of the first gill arch (10-15, rarely 9, modal range 10-13), a generally high number of branched<tei:lb/>dorsal fin rays (11-16, modal range 12-16), mostly cycloid scales on the body (if some ctenoid<tei:lb/>scales are present they are weakly so), a high number of lateral line scales (28-41) as compared<tei:lb/>with other fluviatile 'Haplochromis '-group species and, at least in one subgenus, a greater number<tei:lb/>of scale rows on the cheek (5-9), in having a skull with a relatively protracted preotic region and<tei:lb/>relatively high supraoccipital crest, and in having numerous, small non-ocellate coloured spots<tei:lb/>on the anal fin of male fishes (these markings differing but slightly in size and colour from those<tei:lb/>on the dorsal fin).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diagnostic features for the two subgenera are detailed on pp. 299-301 &amp; 303-304, and in the<tei:lb/>key (p. 316). They involve, chiefly, the higher number of caudal vertebrae and branched dorsal fin<tei:lb/>rays in Serranochromis (Serranochromis) species, and the stouter lower pharyngeal bones and<tei:lb/>dentition in Serranochromis (Sargochromis) species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trewavas (1964) and Bell-Cross (1975) have considered intragroup relationships within the<tei:lb/>subgenera Serranochromis and Sargochromis respectively. A reconsideration of their conclusions<tei:lb/>is beyond the scope of this paper, although Trewavas' (1964 : fig. 1 and p. 10) grouping of the<tei:lb/>Serranochromis (Serranochromis) species would seem, on the basis of the characters used, to be<tei:lb/>a sound hypothesis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trewavas (1964) also made an extensive analysis of the intergroup (i.e. intergeneric) relation-<tei:lb/>ships of what I am treating as the subgenus Serranochromis (treated by Trewavas as a genus). She<tei:lb/>brought into these considerations the 'genus' Sargochromis (S. codringtoni only) and three<tei:lb/>' Haplochromis* species (mellandi, frederici and carlottae) which are now referred to Sargochromis<tei:lb/>(as a subgenus of Serranochromis). In discussing Trewavas' ideas, unless quoting directly, I shall<tei:lb/>use the terms ' Serranochromis', 'Haplochromis'' and ' Sargochromis' to cover her concept of these<tei:lb/>taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In Trewavas' view (1964 : also fig. 1, p. 8) 'Serranochromis'' is '. . . a gradal genus rather than<tei:lb/>a clade', of diphyletic origin from '. . . a small species-flock of Haplochromis' (i.e. the four<tei:lb/>Haplochromis of Angola, '//'. lucullae, '//'. humilis, '//'. acuticeps and '//'. angolensis, plus 'H\<tei:lb/>darlingi of the Zambesi (see below, pp. 310-313).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>'A cladal grouping,' Trewavas continues, 'would recognize Chetia, S. robustus and S. thumbergi<tei:lb/>on the one hand, and H. welwitschii, S. macrocephalus and the other species of Serranochromis<tei:lb/>on the other, but definitions would be almost impossible. . . . The broken line' (referring to fig. 1)<tei:lb/>'at the Haplochromis-Sargochromis transition reflects the absence here too of a clear generic<tei:lb/>division'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Because all 'Serranochromis' species share a high caudal vertebral count and other apparently<tei:lb/>derived features (see p. 299), I cannot accept Trewavas' concept of that taxon having a diphyletic<tei:lb/>origin, nor can I accept, without considerable qualification, the inclusion of Chetia (i.e. C.flavi-<tei:lb/>ventris) and 'H.' welwitschii in one cladal grouping. Neither Chetia nor 'H.' welwitschii has the<tei:lb/>high caudal vertebrae count of 'Serranochromis' (i.e. the nominate subgenus recognized above)<tei:lb/>and, although these two species together with certain other endemic Angolan 'Haplochromis' and<tei:lb/>'//.' darlingi do share some features with Serranochromis, these are not of the kind that would<tei:lb/>suggest a close cladistic relationship.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The question of possible relationships between the Angolan species, '//.' darlingi and Chetia<tei:lb/>flaviventris will be considered on pp. 312-313.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trewavas (1964 : fig. 1, p. 9) recognizes the phyletic affinity between Serranochromis and<tei:lb/>Sargochromis (the latter now of course broadened to include the three 'Haplochromis' (see p. 305)<tei:lb/>species which she indicated as being more closely related to 'Sargochromis' than 'Serranochromis').<tei:lb/>We would differ, however, in our interpretation of the relationship between Sargochromis and<tei:lb/>'Haplochromis' darlingi. Trewavas (1964 : 9) writes of 'The evolutionary line which leads from<tei:lb/>H. darlingi to Sargochromis . . .' But I can find only one derived character (the enlarged pharyn-<tei:lb/>geal mill) that might link 'darlingi' more closely with Sargochromis than with Serranochromis,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT 307</tei:p>
         <tei:p>and none of the synapomorph characters shared by Serranochromis and Sargochromis alone. In<tei:lb/>the absence of these characters from '//.' darlingi, and because an enlarged pharyngeal mill has<tei:lb/>apparently evolved independently in several haplochromine lineages, I consider that the affinities<tei:lb/>between this species and Serranochromis (including Sargochromis} are not as close as those im-<tei:lb/>plicit in Trewavas' proposed ancestor-descendant relationship.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In my view, Serranochromis and Sargochromis shared a recent common ancestry not shared<tei:lb/>with '//.' darlingi (the common ancestor for the former taxa could well have resembled S. (So)<tei:lb/>greenwoodi in its anatomical, morphological and meristic features; see description in Bell-Cross,<tei:lb/>1975).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Any relationship between the genus Serranochromis and '//.' darlingi would be at a more distant<tei:lb/>level because these two taxa share fewer derived features than do Serranochromis and<tei:lb/>Sargochromis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Finally, comment must be made on the superficially close resemblance between members of<tei:lb/>the subgenus Serranochromis (Serranochromis} and certain 'Haplochromis' species of Lake Vic-<tei:lb/>toria (the spekii-serranus species complex, see Greenwood, 1967 : 109, and 19740 : 80 et seq. ; also<tei:lb/>Trewavas, 1964 : 6). That the resemblance is the result of convergent evolutionary trends towards<tei:lb/>the production of an adaptive morphotype (piscivorous predator) and not one of close phyletic<tei:lb/>relationship seems evident from the several features in which the two taxa differ from one another.<tei:lb/>For example, the predominantly cycloid and weakly ctenoid scales of Serranochromis compared<tei:lb/>with the strongly ctenoid scales of the 'Haplochromis' species, the few and fully ocellate egg-<tei:lb/>dummies of the latter as contrasted with the numerous, small and non-ocellate anal spots in<tei:lb/>Serranochromis, and the more numerous gill rakers, branched fin rays and, particularly, the high<tei:lb/>number of abdominal vertebrae in the latter taxon.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certainly it would seem more parsimonious to suppose that Serranochromis and the Lake<tei:lb/>Victoria Haplochromis were derived from different lineages, rather than to suggest a common<tei:lb/>ancestry from some widespread lineage of fluviatile, piscivorous predators (an idea I had enter-<tei:lb/>tained previously when considering the phyletic history of the Lake Victoria species flock).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It would seem possible, too, that there is no close phyletic relationship between Serranochromis<tei:lb/>and certain ' Haplochromis' species in Lake Malawi (see Trewavas, 1964 : 6), but more research is<tei:lb/>required on the Malwai species before this idea can be tested adequately.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CHETIA Trewavas, 1961.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE SPECIES. Chetia flaviventris Trewavas, 1961 (Holotype and paratypes in the BMNH, 3 para-<tei:lb/>types in the Transvaal Museum, Pretoria).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOTE. The species Chetia brevis Jubb, 1968 is excluded from this genus because in adult males<tei:lb/>the anal fin markings are large, true ocelli and few in number (3 or 4). Also, unequally bicuspid<tei:lb/>outer jaw teeth are still present in specimens of a size (86-89 mm SL) when, in Chetia flaviventris,<tei:lb/>the outer row is comprised mainly of unicuspid and caniniform teeth ; the few bicuspid teeth<tei:lb/>present in C. flaviventris of that size are different from those in C. brevis since the minor 'cusp'<tei:lb/>is a shoulder and not a point.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Description</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The body form is moderately slender (depth of body 29-35 % of standard length).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Squamation. The scales on the head, chest, cheek and body above the upper lateral line are<tei:lb/>cycloid, and cycloid scales predominate on the body below that level as well; a few weakly<tei:lb/>ctenoid scales may be present anteriorly on the body, the ctenii on these scales being confined to<tei:lb/>a short median arc on the scale's free margin. It seems possible that a higher proportion of<tei:lb/>ctenoid scales is present in smaller than in larger individuals; the largest specimen examined has<tei:lb/>only cycloid scales on all parts of the body and head (see also Trewavas, 1961).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The cheek is completely scaled (5 or 6 horizontal rows}. The chest scales show a gentle size<tei:lb/>gradation with those on the belly and ventrolateral aspects of the flanks.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>308 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are 34 or 35 scales in the lateral line series, with only the last one or two pore-bearing<tei:lb/>scales of the upper lateral line separated from the dorsal fin base by less than two scales of almost<tei:lb/>equal size.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neurocranium. The skull has a moderately produced preotic region (c. 68-70 % of total neuro-<tei:lb/>cranial length). The ethmovomerine region is not noticeably extended, and slopes at a slight<tei:lb/>angle. In its proportions and general shape, the neurocranium in Chetia approaches that in the<tei:lb/>subgenus Serranochromis (Serranochromis), but has a less elongate ethmovomerine region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vertebral numbers and apophysis for the dorsal retractor muscles of the upper pharyngeal<tei:lb/>bones. There are 30-32 (mode 31) vertebrae, comprising 14 or 15 (mode 15) abdominal and<tei:lb/>15-17 (modes 16 and 17) caudal elements.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trewavas (1961) reports an absence of any bony apophysis for the origin of the pharyngeal<tei:lb/>muscles; from the radiographs I have examined (i.e. of the holo- and 4 paratypes) the structure<tei:lb/>is visible in one specimen. Trewavas (1961) implies that the apophysis serves principally for the<tei:lb/>attachment of the swimbladder. That organ certainly is attached to the posterior face of the<tei:lb/>apophysis in all cichlids I have examined, but the greater surface area of the apophysis serves as<tei:lb/>a point of origin for the pharyngeal retractor muscles.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dentition. Unicuspid teeth predominate (or are the only kind of teeth present) in specimens more<tei:lb/>than 30 mm standard length; the few bicuspid teeth present have a much reduced, shoulder-like minor<tei:lb/>cusp, and are mostly replaced by unicuspids in specimens &gt; 35 mm S.L. There is, however, a size<tei:lb/>correlated change in the kind of unicuspid teeth present. Fishes &lt; 35 mm long have rather<tei:lb/>flattened, almost spear-shaped unicuspids whereas in larger fishes the teeth are caniniform.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Unicuspid teeth also predominate in the inner rows of fishes at all sizes, although a few weakly<tei:lb/>bicuspid teeth are present in specimens less than 40 mm SL. There are one, or, less commonly, two<tei:lb/>rows of inner teeth anteriorly in both jaws, and a single series laterally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower and upper jaws. The lower jaw has the appearance and proportions of that in Serrano-<tei:lb/>chromis (Serranochromis) species, but in the upper jaw the ascending premaxillary process does<tei:lb/>not reach to between the orbits as it does in many of the latter species ; it reaches only to about<tei:lb/>the midpoint of the anterior orbital margin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower pharyngeal bone and teeth. The bone is not thickened, has an almost equilateral denti-<tei:lb/>gerous surface, and its teeth are slender and weakly cuspidate (Fig. 19). Those teeth forming the<tei:lb/>two median rows and the posterior transverse row are slightly coarser than their congeners.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal fin with 14 or 15 spinous and 11 or 12 branched rays.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal fin with 3 spines and 9 or 10 branched rays.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal fin skeleton. All the hypurals are free in the five specimens radiographed (the type<tei:lb/>series).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal fin is subtruncate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pelvic fin has the first branched ray the longest.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal fin markings in male fishes. As in Serranochromis (see p. 302) there are numerous, small<tei:lb/>and non-ocellate spots covering a large area of the soft anal fin, the spots resembling in size and<tei:lb/>coloration those on the soft part of the dorsal fin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>According to Du Plessis &amp; Groenewald (1953) the anal spots in C.flaviventris are more plentiful<tei:lb/>in males than in females, and the species is a female mouthbrooder.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gill rakers are moderately short and slender, with 9 or 10 rakers in the outer row on the lower<tei:lb/>part of the first gill arch.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contained species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chetia flaviventris Trewavas, 1961 (Type species). Tributaries of the Limpopo and Incomati</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rivers, Transvaal, South Africa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diagnosis and discussion</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The single species in this genus is distinguished from the other fluviatile ' Haplochromis' -group<tei:lb/>species, except Serranochromis, by the nature of the anal fin markings in adult males, which are<tei:lb/>numerous, small and non-ocellate (and which barely differ from those in females). In addition,<tei:lb/>Chetia is distinguished from Ctenochromis, Orthochromis and Thoracochromis by the nature of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT</tei:p>
         <tei:p>309</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the scale pattern in the thoracic-abdominal region (a gradual as compared with an abrupt size<tei:lb/>change in the scales of the two body regions).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>From Serranochromis, Chetia is distinguished mainly by having fewer (14 or 15) abdominal<tei:lb/>vertebrae (cf. 16-18, rarely 15, in Serranochromis) and by having bicuspid teeth in specimens of<tei:lb/>a larger size. In meristic characters, other than vertebral numbers, the two genera have a com-<tei:lb/>parable overlap, but for each feature the modal values are distinct, those for Serranochromis<tei:lb/>being the higher.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 19 Lower pharyngeal bone of Chetia flaviventris. A. Occlusal view.<tei:lb/>B. Right lateral view (bone aligned vertically).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I can detect no apomorph features which would suggest that Chetia might be related to any<tei:lb/>of the three lineages showing an abrupt size change in the thoracic-abdominal squamation, and<tei:lb/>nor can I find apomorph characters to associate it with Haplochromis, Astatotilapia or Astatoreo-<tei:lb/>chromis .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>That Chetia and Serranochromis share a similar kind of anal fin marking does not necessarily<tei:lb/>imply a close relationship between them either, since it seems likely that this is a primitive<tei:lb/>(plesimorph) feature for 'Haplochromis' -group species (see above, p. 275). I can detect no unequi-<tei:lb/>vocally synapomorphic features common to Chetia and Serranochromis and thus, despite their<tei:lb/>superficial similarities, cannot place the taxa in the same genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Likewise, the almost identical anal fin markings in Chetia and 'Haplochromis'' darlingi (see<tei:lb/>below, p. 310) cannot be taken to indicate a close relationship. It is for this reason, as well as their<tei:lb/>lack of uniquely shared apomorph features and the presence of autapomorph features in each<tei:lb/>species, that has led me to place Chetia flaviventris and '//.' darlingi in separate lineages, and thus<tei:lb/>to give the latter taxon generic rank (see p. 312).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trewavas (1964 : 10) has remarked on the similarity between Chetia and certain Serranochromis<tei:lb/>species, a similarity which led her to consider Chetia an offshoot from a lineage that also contains<tei:lb/>S. (Serranochromis) thumbergi and S. (S.) robustus. That there are similarities between the three<tei:lb/>species is undeniable, but Chetia does not share with the two Serranochromis species (and with<tei:lb/>other species of the genus) the derived feature of a high number of abdominal vertebrae. It does,<tei:lb/>of course, share with all Serranochromis (Serranochromis) species the early ontogenetic appearance<tei:lb/>of unicuspid outer and inner jaw teeth (see p. 300), an apomorph feature which Serranochromis<tei:lb/>(Sargochromis) does not share with the nominate subgenus.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>310 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thus at present, one cannot find a totality of shared apomorph features which would indicate<tei:lb/>a clear-cut sister group relationship for Chetia. For that reason I would consider that Chetia is<tei:lb/>best represented as a monotypic lineage (genus) of uncertain affinities. Intuitively one suspects<tei:lb/>that Chetia is related either to Serranochromis (especially the nominate subgenus of that taxon)<tei:lb/>or to ' Haptochromis* darlingi. But, the evidence to propose formally one or other of these relation-<tei:lb/>ships is not available if the classification adopted is to reflect phyletic relationships.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Superficially, Chetia also resembles one of the Angolan 'Haphchromis' species, '//.' welwitschii<tei:lb/>Blgr., a taxon known only from its now poorly preserved holotype. Until more and better docu-<tei:lb/>mented material of the Angolan 'Haplochromis' is available for study, any possible relationship<tei:lb/>between Chetia flaviventris and '//.' welwitschii cannot be investigated (see also p. 312 below).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PHARYNGOCHROMIS gen. nov.<tei:lb/>TYPE SPECIES. Pelmatochromis darlingi Blgr., 1911. (Holotype in the BMNH collections.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SYNONYMY. See Regan (1922a).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Description</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body form moderately slender (body depth 30-33 % of standard length).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Squamation. The body squamation type and pattern is like that in Chetia (see p. 307). The<tei:lb/>cheek is fully covered by 4 or 5 horizontal scale rows. There are 32-34 (modes 32 and 33), rarely<tei:lb/>31, scales in the lateral line.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neurocranium. The preotic portion of the skull is slightly less protracted that in Chetia, the<tei:lb/>brain case is a little higher and the slope of the dorsal skull profile a little steeper. In other words,<tei:lb/>the overall skull morphology is somewhat more like that in Serranochromis (Sargochromis)<tei:lb/>species than in Chetia, a resemblance that may be associated functionally with the enlarged<tei:lb/>pharyngeal bones and dentition present in both taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vertebral numbers: 29 or 30 (mode 29), comprising 13 or 14 (mode 14) abdominal and 15 or<tei:lb/>16 (mode 15) caudal elements. An apophysis for the dorsal retractor pharyngeal muscles is<tei:lb/>present on the third centrum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dentition. There is a predominance of unicuspid, caniniform teeth in the outer row of both<tei:lb/>jaws in fishes over 60 mm standard length, but even in the largest specimens examined (90 mm SL)<tei:lb/>many unequally bicuspid teeth persist (and, occasionally, may be the predominant form). Uni-<tei:lb/>cuspids also predominate in the inner tooth rows, the other teeth being bi- or weakly bicuspid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The inner rows of both jaws are arranged in two series anteromedially and a single row laterally<tei:lb/>and posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Jaws. The lower jaw is somewhat shorter and deeper than in Chetia, but the premaxilla is<tei:lb/>similar in both genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower pharyngeal bone and dentition. The dentigerous surface is equilateral or almost so, and<tei:lb/>the bone itself is somewhat thickened medially (noticeably so when compared with that in Chetia).<tei:lb/>The two median tooth rows are composed of coarse, stout and molariform or submolariform<tei:lb/>teeth (Fig. 20), the latter retaining traces of a small, near-central point on the occlusal surface.<tei:lb/>The teeth in the row, or the two rows on either side of the median series, are markedly coarser<tei:lb/>than those in the lateral rows (which are also clearly cuspidate), and may have submolariform<tei:lb/>crowns.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal fin with 14 or 15 (mode 14), rarely 13, spines and 10-12 (mode 1 1) branched rays.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal fin with 3 spines and 7-8 branched rays.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal fin skeleton. All hypurals are free in the 4 specimens (including the holotype)<tei:lb/>radiographed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal fin: strongly truncate to virtually rounded.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pelvic fin: with the first branched ray the longest.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal fin markings in male fishes. As in Chetia and Serranochromis, there are numerous (up to<tei:lb/>18, according to Bell-Cross, 1976), small orange spots on the soft part of the fin, and sometimes<tei:lb/>extending onto the membrane between the spines as well. Pharyngochromis darlingi is a female</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT</tei:p>
         <tei:p>311</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mouthbrooder (Bell-Cross, 1976). For coloured illustrations see Jubb (\961a : pi. 46); Bell-Cross<tei:lb/>(1976 : pi. 16).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gill rakers are short and stout, with 9 or 10 (less commonly 7 or 8) in the outer row on the<tei:lb/>lower part of the first gill arch.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contained species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pharyngochromis darlingi (Blgr.), 1911. Type species. Widely distributed in the Zambesi river</tei:p>
         <tei:p>system and southwards to the Limpopo.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 20 Lower pharyngeal bone of Pharyngochromis darlingi. A. Occlusal view.<tei:lb/>B. Right lateral view (bone aligned vertically).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Poll (1967) recorded this species (as Haplochromis darlingi) from Lake Calundo (Zambesi<tei:lb/>drainage), Angola, and also redetermined, as H. darlingi, specimens from the Cubango river<tei:lb/>which Pellegrin (1936) had identified as Haplochromis welwitschii. However, judging from the<tei:lb/>nature of the anal fin markings in male specimens, I suspect that these specimens should not be<tei:lb/>referred to P. darlingi. Their identity should be more firmly established (possibly as a yet un-<tei:lb/>described species) when a thorough revision of the Angolan 'Haplochromis' species is carried out<tei:lb/>(see p. 312).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The same features distinguishing Chetia from the other fluviatile 'Haplochromis' -group genera,<tei:lb/>including Serranochromis, also serve to distinguish Pharyngochromis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>From Chetia itself, Pharyngochromis is distinguished, chiefly, by its stouter lower pharyngeal<tei:lb/>bone and its partly molarized dentition, by having lower modal numbers of abdominal and<tei:lb/>caudal vertebrae, fewer lateral line scales, and by having a larger proportion of bicuspid teeth<tei:lb/>in the outer tooth row of both jaws in fishes more than 40 mm standard length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>My reason for not treating Chetia flaviventris and Pharyngochromis darlingi as members of the<tei:lb/>same genus is their lack of shared derived features (see above, p. 310). The same reasons led me<tei:lb/>to exclude Pharyngochromis from the Sargochromis division of the Serrano chromis lineage.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Presumably it is the presence of enlarged pharyngeal teeth, as well as overall similarity in body<tei:lb/>form and oral dentition, that led Trewavas (1964 : fig. 1 and p. 9) to place P. darlingi at the base<tei:lb/>of a lineage leading to Sargochromis (then restricted to the type species, S. codringtoni). Deriva-<tei:lb/>tives from, and members of, this lineage also included a number of Zambesi 'Haplochromis'<tei:lb/>species which I now place in Sargochromis.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>312 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Since the subgenera Serranochromis and Sargochromis share certain derived features (especially<tei:lb/>an increased number of abdominal vertebrae) not found in Pharyngochromis it would seem more<tei:lb/>parsimonious to consider that the two former taxa share a recent common ancestry and that any<tei:lb/>relationship they may have with Pharyngochromis is a more distant one.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The alternative classification implicit in Trewavas' (1964) phyletic diagram, that Chetia and<tei:lb/>Serranochromis (i.e. my subgenus Serranochromis (Serranochromis)) are sister-groups, and that<tei:lb/>Sargochromis (i.e. my subgenus Serranochromis (Sargochromis)) plus Pharyngochromis is the<tei:lb/>sister-group of Chetia and Serranochromis combined, is not supported by the distribution of<tei:lb/>derived characters amongst the taxa involved. Such an arrangement would also imply that the<tei:lb/>derived features shared by Sargochromis and Serranochromis were evolved independently. Ad-<tei:lb/>mittedly in my scheme one specialized feature (the enlarged pharyngeal bones and dentition of<tei:lb/>Pharyngochromis and most Sargochromis species) would have to be evolved independently. But,<tei:lb/>evidence from haplochromine lineages in Lake Victoria (see Greenwood, 1974a) and from<tei:lb/>Thoracochromis (e.g. Th. mahagiensis and Th. pharyngalis) seems to indicate that the independent<tei:lb/>evolution of an enlarged pharyngeal mill is not uncommon amongst ' Haplochromis '-group<tei:lb/>cichlids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>To summarize: the relationships amongst those l Haplochromis' -group taxa with non-ocellate<tei:lb/>and numerous anal fin spots (a group essentially of the Zambesi, Limpopo, and Angolan rivers)<tei:lb/>cannot clearly be recognized at present. Two lineages with a presumed recent common ancestry<tei:lb/>(Serranochromis and Sargochromis) are treated as sister-groups and given subgeneric rank; the<tei:lb/>other two lineages cannot be related unequivocally (on the basis of shared derived characters)<tei:lb/>with either the Serranochromis-Sargochromis lineages or with one another; each therefore is<tei:lb/>treated as a monotypic and monophyletic assemblage (on the basis of autapomorphic features)<tei:lb/>and given generic rank (Chetia and Pharyngochromis).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The further resolution of relationships amongst these taxa awaits more detailed studies of their<tei:lb/>contained species (and of the Angolan ' 'Haplochromis' species), and an understanding of the<tei:lb/>phyletic importance which can be attached to anal fin markings.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Angolan ^Haplochromis^ species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Several references have been made to these little-known and poorly represented taxa. The last<tei:lb/>comprehensive revision of the Angolan Haplochromis was that of Regan (19220) who recognized<tei:lb/>three species, H. humilis (Steindachner), 1866, H. acuticeps (Steindachner) 1866 and H. multi-<tei:lb/>ocellatus (Blgr.) 1913. For some reason not stated (but probably because Boulenger (191 5) included<tei:lb/>both species in Pelmatochromis), Regan omitted Steindachner's (1865) Hemichromis angolensis<tei:lb/>and Boulenger's (1898) Pelmatochromis welwitschii. Both species, however, would have fallen into<tei:lb/>Regan's definition of Haplochromis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All the specimens representing these species (and others synonymized therein by Regan,<tei:lb/>19220) are poorly preserved, mostly represented by a single individual (or at best 4 or 5 syntypes),<tei:lb/>and often without precise locality data ; the type of P. angolensis is now lost (see Bell-Cross,<tei:lb/>1975 : 427).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In recent years Poll (1967) has added three species (H. thy si, H. machadoi and H. schwetzi;<tei:lb/>see pp. 305 and 297 above for the first two species respectively), Trewavas and Thys van den<tei:lb/>Audenaerde (1964) a fourth (H. albolabris) and Penrith (1970) a fifth (H. buysi).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>My revision of this material indicates that probably several lineages are represented within it,<tei:lb/>and that Regan's (1922) re-definition of H. acuticeps (Steindachner) embraces at least two<tei:lb/>species. Some of the Angolan species seem to show affinity with the genus Astatotilapia, others<tei:lb/>with Chetia and some may represent lineages yet unrecognized. But, until the species can be<tei:lb/>revised and reviewed on the basis of more extensive, better preserved and better documented<tei:lb/>collections I believe that it is inadvisable to place any species in the genera recognized in this<tei:lb/>paper. It is certainly impossible to demonstrate that the Angolan species are more closely related<tei:lb/>to one another than to any other lineage, although intuitively one recognizes, in at least some<tei:lb/>species, an 'Angolan fades' and feels that this overall appearance suggests relationships with the<tei:lb/>Zambesi-Limpopo genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT 313</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trewavas' (1964) phyletic diagram illustrating the possible relationships of ''Serranochromis'<tei:lb/>and 'Sargochromis' indicates that a number of Angolan ' Haplochromis' species are related to<tei:lb/>'Serranochromis' (i.e. the subgenus Serranochromis (Serranochromis) as defined on p. 299). I can<tei:lb/>find no synapomorph characters to support this supposition. The very faint traces of anal fin<tei:lb/>markings left on the holotype of H. welwitschii suggest that they may be of the Serranchromis-<tei:lb/>Chetia-Pharyngochromis pattern but this is probably a plesiomorph feature. Where anal fin<tei:lb/>markings are detectable in the other species mentioned by Trewavas (1964), for example<tei:lb/>H. lucullae, they appear to be of the true ocellar type and thus a derived feature not represented<tei:lb/>in Serranochromis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The number of vertebrae (especially the abdominal elements) in H. welwitschii and the other<tei:lb/>Angolan species is lower than that in Serranochromis (although within the range for Chetia) and<tei:lb/>again represents a plesiomorph condition.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Other characters and character states are equally lacking in shared apomorph features, or<tei:lb/>represent autapomorphies characterizing the Angolan taxa alone.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As a temporary expedient I can only suggest that the Angolan species be given no formal<tei:lb/>generic status and that they should be referred to under the informal epithet ' 'Haplochromis',<tei:lb/>whose use in no way implies a close relationship with the species of Haplochromis (or, indeed,<tei:lb/>the majority of species previously referred to that genus).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Summary and conclusions</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I am well aware of the shortcomings in this preliminary attempt to clarify the phylogenetic<tei:lb/>relationships of 'Haplochromis' -group cichlids, and in particular members of that manifestly<tei:lb/>polyphyletic 'genus' Haplochromis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two major difficulties were encountered, and although one has been overcome to a greater or<tei:lb/>lesser degree, the other still stands in the way of a fully phylogenetic classification. The first<tei:lb/>difficulty lies in determining morphocline polarity amongst the characters available for research<tei:lb/>of this kind (p. 270). Then, when plesiomorph and apomorph features are recognized, there is the<tei:lb/>problem caused by an apparent absence of synapomorphic features at the various levels of<tei:lb/>relationship necessary to construct a truly cladistic classification.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In other words, one can identify fairly readily what appear to be monophyletic lineages, but<tei:lb/>the difficulties arise when one attempts to interrelate the different lineages on a sister-group basis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The problem is well exemplified by the genera Ctenochromis, Thoracochromis and Orthochromis.<tei:lb/>All three taxa share the presumably derived feature of an abrupt size-change between the scales<tei:lb/>on the thoracic and ventrolateral flank regions of the body (see p. 270), and thus are assumed to<tei:lb/>share, at some level, a common ancestry. Both Orthochromis and Ctenochromis, but not Thoraco-<tei:lb/>chromis exhibit derived features that are unique for each genus (i.e. autapomorphies) but there<tei:lb/>are no synapomorphic characters that would indicate which two of the three genera are more<tei:lb/>closely related to one another. Since Thoracochromis shows only one apomorph feature common<tei:lb/>to all its species it is, presumably, the least derived member of the trio.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Similar difficulties arise with Haplochromis, Astatotilapia and Astatoreochromis, taxa which<tei:lb/>appear to be interrelated (along with the components of the Victoria-Edward-Kivu species<tei:lb/>flock) only on the basis of their possessing true ocellar spots on the anal fin of male fishes (p. 274).<tei:lb/>Haplochromis and Astatoreochromis (and each of the major lineages in the Victoria flock) have<tei:lb/>clear-cut autapomorphic features; Astatotilapia, apparently, has none. Again one is left with an<tei:lb/>unresolved polychotomy, but in this case, because the lake flocks are involved, a far more com-<tei:lb/>plex one.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Finally, but in a rather different category, since no unifying synapomorphic characters have<tei:lb/>been detected, are the genera Chetia, Pharyngochromis and Serranochromis. Intuitively the taxa<tei:lb/>would seem to be interrelated (as they have been assumed to be by other workers, e.g. Trewavas,<tei:lb/>1964), probably because of their similar overall morphology, coloration, and the repeated<tei:lb/>occurrence of enlarged pharyngeal mills amongst their constituent species; in addition, the<tei:lb/>species form a well-defined, Zambesian geographical group. Yet, I have failed to substantiate<tei:lb/>their presumed relationship because there are no apparently derived features common to all three</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>314 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>genera (see p. 312). Of course, my interpretation of one shared feature (the non-ocellate, and very<tei:lb/>numerous anal spots) as a primitive condition may be incorrect (see p. 275); only further research,<tei:lb/>especially comparative ethological research, can clarify that point.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Further research is also needed to test the phylogenetic homogeneity of the speciose lineage<tei:lb/>Thoracochromis (see above and p. 294). As yet no way has been found to test the possibility,<tei:lb/>indicated by certain morphological features, that there are three infragroups represented in the<tei:lb/>lineage, viz. one in Lake Turkana, another in the Nile and Lake Albert (including also the outlier<tei:lb/>species from Lake Edward and possibly Lake Victoria), and a third from the Zaire river system.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Despite these limitations I believe that the classification suggested here is a more efficient one<tei:lb/>than that existing at present (the term 'efficient' used sensu Patterson &amp; Rosen (1977 : 158-159)<tei:lb/>to denote a classification from which a '. . . theory of relationships is recoverable . . . without<tei:lb/>loss of information'). Clearly its efficiency can be improved, but that must await the phyletic<tei:lb/>analysis of ' Haplochromis '-group species in the Great Lakes, especially those of Lakes Malawi<tei:lb/>and Victoria.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It has been generally assumed (see Regan 19216; Trewavas, 1935; Fryer &amp; lies, 1972) that the<tei:lb/>Malawi 'Haplochromis' -group species were derived from an anatomically generalized fluviatile<tei:lb/>' Haplochromis' (i.e. Astatotilapia) species. I now suspect, however, that the story is far more<tei:lb/>complex, that the Malawi flock is probably of polyphyletic origin and that lineages related to<tei:lb/>Thoracochromis as well as to Astatotilapia and even to Serranochromis and Chetia may have<tei:lb/>contributed to the flock. Possibly some of the ideas put forward in this paper may contribute to<tei:lb/>the elucidation of that problem.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Likewise the assumed monophyly of the Lake Victoria ' Haplochromis' species flock (Green-<tei:lb/>wood, 1974a) must be thrown into doubt, because no characters have been found to support this<tei:lb/>concept (see p. 269). As compared with Lake Malawi, however, it does seem more likely that<tei:lb/>fewer and phyletically more closely related lineages were involved, and that most are related to<tei:lb/>the Astatotilapia lineage.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Geographically, the different lineages dealt with in this paper have interesting patterns of<tei:lb/>distribution.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thoracochromis is essentially a Nilotic-Zairean taxon (see p. 294). Unlike the others with<tei:lb/>Zairean representatives (see below), it is best represented in the lower reaches of that river, since<tei:lb/>only one species (Th. moeruensis) is recorded from the upper Zaire system (see p. 293).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The virtual absence of Thoracochromis from Lakes Victoria, Edward and Kivu is, on the<tei:lb/>basis of its overall distribution, rather surprising. Possibly this is attributable to the relatively<tei:lb/>recent association between these lakes and the Nile system (see Beadle, 1974 : 139-146; Green-<tei:lb/>wood, 19746 and 1976; Berry, 1976; Livingstone, 1976; Rzoska, 1976a &amp; b : 2-29). Lake Turkana<tei:lb/>and, as far as can be told, Lake Albert as well, have only ever had major and direct intercon-<tei:lb/>nections with the Nile system; the geologically recent riverine connection between Lakes Albert<tei:lb/>and Victoria probably is made impassable to fishes by the presence of the Murchison Falls (now<tei:lb/>Kabalega Falls), and the connection between Lakes Edward and Albert via the Semliki river<tei:lb/>also seems to be impassable for most fishes (see discussions in Greenwood, 19596, 1973 and<tei:lb/>1976; also Rzoska, 1976c : 197-202).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Astatotilapia, apart from its outliers in North Africa (A. desfontainesi), Syria and Israel<tei:lb/>(A. flaviijosephi) and possibly in Nigeria (see p. 283), is essentially a lineage of the eastern Rift<tei:lb/>Valley (except Lake Turkana) and the rivers of eastern Africa; it is represented in the Zaire<tei:lb/>drainage only by its species in Lake Tanganyika (see p. 284). The absence of Astatotilapia from<tei:lb/>Lake Turkana probably is to be explained through the history of that lake (see above). Far more<tei:lb/>puzzling is the occurrence of two Astatotilapia species north of the Sahara (Tunisia, Algeria,<tei:lb/>Syria and Israel), and the possibility of one or two other species in Nigeria. This disjunct distri-<tei:lb/>bution may, of course, be the result of incorrectly assessing the phyletic relationships of the<tei:lb/>outlier species. On currently available evidence, however, there is nothing to suggest how else<tei:lb/>these outlier species might be interrelated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ctenochromis, with one exceptional species (C. pectoralis) from southeastern Tanzania (Indian<tei:lb/>Ocean drainage), is totally Zairean (including Lake Tanganyika) in its distribution (see p. 289).<tei:lb/>Orthochromis too is an essentially Zairean lineage and, like Ctenochromis, is confined to the upper</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT 315</tei:p>
         <tei:p>parts of that system; it has a representative in the Malagarasi river system of Tanzania, but<tei:lb/>historically that river should be considered part of the upper Zaire drainage (Poll, 1956). The<tei:lb/>only outlier species, Orthochromis machadoi, occurs in the Cunene river, Angola, a river whose<tei:lb/>ichthyofaunal affinities are closer to those of the Zambesi than the Zaire (Poll, 1967).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serranochromis is widely distributed (see p. 302), having representatives in the Zaire and Zam-<tei:lb/>besi systems, as well as in the Limpopo and certain Angolan rivers (including the Cunene). Both<tei:lb/>its Zairean and Zambesi components are confined to the upper portions of their respective<tei:lb/>systems (cf. the distribution of Thoracochromis).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chetia and Pharyngochromis have, geographically speaking, the most restricted distributions<tei:lb/>of all the fluviatile species considered in this paper (apart from Astatoreochromis which occurs<tei:lb/>only in parts of the Malagarasi and Lukuga rivers, in Lakes Edward and Victoria and in some<tei:lb/>physiographically related water bodies, see p. 286). Chetia, a monotypic genus, is confined to the<tei:lb/>Limpopo drainage system, and Pharyngochromis, also monotypic, to the Upper and Middle<tei:lb/>Zambesi, the Sabi-Lundi system and the Limpopo system.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The only truly lacustrine lineage discussed in this paper, Haplochromis, is confined to Lakes<tei:lb/>Victoria, Edward, George and Kivu. The significance of this distribution, and the possible<tei:lb/>relationships of the genus, will be discussed in a forthcoming revision of the lineages from those<tei:lb/>lakes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to the genera</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Notes (i) When citing the range for meristic characters, values rarely encountered are given in<tei:lb/>square brackets and precede or follow, respectively, the most frequently recorded low and high<tei:lb/>values for that character.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(ii) Modal values (or modal ranges) are in bold type and enclosed in round brackets.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(iii) Gill raker counts are for the outer row of rakers on the lower part of the arch, and do not<tei:lb/>include the raker (if such is present) on the epi-ceratobranchial articulation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(iv) For further notes, and definitions of the characters used see pp. 270-276.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A gradual change in size between the scales on the chest (i.e. ventral and ventrolateral body region<tei:lb/>anterior to the insertions of the pectoral and pelvic fin bases) and those on the ventral and<tei:lb/>ventrolateral aspects of the flanks and belly (see Fig. 1) ....... 1</tei:p>

         <tei:p>1) (a) Anal fin in adult males with 3-9 (3 or 4) ocelli (coloured spots each with a clear or trans-<tei:lb/>lucent area surrounding it) arranged in one or two lines and lying about midway between<tei:lb/>the base and the distal margin of that fin. (Most females and juvenile males with 3 or 4<tei:lb/>non-ocellate spots in the same position, or fin without spots.) Anal fin with 3 spines (individuals with 4 spines are so rare that<tei:lb/>this number can be considered as an individual abnormality). Dorsal fin rarely with<tei:lb/>more than 16 spines. Marked sexual dimorphism in adult coloration (males colorful,<tei:lb/>females drab) ............. A</tei:p>
