         <tei:p>Appendix 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A replacement 'generic' name for the Lake Malawi ^ Haplochromis'' species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Since the genus Haplochromis is now restricted to five species, all members of the Lakes Victoria,<tei:lb/>Edward, George and Kivu species flock (p. 280), the Lake Malawi species formerly referred to<tei:lb/>Haplochromis are without a generic name. Because it is obvious that the 'Haplochromis' of Lake<tei:lb/>Malawi are a polyphyletic group, any generic placement at the present time must be considered<tei:lb/>merely a formal nomeclatural action unrelated to the phyletic affinities of the species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two generic names would appear to be available for this purpose (see Trewavas, 1935), namely<tei:lb/>Cyrtocara Boulenger (1902) and Champsochromis Boulenger (1915). A third name, Otopharynx,<tei:lb/>Regan (1920), apparently is also available, but it is junior to the others and there are anatomical<tei:lb/>grounds for regarding its contained species as representing a lineage distinct from that to which<tei:lb/>many Malawi 'Haplochromis'' belong (Greenwood, 1978).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cyrtocara (type species C. moori) has a pharyngeal apophysis of the typical 'Haplochromis'-type<tei:lb/>(Trewavas, 1935) and its oral dentition is composed of slender unicuspid outer teeth and mixed<tei:lb/>uni- and tricuspid inner teeth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although at least some members of the type species have a moderately developed hump in the<tei:lb/>frontal region of the head, I can see no morphological grounds for not accepting Cyrtocara as a<tei:lb/>temporary formal name for the ' Haplochromis' species of Lake Malawi. I thus propose that it be<tei:lb/>used in that capacity until the Malawi species are revised. This action by no means implies that<tei:lb/>I consider many of these species to have a true phyletic relationship with Cyrtocara moori.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Appendix 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The taxonomic status of the genus Limnotilapia Regan, 1920</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In a recent paper (Greenwood, 1978) I treated the genus Limnotilapia Regan (1920) as a synonym<tei:lb/>of Simochromis Boulenger, 1898, thus unintentionally anticipating the publication of a paper<tei:lb/>giving detailed reasons for this nomenclatural change. Since publication of the paper in which<tei:lb/>the two 'genera' are to be discussed is likely to be delayed further, the reasons for synonymizing<tei:lb/>Limnotilapia with Simochromis are dealt with below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A comparison of Regan's (1920) description for Limnotilapia with his redescription of Simo-<tei:lb/>chromis reveals that the taxa apparently are differentiable only on the former having a rather<tei:lb/>small, terminal mouth, and the latter having the mouth subterminal and rather wide.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>When the type species of the genera, Limnotilapia dardennii (Blgr.) and Simochromis diagramma<tei:lb/>(Giinth.), are compared, these differences can be translated into more substantial osteological<tei:lb/>ones involving the morphology of the premaxilla and dentary.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Viewed from below (i.e. occlusally), the premaxillary outline in L. dardennii is gently curved<tei:lb/>and relatively narrow; in other words, it has an outline approximating to that of a Norman arch.<tei:lb/>The premaxillary outline in S. diagramma, by contrast, has a virtually straight and wide anterior<tei:lb/>margin, with the short posterior dentigerous arms meeting it almost at right angles; the outline</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>318 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>of the bone is thus more nearly that of a hollow square. The posterior dentigerous arms of the<tei:lb/>premaxilla in 5 1 . diagramma are slightly bullate, whereas in L. dardennii they are slender and<tei:lb/>compressed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are, of course, comparable interspecific differences in the occlusal outline of the dentary.<tei:lb/>In Limnotilapia dardennii the lateral arms of the dentary are protracted relative to the trans-<tei:lb/>versely directed anterior part of the bone, and the outline of the whole bone is similar to that of<tei:lb/>the premaxilla. In Simochromis diagramma the dentary, like the premaxilla, is foreshortened, with<tei:lb/>the short lateral dentigerous arms (about equal in length to the transverse part) meeting the<tei:lb/>slightly curved transverse portion at almost a right angle. The dentary in S. diagramma also<tei:lb/>differs from that of L. dardennii in having virtually no upward sweep to its coronoid portion; in<tei:lb/>L. dardennii this region slopes upward at a gentle but noticeable angle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Seen in these terms, the osteological 'morphological gap' separating the taxa would appear to<tei:lb/>be a more substantial one than that expressed in Regan's (1920) key and generic synopsis. But,<tei:lb/>the 'gap' is bridged when one examines the premaxilla and dentary of Limnotilapia loocki Poll,<tei:lb/>1949 (see Poll, 1956 : 62, fig. 10 for an expanded description of the species, and illustrations of<tei:lb/>the jaws and dentition).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The morphology of both these bones in L. loocki is virtually intermediate between those in<tei:lb/>L. dardennii and S. diagramma. Thus, it is impossible to differentiate the 'genera' on the osteologi-<tei:lb/>cal features characterizing the jaws of the type species. Furthermore, the external oral characters<tei:lb/>used by Regan (1920) also intergrade when growth-series of the type species are examined, and<tei:lb/>I have been unable to detect other characters that might serve to distinguish the taxa (it being<tei:lb/>understood that the 'genera' are being interpreted here, as they were by Regan, merely on the<tei:lb/>presence of a discrete morphological gap that is 'greater' than one which might be used to<tei:lb/>characterize species). There would, therefore, seem to be no grounds for treating Limnotilapia and<tei:lb/>Simochromis as distinct genera, the more so when one considers the various (and apparently<tei:lb/>synapomorphic) features that are shared by all but one of their included species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Limnotilapia loocki (like L. dardennii, Simochromis diagramma, S. babaulti Pellegrin, S. curvifrons<tei:lb/>Poll and S. marginatus Poll) has, in both jaws, slender-shafted, recurved, outer teeth with markedly<tei:lb/>compressed and expanded, obliquely bicuspid crowns, a greatly reduced (or absent) interspace<tei:lb/>between the numerous inner and single outer tooth rows in both jaws, a densely toothed lower<tei:lb/>pharyngeal bone (the teeth fine and compressed) and a strongly decurved anterior profile to the<tei:lb/>neurocranium (where, in some species, the ethmovomerine region is almost vertically inclined)<tei:lb/>In all these species, too, the chest scales are small, deeply embedded and have an abrupt size<tei:lb/>demarcation with the larger scales on the anterior abdominal region of the body.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For the moment it is these apparently apomorphic features which should be used to define the<tei:lb/>genus Simochromis Blgr., 1898 (with which is now included, as a junior synonym, the genus<tei:lb/>Limnotilapia Regan, 1920).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The one species not included in the character analysis given above is Limnotilapia trematoce-<tei:lb/>phala (Blgr., 1901), a taxon known only from its holotype. I have not, of course, been able to<tei:lb/>examine all the relevant osteological features in this specimen, but its relatively sparsely toothed<tei:lb/>lower pharyngeal bone, the morphology of its outer row jaw teeth (which are without noticeably<tei:lb/>compressed, expanded and obliquely bicuspid crowns, and which are not strongly recurved), and<tei:lb/>its relatively large pectoral scales, all suggest that the species probably belongs to a different<tei:lb/>lineage and should not, therefore, be included in the genus Simochromis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For the moment it is impossible to indicate the phyletic relationships of the genus Simochromis,<tei:lb/>either within or without the cichlid flocks of Lake Tanganyika. Much further research will be<tei:lb/>required before this can be achieved (and will also be needed before a generic placement of<tei:lb/>''Limnotilapia'' trematocephala can be effected).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As was noted in my paper on the pharyngeal apophysis in African cichlids (Greenwood, 1978),<tei:lb/>Simochromis dardennii has a near-typical Tilapia-type of apophyseal structure. Simochromis<tei:lb/>loocki, on the other hand, has an apophysis of the modified Tropheus-type; the basioccipital is<tei:lb/>inflated and bullate, with its ventral tip almost reaching the level of the parasphenoidal facets but<tei:lb/>not contributing in any way to the articular surface provided by these facets. In its general<tei:lb/>organization, the apophysis in S. loocki is intermediate between the Tilapia and Tropheus types</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE HAPLOCHROMIS GENERIC CONCEPT 319</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(see Greenwood, 1978), but differs from the modal condition of both types in having the basiocci-<tei:lb/>pital noticeably inflated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Since S. dardennii (with a Tilapia-type apophysis) has the least specialized premaxillary and<tei:lb/>dentary of any Simochromis species, and since S. babaulti and S. diagramma have the most<tei:lb/>derived jaws (the species having, respectively, Tropheus and near Haplochromis type apophyses;<tei:lb/>see Greenwood, 1978), it is tempting to conclude that in this lineage the Tilapia-type apophysis<tei:lb/>is the plesiomorph one. That S. loocki (whose jaw morphology is intermediate between that of<tei:lb/>S. dardennii and those of the other Simochromis species) has an apophysis intermediate between<tei:lb/>the Tilapia and Tropheus types, would also seem to support this hypothesis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Finally, it is my pleasure to thank my colleagues of the freshwater fish section (then including<tei:lb/>Dr Richard Vari, a NATO postdoctoral research fellow) for the innumerable arguments we have<tei:lb/>had on the subject of phylogenetic systematics.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Monographs &amp; Handbooks</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Museum publishes some 10-12 new titles each year on subjects<tei:lb/>including zoology, botany, palaeontology and mineralogy.<tei:lb/>Besides being important reference works, many, particularly among<tei:lb/>the handbooks, are useful for courses and students' background<tei:lb/>reading.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lists are available free on request to :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Publications Sales</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cromwell Road</tei:p>
         <tei:p>London SW7 5BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Standing orders placed by educational institutions earn a discount<tei:lb/>of 10% off our published price.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>Miscellanea</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The planktonic copepods of the northeastern Atlantic Ocean:<tei:lb/>Harpacticoida, Siphonostomatoida and Mormonilloida. By G. A.<tei:lb/>Boxshall.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Bulletin of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A revision of the British species of the<tei:lb/>genus Phthiracarus Perty, 1841<tei:lb/>(Cryptostigmata: Euptyctima)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. W. Parry</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Zoology series Vol 35 No 5 28 June 1979</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology, and<tei:lb/>an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready. Volumes will contain about<tei:lb/>three hundred pages, and will not necessarily be completed within one calendar year.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subscription orders and enquiries about back issues should be sent to: Publications Sales,<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London SW7 5BD, England.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World List abbreviation : Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Zool.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History), 1979</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This number completes volume 35</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISSN 0007-1498 Zoology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol 35 No 5 pp 323-363<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road<tei:lb/>London SW7 5BD Issued 28 June 1979</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>'Complete' and 'reduced' leg chaetotaxy - a possible basis for a subdivision of the<tei:lb/>genus Phthiracarus ...........</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements ............</tei:p>
         <tei:p>References .............</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Appendix 1. Species described between 1763 and 1977 currently classified in<tei:lb/>Phthiracarus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A detailed account is presented of the external morphology of the British representatives of the genus<tei:lb/>Phthiracarus. The literature relating to the genus is reviewed and the status of certain of the older species<tei:lb/>considered. Thirteen British species, seven of which are considered to be new, are described, figured and<tei:lb/>keyed. Of these, only P. affinis (Hull), P. anonymum Grandjean and P. murphyi Harding were known<tei:lb/>previously from the British Isles, while P. laevigatus (C. L. Koch), P. nitens (Nicolet) and P. tardus<tei:lb/>Forsslund are recorded for the first time. A neotype for P. affinis is designated. On the basis of the chaeto-<tei:lb/>tactic pattern of the legs it is suggested that the genus could be divided into two species groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. not. Hist. (Zool.) 35 (5) : 323-363. Issued 28 June 1979</tei:p>
         <tei:p>323</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>324 B. W. PARRY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genus Phthiracarus comprises free-living ptychoid mites occurring predominantly in the<tei:lb/>upper layers of highly organic forest soils. Containing about 70 nominate species (see Appendix 1),<tei:lb/>it is the largest of the Euptyctimoid genera and in many respects the most difficult to study. Apart<tei:lb/>from P. anonymum Grandjean and certain of the more recently described species (notably P.<tei:lb/>mwphyi Harding), the original descriptions have been somewhat superficial and it is even doubt-<tei:lb/>ful whether some of the nominate species listed in Appendix 1 have been correctly assigned to<tei:lb/>Phthiracarus. Partial revisions of the genus have been published by Jacot (1930, 1936, 1938 &amp;<tei:lb/>1939), Feider &amp; Suciu (1957) and van der Hammen (1963 &amp; 1964) but only two of the species<tei:lb/>redescribed, namely, P. laevigatus (C. L. Koch) and P. nitens (Nicolet), can now be positively<tei:lb/>identified. The only substantial keys to the genus are those published by Willmann (1931),<tei:lb/>Sellnick (1960), and Gilyarov &amp; Krivolutsky (1975), all of which employ characters that have<tei:lb/>proved generally to be useless for species differentiation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Materials and methods</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This revision is based on a comprehensive survey of the literature and detailed morphological<tei:lb/>studies of all the available Phthiracarus material from widely separated areas in the British Isles.<tei:lb/>A large part of the material was taken from the unnamed and unsorted collections of the British<tei:lb/>Museum (Natural History). Additional material was obtained from a series of fermentation and<tei:lb/>humus layer samples collected under stands of beech, larch, oak, Scots pine and Sitka spruce at<tei:lb/>the following four areas: The Woburn Estate, Bedfordshire; New Forest, Hampshire; Tintern<tei:lb/>Forest, Monmouthshire; Alice Holt Forest, Surrey. These four areas were sampled during the<tei:lb/>period April 1972 to October 1973 as part of a study designed to compare the effects of hardwood<tei:lb/>and coniferous tree species on populations of Euptyctima and full descriptions of the sampling<tei:lb/>sites will be published elsewhere. The mites were extracted using a 'controlled-gradient' funnel<tei:lb/>apparatus similar to that described by Macfadyen (1961). All the available type material of<tei:lb/>Phthiracarus species has also been examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For detailed studies of the external morphology, the mites were cleared and softened by heating<tei:lb/>in a test tube of 75 % lactic acid in a boiling water bath, the duration of heating being dependent<tei:lb/>on the degree of sclerotization. Each mite was then transferred to a small quantity of Berlese's<tei:lb/>fluid on a slide and dissected using two fine needles. Cavity slides containing lactic acid were used<tei:lb/>for temporary preparations of the aspis, notogaster, ventral plates and ovipositor. Permanent<tei:lb/>preparations of the legs, chelicerae and infracapitulum requiring examination under oil immersion<tei:lb/>were made on plain slides in Berlese's fluid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For each species measurements were taken from all the available specimens. The length of the<tei:lb/>aspis was taken along the mid-dorsal line and the greatest width as the transverse distance between<tei:lb/>the antiaxial margins of the bothridia. The sensillus, interlamellar and lamellar setae were mea-<tei:lb/>sured with the aspis mounted dorsally and the rostrals with the aspis positioned laterally. The<tei:lb/>notogaster was measured in lateral aspect and the length was taken from the anterodorsal limit<tei:lb/>of the collar to a point just ventral to seta h\. The greatest depth of the notogaster was measured<tei:lb/>between the seta e\ and the ventral margin. Each chelicera was measured from the base of the<tei:lb/>principal segment to the end of the fixed digit. For detailed study of the leg chaetotaxy, the legs<tei:lb/>were positioned laterally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morphological studies were also undertaken using the scanning electron microscope - good<tei:lb/>results being obtained using air-dried spirit-preserved material. Any foreign matter adhering to<tei:lb/>the specimens was first removed by brief treatment in an ultrasonic bath. The mites were then<tei:lb/>soaked in a small quantity of an anti-static solution of 0-5 % 'Duron' in isobutyl alcohol for a<tei:lb/>period of 12-24 h (Sikorski el al., 1967). It was found that this treatment eliminated any 'charging'<tei:lb/>due to incomplete coating of cavities such as the bothridia. After soaking, the specimens were<tei:lb/>removed from the solution, washed in isobutyl alcohol and allowed to dry. The mites were stuck<tei:lb/>onto specimen stubs using double-sided adhesive tape and coated with a 20 nm layer of evaporated<tei:lb/>gold.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE GENUS PHTHIRACARUS 325</tei:p>
         <tei:p>External morphology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The following account of the external morphology of Phthiracarus refers to the adult only; full<tei:lb/>descriptions of the immature stages will form the basis of another paper. The setal nomenclature<tei:lb/>used in the later works of Grandjean has been followed throughout the account.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Idiosoma</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ASPIS; Fig. 1B-D; PI. la, e): A pair of oval weakly-sclerotized areas anterodorsally marks the<tei:lb/>positions of the retracted chelicerae. The ventral margin of the aspis is reflexed to form the<tei:lb/>aspal rim (a.r.) and there is a distinct lateral ridge (l.r.). The bothridium (b.) has an inner multi-<tei:lb/>chambered wall and a smooth outer one from which three finger-like chitinous tracheoles arise and<tei:lb/>are directed mid-dorsally. The margin of the bothridial aperture is thickened (as shown by the<tei:lb/>arrow in PI. le) and flanked posteriorly by a pronounced scale. There are three pairs of procum-<tei:lb/>bent dorsal setae, the rostrals (ro), lamellars (la) and interlamellars (//), and two pairs of setae<tei:lb/>laterally, the exobothridials (ex) and the sensilli. In most of the species examined, setae // and la<tei:lb/>are located at the level of the bothridia, la being somewhat shorter than //. The sensilli are variable<tei:lb/>in form and so provide a useful taxonomic feature. In some species they are short, ovate or<tei:lb/>lanceolate while in others they are long, narrow and tapering. The sensillar margin may be<tei:lb/>serrated (PI. la) and in P. serrulatus sp. nov. it bears a number of straight-edged teeth sub-<tei:lb/>terminally. The sensillus is most easily observed in scanning electron micrographs as in flattened<tei:lb/>slide preparations its appearance can depend very much on orientation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOTOGASTER (Fig. 1A, E; PI. le): The anterior margin of the notogaster is well sclerotized and,<tei:lb/>following Jacot (1930), can be subdivided into three regions: the thickened collar (C), thepseudo-<tei:lb/>stigmatic [sensillar] notch (N) (PI. le) and the lappet (L) which projects somewhat anteriorly. Of<tei:lb/>the 15 pairs of setae, 14 are regarded as being homologues of ci_3 and cp, d\-2, 1-2, A 1-3 and<tei:lb/>psi-3 of the holotrich nomenclature, and the additional seta as ps*. The distributional pattern of<tei:lb/>notogastral setae is essentially similar in all the British species but the relative lengths and attitudes<tei:lb/>of the setae vary considerably from one species to another. The vestiges of setae (f\) and (/2) are<tei:lb/>thought to be represented by two pairs of subcuticular structures located posterolaterally<tei:lb/>(Grandjean, 1950). Vestigial f\ normally lies between setae h\ and/wi and/2 between setae h\ and<tei:lb/>hi but in certain small species (for example, P. serrulatus} f\ is closely associated with the seta hi.<tei:lb/>There are four pairs of prominent subcuticular fissures: the anteriors (id) and medians (im) are<tei:lb/>situated just posterior to seta cp while the posterior pleurals (ip) and infrapleurals (ips) (when<tei:lb/>present) are situated on either side between setae /*2 and h$ and between setae ps$ and ps*<tei:lb/>respectively.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ANO-GENITAL REGION (Figs 2E; 3B; PI. Ib): On each anal plate there are five setae. Two anal<tei:lb/>setae an\-2 are located on the paraxial margin and three adanals ad\-$ submarginally ; setae ad\-2<tei:lb/>are often vestigial. Each anal plate has a prominent hood-like lobe located ventro-anteriorly on<tei:lb/>its paraxial margin and in the so-called 'left fitting' arrangement (van der Hammen, 1963) the<tei:lb/>lobe on the right-hand plate overlaps that on the left-hand plate while in the 'right fitting' arrange-<tei:lb/>ment (as shown by the arrow in Fig. 2E) the reverse is true. Van der Hammen has suggested that<tei:lb/>the arrangement of these interlocking lobes and the condition of setae ad\-2 (present or vestigial)<tei:lb/>could be useful taxonomic features. This view is not, however, supported by the present study<tei:lb/>since these two features have been found to exhibit considerable intraspecific variation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>On each genital plate there are two well-developed anterior ridges separated by a median furrow.<tei:lb/>The furrow bears a single aggenital seta ag\ antiaxially (PI. Ib). There are nine genital setae<tei:lb/>arranged in two rows. The anterior five setae g\-s are minute and located on the paraxial border<tei:lb/>while the posterior four setae ge-9 are moderately short and submarginal. There are three pairs of<tei:lb/>genital papillae (g.p.}, the anterior pair being rather small. Elongate oval structures have been<tei:lb/>observed inside the genital papillae and these may prove to be spermatophores. The first two<tei:lb/>pairs of genital papillae border the ovipositor, which, when fully extended, can be seen to be a<tei:lb/>rather short tube divided into a distal and a proximal portion by a weak circular constriction.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>326</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. W. PARRY</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE GENUS PHTHIRACARUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>327</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 2 Phthiracarus affinis: (A) pedipalp; (B) chelicera, antiaxial; (C) chelicera, paraxial ; (D)<tei:lb/>infracapitulum, ventral ; (E) ano-genital region.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>328</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. W. PARRY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 3 Phthiracarus affinis: (A) coxisternal region; (B) ovipositor, lateral.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The six coronal (k) setae which Grandjean (1956) found on the constriction in Heminothrus<tei:lb/>targionii (Berlese) and in the 'higher' oribatid mite Eremaeus hepaticus C. L. Koch are apparently<tei:lb/>absent in all the British Phthiracarus species. The surfaces of both portions of the ovipositor are<tei:lb/>strongly pleated. Distally, three eugenital lobes surround the opening of the ovipositor: an<tei:lb/>unpaired ventral lobe and a pair of laterodorsal lobes (as shown by the arrows in Fig. 3B). The<tei:lb/>ventral lobe is triangular in anterior view and bears two pairs of setae distally (\|/i-2), the posterior<tei:lb/>pair (11/2) being the shorter. The two laterodorsal lobes are larger, compressed laterally, and each<tei:lb/>bears seven setae (TI-V) antiaxially.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Feider &amp; Suciu (1957) figured two pairs of setae, presumably (\|/i) and (vj/a), on the ovipositor<tei:lb/>of P. lentulus (C. L. Koch), and in P. parabotrichus Feider &amp; Suciu, a dorsal group of seven setae<tei:lb/>and a smaller ventral group of three setae were shown, possibly (T) and (\|/) respectively. Harding<tei:lb/>(1976), in his description of P. murphyi, identified 16 setae on the ovipositor: three setae on each<tei:lb/>of the laterodorsal lobes, two setae on the ventral lobe and six setae which he considered as the<tei:lb/>coronals.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gnathosoma</tei:p>
         <tei:p>INFRACAPITULUM (Fig. 2D; PI. Ic): The lateral lips (L) bear three pairs of adoral setae (ori_ 3 ),<tei:lb/>the anterior pair (or\) being brush-like (PI. Ic) and the two posterior pairs weakly serrated. The<tei:lb/>infracapitulum is 'sternarthrous' (Grandjean, 1957) and the rutella (RU) are without atelobasic<tei:lb/>expansions. There are three pairs of infracapitular setae: an anterior (a) and a median pair (m)<tei:lb/>of long smooth setae located on the genae (G) and a rather short posterior pair (h) located on<tei:lb/>the hysterostoma (H). Laterally there is a single pair of barbed supracoxal setae (e).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PEDIPALPS (Fig. 2A; PI. Id): The pedipalps are only three-segmented. The basal segment,<tei:lb/>formed from the fused trochanter, femur and genu, bears two setae, the tibia two setae and the<tei:lb/>tarsus seven setae and a solenidion. The three most distal of the tarsal setae are eupathidial: the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE GENUS PHTHIRACARUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>329</tei:p>
         <tei:p>anteroculminal acm, anterior ultimal ul' and posterior ultimal ul" . The subultimal seta sul is a<tei:lb/>minute spine-like process at the base of seta ul' (as shown by the arrow in PI. Id) and also appears<tei:lb/>to be eupathidial.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CHELICERAE (Fig. 2B, C) : Both the fixed and the movable digits are dentate. The movable digit<tei:lb/>has four teeth and the fixed digit carries five. The latter are arranged in two rows, an outer one<tei:lb/>of two and an inner one of three teeth. The large principal segment which terminates in the fixed<tei:lb/>digit, bears a number of short conical spines on the antiaxial surface and a larger number of<tei:lb/>sharply pointed spines paraxially; the spines are distributed extensively on the paraxial surface<tei:lb/>but are restricted to a more compact zone antiaxially. There are two cheliceral setae, an anterior<tei:lb/>seta chb inserted on the antiaxial surface and &amp; posterior seta cha located dorsally. Both setae are<tei:lb/>serrated, cha being somewhat longer than chb.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legs</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legs II to IV are approximately equal in length while leg I is longer and more robust. The indivi-<tei:lb/>dual epimera are separate and, except for epimera II, each bears a single seta, la, 3a and 4a<tei:lb/>respectively (Fig. 3A). All the legs have five segments: the trochanter, femur, genu, tibia and<tei:lb/>tarsus, and terminate in a single claw bearing two ventral teeth and an antero- and posterolateral<tei:lb/>row of serrations (PI. 2c).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SOLENIDIA (PI. 2a, b, e): The solenidiotaxy (12-1-3; II 1-1-2; III 1-1-0 and IV 0-1-0) is<tei:lb/>constant in the 13 species examined and typical of that found in other Phthiracaridae. All the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 4 Phthiracarus affinis, leg 1 : (A) tarsus, dorsal aspect; (B) trochanter to tibia, posterolateral<tei:lb/>aspect.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>330</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. W. PARRY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tc"</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 5 Phthiracarus affinis, legs II-IV; (A) leg II, posterolateral aspect; (B) leg III, anterolateral<tei:lb/>aspect; (C) leg IV, anterolateral aspect. (Fig. 5A-C are drawn at the same magnification.)</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE GENUS PHTHIRACARUS 331</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tarsal solenidia are transversely striated as described by Grandjean (1935) for Oribotritia berlesei<tei:lb/>(Michael). On tarsus I the solenidion GDI is closely associated with the famulus e (PI. 2a) which is<tei:lb/>short and rugose. Solenidion 0)2 is the longest of the three tarsal solenidia and has a small distal<tei:lb/>coupling seta (PI. 2b). Harding (1976) described such a setal/solenidial association in P. murphyi<tei:lb/>and in P. nitens but noted that solenidion 02 was apparently free in P. anonymum. In the present<tei:lb/>study the scanning electron microscope has revealed the presence of a distal coupling seta in all<tei:lb/>the British species. Although usually short and simple, in P. rectisetosus sp. nov. this seta is long,<tei:lb/>prominent and apparently divided into two parts by a longitudinal constriction, the distal part<tei:lb/>being produced into a scabre-shaped process reminiscent of that found in species of the genus<tei:lb/>Steganacarus (see Parry, 1978). On all legs the tibial solenidion cp is coupled with a reduced dorsal<tei:lb/>seta (PI. 2e) while on genu I solenidion crj is coupled with a reduced lateral seta.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LEG SETAE (Figs 4; 5; 14; PI. 2d): In all the larger species examined the formulae for the leg<tei:lb/>setae are: I (1-4-2-5-16-1); II (1-3-2-3-12-1); III (2-2-1-2-10-1) and IV (2-1-1-2-10-1). This<tei:lb/>complement will be referred to as the 'complete chaetotaxy type' (Figs 4; 5). On tarsus I only 16<tei:lb/>of the 20 setae regarded by Grandjean (1940) as being characteristic of 'higher' Oribatei are<tei:lb/>present, the primilaterals and postlarvals always being absent. Four setae surround the base of the<tei:lb/>claw, namely, a dorsal pair of pr orals (p) and a ventral pair of unguinials (u). Three pairs of setae<tei:lb/>are located posterodorsally to the prorals: the iterals (if), tectals (tc) and fastigials (ft). Ventrally,<tei:lb/>behind the unguinials, there is an unpaired subunguinial seta s and a pair of primiventral setae<tei:lb/>(pv). A single pair of anterolateral setae (a) is located laterally behind the prorals and the<tei:lb/>unguinials.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>On tarsi II to IV there is a reduction in the number of setae to 12, 10 and 10 respectively: setae<tei:lb/>(it), a' and e are absent on tarsi II to IV, setapv" on tarsus III, seta a" on tarsi III and IV and seta<tei:lb/>ft" on tarsus IV. Furthermore, the tarsal setae exhibit considerable variety in form. On tarsus I<tei:lb/>six of the setae (s, (it), (p) and a') are hollow eupathidia. On all four tarsi setae (ft) and (pv),<tei:lb/>together with a" on tarsi I and II, are generally more or less straight, circular in section and bear<tei:lb/>two or three rows of lateral serrations. In certain species (for example, P. globus sp. nov.) seta<tei:lb/>ft" on tarsus II is hooked distally. The other tarsal setae, (tc) and (u) on tarsus I and (tc), (u), (p)<tei:lb/>and s on tarsi II to IV, are ribbon-like, hooked distally and covered with whorls of spicules in the<tei:lb/>middle third. Such setal ornamentation is, however, only discernible in the larger species of the<tei:lb/>genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The setation of the four proximal leg segments is shown in Table 1 . Apart from tibia I which<tei:lb/>bears a whorl of five setae (d, I', I", v' and v"), each of the other segments bears an incomplete<tei:lb/>whorl of one to four setae. Seta d on femur I is somewhat thickened, serrated and curved distally<tei:lb/>(PI. 2d) in all the species examined except P. clavatus sp. nov. and P. globus sp. nov. where it is<tei:lb/>rather long, straight and only weakly serrated. On all segments setae (/) and (v) carry two or three<tei:lb/>rows of serrations.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 1 Chaetotaxy of the four proximal leg segments in Phthiracarus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Segment Leg I II III IV</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In all the smaller species of the genus (for example, P. tardus Forsslund) there are fewer setae<tei:lb/>on legs I, II and IV (Fig. 14): tarsus I bears 15 setae (a 1 absent), tarsi II and IV usually bear 11<tei:lb/>and 9 setae respectively (s absent), femur I bears 3 setae (v' absent) and genu IV is without any<tei:lb/>setae (/' absent). Thus the setal formulae (referred to here as the 'reduced chaetotaxy type') are:<tei:lb/>I (1-3-2-5-15-1); II (1-3-2-3-11-1); III (2-2-1-2-10-1) and IV (2-1-0-2-9-1). In P. anonymum<tei:lb/>(a variant of the 'reduced phaetotaxy type') the number of setae on tarsus IV is further reduced</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>332 B. W. PARRY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>by the absence of seta pv'. Although the total number of setae on leg III is constant throughout<tei:lb/>the genus, in species of the 'complete chaetotaxy group' seta pv" is absent and seta s present<tei:lb/>while the reverse is true in the 'reduced' group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Review</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Perty proposed the genus Phthiracarus in 1 839 and two years later created the 'family' Phthiracarea<tei:lb/>(now Phthiracaridae) for the single species P. contractilis. Perty's original specimens are presumed<tei:lb/>to be lost and his figures (subsequently published by Claparede, 1868) and description are such<tei:lb/>as to make the specific identity of contractilis impossible to determine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acarus piger Scopoli, 1763, the oldest species currently classified in Phthiracarus, was originally<tei:lb/>assigned to the genus by Oudemans (1915). The mite described by Scopoli, for which there is no<tei:lb/>type material available, is undoubtedly ptychoid but there is no evidence to suggest that it is a<tei:lb/>species of Phthiracarus - it is probably a member of the Euphthiracaroidea (see Jacot, 1930).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The systematic position of Oribates dasypus Duges, 1 834 is also somewhat uncertain although<tei:lb/>the species is evidently ptychoid. Michael (1888) recorded dasypus in the British Isles. The speci-<tei:lb/>men labelled Hoplophora* dasypus from Theydon Bois in the Michael Collection (deposited in<tei:lb/>the BMNH) is P. clavatus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In 1841 ten species of Hoplophora, ninef of which are currently classified in Phthiracarus, were<tei:lb/>described by Koch from woodland habitats near Regensburg. While it seems probable that these<tei:lb/>mites have been correctly assigned to Phthiracarus (with the ecxeption of H. testudinea which is<tei:lb/>possibly a member of the Euphthiracaroidea), only two of Koch's descriptions refer to 'key<tei:lb/>characters' which might permit certain reidentification. In comparison with the other Regensburg<tei:lb/>species, H. globosa is very 'globular' while in H. laevigata the notogaster is 'angled' at the level of<tei:lb/>seta c\. The remaining six species can only be divided into two groups on the basis of their<tei:lb/>notogastral setae; crinita, ferruginea and longula are each characterized by 'long setae' while the<tei:lb/>other three species (lentula, lucida and straminea) are all described as being 'sparsely setose'.<tei:lb/>Despite the inadequacy of Koch's descriptions and the apparent absence of any type material,<tei:lb/>various interpretations of his species have been published, amongst others by Jacot and van der<tei:lb/>Hammen. In Les Phthiracaridae de Karl Ludwig Koch, Jacot (1936) redescribed six species from<tei:lb/>topotypic material but neglected details of the leg and notogastral chaetotaxy, now regarded as<tei:lb/>being essential for the separation of Phthiracarus species. More recently, van der Hammen (1963),<tei:lb/>in one of his series of papers on the Phthiracaridae, has published a detailed description of P.<tei:lb/>laevigatus (from material collected at Regensburg) and has designated a neotype. Van der Hammen<tei:lb/>(personal communication) also believes that he has topotypic material of Koch's seven other<tei:lb/>species but until these specimens have been examined it seems advisable to postpone any decision<tei:lb/>concerning their taxonomic status.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hoplophora nitens Nicolet (1855), recorded as common in the woods around Paris, is a Phthira-<tei:lb/>carus species. The true identity of nitens appears to be doubtful, although van der Hammen's<tei:lb/>redescription (see Hammen, 1964) from topotypic material is generally accepted.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hoploderma italicum Oudemans (1907), recorded from Tiarno, Italy, is not based on a type<tei:lb/>specimen but on Berlese's description of H. dasypus which Oudemans regarded as being distinct<tei:lb/>from O. dasypus Duges. Van der Hammen (1952) considers the specimens of both Berlese and<tei:lb/>Oudemans as being useless for reidentification purposes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>* Certain species now assigned to Phthiracarus have in the past been classified in two other genera, Hoplophora<tei:lb/>C. L. Koch and Hoploderma Michael. The genus Hoplophora was erected by Koch in 1836 for two species, H.<tei:lb/>decumana C. L. Koch and H. stricula C. L. Koch, currently classified in Oribotritia and Steganacarus respectively.<tei:lb/>In 1841 Koch described further species of Hoplophora but did not publish a diagnosis of the genus or designate a<tei:lb/>type (H. laevigata) until the following year. Jacot's 1928 application to the International Commission on Zoological<tei:lb/>Nomenclature for a ruling on the validity of the type designation (Koch, 1842) for a genus first published six<tei:lb/>years earlier (Koch, 1836) was not published until 1946 (see Jacot, 1946). The Commission's subsequent ruling<tei:lb/>(I.C.Z.N., 1953) allowed H. laevigata to be retained as the type (H. laevigata is here regarded as a species of<tei:lb/>Phthiracarus) since the genus was not originally monotypic and did not contain a species called typus or typicus.<tei:lb/>However, the generic name Hoplophora had been found by Michael (1898) to be preoccupied by Hoplophora Perty,<tei:lb/>1 833 (Neuroptera), and the new name Hoploderma was proposed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>t The tenth species of Hoplophora, H. ardua, is now classified in Rhysotritia.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE GENUS PHTHIRACARUS 333</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hoploderma boreale Triigardh (1910) and Hoploderma affine Hull (1914) are both Phthiracarus<tei:lb/>species. This is evident from the figures of these mites and has been confirmed by examination of<tei:lb/>'cotype' and syntype material respectively. The characteristic features of these two species are now<tei:lb/>certain.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Oudemans (1915) proposed the name Phthiracarus undatus for the 'larve' of Hoplophora<tei:lb/>stricula (sensu Nicolet, 1855). While Nicolet's figures and description appear to refer to an adult<tei:lb/>oribatid mite, there is no evidence to suggest a Phthiracarus species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Berlese (1920 &amp; 1923) described six species of Phthiracarus: rotundus, roubali and subglobosus<tei:lb/>are European while P. nigerrimus was collected from Argentina, P. curtulus from the United<tei:lb/>States and P. pudicus from South Africa. The type of each of these species has been examined by<tei:lb/>Dr J. G. Sheals (BMNH) who has found that their condition is such as to make any chaetotactic<tei:lb/>characters impossible to discern. In 1959 van der Hammen reviewed all Berlese's species of<tei:lb/>primitive oribatid mites deposited in the 'Stazione di Entomologia Agraria', Florence, but could<tei:lb/>not confirm the identities of any of the Phthiracarus species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Jacot (1928-1939) described 13 species from North America and a single species (P. insularis)<tei:lb/>from the Marquesas Islands. Of these, type material is available for eight species (see Appendix 1),<tei:lb/>seven of which are represented by a number of 'cotypes' while only P. brevisetae is based on a<tei:lb/>holotype. All Jacot's Phthiracarus specimens are mounted in Canada Balsam, the majority being<tei:lb/>entire and uncleared. The shape of the sensillus and the relative lengths and attitudes of the dorsal<tei:lb/>notogastral setae can usually be seen in such preparations but the leg chaetotaxy is extremely<tei:lb/>difficult to study. In view of the condition of Jacot's material, it seems advisable to postpone any<tei:lb/>decision regarding the identities of his Phthiracarus species until all the type specimens have been<tei:lb/>dismounted and cleared (an exercise which will be complicated by the presence on each 'cotype'<tei:lb/>slide of additional species of this and other genera). It can, however, be noted that P. brevisetae<tei:lb/>appears to be close to if not conspecific with P. laevigatus, while the differences between anonymus<tei:lb/>amicus and Grandjean's anonymum are evidently not sufficient to warrant subspecific ranking.<tei:lb/>P. insularis and P. setosellum bryobium possibly have affinities with two British species, P. murphyi<tei:lb/>and P. clavatus respectively.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In 1933 Grandjean published the first of a series of detailed works on the external morphology<tei:lb/>of P. anonymum, a species he recorded from rotting wood in his cellar at Perigueux, Dordogne,<tei:lb/>France. By clearing whole and dissected specimens (Grandjean, 1949) he was able to observe<tei:lb/>the patterns of setae on the body shields (Grandjean, 1933, 1934 &amp; 1950), which provided new<tei:lb/>criteria for the identification of species of this genus. Hitherto, species differentation had been<tei:lb/>based almost entirely on body shape and colour, two characters now known to be uniform in<tei:lb/>many Phthiracarus species. Grandjean (1935, 1940 &amp; 1946) also undertook the first detailed<tei:lb/>studies of the leg chaetotaxy of oribatid mites, introducing the system of nomenclature now in<tei:lb/>general use. However, in recent years the majority of Phthiracarus species have been defined<tei:lb/>solely in terms of characters visible in undissected material. Leg chaetotactic characters have<tei:lb/>only rarely been studied (van der Hammen, 1963; Sheals, 1965; Ramsay, 1966; Harding, 1976)<tei:lb/>probably due to difficulties in interpretation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Further Phthiracarus species have been described by Willmann (1932, 1939 &amp; 1951), Woolley<tei:lb/>(1954) and Forsslund (1956) (see under Descriptions of species). However, P. peristomaticus,<tei:lb/>recorded by Willmann (1951), from a number of habitats including leaves, turf and subsoil under<tei:lb/>buckthorn, guelder-rose and alder, nordlich Moosmiihle, near Vienna, Austria, cannot be<tei:lb/>identified either from Willmann's figure or from his description. Moreover, there are no specimens<tei:lb/>of P. peristomaticus in Willmann's Collection (Dr W. Hirschmann, personal communication).<tei:lb/>Feider et al. (1957, 1958 &amp; 1968) recorded eight species from Rumania, none of which were<tei:lb/>described in sufficient detail to permit certain reidentification, although P. baloghi, collected from<tei:lb/>oak leaves in lasi, appears to be unique among described species of the genus in having notogastral<tei:lb/>setae of two markedly different lengths. Unfortunately, it has not been possible to borrow the<tei:lb/>types of any of the Rumanian species for study. This was also the case with species described by<tei:lb/>Balogh (1958, 1962, 1963 &amp; 1977) and Krivolutsky (1966 &amp; 1975). Other Phthiracarus species<tei:lb/>have been described from Japan (Aoki, 1958 &amp; 1963), Chile (Hammer, 1962), Nepal (Sheals,<tei:lb/>1965), New Zealand (Ramsay, 1966), Spain (Perez-Inigo, 1969), Tahiti (Hammer, 1972), the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>334 B. W. PARRY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tonga Islands (Hammer, 1973) and the British Isles (Harding, 1976) (see Appendix 1). Of these,<tei:lb/>P. robertsi, recorded by Sheals from rhododendron litter in Nepal, is of particular interest for,<tei:lb/>although having certain affinities with Phthiracarus, it shows a general similarity to Steganacarus.<tei:lb/>The arrangement of setae on the genital and anal plates, while reminiscent of Phthiracarus, is<tei:lb/>nevertheless 'unusual' for setae ad\^ are almost marginal. The only diagnostic feature which<tei:lb/>P. robertsi appears to share with all species of the genus is the presence of a coupled solenidion<tei:lb/>on tibia IV. The general shape of the aspis and the form of the integumental ornamentation are<tei:lb/>characteristic of Steganacarus species and it is questionable whether P. robertsi should have been<tei:lb/>classified in Phthiracarus (see Sheals, 1969).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There have been relatively few reviews of the British species. In his Synonymic catalogue of<tei:lb/>British Acari, Turk (1953) listed only five species of Phthiracarus: piger (Scopoli) (=Hoplophora<tei:lb/>dasypus Duges sensu Michael), affine (Hull), anonymum Grandjean, ligneus Willmann and<tei:lb/>spinosum (Sellnick) (now classified in Steganacarus). Turk does not give sources for individual<tei:lb/>records but the above are presumably based on the following published records: Michael, 1888,<tei:lb/>Halbert, 1915 and Hull, 1916 (dasypus); Hull, 1914 (affine); Murphy, 1954 (anonymum);<tei:lb/>Macfadyen, 1952 (ligneus and spinosum). Of these, only P. affinis and anonymum are recognized<tei:lb/>in the present revision since the taxonomic status of the other two Phthiracarus species is doubtful.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Descriptions of species<tei:lb/>Genus PHTHIRACARUS Perty</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hoplophora Koch, 1836 : Hft. 2, Nr. 9. Preoccupied name (Michael, 1898 : 77). Type, by subsequent</tei:p>
         <tei:p>designation, Hoplophora laevigata Koch, 1841 : Hft. 38, Nr. 16.<tei:lb/>Phthiracarus Perty, 1839 : column 847. Type, by monotypy, Phthiracarus contractilis Perty, 1841 : 874.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figured by Claparede, 1868 : pi. 36, figs 15-19.<tei:lb/>Hoploderma Michael, 1898 : 77. Proposed as replacement name for Hoplophora Koch.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DEFINITION: Weak to heavily sclerotized Phthiracaridae ranging in length from about 350-<tei:lb/>1300um (lateral measurement taken in closed position). The integument of the dorsal and<tei:lb/>ventral shields, infracapitulum and chelicerae is densely punctate while that of the appendages is<tei:lb/>smooth. The interlamellar and lamellar setae are procumbent and the aspis without a median<tei:lb/>keel. The notogaster bears 15 pairs of fine and generally smooth setae. Fissures ip and ips may<tei:lb/>be present or absent. The notogaster bears neither a cowl nor a carina. Two pairs of anal setae<tei:lb/>are located on the paraxial margins of the anal plates and three pairs of adanals submarginally<tei:lb/>(the exception being P. anonymum with three pairs of setae located marginally). All are usually<tei:lb/>more or less equal in length although the two posterior pairs of adanal setae may be vestigial.<tei:lb/>The genital setae are arranged in a pattern of 5+4 along the paraxial margins of the genital<tei:lb/>plates. On leg IV the tibial solenidion is coupled.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS: Phthiracarus is distinguished from other genera of the Phthiracaridae by having a<tei:lb/>combination of procumbent interlamellar setae and a 2+3 arrangement of setae on the anal plates.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to adults of the British species of the genus Phthiracarus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Only two species can be recognized on the basis of a single character. In P. anonymum seta ad 3 is located<tei:lb/>marginally (submarginally in all other species) while P. laevigatus appears to differ from all the other<tei:lb/>members of this genus in that the notogaster is strongly arched at the level of seta c { .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It has been concluded from an investigation of the external morphology of the British species that the<tei:lb/>number of setae on femur I (4 or 3) and genu IV (1 or 0), the shape of the sensillus, the presence or ab-<tei:lb/>sence of fissures ip and ips and the relative lengths and attitudes of the notogastral setae are the most<tei:lb/>useful characters for species differentiation. These are the main characters used in the following key.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Femur I with four setae (Fig. 4B); genu IV with a single seta (Fig. 5C) .... 2<tei:lb/>Femur I with three setae (Fig. 14B); genu IV without setae . . . . . .9</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Notogastral fissures ip and ips absent (Fig. 1A) . . . . . ... 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Notogastral fissures ip and ips present (Fig. 10D) ........ 6</tei:p>

         <tei:p>- Sensillus serrated distally (Fig. 13B) ..... P. serrulatus sp. nov. (p. 348)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>- Notogastral setae greater than c 1 -d l and slightly flexuose (Fig. 7F); tarsus II with 11 setae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P.flexisetosus sp. nov. (p. 340)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracarus affinis (Hull)<tei:lb/>(Figsl;2;4;5;Pls2a, b, d; 3a, d)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hoploderma affine Hull, 1914 : 287, pi. C9.<tei:lb/>Phthiracarus affine: Turk, 1953 : 89.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (PI. 3a): Small and moderately sclerotized. The aspis (Fig. 1C, D) ranges in length from<tei:lb/>223 -253 um with a greatest width of 162-192 um. All the dorsal setae are fine and short.<tei:lb/>Setae (//) are about 1-5 times the length of setae (Id) and extend two-thirds of the distance between<tei:lb/>the bases of setae (//) and (ro). The latter do not reach the anterior limit of the aspis. The sensillus<tei:lb/>(Fig. IB; PI. 3d) is 50 - 60 um long, lanceolate and serrated. The notogaster (Fig. 1A, E) ranges<tei:lb/>in length from 406 - 487 um with a greatest depth of 294 - 345 urn. All the setae are relatively<tei:lb/>long (equal to the distance c\ - d\), fine and erect. Setae c\ and CT, are inserted on the posterior<tei:lb/>margin of the collar and seta 02 submarginally. Vestigial f\ is located a short distance posterior to<tei:lb/>seta hi. The fissures ip and ips are absent. On each anal plate (Fig. 2E) there are three setae; an\<tei:lb/>and a2 being much longer than ad*. The chelicerae (Fig. 2B, C) are about 121 um long. The<tei:lb/>principal segment carries 14-26 sharply pointed spines on the paraxial surface and 9-21<tei:lb/>conical spines antiaxially. The leg chaetotaxy (Figs 4; 5) is of the 'complete type' with the setal<tei:lb/>formulae: I (1-4-2-5-16-1); II (1-3-2-3-12-1); III (2-2-1-2-10-1) and IV (2-1-1-2-10-1). On<tei:lb/>tarsus I the distal seta coupled with solenidion 002 is short; its form can only be seen clearly in<tei:lb/>scanning electron micrographs (PI. 2a, b). Seta u' on tarsi I and II is often short and thick and<tei:lb/>resembles a eupathidium. On femur I seta d is short, serrated and curved distally (PI. 2d).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION: P. affinis is apparently widely distributed in forest soils with a mor humus<tei:lb/>formation. This species was recorded in the F (fermentation) and H (humus) layers under both<tei:lb/>the hardwood and coniferous tree species at each of the four study areas (see p. 324) being<tei:lb/>particularly abundant in the F layer under beech and oak where it constituted 20 - 30 % of the<tei:lb/>euptyctimoid population. Material collected from the following localities was also examined.:</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>336 B. W. PARRY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wytham Woods Estate, Berkshire, 28.X.70 (T. G. Wood); St. Agnes, Isles of Stilly, Cornwall,<tei:lb/>5.iv.57 (K. H. Hyatt); Bramshill Forest, Hampshire, 6.xii.70 (B. W. Parry); Woodwalton Fen,<tei:lb/>Huntingdonshire, 20.V.65 (P. N. Lawrence); Keston Bog, Kent, 8.i.56 (P. N. Lawrence); Thetford<tei:lb/>Chase, Norfolk, 23.vi.71 (B. W. Parry) ; Springwell Forest, Co. Londonderry, 1973 (J. Longworth);<tei:lb/>as well as material labelled 'Hoploderma affine Hull (Ninebanks)' in the Hull Collection deposited<tei:lb/>in the BMNH.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS: Hull (1914) recorded affinis in moss in woods and in Sphagnum on moors, West<tei:lb/>Allendale, Northumberland and Gibside, Durham and later (1916) included it in his key to<tei:lb/>species of the genus Hoploderma. A holotype does not appear to have been designated and no<tei:lb/>type material is known to exist. Hull's collection was found to contain one tube labelled<tei:lb/>Hoploderma affine. Three of the specimens are in good condition, conspecific and the shape of<tei:lb/>their sensilli corresponds with Hull's description: 'Pseudostigmatic organs prominent, slender,<tei:lb/>fusiform, curved outward and forward, rather long, with a fine point'. Moreover, the specimens<tei:lb/>are of a similar size to that given by Hull (about 420 urn). One of these specimens, BMNH reg.<tei:lb/>no. 1973.28 (now mounted in Berlese's fluid), is hereby designated as the neotype. The fourth<tei:lb/>specimen, although badly damaged, is clearly another larger species with a differently shaped<tei:lb/>sensillus. The other British material has been compared with the neotype - no morphological<tei:lb/>differences apart from size variation could be detected.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. affinis appears to be close to P. crenophilus, a species described by Willmann (1951) from the<tei:lb/>edge of a marsh, Ebreichsdorf, Austria, and earlier identified as P. borealis (Tragardh) (see<tei:lb/>Willmann, 1923, 1928 &amp; 1931). The syntype series (10 specimens collected in Austria, Germany<tei:lb/>and Switzerland) has been examined and found to be composed of two species, only one of which<tei:lb/>resembles Willmann's figure of crenophilus and also the neotype of P. affinis. However, the<tei:lb/>notogastral setae of the latter are considerably shorter than in P. crenophilus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracams anonymum Grandjean<tei:lb/>(Fig. 6; PI. 3b, e)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracarus anonymum Grandjean 1933 : 312 (ano-genital region); 1934 : 51 (aspis &amp; notogaster); 1950 :<tei:lb/>73 (setae /j,/ 2 and/?.v 4 ); van der Hammen, 1965 : 376 (leg chaetotaxy).<tei:lb/>[Phthiracarus anonymum: Feider &amp; Suciu, 1957 : 24. Misidentification.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (PI. 3b): Small, weakly sclerotized and opalescent. The aspis (Fig. 6C) ranges in length<tei:lb/>from 208 - 248 um with a greatest width of 162 - 172 urn. All the dorsal setae are fine and short.<tei:lb/>Setae (/'/) are about 1 -5 times the length of setae (la) and extend two-thirds of the distance il-ro.<tei:lb/>The rostrals which are inserted relatively far apart are widely removed from the anterior margin.<tei:lb/>The sensillus (Fig. 6D) is short (20 um), ovate and serrated. The notogaster (Fig. 6E) ranges in<tei:lb/>length from 406 - 466 um with a greatest depth of 253 - 294 jam. All the setae are short (less than<tei:lb/>the distance c\ - d\), fine and erect. Setae c\ and c^ are inserted on the posterior margin of the<tei:lb/>collar and seta ci submarginally. Vestigial/i is located just dorsal to seta h\. The fissures ip and ips<tei:lb/>are absent. On each anal plate (PI. 3e) there are five relatively short setae, of which, three,<tei:lb/>evidently adi and an\-2, are inserted on the paraxial margin, the longest in the row being an\<tei:lb/>which is approximately twice as long as ad^. The chelicerae are approximately 137 jim in length.<tei:lb/>The principal segment carries about 12 sharply pointed spines on Jhe paraxial surface and about<tei:lb/>10 conical spines antiaxially. The leg chaetotaxy is of the 'reduced type' with the setal formulae:<tei:lb/>I (1-3-2-5-15-1); II (1-3-2-3-11-1); III (2-2-1-2-10-1) and IV (2-1-0-2-8-1). On tarsus I<tei:lb/>(Fig. 6A) true setae and eupathidia are difficult to distinguish since the former are more or less<tei:lb/>straight distally. The distal seta coupled with solenidion 0)2 resembles that of P. affinis. Seta u' on<tei:lb/>tarsi I and II is often short and thick and resembles a eupathidium. On tarsus IV (Fig. 6B) seta<tei:lb/>pv' is absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION: P. anonymum, the only endophagous species identified in the present study, is<tei:lb/>apparently widely distributed in the F layer or mor forest soils. This species was common under<tei:lb/>both the hardwood and coniferous tree species at each of the study areas (see p. 324) being<tei:lb/>particularly abundant under oak where it constituted 5 - 10% of the euptyctimoid population.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE GENUS PHTHIRACARUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>337</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 6 Phthiracarus anonymum: (A) tarsus I, posterolateral aspect; (B) tarsus IV, posterolateral<tei:lb/>aspect; (C) aspis, dorsal; (D) sensillus and bothridium; (E) notogaster, lateral. (Fig. 6A, B are<tei:lb/>drawn at the same magnification.)</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>338 B. W. PARRY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Material was also examined from: Wytham Woods Estate, Berkshire, 28.x. 70 (T. G. Wood);<tei:lb/>Burnham Beeches, Buckinghamshire, 1964 (G. O. Evans); Bramshill Forest, Hampshire,<tei:lb/>6.xii.70 (B. W. Parry); Woodwalton Fen, Huntingdonshire, 20.iv.65 (P. N. Lawrence); Hollows<tei:lb/>Wood, Kent, 3.iv.60 (P. N. Lawrence); Grasmere, Westmorland, 3.xii.54 (M. Bacchus); Meathop<tei:lb/>Wood, Westmorland, 19.iii.63 (P. N. Lawrence); Shawley Woods, Worcestershire, 4.X.63 (F.<tei:lb/>Flowers); Springwell Forest, Co. Londonderry, 1973 (J. Longworth); Perigueux, Dordogne,<tei:lb/>France (topotypes).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS: In comparison with the other British Phthiracarus species examined, P. anonymum<tei:lb/>is somewhat atypical: it alone is opalescent; bears /j dorsal to hi; carries ad-}, on the paraxial<tei:lb/>margin of the anal plate and lacks the anterior primiventral seta on tarsus IV. The British material<tei:lb/>has been compared with a number of topotypes - no morphological differences could be detected.<tei:lb/>P. anonymus amicus Jacot, described from deciduous leaf mould, Connecticut Hill, New York,<tei:lb/>USA, may well prove to be conspecific with P. anonymum. Jacot (1938) based his description on<tei:lb/>the position of seta di and the length of seta an\ ; di was located further towards d\ than was in<tei:lb/>fact shown in Grandjean's figure (Grandjean, 1934) while seta an\ appeared to be longer. Although<tei:lb/>Grandjean's figure does indeed differ in these two respects from Jacot's anonymus amicus, the<tei:lb/>topotypic material of anonymum which has been examined agrees well with Jacot's description.<tei:lb/>A 'cotype' of anonymus amicus (slide no. 32108h2, undissected and mounted in Canada Balsam)<tei:lb/>has been examined and appears to be close to anonymum although the seta an\ is difficult to<tei:lb/>discern. Moreover, Jacot's species (diagonal length of notogaster about 400 um) falls within the<tei:lb/>size range given by Grandjean (notogastral length 330 - 420 um).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracarus clavatus sp. nov.<tei:lb/>(Fig. 7A-C;P1. 3c, f)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (PI. 3c) : Large and strongly sclerotized. The aspis (Fig. 7C) ranges in length from 279 -<tei:lb/>324 um with a greatest width of 192 - 208 um. All the dorsal setae are long and conspicuous.<tei:lb/>Setae (//) and (la) are more or less equal in length and both pairs of setae reach the level of the<tei:lb/>rostrals. The latter extend to the anterior margin of the aspis. In the paratype setae (la) are only<tei:lb/>half the length of setae (//). The sensillus (Fig. 7B; PI. 3f) is 30 - 40 um long, broadly clavate and<tei:lb/>distinctly serrated in the distal half. The notogaster (Fig. 7 A) ranges in length from 619 - 659 um<tei:lb/>with a greatest depth of 421 -458 um. All the setae are long (more than the distance c\ -di)<tei:lb/>and procurved. Setae ci_3 form a row just behind the posterior margin of the collar. Vestigial f\<tei:lb/>is located a short distance posterior to seta h\. The fissures ip and ips are absent. On each anal<tei:lb/>plate there are five long setae; an\-i and ad$ being more or less equal in length and somewhat<tei:lb/>shorter than ad\-2. The chelicerae are approximately 182 um in length. The principal segment<tei:lb/>carries about 20 sharply pointed spines on the paraxial surface and about 18 conical spines<tei:lb/>antiaxially. The leg chaetotaxy is of the 'complete type' with the setal formulae: I (1-4-2-5-16-1);<tei:lb/>II (1-3-2-3-12-1); III (2-2-1-2-10-1) and IV (2-1-1-2-10-1). On tarsus I the distal seta coupled<tei:lb/>with solenidion 002 is rather short. Seta d on femur I is long, straight and only weakly serrated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPES: Holotype, BMNH reg. no. 1976.2.18.1, from mull soil, Meathop Wood, Westmorland,<tei:lb/>19.iii.63 (P. N. Lawrence). Paratype, 1976.2.18.2, from Phragmites litter, Woodbastwick Marshes,<tei:lb/>Norfolk, 10.vii.74 (S. J. Moore).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION: P. clavatus was also recorded from The Woburn Estate, Bedfordshire, 10.iv.72<tei:lb/>(B. W. Parry) and from Rosthwaite, Cumberland, 18.V.59 (P. N. Lawrence). This species was not<tei:lb/>abundant in any of the samples examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS: P. clavatus appears to be similar to P. borealis (Tragardh) recorded in rotting birch<tei:lb/>leaves, Sarek, Swedish Lapland. Three 'cotypes' of borealis (cleared but undissected) were ex-<tei:lb/>amined and found to be generally larger (notogastral length 659 - 842 um) and more heavily<tei:lb/>sclerotized than clavatus. Moreover, in P. borealis the notogastral setae are erect while in P.<tei:lb/>clavatus they are procurved. The general form of the sensillus is similar in both species.<tei:lb/>P. clavatus also resembles P. setosellum bryobium described by Jacot (1930) from upland</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE GENUS PHTHIRACARUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>339</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 7A-C Phthiracarus clavatus: (A) notogaster, lateral; (B) sensillus and bothridium; (C)<tei:lb/>aspis, dorsal.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 7D-F Phthiracarus flexisetosus: (D) aspis, dorsal; (E) sensillus and bothridium; (F)<tei:lb/>notogaster, lateral.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>340</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. W. PARRY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>swamp moss, East Village, Monroe, Connecticut, USA. However, in comparison with clavatus,<tei:lb/>the 'cotype' of setosellum bryobium is much smaller (notogastral length about 252 um). The<tei:lb/>notogastral setae appear to be of the same general form in both species. The sensillus, which<tei:lb/>appears to be lobular in Jacot's figure, is missing in the 'cotype'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracams flexisetosus sp. nov.<tei:lb/>(Fig. 7D-F)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT: Medium-sized and moderately strongly sclerotized. The aspis (Fig.7D) ranges in length<tei:lb/>from 230- 255 um with a greatest width of 170- 220 um. All the dorsal setae are fine and<tei:lb/>rather long. Setae (//) are about 1 -5 times the length of setae (la) and equal to the distance il-ro.<tei:lb/>The rostrals, which are inserted relatively far apart, do not reach the anterior limit of the aspis.<tei:lb/>The sensillus (Fig. 7E) is 30 - 40 um long, broadly clavate, serrated and closely resembles that<tei:lb/>found in P. clavatus. The notogaster (Fig. 7F), about 560 um long and with a greatest depth of<tei:lb/>about 330 um, is elongate in lateral aspect. All the setae are long (more than the distance<tei:lb/>ci - d\), fine and slightly flexuose. Setae c\ and cj are inserted on the posterior margin of the collar<tei:lb/>and seta 2 submarginally. Vestigial f\ is located adjacent to seta h\ and towards the mid-dorsal<tei:lb/>line. The fissures ip and ips are absent. On each anal plate there are only three setae, of which adz<tei:lb/>is rather short. The chelicerae are about 172 um long. The principal segment carries 16- 19<tei:lb/>sharply pointed spines on the paraxial surface and 12-17 conical spines antiaxially. The leg<tei:lb/>chaetotaxy is of the 'reduced type' with the setal formulae: I (1-3-2-5-15-1); II (1-3-2-3-11-1);<tei:lb/>III (2-2-1-2-10-1) and IV (2-1-0-2-9-1). On tarsus I seta u' is short, thick and resembles a<tei:lb/>eupathidium.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPES: Holotype, BMNH reg. no. 1976.2.18.17, and two paratypes, 1976.2.18.18-19, from the<tei:lb/>F layer under a mixed stand of beech and oak, New Forest, Hampshire, 27.iii.73 (B. W. Parry).<tei:lb/>P. flexisetosus is known only from the type locality.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 8 Phthiracams globus: (A) notogaster, lateral; (B) sensillus and bothridium; (C) aspis,<tei:lb/>dorsal.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>THE GENUS PHTHIRACARUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>341</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS: In comparison with the other 'reduced chaetotaxy' species examined, P.flexisetosus<tei:lb/>is rather large and the interlamellar and notogastral setae are much longer.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracams globus sp. nov.<tei:lb/>(Figs 8; 9; PI. 4a)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (PI. 4a): Large and moderately sclerotized. The aspis (Fig. 8C) ranges in length from<tei:lb/>324 - 365 um with a greatest width of 263 - 294 um. All the dorsal setae are moderately long and<tei:lb/>fine. Setae (//) are about 1-5 times the length of setae (la) and almost reach the level of the rostrals.<tei:lb/>The latter extend beyond the anterior margin of the aspis. The sensillus (Fig. 8B) is 50 - 60 um<tei:lb/>long, lanceolate and serrated. It closely resembles that found in P. affinis. The notogaster (Fig.SA),<tei:lb/>578 - 852 um long and with a greatest depth of 426 - 553 um, is globular in lateral aspect. All<tei:lb/>the setae are long (more than the distance c\ - d\), fine and almost erect. Seta c$ is inserted on the<tei:lb/>posterior margin of the collar and setae ci_i submarginally. Vestigial f\ is located adjacent to<tei:lb/>seta h\ and towards the mid-dorsal line. In one paratype/i is located a short distance posterior to<tei:lb/>seta h\. The fissures ip and ips are absent. On each anal plate there are five long setae; an\-i and<tei:lb/>adj, being more or less equal in length and somewhat shorter than ad\-2. The chelicerae are<tei:lb/>approximately 208 um long. The principal segment carries about 26 sharply pointed spines on the<tei:lb/>paraxial surface and about 24 conical spines antiaxially. The leg chaetotaxy is of the 'complete<tei:lb/>type' with the setal formulae: I (1-4-2-5-16-1); II (1-3-2-3-12-1); III (2-2-1-2-10-1) and</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 9 Phthiracarus globus : (A) leg I, trochanter to tibia, dorsal aspect ; (B) tarsus II, anterolateral<tei:lb/>aspect.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>342 B. W. PARRY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IV (2-1-1-2-10-1). Seta d on femur I is long, straight and only weakly serrated (Fig. 9A). On<tei:lb/>tarsus II (Fig. 9B) seta//" is hooked distally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPES: Holotype, BMNH reg. no. 1976.2.18.3, from mosses and liverworts on rocks, Rydal<tei:lb/>Water, Westmorland, 29.J.54 (P. N. Lawrence). Two paratypes, 1976.2.18.4-5, from mosses,<tei:lb/>Long Compton Woods, Warwickshire, 15.viii.51 (P. N. Lawrence).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION: P. globus was also recorded in small numbers in the F and H layers under beech<tei:lb/>and oak at each of the study areas (see p. 324). Other material was examined from Wytham<tei:lb/>Woods Estate, Berkshire, 28.ix.70 (T. G. Wood) and from Woodwalton Fen, Huntingdonshire,<tei:lb/>20.V.65 (P. N. Lawrence).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS: Of the 'complete chaetotaxy' species examined, P. globus is somewhat unusual in<tei:lb/>bearing /i adjacent to h\, a feature generally associated with those species having the 'reduced<tei:lb/>chaetotaxy' combination.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. globus is similar to P. clavatus. However, in contrast to the latter, the sensillus of P. globus<tei:lb/>is lanceolate and the notogastral setae are distinctly procurved. Moreover, in P. globus vestigial<tei:lb/>/i is located much closer to the seta h\.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracarus juvenalis sp. nov.<tei:lb/>(Fig. 10A-C; PI. 4b, d)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (PI. 4b): Medium-sized and weakly sclerotized. The aspis (Fig. IOC) ranges in length<tei:lb/>from 258 - 279 jam with a greatest width of 213 - 223 urn. All the dorsal setae are moderately<tei:lb/>long and fine. Setae (/'/) are about 1-5 times the length of setae (la) and equal to the distance il-ro.<tei:lb/>The latter do not reach the anterior margin of the aspis. The sensillus (Fig. 10B; PI. 4d) is rather<tei:lb/>long (80 urn), narrow and pointed distally. The tracheoles are short and finger-like. The notogaster<tei:lb/>(Fig. 10A) ranges in length from 558 - 588 urn with a greatest depth of 365 - 406 urn. All the<tei:lb/>setae are short (less than the distance c\ - d { ), fine and directed posteriorly. Setae c\ and c 3 are<tei:lb/>inserted close to the posterior margin of the collar and seta c 2 submarginally. Vestigial f\ is<tei:lb/>located a short distance posterior to seta h\. The fissures ip and ips are absent. On each anal plate<tei:lb/>there are two setae in the anal series and one in the adanal series; all are moderately long and<tei:lb/>more or less equal in length. The chelicerae are approximately 152 urn long. The principal<tei:lb/>segment carries about 19 sharply pointed spines on the paraxial surface and about 15 conical<tei:lb/>spines antiaxially. The leg chaetotaxy is of the 'complete type' with the setal formulae:<tei:lb/>I (1-4-2-5-16-1); II (1-3-2-3-12-1); III (2-2-1-2-10-1) and IV (2-1-1-2-10-1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPES: Holotype, BMNH reg. no. 1976.2.18.6, and one paratype, 1976.2.18.7, from leaf litter,<tei:lb/>Higher Kiln Quarry, Buckfastleigh, Devon, 25.iv.64 (C. Moreby).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION: Common in mor forest soils. P. juvenalis was recorded under both the hard-<tei:lb/>wood and coniferous tree species at each of the study areas(see p. 324) being particularly abundant<tei:lb/>in beech and oak F where it accounted for 5-15% of the euptyctimoid population. Other<tei:lb/>material was examined from Woodwalton Fen, Huntingdonshire, 20.V.65 (P. N. Lawrence) and<tei:lb/>from Castor Hanglands, Northamptonshire, 21.vi.63 (P. N. Lawrence).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS: Of the species examined with a 'complete chaetotaxy', P. juvenalis is the only one to<tei:lb/>possess a rather long sensillus and backwardly directed notogastral setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. ligneus, recorded by Willmann (1932) in humus, moist Juncus and moss on the Dummersdorf<tei:lb/>bank, River Trave, West Germany, shows an overall similarity to P. juvenalis. The syntype series<tei:lb/>(five specimens mounted in Canada Balsam) has been examined, and in comparison to P. juvenalis<tei:lb/>the specimens found to be much smaller (notogastral length 375 - 420 urn) while the notogastral<tei:lb/>setae and the sensilli are distinctly longer than in P. juvenalis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. juvenalis also resembles two recently described species, P. clemens Aoki 1963 from Tokyo<tei:lb/>and P. crispus Hammer 1972 from Tahiti. However, in comparison with P. juvenalis, topotypes of<tei:lb/>P. clemens were found to be larger (notogastral length about 700 urn) while the holotype of<tei:lb/>P. crispus was much smaller (notogastral length about 430 urn). Moreover, in contrast to P.<tei:lb/>juvenalis, the notogastral setae of both species are procurved.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE GENUS PHTHIRACARUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>343</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 10A-C Phthiracarus juvenalis: (A) notogaster, lateral; (B) sensillus and bothridium; (C)<tei:lb/>aspis, dorsal.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 10D-F Phthiracarus laevigatus: (D) notogaster, lateral; (E) sensillus and bothridium; (F)<tei:lb/>aspis, dorsal.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>

         <tei:p>344 B. W. PARRY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracarus laevigatus (C. L. Koch)<tei:lb/>(Fig. 10D-F; PI. 4e)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hoplophora laevigata Koch, 1841 : Fasc. 38 t.16; 1842 : 1 16.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracarus laevigatus: Jacot, 1936 : 167; van der Hammen, 1963 : 704 (neotype designated).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT: Large and strongly sclerotized. The aspis (Fig. 10F) ranges in length from 406 - 456 um<tei:lb/>with a greatest width of 355 - 400 um. All the dorsal setae are fine and short. Setae (//) are about<tei:lb/>1-5 times the length of setae (Id) and extend two-thirds of the distance il-ro. The sensillus (Fig.<tei:lb/>10E) is about 50 urn long, narrow and finely serrated. The notogaster (Fig. 10D) ranges in length<tei:lb/>from 812- 1065 urn with a greatest depth of 521 -771 urn, and in lateral view is seen to be<tei:lb/>sharply angled at the level of seta c\ (PI. 4e). The latter is inserted relatively far back. All the<tei:lb/>setae are short (less than the distance c\ - d\), fine and procurved. Vestigial f\ is located midway<tei:lb/>between setae h\ and ps\. The fissures ip and ips are present. On each anal plate there are only<tei:lb/>three setae, an\-2 being much longer than ad$. The leg chaetotaxy is of the 'complete type' with<tei:lb/>the setal formulae: 1(1-4-2-5-16-1); 11(1-3-2-3-12-1); 111(2-2-1-2-10-1) and IV(2-l-l-2-10-l).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION : Three specimens only have been recorded in the British Isles from beech litter,<tei:lb/>Old Winchester Hill, Hampshire, 1971 (D. R. Kime).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS : P. laevigatus is quite distinctive, being easily recognized by the marked angle of the<tei:lb/>notogaster at the level of seta c\. The leg chaetotaxy is similar to that noted for the other 'com-<tei:lb/>plete chaetotaxy' species; on tarsus I the solenidion 0)2 is coupled with a small distal seta, a<tei:lb/>feature not mentioned by van der Hammen in his redescription. The British material has been<tei:lb/>compared with the neotype from Regensburg - no morphological differences could be detected.<tei:lb/>P. brevisetae Jacot, described from decaying grass, Monroe, Connecticut, USA, appears to be<tei:lb/>close to P. laevigatus. The holotype (slide no. 2534h) has been examined and found to be badly<tei:lb/>damaged. Jacot's description (Jacot, 1930), however, agrees well with van der Hammen's (1963)<tei:lb/>and with the British material, but the attitude of the notogastral setae appears to differ slightly.<tei:lb/>In P. laevigatus the notogastral setae are procurved while in P. brevisetae they are directed<tei:lb/>posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracarus membranifer sp. nov.<tei:lb/>(Fig. 11A-C)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT: Small and weakly sclerotized. The aspis (Fig. 1 1C) ranges in length from 213 - 324 urn<tei:lb/>with a greatest width of 157 - 243 urn. All the dorsal setae are fine and short. Setae (//) are about<tei:lb/>1-5 times the length of setae (Id) and extend two-thirds of the distance il-ro. The latter do not<tei:lb/>reach the anterior limit of the aspis. The sensillus (Fig. 1 IB) is 70 um long, narrow, membranous<tei:lb/>marginally and reminiscent of that of P. juvenalis. The tracheoles are short and finger-like. The<tei:lb/>notogaster (Fig. 1 1 A) ranges in length from 314-517 um with a greatest depth of 223 - 324 um.<tei:lb/>All the setae are relatively long (equal to the distance c\ - d\), fine and almost erect. Setae c\ and<tei:lb/>cs are situated on the posterior margin of the collar and just anterior to seta 02- Vestigial f\ is<tei:lb/>located a short distance posterior to seta h\. The fissures ip and ips are absent. On each anal plate<tei:lb/>there are only three setae; an\-2 being much longer than ad-&gt;,. The chelicerae are 116- 167 um<tei:lb/>long. The principal segment carries 9-23 sharply pointed spines on the paraxial surface and<tei:lb/>8-20 conical spines antiaxially. The leg chaetotaxy is of the 'reduced type' with the setal formulae:<tei:lb/>I (1-3-2-5-15-1); II (1-3-2-3-11-1); III (2-2-1-2-10-1) and IV (2-1-0-2-9-1). On tarsus I<tei:lb/>seta u' is short, thick and resembles a eupathidium. In one paratype the 'complete chaetotaxy'<tei:lb/>condition of tarsi I to IV (16, 12, 10 and 10) is associated with a 'reduced chaetotaxy' condition<tei:lb/>on femur I (3) and genu IV (0).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPES: Holotype, BMNH reg. no. 1976.2.18.14, and two paratypes, 1976.2.18.15-16, from<tei:lb/>Sitka spruce F, Tintern Forest, Monmouthshire, 4.vi.73 (B. W. Parry).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION: P. membranifer was also recorded from Higher Kiln Quarry, Devon, 25.iv.64<tei:lb/>(C. Moreby) and from Torboll, Sutherland, 29.vi.76 (P. D. Hillyard). This species was not<tei:lb/>abundant in any of the samples examined.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>THE GENUS PHTHIRACARUS</tei:p>
