         <tei:p>REMARKS: The smallest of the British species examined, P. membranifer is somewhat unusual<tei:lb/>in bearing vestigial f\ posterior to the seta h\ (a feature generally associated with the larger<tei:lb/>'complete chaetotaxy' species).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracarus murphyi Harding<tei:lb/>(Fig. 11D-F;P1. 4c)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracarus murphyi Harding, 1976 : 164.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (PI. 4c): Large and strongly sclerotized. The aspis (Fig. 1 ID) is about 300 um in length<tei:lb/>with a greatest width of about 250 um. All the dorsal setae are fine and short. Setae (//) are about<tei:lb/>1-5 times the length of setae (la) and extend two-thirds of the distance il-ro. Setae (ro) do not<tei:lb/>reach the anterior limit of the aspis. The sensillus (Fig. HE) is short (40-50um), ovate and<tei:lb/>serrated. The notogaster (Fig. 11F) is about 700 um in length with a greatest depth of about<tei:lb/>420 um. All the setae are relatively long (equal to the distance c\ - d\) and markedly procurved.<tei:lb/>Seta C3 is inserted on the posterior collar margin and setae c\-2 submarginally. Vestigial /i is<tei:lb/>located midway between setae h\ and ps\. The fissures ip and ips are present. On each anal plate<tei:lb/>there are five long setae; an 1-2 and adi being more or less equal in length and somewhat shorter<tei:lb/>than adi-2. The chelicerae are approximately 213 um in length. The principal segment carries<tei:lb/>about 18 sharply pointed spines on the paraxial surface and about 16 conical spines antiaxially.<tei:lb/>The leg chaetotaxy is of the 'complete type' with the setal formulae: I (1-4-2-5-16-1); 11<tei:lb/>(1-3-2-3-12-1); III (2-2-1-2-10-1) and IV (2-1-1-2-10-1). On tarsus I the distal seta coupled<tei:lb/>with solenidion 0)2 is rather short. Seta ft" on tarsus II is hooked distally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION: This species was collected in small numbers from Wytham Woods Estate,<tei:lb/>Berkshire, 28.X.70 (T. G. Wood) and from Torboll, Sutherland, 29.vi.76 (P. D. Hillyard).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS : Although rather larger, P. murphyi appears to bear some resemblance to P. insularis<tei:lb/>Jacot (notogastral length about 500 um) recorded from Teuanui, Tovii, the Marquesas Islands.<tei:lb/>Jacot (1935) did not refer in his description to the fissures ip and ips although his figure shows<tei:lb/>quite clearly that these fissures are present. In comparison with P. murphyi, the notogastral setae<tei:lb/>of insularis appear to be shorter (less than the distance c\ - d\). Unfortunately, the 'cotype' of<tei:lb/>P. insularis is apparently lost.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracarus nitens (Nicolet)<tei:lb/>(Fig. 12A-C)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hoplophora nitens Nicolet, 1855 : 472.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracarus nitens: van der Hammen, 1964 : 400 (neotype designated).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT: Large and moderately sclerotized. The aspis (Fig. 12B) ranges in length from 253-<tei:lb/>460 um with a greatest width of 213 - 360 um. All the dorsal setae are fine and short. Setae (//)<tei:lb/>are about 1-5 times the length of setae (la) and extend two-thirds of the distance il-ro. The<tei:lb/>sensillus (Fig. 12A) is 50-60um in length, narrow and resembles that of P. laevigatus. The<tei:lb/>notogaster (Fig. 12C) ranges in length from 502 - 900 um with a greatest depth of 299 - 600 um.<tei:lb/>All the setae are short (less than the distance c\ - d\), fine and procurved. Seta c^ is inserted on the<tei:lb/>posterior margin of the collar and setae c\-2 submarginally. Vestigial/i is located midway between<tei:lb/>setae h\ and ps\. The fissures ip and ips are present. On each anal plate there are only three setae;<tei:lb/>an\-2 being much longer than adj. The chelicerae are approximately 270 um long. The principal<tei:lb/>segment carries 17-21 sharply pointed spines on the paraxial surface and 10-19 conical spines<tei:lb/>antiaxially. The leg chaetotaxy is of the 'complete type' with the setal formulae: I (1-4-2-5-16-1);<tei:lb/>II (1-3-2-3-12-1); III (2-2-1-2-10-1) and IV (2-1-1-2-10-1). On tarsus II seta/?" is hooked<tei:lb/>distally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION: P. nitens was collected in small numbers from the following localities: Wytham<tei:lb/>Woods Estate, Berkshire, 28.X.70 (T. G. Wood); St Agnes, Isles of Scilly, Cornwall, 5.iv.57<tei:lb/>(K. H. Hyatt); Higher Kiln Quarry, Devon, 25.iv.64 (C. Moreby); Tring Deer Park, Hertford-<tei:lb/>shire, l.ii.64 (P. N. Lawrence).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE GENUS PHTHIRACARUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>347</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 12A-C Phthiracarusnitens: (A)sensillusand bothridium; (B)aspis, dorsal; (C) notogaster,<tei:lb/>lateral.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 12D-F Phthiracarus rectisetosus: (D) aspis, dorsal; (E) sensillus and bothridium; (F)<tei:lb/>notogaster, lateral.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>348 B. W. PARRY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS: The neotype from Regensburg has been examined and in comparison with the<tei:lb/>British material the notogastral setae appear to be somewhat longer. The leg chaetotaxy is of the<tei:lb/>'complete type'. On tarsus I the solenidion 0)2 is coupled with a short distal seta and on tarus II<tei:lb/>the posterior fastigial seta is hooked distally. Neither of these features was noted by van der<tei:lb/>Hammen in his redescription.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. nitens is similar to if not conspecific with P. montanus recorded by Perez-Ifiigo in grassland<tei:lb/>soil and moist moss, Sierra de Guadarrama, Spain. The holotype was examined and seen to be<tei:lb/>cleared but undissected. In comparison with P. nitens, it differs only in the form of the distal<tei:lb/>region of the sensillus which is lobular in montanus and pointed in nitens.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracarus rectisetosus sp. nov.<tei:lb/>(Fig. 12D-F; PL 5c)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (PI. 5c): Large and strongly sclerotized. The aspis (Fig. 12D) ranges in length from<tei:lb/>350 - 477 um with a greatest width of 268 - 360 um. All the dorsal setae are fine and short.<tei:lb/>Setae (//) which are inserted rather far forward and on a level with setae (Id) are about 1-5 times<tei:lb/>the length of the latter and extend two-thirds of the distance il-ro. Setae (ro) do not reach the<tei:lb/>anterior limit of the aspis. The sensillus (Fig. 12E) is 40 um long, ovate, serrated distally and<tei:lb/>resembles that found in P. murphyi. The notogaster (Fig. 12F) ranges in length from 710 - 994 um<tei:lb/>with a greatest depth of 482 - 720 um. All the setae are relatively long (equal to the distance<tei:lb/>ci - di) and almost erect. Setae c\ and c$ are situated on the posterior margin of the collar and<tei:lb/>seta c^ submarginally. Vestigial f\ is located a short distance posterior to seta h\. The fissures ip<tei:lb/>and ips are present. On each anal plate there are five long setae; ai_2 and adi being more or less<tei:lb/>equal in length and somewhat shorter than ad\-i. The chelicerae are 168 - 294 um long. The<tei:lb/>principal segment carries 22 - 24 sharply pointed spines on the paraxial surface and 17-22 conical<tei:lb/>spines antiaxially. The leg chaetotaxy is of the 'complete type' with the setal formulae: I<tei:lb/>(1-4-2-5-16-1); II (1-3-2-3-12-1); III (2-2-1-2-10-1) and IV (2-1-1-2-10-1). On tarsus I the<tei:lb/>distal seta coupled with solenidion (02 is almost as long as the famulus. Seta/?" on tarsus II is<tei:lb/>hooked distally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPES: HOLOTYPE, BMNH reg. no. 1976.2.18.8, and one paratype, 1976.2.18.9, from beech<tei:lb/>litter, Burnham Beeches, Buckinghamshire, 1964 (G. O. Evans). Two paratypes, 1976.2.18.10-11,<tei:lb/>from beech F, Wytham Woods Estate, Berkshire, 28.ix.70 (T. G. Wood).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION: Common in mor soils particularly under beech. P. rectisetosus is evidently<tei:lb/>widely distributed in the British Isles and was abundant in all the samples examined from Monks<tei:lb/>Wood, Cambridgeshire, 16.V.75 (J. A. MofFat); Woodbastwick Marshes, Norfolk, 10.vii.74<tei:lb/>(S. J. Moore); West Allendale, Northumberland, 18.ix.75 (R. M. Emberson); Long Compton<tei:lb/>Woods, Warwickshire, 15.viii.51 (P. N. Lawrence); Hag Wood, Yorkshire, 12.iv.71 (D. R. Kime);<tei:lb/>Newtonmore, Inverness-shire, 3.vii.73 (M. J. Bishop); Lochdonhead and Tobermory, Mull,<tei:lb/>28.V.70 (P. N. Lawrence); Torboll, Sutherland, 29.vi.76 (P. D. Hillyard); Llanthony, Monmouth-<tei:lb/>shire, i.iv.73 (M. J. Bishop).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS: P. rectisetosus bears some resemblance to two other 'complete chaetotaxy' species,<tei:lb/>namely P. clavatus and P. globus. However, P. rectisetosus bears four pairs of lateral fissures while<tei:lb/>P. clavatus and P. globus bear only two pairs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracarus serrulatus sp. nov.<tei:lb/>(Fig. 13A-C; PI. 5b)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (PI. 5b): Small and weakly sclerotized. The aspis (Fig. 13C) ranges in length from<tei:lb/>182- 213 um with a greatest width of 137- 157 um. All the dorsal setae are fine and short.<tei:lb/>Setae (//) are about 1-5 times the length of setae (la) and extend two-thirds of the distance il-ro.<tei:lb/>The rostrals which are inserted relatively far apart do not reach the anterior limit of the aspis.<tei:lb/>The sensillus (Fig. 13B) is long (70 um), narrow and tapers to a point distally with three or four<tei:lb/>straight-edged teeth subterminally. The tracheoles are short and finger-like. The notogaster<tei:lb/>(Fig. 13 A) ranges in length from 456 - 466 um with a greatest depth of 324 - 334 um. All the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE GENUS PHTHIRACARUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>349</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Fig. 13D-F Phthiracarus tardus : (D) aspis, dorsal; (E) sensillus and bothridium; (F) notogaster,<tei:lb/>lateral.</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE GENUS PHTHIRACARUS 351</tei:p>
         <tei:p>setae are relatively long (equal to the distance ci - d\), fine and procurved. Seta c\ is inserted on<tei:lb/>the posterior collar margin and setae ^2-3 submarginally. Vestigial f\ is located adjacent to seta h\<tei:lb/>and towards the mid-dorsal line. The fissures ip and ips are absent. On each anal plate there are<tei:lb/>two setae in the anal series and one in the adanal series - all are moderately long and more or<tei:lb/>less equal in length. The chelicerae are approximately 120 um long. The principal segment carries<tei:lb/>about 17 sharply pointed spines on the paraxial surface and about 16 conical spines antiaxially.<tei:lb/>The leg chaetotaxy is of the 'reduced type' with the setal formulae: I (1-3-2-5-15-1); II<tei:lb/>(1_3_2_3-11-1); III (2-2-1-2-10-1) and IV (2-1-0-2-9-1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPES: Holotype, BMNH reg. no. 1976.2.18.12, and one paratype, 1976.2.18.13, from beech F,<tei:lb/>Wytham Woods Estate, Berkshire, 28.ix.70 (T. G. Wood). P. serrulatus is only known from the<tei:lb/>type locality.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS: P. serrulatus shows an overall similarity to P. minimarginatus Woolley 1954, a<tei:lb/>species described from Colorado, USA. However, in comparison with serrulatus, the holotype<tei:lb/>of minimarginatus (dissected, partially cleared and mounted in Berlese's fluid) was found to<tei:lb/>possess shorter notogastral setae while vestigial f\ was located midway between setae h\ andps\.<tei:lb/>Moreover, the sensillus of the American species was found to bear many more distal serrations<tei:lb/>than that of P. serrulatus. Both species are of a similar size (about 450 um).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracarus tardus Forsslund<tei:lb/>(Figs 13D-F; 14; PL 5a, d)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phthiracarus tardus Forsslund, 1956 : 216.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (PI. 5a): Small and weakly sclerotized. The aspis (Fig. 13D) is about 223 um in length<tei:lb/>with a greatest width of about 187 um. All the dorsal setae are fine and short. Setae (//) are about<tei:lb/>1-5 times the length of setae (la) and extend two-thirds of the distance il-ro. The rostrals which<tei:lb/>are inserted relatively far apart do not reach the anterior limit of the aspis. The sensillus (Fig. 13E;<tei:lb/>PI. 5d) is 30 - 40 um in length and broadly clavate. The notogaster (Fig. 13F) is about 497 um in<tei:lb/>length with a greatest depth of about 314 um. All the setae are relatively long (equal to the<tei:lb/>distance c\ - d\), fine and erect. Setae c\-i form a row just behind the posterior margin of the<tei:lb/>collar. Vestigial f\ is located adjacent to seta hi and towards the mid-dorsal line. The fissures ip<tei:lb/>and ips are absent. On each anal plate there are only three setae; an\-i being much longer than<tei:lb/>ad$. The chelicerae are approximately 147 um long. The principal segment carries about 16<tei:lb/>sharply pointed spines on the paraxial surface and about 9 conical spines antiaxially. The leg<tei:lb/>chaetotaxy (Fig. 14) is of the 'reduced type' with the setal formulae: I (1-3-2-5-15-1): II<tei:lb/>(l_3_2-3-12-l); III (2-2-1-2-10-1) and IV (2-1-0-2-9-1). On tarsus I seta u' is short, thick and<tei:lb/>resembles a eupathidium. Seta ft" on tarsus II is hooked distally and this segment carries a<tei:lb/>subunguinial seta s.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION: Only a small number of specimens have been recorded in the British Isles from<tei:lb/>mull soil, Meathop Wood, Westmorland, 19.iii.63 (P. N. Lawrence).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS: P. tardus is somewhat unusual in bearing 12 setae on tarsus II and by having a<tei:lb/>hooked posterior fastigial seta on this segment (both features are generally associated with<tei:lb/>'complete chaetotaxy' species).<tei:lb/>A comparison of British and paratype material revealed no morphological differences.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>'Complete' and 'reduced' leg chaetotaxy a possible basis for a subdivision of</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the genus Phthiracarus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The earliest proposed subdivision of the genus Phthiracarus appears to be that of Feider and<tei:lb/>Suciu (1957) who recognized two species groups based solely on the shape of the sensillus. Their<tei:lb/>'anonymum group' included species with spindle-shaped sensilli (anonymum, globosus, lanatus and<tei:lb/>piger} and their 'lentulus group' species with thread-like sensilli (baloghi, italicus, lentulus, ligneus,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>352 B. W. PARRY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>parabotrichus and sellnicki). However, these do not appear to be satisfactory groupings since the<tei:lb/>present study has suggested that sensillar shape is not correlated with other features, such as the<tei:lb/>chaetotactic pattern of the legs or notogaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eight years later and based on a study of three species, van der Hammen (1965) suggested that<tei:lb/>the number of notogastral fissures, the position of the vestigial seta f\ , the number of adanal<tei:lb/>setae and the chaetotactic pattern of the legs were features which could be used in a future<tei:lb/>subdivision of the genus, and placed P. laevigatus and P. nitens (ip and ips present ; f\ ventral to<tei:lb/>h\; adi-2 absent; femur I with four setae; genu IV with a single seta) in a separate group from<tei:lb/>P. anonymum (ip and ips absent ;/i dorsal to hi ; adi-2 present; femur I with three setae; genu IV<tei:lb/>without any setae). Although the number of adanal setae has been found to be uncorrelated with<tei:lb/>other morphological features, the present study supports van der Hammen's proposed division<tei:lb/>of the genus on the remaining characters. Of the eight British species having the combination<tei:lb/>'femur 1-4, genu IV-1', only murphy i and rectisetosus have all the attributes of van der Hammen's<tei:lb/>'laevigatus-nitens group', since the other species (qffinis, clavatus, globus and juvenalis) all lack the<tei:lb/>fissures ip and ips. In the case of species having the combination 'femur 1-3, genu IV-0', only<tei:lb/>P. anonymum possesses all the characters of van der Hammen's second grouping.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Using numerical methods, Sheals (1969) examined the affinities of 19 Phthiracarus species from<tei:lb/>Europe, Israel, Labrador and Morocco, recognizing three species groups based on the following<tei:lb/>combinations of characters: femur 1-4, genu IV-1, fissure ips present; femur 1-4, genu IV-1,<tei:lb/>fissure ips absent; femur 1-3, genu IV-0, fissure ips absent. It is noteworthy that P. anonymum<tei:lb/>which in the present study was found to be rather atypical, formed part of a reasonably compact<tei:lb/>cluster of five species in this grouping studied by Sheals (P. anonymum and four new species from<tei:lb/>France, Labrador, Sweden and Switzerland).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The evidence suggests therefore, that morphological differences, particularly in the leg<tei:lb/>chaetotaxy, could provide a useful basis for dividing this large genus into two species groups.<tei:lb/>In the present study all the British species (and all the type specimens examined) fell into either a<tei:lb/>'complete' (affinis, clavatus, globus, juvenalis, laevigatus, murphyi, nitens and rectisetosus) or a<tei:lb/>'reduced chaetotaxy group' (anonymum, flexisetosus, membranifer, serrulatus and tardus). In<tei:lb/>addition to features of the leg chaetotaxy, a number of other characters were also used to<tei:lb/>distinguish between the two groupings. With the exception of P. affinis (notogastral length<tei:lb/>406 - 487 um), the species in the 'complete chaetotaxy group' are all rather large (notogastral<tei:lb/>length 502 - 1065 um). Moreover, in this grouping, the vestigial seta f\ is generally ventral to<tei:lb/>seta h\ while on the aspis the rostral setae are always located rather close together. The fissures<tei:lb/>ip and ips are present in some members of the 'complete group' (laevigatus, murphyi, nitens and<tei:lb/>rectisetosus) while they are absent in affinis, clavatus, globus and juvenalis. By contrast, species<tei:lb/>in the 'reduced chaetotaxy group' are all relatively small (notogastral length 314 - 507 um), the<tei:lb/>fissures ip and ips are always absent, vestigial f\ is dorsal or slightly ventral to seta h\ and on the<tei:lb/>aspis the rostrals are often located relatively far apart.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Any formal subdivision of the genus will, however, have to be deferred until a new type species<tei:lb/>has been designated. Van der Hammen (1965) considered P. contractilis (type) as being close to<tei:lb/>his 'laevigatus-nitens group' (and thus to the 'complete chaetotaxy group'), but the type material<tei:lb/>of P. contractilis must be presumed to be lost and Perty's original description is such as to make<tei:lb/>the specific identity of his species impossible. Moreover, on the evidence available from the<tei:lb/>present study, P. anonymum would not be a suitable typical specimen of the 'reduced chaetotaxy<tei:lb/>group'.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>THE GENUS PHTHIRACARUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>359</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plate 1 Phthiracarus affinis: idiosomal and gnathosomal features, (a) Sensillus and bothridial<tei:lb/>scale, x2400. (b) Aggenital seta in furrow of genital plate, anterior aspect, x 1300. (c) Adoral<tei:lb/>setae and rutella, ventral aspect, x!300. (d) Terminal segment of pedipalp showing reduced<tei:lb/>subultimal seta, x 1450. (e) Sensillar notch and thickened bothridial aperture, x 1500.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>360</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. W. PARRY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plate 2 Phthiracarus affinis: legs, (a) Tarsus I, anterolateral aspect, x 1 100. (b) Distal solenidion<tei:lb/>and associated seta on tarsus I, posterolateral aspect, x 5100. (c) Proximal region of tarsal claw,<tei:lb/>anterolateral aspect, x!700. (d) Dorsal seta on femur I, x4800. (e) Solenidion and associated<tei:lb/>seta on tibia II, anterolateral aspect, x2400; dorsal aspect, x 15 000 (shown in inset).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>The Museum publishes some 10-12 new titles each year on subjects<tei:lb/>including zoology, botany, palaeontology and mineralogy.<tei:lb/>Besides being important reference works, many, particularly among<tei:lb/>the handbooks, are useful for courses and students' background<tei:lb/>reading.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lists are available free on request to :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Publications Sales</tei:p>
